div2.p: tou= de\ qe/rous—the same words with which the third and fourth books begin; see note on iv. 1, 1. ai( me/n—answered by de/ at the beginning of chapter 2, the rest of this chapter being parenthetical. A second protasis to the same de/ occurs below in line 9, oi( me\n *dh/lioi. Krüger however considers that this first me/n is answered by kai/ in the next clause, as in chapter 71, 1, where poiei= me\n kai\ a(/panta is followed by kai\ to/te.

diele/lunto—‘had come to an end’ or ‘was ipso facto at an end’, the pluperfect denoting the termination of the treaty and the state of things resulting, as in iv. 16, 3, to/te lelu/sqai ta\s sponda/s. For the terms of the year's truce see iv. 117—119. The words me/xri *puqi/wn define the time when the treaty actually ended, ‘(after lasting) till the Pythian games’. For this force of me/xri cf. i. 71, 3, me/xri tou=de w(ri/sqw u(mw=n h( braduth/s ‘let this be the limit of your inaction’: so i. 51, 2, h( naumaxi/a e)teleu/ta e)s nu/kta, ‘lasted till night and then ended’: ni. 108 (fin). e)teleu/ta e(/ws o)ye/: iv. 48, 4, h( sta/sis e)teleu/ths en e)s tou=to. Poppo and others take the sense of the clause to be that ‘the truce was ended (and a state of war followed) till the Pythian games’; but no warlike operations are recorded, nor any hint given of the war beginning again; and on the contrary it seems clear that Cleon's expedition was not allowed to start till after the sacred season. Other editors think that a nondescript state of things, neither peace nor war, is meant, which followed the expiration of the treaty. There seems some justice in Classen's view, that Thucydides had mtended at first to write only ai( me\n .diele/lunto: *kle/wn de/ k.t.l. and then had inserted a note of time and the account of the cleansing of Delos. It is ascertained by an inscription that the Pythian games were held in the Delphian month Bucatius, which corresponded to Metageitnion at Athens, and to part of our August and Sep
tember (see Classen and Jowett). The year's truce therefore which formally expired in Elaphebolion (March—April) was informally prolonged because of the approach of the Pythian festival.

e)n th=| e)kexeiri)a|—the year's truce is called h( e)kexeiri/a in iv. 119 (fin.), 122, 1, and 123, 1, and this might be the meaning here. Most editors however take it to denote either the informal truce after the regular expiration of the treaty, or the sacred truce of the Pythian festival.

*dhli/ous a)ne/sthsan—Arnold points out that the Athenians were naturally anxious to propitiate Apollo, who was the national deity of their enemies, and whose temple at Delium they themselves had lately profaned. They had been excluded from Delphi by the war, and now that the sacred games drew near, ‘what wonder if the peace party ava led themselves of this pretext to delay Cleon's proposed expedition: if they urged the duty and wisdom of not trying again the chances of war till the god at Delphi had been fully appeased. His birthplace had been now completely purified; it only remained to approach his temple with their suppliant offerings at his great Pythian festival; to profane it by no d<*> of wailike preparation, but to wait till they should be assured of his favour, in consideration of their devout reverence to his solemnity’.

ou) kaqarou\s o)/ntas—the participial construction gives the principal thing in the clause, the suspected impurity of the Delians when their island was consecrated: cf. i. 20, 2, *(/ipparxon oi)/ontai tu/rannon o)/nta a\poqanei=n, ‘think that Hipparchus who was slain was tyrant’.

h(=|—‘in which’, in construction a sort of instrumental dative (or perhaps rather dative of ‘occasion when’, like oi(= ch. 49, 1) with a)nelo/ntes: see ch. 7, 10. In sentences of this character, with a participle and a verb, the Greek idiom generally differs from the English, and the construction is determined by the participle, especially if it is closer to the dependent word, as it is here to h(=|. We should say, ‘which they thought they had properly carried out by removing the sepulchres of the dead’.

pro/teron—the former purification was in 426. It is described in iii. 104, where a still earlier purification by Peisistratus is mentioned, and an account given of the ancient Delian festivals: see also i. 8, 1. The qh=kai are mentioned in both passages.

*)atramu/ttion—(or -eion) acc. governed by w)/|khsan: i. 8, 1, ta\s plei/stas tw=n nh/swn w)/|khsan. At(d)ramyttium was on the
coast of Mysia near Lesbos. Pharnaces (ii. 67, 1) appears to have been satrap of the district near the Hellespont, in which he was succeeded by his son Pharnabazus (viii. 6, 1).

w(/rmhto—this form, which is a virtual imperfect, is used with words of motion, as in iv. 48, 6, and 74, 1 with i(/na: or of impulse of mind, as in iv. 27, 4, w(rmhme/nous th=| gnw/mh: vi. 6, 1, strateu/ein w(/rmhnto. Whichever is the literal force here, the sense is that the Delians did not migrate in a body, but as each chose to go. In ch. 32, 5 we find the Delians restored to Delos, but others were still at Adramyttium 10 years later (viii. 108, 3).

*)aqhnai/ous pei/sas—these words show that Cleon alone had the courage and statesmanship to urge the necessity of recovering Amphipolis and the other revolted towns as a matter of vital importance. By his influence in the assembly the expedition was decreed. But what is to be said of Nicias, and the other home authorities, who allowed him to conduct singlehanded an enterprise of such moment? At Pylos he had a thoroughly competent colleague in Demosthenes. Now 1200 men at arms, and 300 cavalry. the flower of the Athenian troops, besides a large force of allies, are entrusted to his sole command. The general assembly very possibly believed that Cleon might succeed as he had done at Pylos, but the strategi could be under no such delusion They knew that he had no military skill or experience, they knew that he had to encounter Brasidas, and their imbecility or their party-hatred sacrificed an Athenian army and lost the Thrace-ward possessions.

sxw\n e)s—‘landing, putting in at’; so iv. 42, 2, e)/sxon e)s to\n ai)gialo/n. e)/ti poliorkoume/nhn—Scione was completely invested by the end of the summer before; see iv. 133 (fin.). The long duration of the blockade became proverbial; cf. Ar. Vesp. 209 (exhibited in 422), h)= moi krei=tton h)=n threi=n *skiw/nhn a)nti\ tou=de tou= patro/s.

*kwfo\n lime/na—a conjectural alteration of the manuscript reading *kolofwni/wn lime/na, which is unintelligible, unless it possibly denoted a name derived from some resemblance in appearance. kwfo\s limh/n=a)/klustos, silent, as in Xen. Hel. ii. 4, 31. Strabo speaks of a kwfo\s limh/n near Torone; and a harbour south of the city is still called Kufo; see Jowett's note.

tw=n *torwnai/wn—ambiguously placed (ch. 29, 23). Poppo and Kruger connect it with th=s po/lews, Classen with lime/na. The latter way of taking it seems right, as it gives the explanation that the harbour in question was in the territory of Torone. Torone had been taken by Brasidas in 424 (iv. 110—116).
ai)sqo/menos u(p) au)tomo/lwn—the quasi-passive force of ai)sqo/menos=‘informed by’, seems sufficient to justify u(po/, which is read in all the manuscripts. Kruger would read a)po/

e)n th=| *torw/nh|—sc. ei)/h, a very awkward ellipse. Krüger notes that a)cio/maxos is not found in classical Greek writers besides Thucydides and Herodotus. e)s th\n po/lin—e)s here denotes approach, not entrance; so ii. 18, 1, a)fi/keto e)s *oi)no/hn prw=ton. The harbour here spoken of is different from the kwfo\s limh/n. For the infinitive periplei=n cf. iv. 132, 3, e)pidei=n pemya/ntwn ta\ pra/gmata: see Goodwin § 97. peritei/xisma—periteixi/zw and its compounds are commonly used by Thucydides of the works of a besieger, not of defensive fortifications (tei=xos, tei/xisma, peri/bolos): see ch. 115, 12, etc. Possibly therefore protei/xisma ought to be read, or tei/xisma as in the next chapter, line 8. In Ar. Av. 551 however periteixi/zein is used of defensive lines. poih=sai—i. 109, 3, ta\s nau=s e)pi\ tou= chrou= e)poi/hse: vi. 67, 2, tou\s skeuofo/rous e)nto\s tou/twn e)poih/santo.

dielw\n tou=—‘making a breach in’, so as to open a free passage between the city and the suburb. tei/xous is partitive genitive, as in ii. 75, 4, dielo/ntes tou= tei/xous. In iv. 111, 2 we have h( puli\s dih/|rhto, ‘had been forced open’ or ‘broken through’. Note the demonstrative form which the second clause of the relative sentence assumes, as in ch. 5, 8: cf. note on iv. 67, 1, o(/qen e)pli/nqeuon ta\ tei/xh kai\ a)pei=xen.
au)th/n—agreeing with po/lin by attraction; the whole space enclosed is meant.

e)s au)to/—the new peritei/xisma or outwork. *pasiteli/das—in iv. 132 (fin.), according to the manuscripts, the Lacedaemonian commandant is called Epitelidas, a name which most editors alter to Pasitelidas on the strength of the present chapter.

e)bia/zonto—passive; iv. 10, 3 (note). Note in this sentence the different force of the imperfects and aorists.
ai( e)s to\n lime)na—ai( is read by Poppo and Classen, with one manuscript. If ai\ be omitted we have the sense ‘after being sent round’. e)gkatalhfqh=|—sc au)to/s. For the word cf. iv. 116, 1, o)/sous e)gkate/labe die/fqeiren.

oi( *)aqhnai=oi—resolved into oi(/ te a\po/ kai\ o) pez<*>s, fqa/nousi being connected both with e(lo/ntes and cunespesw/n, while e)pispo/menos is a predicate in agreement with pezo/s. According to this view au)toboei/ goes with cunespesw/n: Kruger however puts a comma after the word, connecting it with the preceding e(lo/ntes. o( pezo/s—sc. strato/s: iv. 25, 3. au)toboei/—primo clamore atque impetu (Poppo); usually with e(lei=n, as ii. 81, 3, au)toboei\ th\n po/lin e(lei=n. Here cunespesw)n implies forcing the passage. The Athenians at the first onset broke into the city pell mell with the enemy: cf. vi. 100, 2, kai\ au)toi=s cunese/peson oi( diw/kontes. e)n xersi/—iv. 43, 2, h)=n h( ma/xh e)n xersi\ pa=sa.

e)boh/qei—note the force of the imperfect ‘de consilio et conatu opitulandi’ (Poppo). We are not told where Brasidas was when Cleon's expedition arrived. a)posxw/n contains a negative idea of failure or hindrance, and is therefore constructed with mh/ following.

tropai=a du/o—one for each branch of the service. gunai=kas—for the omission of the article in regular phrases of frequent occurrence, see note on iv. 18, 3, po/lews te k.t.l. In this particular phrase pai=des kai\ gunai=kes is the more usual order.
kai\ ei)/ tis—so iii. 35, kai\ ei)/ tis a)/llos, after two accusatives. e)s ta\s *)aqh/nas—the more usual Thucydidean form, not *)aqh/naze: see note on iv. 21, 3.

au)toi=s—the defenders of Torone generally. au)toi=s is the common Thucydidean initial dative, in construction loosely connected with a)ph=lqen, but in sense concerned with both the following clauses: ‘as for them’, ‘this befell them’ etc.: cf. i. 48, 3, *korinqi/ois de\ to\ me\n decio\n ke/ras ai( *megari/des nh=es ei)=xon, kata\ de\ to\ me/son k.t.l. Arnold takes au)toi=s to denote the Athenians, meaning that ‘they afterwards lost their captives’, but this part of the sentence seems entirely to refer to the Toroneans.

to\ *peloponnh/sion—so iv. 61, 2, oi( me\n *dwrih=s to\ de\ *xalkidiko/n. Note what we may call the resolved apposition a)nh\r a)nt' a)ndro\s luqei/s: so ii. 103, 1, oi(\ a)nh\r a)nt' a)ndro\s e)lu/qhsan. genome/nais—see ch. 18 sq.
ei(=lon de/—note the breaking up of this sentence, so that the emphasis naturally falls on the more important words, while the rhythm is duly balanced.
perie/plei—by this use of the imperfect Thucydides leaves Cleon on his way to Amphipolis, and passes to another subject. A summary of events in Sicily, which has not been mentioned since iv. 65.
*fai/ac—Phaeax is mentioned by Plutarch, Alc. 13, as a contemporary and opponent of Alcibiades: Ar. Eq. 1377, sofo/s g' o( *fai/ac deciw=s t' ou)k a)pe/qane.
tri/tos au)to/s—i. 46, pe/mptos au:to/s: so Hdt. iv. 113, deute/rhn au)th/n, ‘with one companion’. *)aqhnai/wn pempo/ntwn— cf. ch. 39, 2: i. 89, 2, *shsto\n e)polio/rkoun *mh/dwn e)xo/ntwn, etc.

meta\ th\n cu/mbasin—the general peace made by the Sicilian Greeks, two years before, on the advice of Hermocrates (iv. 65). poli/tas e)pegra/yanto—‘enrolled many new citizens’; cf. ascribere, ascriptus. For e)pi/ in composition implying sequence and addition, see note on iv. 36, 2.

e)peno/ei a)nada)sasqai—‘contemplated a redistribution of the land’. ‘So when an additional number of citizens was wanted at Cyrene, settlers were invited from all parts of Greece, e)pi\ gh=s a)nadasmw=| (Hdt. iv. 159)’. It was regarded as a revolutionary measure, as shown in Arnold's interesting note, from which this is quoted. Arnold assumes that the ager publicus of the state is meant, but Grote doubts if there would be such lands belonging to a state like Leontini (ch. 57, p. 123).

oi( dunatoi/—here the oligarchical or aristocratical party, who were threatened with the loss of some of their possessions or holdings; i. 24, 3, o) dh=mos e/cedi/wce tou\s dunatou/s. In ii. 65, 1, oi( dunatoi/ is used to denote men of wealth and position, as contrasted with the dh=mos or mass of the people, without implying political partizanship. ai)sqo/menoi—sc. the matter; cf. note on iv. 14, 1, gno/ntes. e)pa)gontai—so ii. 2, 2, e)phga/gonto.

w(s e(/kastoi—so i. 3, 4 etc.: see note on iv. 32, 2. e)rh mw/santes—‘abandoning’; Aesch. Ag. 1070, to/nd) e)rhmw/sas' o)/xon. e)pi\ politei/a|—‘on condition of receiving citizenship’; ch. 31, 9: for e)pi/ implying conditions cf. e)pi\ toi=sde, e)f) w(=|, etc.: also Hdt. cited on line 7.

a)re/skesqai—so ch. 37, 23, oi( boiwta/rxai h)re/skonto: also with dat. ‘to be pleased with’. a)polipo)ntes e)k—so iii. 10, 1, with e)k tou= pole/mou: this usage is rare. Krüger cites Hdt. vii. 221, au(to\s ou)k a)pe/lipe, ‘did not depart’.
katalamba/nousi—occupant; iv. 1, 1, note. on—agreeing with the predicate; i. 96, 2, *(ellhnotami/ai kate/sth a)rxh/. to/te=‘as related’; ch. 6, 1, etc.

katasta/ntes—probably to be connected with e)pole/moun, of ‘settling down to’ a course of warfare: cf. i. 59, 2, katasta/ntes e)pole)moun: so ii. 1. In i. 49, 2, however, katasta/ntes e)ma/xonto is used of soldiers who were ‘firmly posted’ on shipboard. Some editors therefore take the meaning here to be, ‘when they had established themselves’. e)k tw=n teixw=n—from the strongholds in question, each of which was a tei=xos (Classen).

cumma/xous—we find in iii. 86 that the Chalcidian cities and the Dorian colony of Camarina were in alliance with Leontini and joined in appealing to Athens. *sikeliw/tas— Greek colonists, as opposed to the *sikeloi/, the general name for the non-Greek inhabitants: cf. vi. 2, 5. koinh=| is to be taken with e:pistrateu=sai.

a)ntista/ntos.. pra/gmatos—so ch. 38, 23, w(s a)nte)sth to\ pra=gma, ‘went against them’. pra=gma has no doubt the notion of political intrigue which is so often conveyed by pra/ssw: e.g. i. 128, 3, pro\s basile)a pra/gmata pra/ssein.
ou)ke/ti—=he gave up his intention e)pi/—in a friendly sense, iv. 85, 3, e)pi\ ou(\s prw=ton h)=lqon. For inf. with ai)sqo/menos cf. vi. 59, 3, ai)sqano/menos .du/nasqai.

dia\ tw=n *sikelw=n—through the interior; the *sikeloi/ occupied the central and northern parts of the island. para*qarsu/nas—‘reassured’; iv. 115, 1: viii. 77. We are not told what became of this garrison. It was probably reduced and expelled by the Syracusans; cf. vi. 6, 1, ei) *surako/sioi *leonti/nous a)nasth/santes a)timw/rhtoi genh/sontai.

th=| parakomidh=| k.t.l —the article applies to both substantives, which are equivalent to ‘on his way to Sicily and back’; cf. i. 120, 2, th\n katakomidh\n ..kai\ pa/lin <*>nti/lhyin=exchange of exports and imports.

kai/—‘also’, with e)n th=| *)itali/a|. e)xrhma/tise—‘treated’, only here with the dative (Classen): i. 87, 4, e)f) a(/per h)=lqon xrhmati/santes. fili/as toi=s *aqhnai/ois=pro\s tou/s: iv. 22, 1, cune/drous sfi/sin e:le/sqai: ib. infr. o)li/gous cu/nedroi gi/gnesqai.

toi=s e)k *messh/nhs—the definite article is explained by what follows: the circumstances have not been mentioned before. The Epizephyrian Locrians had joined in occupying Messene in 425 (iv. 1, 1), but only with a naval force. Messene from the earliest days had been a centre of faction; see the
account of it in vi. 4. e)poi/kois—‘settlers’ or colonists, ii. 27, 1, au(tw=n pe/myantas e)poi/kous e)/xein.

e)kpeptwko/sin—part of the epithet, but placed after the substantive, as is not uncommon, especially with participles; cf. ch. 34, 6: i. 11, 3. o(mologi/an=cu/mbasin ch. 4, 5. kai\ e)ge/veto—the second division of the relative construction, put in demonstrative form; see note on ch. 2, 16.

komizome/nois—‘on their way’ (back to Locri); so i. 52, 3, komisqh/sontai, etc. The manuscripts have toi=s komizome/nois, ‘those namely etc.’, with proskomizome/nois as a correction in one. Bekker suggests a)pokomizome/nois. Classen would omit both words, as being an interpolation. For other instances of an article which we might at first sight think better away, cf. iv. 46, 3, tou\s e)lqontas, and Jowett's note on iv. 33, 2, oi( u(postre/fontes.

toi=s *lokroi_s pro\s au)to/n—render ‘between him and the Locrians’; see iv. 80, 2, note, and Shilleto on i. 17, 1. katei=xen—kate/xw=‘to constrain’ or ‘press hard on’; i. 103, 3, *kori/nqioi au:tou\s pole/mw| katei=xon: iv. 92, 5, ei)w/qasi kate/xein. For *)itwne/as kai\ *melai/ous, unknown people, Classen adopts *)ippwnia/tas kai\ *medmai/ous, from names of places found in Strabo. *(ipwnie/as seems the right form (F.). Note the definite article with po/lemos, as in line 4; though the war has not been mentioned before. CHAPTER VI.

to/te—see the end of ch. 3. *stagei/rw|—Stageirus joined Brasidas soon after Acanthus, iv. 88: for Galepsus see iv. 107, 2. The article with a)poiki/an is a Thucydidean mannerism, sometimes implying ‘the well-known’ or ‘the before-named’ colony; but often used with no especial definitive force.

*perdi/kkan—this fickle prince had made peace with the Athenians two years before, after quarrelling with Brasidas, iv. 132, 1. kata\ to\ cummaxiko/n—so i. 107 fin.: ii. 22, 2, kata\ to\ palaio\n cummaxiko/n.
a)/conta—‘who was to bring’: Classen approves the suggestion a)/contas, referring to the envoys; cf. ch. 80, 20: ch. 84, 21. For misqou= cf. iv. 124, 4, misqou= me/llontes h:/kein.
kai\ au)to/s=‘on his side’; the words belong to a:nteka/qhto or strictly to e)ka/qhto only: cf. iv. 124, 3, a)ntepagago/ntes kai\ au)toi/: so ch. 8, 2.

*)argili/wn—see iv. 103, 2. For the genitive cf. iv. 41, 2, e)/sti h( *pulos th=s *messhni/dos pote\ ou)/shs gh=s. Xen. Anab. v.
5, 7, *kotu/wra h)=n *sinwpe/wn. pe/ran—i.e. the side opposite Amphipolis, which lay to the east of the Strymon in a bend of the river; see iv. 102, 2.

au)to/qen—the second au)to/qen if genuine goes with ou)k a)\n e)/laqen. It is however a mere repetition, and probably ought to be omitted or altered to au)to/n. Classen adopts the alteration, for which there is some slight manuscript authority.

o(/per a)nabh/sesqai—e)pi\ th\n po/lin is to be taken with a)nabh/sesqai: the construction being appositional and explanatory of o(/per poih/sein: iv. 125, 1, o:/per filei=. .e)kplh/gnusqai: so iii. 59, 3 u(perido/nta: vi. 104, 4, uperei=de to\ plh=qos tw=n new=n. plh=qos—of small numbers, as in iv. 10, 2, a)ntipa/lous tw=| h)meterw| plh:qei.

pareskeua/zeto—this governs *qra=|kas, and parakalw=n= ou(\s pareka/lei: see note on iv. 48, 3, parairh/mata poiou=ntes= parairh/masin a(\ e)poi/oun. Edones are mentioned in iv 109, 3, as dwelling on the peninsula of Acte: in i. 100, 3 as once holding *)enne/a o(doi/ (Amphipolis).

*murkini/wn—Myrcinus was an Edonian town (iv. 107, 3), N. of Amphipolis. cu/mpan—predicate, ‘in all’. For disxi/lioi cf. Xen. Cyr. ii. 1, 25, h( de\ ta/cis h)=n e\kato\n a)/ndres. The i(pph=s *(/ellhnes were probably the Chalcidians, as we see from ch. 10, 51. For e)s cf. iv. 48, 1, e)s e(ch/konta e)/laqon diafqei/rantes.

meta\ *kleari/dou—Clearidas was sent out from Sparta and appointed governor of Amphipolis the year before, iv. 132, 3. For the Ionic 3rd plural e)teta/xato (=nto) see note on iv. 31, 2, w(=de ga\r dieteta/xato.
te/ws me/n—followed by e)/peita without de/, as is often the case with prw=ton me/n: vi 61, 6, te/ws me\n...w:s de/.
th=| e(/dra|—so ii. 18, 3, e)n th=| kaqe/dra|, of the delay of Archidamus at Oenoe: Hdt ix. 41, perihme/ktee th=| e\drh=|, ‘was galled at remaining inactive’.

pro\s oi(/an meta\ oi(/as—so vii. 75, 6, a)po\ oi(/as...e)s oi:/an: cf. Soph. Fl. 750, a:nwlo/luce to\n neani/an, oi)=' e)/rga dra/sas oi(=a lagxa/nei kaka/. oi)/koqen stands first for the sake of emphasis. Several editors approve of Dobree's alteration of cunh=lqon into cunech=lqon. a)nepisthmosu/nhs—‘incompetence’; only here in Thucydides, though the adjective is found more than once.

ai)sqo/menos to\n qrou=n—so iv. 66, 2: viii. 79, 1 etc.: cf. ch. 30, 1. dia\ to\...kaqhme/nous—a confusion between the par
ticipial construction and dia\ to/ with the infinitive; so iv. 63, 1, dia\ to\...paro/ntas: in viii. 105, 2, most manuscripts have dia\ to\...diw/kontes. Kruger however takes dia\ to\ e)n tw=| au)tw=| as forming one expression ‘owing to their (being) stationary’, like e)k tou= e)pi\ plei=ston, i. 2, 2. Stahl takes kai\ ou) boulo)menos by itself ‘although he did not wish it’; and makes au)tou/s governed by a)nalabw\n h)=gen. The result is a sentence which can indeed be construed, but could scarcely have been written by anyone, while au)tou/s is in an almost impossible position.
a)nalabw/n—ch. 64, 23, a)nalabo/ntes tou\s cumma/xous. Here it means calling his men to their ranks and setting his army in motion.

e)xrh/sato tw=| tro/pw|—‘he adopted the principle the success of which at Pylos gave him confidence in his abihty’. He prepared, that is, for a general assault upon the city at all points. tro/pw| is then explained by what follows, and denotes the plan of attack. Many editors take tro/pw| of Cleon's ‘temper of mind’ and rash confidence; but would not this suggest the imperfect rather than e)xrh/sato? The sense is certainly good, and the aorist might imply a sudden fit of rashness. w(=|per is an instrumental dative, or dative of accompaniment, with eu)tuxh/sas; cf. ch. 1, 7, and for dat. ch. 14, 9.

e)s th\n *pu/lon—the preposition e)s is very loosely used by Thucydides to denote relation of any kind. Here it means the operations at or ‘in respect of’ Pylos, or Pylos is used in a general sense and includes Sphacteria. fronei=n ti—‘to have intelligence’; vi. 89, 6, oi( fronou=nte/s ti: so le/gein ti)(ou)de\n le/gein.
kata\ qe/an—‘to reconnoitre’; this phrase, like some of the rest of the sentence, sounds like a contemptuous reminiscence of Cleon's actual words; cf. e)qea=to infr. and ch. 10, 9.

th\n mei/zw—as opposed to his parou=sa strati/a, ch. 6, 18: see the beginning of ch. 6. tw=| a)sfalei=—with the certainty of success which a superior force would ensure: a sort of instrumental dative. Arnold compares vi 55, 3, pollw=| tw=| perio/nti tou= a)sfalou=s katekra/thse. perisxh/swn—here ‘to gain the superiority’ as in viii. 105, 1, tw=| e)/rgw| polu\ perisxo)ntes. In ch. 71 and elsewhere it is used of outflanking or extending beyond an enemy's force. bi/a| ai(rei=n is the regular phrase for taking by assault, as opposed to a siege.

e)lqw/n te—‘so having come’. e)pi\ lo/fou—see ch. 10, 32. to\ limnw=des—cf. iv. 108, 1, a)/nwqen mega/lhs ou)/shs e)pi\ polu\ li/mnhs tou= potamou=. It was this lake which helped to make Amphipolis of such importance as the key of the Thrace-ward district. e)pi\ th=| *qra|kh|—‘over against’ or ‘commanding Thrace’: iv. 14, fin. e)/menon kata\ xw/ran e)pi\ th=| *pu/lw|.

kai\ ga\r ou)de/—the negatives here require attention: ou)de/, ‘also not’, joins the whole sentence to what has gone before, while ou)/te...ou)/te connect e)pi\ tou= tei/xous and kata\ pu/las e)ch/ei, the final verb e)ch/|ei being irregularly written instead of e)ciw/n. See note on iv. 114, 3, ou)de\ ga\r e)pi\ doulei/a| ou)o(\e/ k.t.l., where there is no correspondence between ou)de/ .ou)de/.

mhxana/s—used especially of scaling-ladders, according to Poppo. kath=lqen—this reading is probably right, and means ‘landed’, referring to Cleon's arrival at Eion; cf. Eur. Iph. T. 39, o)\s a)\n kate/lqh| th/nde gh=n This view is approved by Grote and Shilleto. The meaning is that Cleon regretted that he had not brought his own siege appliances, instead of waiting till they could be made, or furnished by the allies who were expected. Such things were soon constructed: thus the Spartans sent round the coast e)pi\ cu/la e)s mhxana/s as soon as they resolved to attack Pylos (iv. 13, 1).

Arnold takes kath=lqen to mean that Cleon had descended from the lo/fos kartero/s towards the city with a part of his forces. No such movement however is mentioned. Poppo approves of a)nh=lqen (sc. from Eion), which Classen adopts. This reading has some support from the fact that some inferior manuscripts have a)ph=lqen. Krüger suggests h)=lqen.

kai\ au)to/s—see note on ch. 6, 11. The words do not necessarily imply a corresponding descent from anywhere on the part of the Athenians, but simply show that Brasidas by coming down made a counter-movement on his part.
dediw/s—‘mistrusting’, ‘having misgivings about’; cf. ch. 61, 22, dei/santes. So me/mfomai is sometimes used, e.g. Hdt. i. 77, memfqei\s kata\ to\ plh=qos to\ e(wutou= stra/teuma.

u(podeeste/rous—sc. tou\s e(autou=, a sense easily supplied; possibly however u(podee/steros should be read. a)nti/pala, according to the scholiast, agrees with e(ka/tera ta\ strateu/mata. Poppo and Classen however take it to mean ‘things were fairly matched’, comparmg iv. 117, 2, a)nti/pala katasth/santos: vii. 13, 2, e)s a)nti/pala kaqesth/kamen. This neuter phraseology is common, e.g. ii. 56, 1 e(toi=ma h)=<*>: iii. 88, 1, a)du/nata h)=n, etc. a)ciw/mati—‘quality’ (Jowett).

kaqaro/n—the idea of kaqaro/s is ‘clear’ or ‘cleared’. As applied to troops it means either (1) ‘picked men’, clear of inefficients, or (2) according to the scholiast=au)tw=n tw=n politw=n, ‘of pure Athenian blood’, with no admixture of aliens. In
Hdt. i. 211, we have tou= kaqarou=, stratou=, ‘the effective force’, contrasted with tou= a)xrhi/<*>ou: and in Hdt. iv. 135, to\ kaqaro\n tou= stratou= is contrasted with sick troops left behind. Classen also quotes from Plut. Aem. Paul. ch. 6, au)tw=n tw=n *makedo/nwn a)reth=| kai\ h:liki/a| to\ kaqarw:taton. These passages are in favour of (1).

*lhmni/wn kai\ *)imbri/wn—cf. iv. 28, 4, where we find Lemnians and Imbrians chosen by Cleon for his expedition to Pylos. ‘Lemnos had been taken and colonized by Miltiades a few years before the battle of Marathon (Hdt. vi. 140). Imbros was, I suspect, colonized also by him about the same time’ (Arnold on vii. 57, 2).
e)piqhso/menos—to be connected with te/xnh|: the participle is joined to the verb without w(s, as in ii. 91, 1, pareskeua/zonto a)munou/menoi, etc.
a)nagkai/an—‘make-shift’, such as a)na/gkh compelled him to use: i. 61, 2, cummaxi/a a)nagkai/a: vi. 37, 2, a)nagkai/a paraskeuh/.

ou)k a)\n h(gei_to k.t.l—‘(thinking that) he would be less likely to succeed than if he came upon them before there had been time to observe him, and when as yet they had no real grounds for their contempt of him’ (Jowett). ou) ma=llon= h)=sson, the usual litotes. au)tw=n is the objective genitive, referring to tou\s meq) e(autou=, and dependent on the active words proo/yews and katafronh/sews. In the last clause mh/ is a redundant negation, the negative form of the sentence being already determined by a)/neu.

a)po\ tou= o)/ntos—the preposition denotes the source or ground of the contempt which the enemy would feel, if they saw Brasidas' actual force; cf. i. 91, 6, a)po\ a)ntipa/lou paraskeuh=s, ‘starting from, i.e. bached by equal defences’: iv. 18, 2 a:po\ tw=n a)ei\ u:parxo/ntwn gnw/mh| sfale/ntes. Somewhat similar in origin are various adverbial phrases with a)po/, c.g. in the following chapter, line 14. Classen and others restrict the force of a)/neu to the first clause, and make katafronh/sews dependent on mh\ a)po/, taking the whole clause as equivalent to ei) mh\ tou= o)/ntos katafronh/seian ‘if the enemy should not despise their real weakness’. But, not to insist on the co-relation of the nouns coupled by te and kai/, to\ o)/n is a strange expression for ‘their real strength’, though a)po\ tou= o)/ntos is a reasonable adverbial phrase. Moreover such a construction would refer to the main subject of the sentence, and would imply contempt felt by Brasidas for the enemy, a meaning which makes nonsense of the passage.
a)poleca/menos—so iv. 9, 2, with au(to/s. prosta/cas—vi. 42, 1, strathgw=| prostetagme/noi. a)polabei=n—‘cut off’, or catch in an isolated state; iv. 14, 2, oi( a)/ndres a)pelamba/nonto.

a)po\ me\n oi(/as—the protasis introduced by me/n contrasts generally the Lacedaemonians with their Ionian foes, the apodosis with de/ deals with the particular enterprise which Brasidas was about to attempt. o(/ti. .e)leuqe/ras—sc. h(/komen a)po\ xw/ras, the construction of the previous clause being repeated.

dia\ to\ eu)/yuxon—‘owing to its courage’; ii. 39, 2, pisteu/ontes tw=| eu\yu/xw|: so eu)yuxi/a, i. 84, 3; i. 121, 3. o(/ti *dwrih=s.. *)/iwsi—cf. vi. 77, 1, ou(k *)/iwnes ta/de ei)si\n.. a)lla\ *dwrih=s e)leu/qeroi. Poppo on i. 124, 1 cites other similar passages.
a)rkei/tw braxe/ws—‘let a brief statement of this suffice’. The perfect participle implies that the fact is to be considered settled once for all.

th\n de\ e)pixei/rhsin—put first for emphasis and contrast. For the word cf. i. 33, 3, e)s th\n u(mete/ran e)pixei/rhsin, ‘with a view to assailing you’. e)pixeirw= with dative is often used in the sense of attacking.

to/ te kat' o)li/gon—the reading is not certain. The best manuscripts have tw=| te, which leaves the sentence without a nominative to para/sxh|. Poppo and others read to/ te: Classen considers the connexion of te and kai/ out of place here, and reads tw| (=tini) to\ kat' o)li/gon. For kat' o)li/gon, ‘in small divisions’, see note on iv. 10, 3. e)ndee\s—lit. ‘deficient’, i. e. a disadvantage.

ou)k a)
 e)lpi/santas—‘because they never could have expected’; taking a)/n with the participle. Possibly however it is merely anticipatory, and belongs to the following subordinate construction where it is repeated; cf. Eur. Med. 941, ou<*>k oi=d) a)
 ei) pei/saimi. The following aorist optative with w:s a<*>/n is a rare instance: e)lpi/zwn w(s with the future indicative occuis viii. 54, 1: so Eur. El. 919, h:/lpisas w(s e(/ceis: cf. 11. 42, 5, peni/as e)lpi/di. w(s ka)
 plouth/seian. We have a similarly formed sentence in ii. 93, 2, ou)/te prosdoki/a ou)demi/a, mh\ a_n pote oi( pole/mioi e)capinai/ws ou(/tws e)pipleu/seian.
kata\ qe/an—see ch. 7, 13. With the whole phrase we may compare ii. 40, 1, pro\s e)/rga tetramme/nois.

kai\ a(/ma—connecting i)dw/n with pro\s th\n e(autou= du/namin. pro/s—‘looking to, having regard to’, i. e. making the most of the force at his disposal. Brasidas did not feel strong enough to fight a pitched battle.

a)po\ tou= a/ntiparataxqe/ntos—‘by way of counterarray’. The use of the neuter participle for an abstract substantive, or as equivalent to to/ with the infinitive, is peculiar to Thucydides among prose writers; e. g. i. 36, 1, to\ me\n dedio\s au:tou= to\ de\ qarsou=n: i. 142, 4, e)n tw=| mh\ meletw=nti, ‘in the want of practice’: ch. 102, 4, meta\ tou= drwme/nou, ‘with action’: cf. infra tou= me/nontos. Krüger gives other instances. th=s gnw/mhs to\ mh\ nikhqe/n, ii. 87, 2, is somewhat different: cf. to\ poqou=n, Soph. Phil. 674; Trach 196. See Goodwin § 108; Madv. § 180.

kle/mmata—‘stratagems’; Dem. de Cor. 236, kl<*>mma *fili/ppou, ‘a trick of Philip's’. e)/xei=‘bring’ or ‘involve’: cf. note on iv. 1, 1. a(/ is cognate accusative after a)path/sas: cf. Soph. Aj. 2, pei=ra/n tin' a(rpa/sai. a)/n is repeated as in i. 36, 3: iv. 18, 3, etc.

e)c w)=n e)moi\ fai/nontai—‘from what they clearly look like to me’; the personal construction, such as is usual with dokw=, e)/oika, le/gomai etc.: Plat. Polit. 280 B, ou)k e)/spou toi=s lexqei=sin, w:s fainei.

a)neime/nw|—‘unstrung’, dum sunt remissis animis: i. 6, 1, a)neime/nh| diai/th|, ‘easy, luxurious’: ii. 39, 2, a)neime/nws diaitw/menoi. Classen adopts Kruger's suggestion of cuntaqh=nai for the following cuntaxqh=nai. No doubt the converse of a)ni/hmi ‘to slacken’ is e)pitei/nw ‘to tighten’, which is commonly found metaphorically used like the Latin intendo. cuntei/nw is also used in a somewhat similar way, e.g. Plat. Phaed. 98D, as antithetical to xalw=: so suntetame/nos, id. Euthyd. 288D: Rep. 504 E: Xen Oec. ii. 18, gnw/mh| suntetame/nh|. Here however cuntaxqh=nai may well be a military metaphor, contrasting a ‘close and firm array’ of mind with the ‘loose and feeble’ condition implied by e)n tw=| a)neime/nw|.

do/can—‘ideas’, lit. ‘expectation’; as in the well-known passage ii. 42 (fin.), a(/ma a)kmh=| th=s do/chs. Brasidas means that the Athenians' ideas would be all abioad, in the confusion caused by a sudden attack.
tou\s meta\ seautou=—see the end of ch. 6 for the amount of the force under Brasidas and Clearidas.

e)pekqei=n e)pei/gesqai—the only instance in Thucydides of the infinitive used for the 2nd person imperative. The construction, which has the subject in the nominative, is chiefly epic (Goodwin, § 101). The word e)pekqei=n is used in iv. 34, 1, of soldiers in the field meeting the desultory attacks of light troops.
fobhqh=nai—note the use of the aorist with e)lpi/s: iv. 9, 2 note. to\ e)pio/n—the usual collective neuter, like o(plitiko/n, ch. 6, 23: cf. ii. 45, 1, fqo/nos toi=s zw=si pro\s to\ a)nti/palon.

nomi/sate ei)=nai tou= k.t.l.—it is possible in this sentence to make ai)sxu/nesqai and pei/qesqai dependent on e)qe/lein, in which case to/ should be omitted before ai)sxu/nesqai. More probably however the qualities of a good soldier are expressed by three coordinate infinitives. Classen makes this sense clearer by reading nomi/sate tri/a ei)=nai (with Stahl), in accordance with the scholiast's explanation, e/k triw=n gi/gnetai to\ kalw=s polemei=n. In similar sententious phrases a number is often named, e.g. i. 74, 1, tri/a ta\ w)felimw/tata paresxo/meqa, followed by three accusatives. Classen also repeats to/ with pei/qesqai, as being necessary for a clear coordinate sense.

to\ e)qe/lein—‘readiness’, ‘alacrity’.—ai)sxu/nesqai—like ai)sxunh/, ‘self respect’, ‘a sense of honour’: ii. 43, 1, e)n toi=s e)/rgois ai)sxuno/menoi. ai)dw/s is used in the same way; see i. 84, 3, ai)dw\s swfrosu/nhs plei=ston mete/xei ai)sxu/nhs de\ eu(yuxi/a: cf. Hom. Il. v. 531, ai)dome/nwn a)ndrw=n ple/ones so/oi h)e\ pe/fantai.

h)\ a)gaqoi=s k.t.l.—this sentence is complicated by the addition of accessory matter subordinate to the main ideas. Removing these accretions the outline stands thus:—(nomi/sate) h)\ e/leuqeri/an te u(pa/rxein kai\ *lakedaimoni/wn cumma/xois keklh=sqai, h)\ *)aqhnai/wn te dou/lois(keklh=sqai), toi=s de\ loipoi=s *(/ellhsi kwlutai=s gene/sqai e)leuqerw/sews. The choice put forward is between two pairs of things, all of which are in construction expressed as subjects of u(pa/rxein. In the second half of the sentence the order is inverted by the figure called chiasmus.

a)gaqoi=s genome/nois—‘if you quit yourselves like men’. The speaker omits the offensive suggestion of kakoi=s geno/menois or the like in the corresponding clause. keklh=sqai=‘the title of’: ii. 37, 1, dhmokrati/a ke/klhtai: iii. 82, 7, r(a=|on kakou=rgoi o)/ntes de/cioi ke/klhntai. The perfect tense denotes that the name is permanently acquired.

*)aqhnai/wn te dou/lois—te is omitted in some manuscripts. If we retain it, we must suppose that a corresponding kai/ was intended, but owing to the insertion of additional clauses toi=s de\ loipoi=s is written instead. With dou/lois understand keklh=sqai. It is possible to supply gene/sqai, but the sense is not so forcible or the rhythm of the sentence so good.

h)\n ta\ a)(rista...pra/chte—‘if you are most fortunate’: superlative of eu)= pra/ssein: vii. 71, 1, mh\ xei/rw pra/cwsi. Krüger quotes an instance of the adjective thus used from Xen. Anab. vi. 2, 8, polla\ kai\ a)gaqa\ pra/ttein. a)/neu k t l.—explanatory
of ta\ a)/rista. a)ndrapodismou=—selling or carrying off into slavery, while doulei/a is merely a general though invidious word for subjugation of any kind. As Arnold says, ‘dou=los is the general term, applying equally to political and domestic slavery; a)ndra/podon applies exclusively to the latter’. a)ndrapodismo/s, like the following forms in wsis, is active in force. qana/twsis is not found elsewhere till Plutarch.

kai\ doulei/an—this clause is loosely connected with the last but one. In construction doulei/an is either to be taken with u(pa/rxein, in conformity to the main outline of the sentence, or it is a cognate accusative connected with dou/lois, as if douleu/ousi (dative participle) liad been written. In illustration of the latter view Jowett cites Plato, Rep. 579D, e)/stin a)/ra o( tw=| o)/nti tu/rannos tw=| o)/nti dou=los ta\s megi/stas q<*>pei/as kai\ doulei/as. To this we may add the construction of a)timi/an after a)ti/mous e\poi/hsan in ch. 34, 15.

e)/rgw|—‘in deed’, opposed to paraine/sai. It is not governed by e)pecelqei=n, which does not take the dative in the sense of ‘carrying out’ or ‘prosecuting’ a plan, but either stands absolutely as here, or takes the accusative. See note on iv. 14, 3, th=| parou/sh| tu/xh| w\s e)pi\ plei=ston e)pecelqei=n, which is similar in construction to the present passage.

o( me/n—note the force of the following imperfects, and of the coordinate construction with me/n and de/. While Brasidas, having made his speech, is now getting ready to sally out, Cleon is told of a movement on the enemy's part.

*kleari/da—Doric genitive: ch. 25, 2, e)pi\ *pleisto/la: so i. 103, 2, tou= *dw\s tou= *)iqwmh/ta. In ch. 6, 27 we have *kleari/dou. e)pi\ ta\s *qra|ki/as—the Thracian gates seem to have led out on the north-eastern side of the town near the shore of the lake. The accusative with e)pi/ denotes the quarter or direction in which the troops under Clearidas were appointed to serve. We may compare such phrases as kaqista/nai e)pi\ a)rxh/n, etc.
e)peci/oien—here e)pi/ in composition probably denotes the attack to be made by a resetve force, though it may simply mean ‘sally out to attack’.

tw=| de\ *kle/wni—cf. iv. 93, 2, tw=| de\ *ippokra/tei w(s au)tw=| h:gge/lqh. fanerou= genome/nou—with this are connected kataba/ntos and the two following present participles. For the construction cf. Hdt. v. 26, a)piko/menoi faneroi/ ei)sin: so Ar. Vesp. 735, dh=lo/s e)stin eu)= poiw=n: the adjective with ei)mi/ being constructed like the corresponding verb.

*)aqhna=s—from contracted nom. *)aqhna==*)aqhnai/a: see Lid. and Scott. quome/nou—the middle is used of the general who took the auspices by causing victims to be slain; so ch. 54, 7. This use of the word is common in Herodotus and Xenophon. tau=ta—ta\ peri\ th\n e)/codon (Poppo): but according to Krüger and others referring to quome/nou and denoting the ceremonial accompaniments of the sacrifice.
to/te—referring, as does th\n qe/an, to what has been already said in ch. 7, 21. a(/pasa is emphatic, for Cleon thought the city was feebly guarded; see the latter part of ch. 7.

u(po\ ta\s...u(pofai/nontai—the meaning is not perfectly clear, for u(po/ may mean either ‘under’ or ‘close up to’, and similarly u(pofai/nomai may mean either ‘apparere sub’ or ‘subapparere’. To translate ‘The feet of horses and men are to be seen under the gate’ gives a good sense; for the Athenians, as shown in Arnold's note, might have got up close to the walls, and the roadway being worn hollow there would be a space at the bottom of the gates. For the accusative cf. ii. 17, 1, to\ *pelasgiko\n to\ u(po\ th\n a(kro/polin. On the other hand the rendering ‘there are signs of’, etc. gives a more feeble conclusion of the sentence, especially after a:/pasa...fanera/ in the preceding clause, and is therefore, I think, less desirable, though quite consistent with the Greek. With this latter view it has been rather oddly suggested that po/des may mean the sound of horses' hoofs.

e)ph=lqen—‘came up’. pri\n...h(/kein—‘pri/n with the infinitive after a negative is rare in the Attic poets, but more frequent in Attic prose’ (Goodwin § 106, 2): so i. 68, 2, ou) pri(n pa/sxein, a)ll) e/peidh\ e)n tw=| e)/rgw| e)sme/n: i. 39, 2, etc. Note the dative oi( with h(/kein, a construction not uncommon with e)lqei=n.
shmai/nein...a)naxw/rhsin—editors give no exact parallel to this cognate construction. The nearest is from Xen. Anab. iv. 3, 29, e/peida\n o( salpigkth\s shmh/nh| to\ polemiko/n.

parh/ggeile toi=s a)piou=si—‘passed the word to the retiring force’. Classen reads parh/ggelle, with some manuscript authority. paragge/llw, like shmai/nw, is a technical word for giving military orders; so paragge/lseis, ch. 66, 15. We might rather expect a)piou=si without toi=s: see however note on ch. 5, 9. oi( a(pio/ntes are the troops who had begun to carry out the order of a)naxw/rhsis.

e)pi\ to\ eu)w/numon—with u(pa/gein. The following note of Arnold's shows how things stood. ‘The army was drawn up in line fronting Amphipolis, and as the left was nearest Eion,
the movement of retreat would naturally begin with that part of the army. Meantime the right should have maintained their position, and continued to face the enemy, in order to check pursuit till the other part of the army was fairly on its march to Eion’.
u(pa/gein—of an orderly and deliberate retreat: so iv. 126, 6, ko/smw| kai\ ta/cei u(pagago/ntes. Eion was on the left bank of the river, like Amphipolis.

sxolh\ gi/gncsqai—if the nominative sxolh/ is right, we must compare such phrases (mostly negative) as ou/k au)tw=| sxolh/ (e)sti). sxolh\ gi/gnetai/ tini thus means ‘a man finds he has (lit. gets) time’, gi/gnetai instead of e)sti/ implying a change in the look of circumstances: so iv. 68, 5, a)sfa/leia de\ au)toi=s ma=llon e)gi/gneto th=s a)noi/cews. The meaning then is that Cleon no longer thought it necessary for the right wing to stand fast in order to cover the retreat, but supposed that the whole army might be safely withdrawn.

sxolh=|—‘at leisure’, i.e. in a slow and dilatory manner, has some manuscript authority, and is read by Krüger and Classen. It would mean that Cleon became uneasy and impatient at the time taken to carry out his orders, and so made a premature movement which proved disastrous. The subject of gi/gnesqai is then to be supplied from the context; as in ch. 64, 20. For the adverbial use of sxolh=| cf. iii. 46, 2, ei) to\ au)to\ du/natai sxolh=| kai\ ta/xu cumbh=nai.

e)pistre/yas to\ decio/n—the Athenians were fronting the town in line, looking west; they now faced to the left, and the line became a column heading southwards towards Eion. The right flank, which was not covered by the shield, was thus exposed to attack. For the military usage of e)pistre/fw and e)pistrofh/ see ii. 90, 3, e)pistre/yantes ta\s nau=s: cf. Soph. Oed. Col. 1045, dai+/wn a)ndrw=n e)pistrofai/. We have ta\ gumna/ in ch 71, 6, also gu/mnwsis ib. line 12: cf. iii. 23, 4, e)shko/ntizon e)s ta\ gumna/.

o(/ti—introducing the actual words; so i. 137, 4, e)dh/lou d) h( grafh\ o(/ti, *qemistoklh=s h(/kw para\ se/: so iv. 38, 2. For me/nousi Krüger reads menou=si, but the present seems more forcible and appropriate. Kr&udot;ger also reads dh=loi dh/ and objects to tou(s e)pio/ntas as otiose, and probably a gloss. In similar sentences however de/ often introduces an explanation or reason for a preceding statement. And e)pio/ntas has considerable force, viz. that ‘a sudden onset’ would be likely to rout unsteady troops like the Athenians.
a)noige/tw—a)noi/gw is the usual Thucydidean form; iv. 68, 3; iv. 74, 1, etc. The imperative use of tis commonly implies ‘any one (every one) concerned’, as in ch. 20, 6; but the usage here is slightly different. a(\s ei)/rhtai—sc. a)noi/gein.

ta\s e)pi\ to\ stau/rwma pu/las—Thucydides does not tell us what this stau/rwma was; but Grote's view is probably right, that it was an outwork constructed by Brasidas to secure the bridge over the Strymon. We learn from iv. 102, 2, that Amphipolis stood on a peninsula and was fortified by a wall from a point in the river's course above the city to a point below. In iv. 103, 4 we find that the bridge, which seems undoubtedly to have been below the city, was some distance from the fortress, and was not then connected with it by walls. Brasidas however had now held Amphipolis for eighteen months, and would no doubt have secured his hold on the bridge, the possession of which was of vital importance. He appears to have constructed a palisade, extending from a point in the city walls, and touching the river at some point below the bridge, which was thus brought within the line of defence. It is plain from the first part of chapter 8 that Brasidas had full command over crossing the river when he pleased. The ‘gate to the stockade’ then led first into the space enclosed between the original wall and the new outwork; while the ‘first gate in the long wall’ was above the starting point of the stockade, and led directly out. The words to/te o(/ntos show that the works had been altered when Thucydides wrote.

th
 o(do
 tau/thn eu)qei=an—for this accusative ‘of the space traversed’ cf. Eur. Med. 384, kra/tista th
 eu(qei=an (sc. o)do
 poreu/esqai). tau/thn denotes the road at the place spoken of, further explained by h)=|per k.t.l. ou)=tos thus used is often to be rendered ‘that’. eu)qei=an is predicate; lit. ‘taking it straight’. The meaning is that Brasidas led his men straight up towards the ridge on which Cleon was posted; see ch. 7, 18. to\ karterw/taton seems to be the steepest part of the ascent to this ridge, which connected the hill on which Amphipolis stood with the higher eminence of Mount Pangaeus to the east of the city.
i)o/nti—so i. 24, 1, *:epi/damno/s e)sti po/lis e)n decia=| e)sple/onti to\n *)io/nion ko/lpon.

cune/bh te—‘and so it fell out’. This phrase, as Classen points out, is used of ‘various concurrent circumstances’, as in ch. 14, 1, etc. Here however it rather sums up and states the general result of ‘concurrent circumstances’, as phrases with te are commonly used to conclude an account; e. g. iv. 26, 5, panti/ te tro/pw| e(ka/teroi e)texnw=nto.

kai\ e)capi/nhs—probably to be taken with tw=|, though the connexion of an adverb with an adjective is certainly awkward. Poppo therefore proposes, with some manuscript authority, to leave out kai/ and to take e)capi/nhs with the following infinitive, comparing iv. 36, 2, where e)capi/nh<*> and tw=| a)dokh/tw| occur in the same clause.

e)pipariw/n—with the dative this word imphes passing along to attack; plhsia)zwn e)peti/qeto tw=| deciw=| (schol.). In iv. 94, 2, the same word is used with the accusative of passing along the lines of a friendly army: so vi. 67, 4. with e(/kasta. In iv. 108, 3, and vii. 76, we find it without a case following. Similarly e)/peimi and e)ph=lqon with the dative commonly denote hostile approach, but not so with the accusative. In Xenophon e)pipa/reimi is used of light troops advancing parallel to a marching army.

peso/nta au)to/n—Classen notes that this and viii. 102, 1, are the only passages where the aorist participle is used with ai)sqa/nomai to denote what has just happened. In 24 passages the present or perfect participle is found. See also ch. 30, 3.

e)/mene ma=llon—several MSS. have e)/mene/ te, which is defended by Arnold as being answered by kai\ h)mu/nonto, and giving the sense ‘the right wing not only kept its ground, but, though Cleon himself fled, and was killed, the soldiers formed in a ring and repulsed Clearidas in two or three attacks’. In favour of this view may be alleged the well known rule that in sentences coordinately constructed with me/n and de/ the clause with me/n (o( me\n *kle/wn) is often subordinate in sense. See note on iv. 80, 3, prokri/nantes e)s disxili/ous, oi( me/n...oi( de/ k.t.l.

oi( de\ au)tou= custrafe/ntes—the subject of this clause is oi( au)tou= o)pli=tai, and the words custrafe/ntes e)pi\ to\n lo/fon, ‘rallying, or closing together on the hill’, are in apposition. custrafe/ntes is put out of its grammatical place for the sake of the rhythm of the sentence, as noted on iv. 24, 2, o(rw=ntes ta\s me\n parou/sas o)li/gas nau=s, where o)li/gas is the predicate. Compare the order in ch. 41, 1, oi( pre/sbeis a)fiko/ menoi au)tw=n. From the position of au)tou= we should naturally assume it to be the adverb of place rather than the personal pronoun, which would regularly take the order oi( o(pli=tai au)tou=, as in line 40. Poppo however takes it to be the pronoun, and compares iii. 22, 4, e)k th=s au(tw=n fulakh=s: iii. 91, 1, e)s to\ au(tw=n cummaxiko/n: viii. 48, 4, e)n th=| au)tou= a)rxh=|. But in all these passages the reading au(tw=n or au(tou= can be supported, and is probably right; see note on ch. 71, 3. Here at any rate the adverbial
meaning ‘on the spot’ gives an excellent sense, contrasting the right wing, which stood its ground, with the left, which had retreated.

kai\ di\s h)\ tri/s—so i. 82, 3, dielqo/ntwn e)tw=n kai\ du/o kai\ triw=n. With this emphatic use of kai/ may be compared kai\ a(/pantes, etc. Similar to it is the Tacitean use of quoque for even, lit. ‘not only...but also’.

ou(/tw de/—Classen reads Krüger's suggestion ou(/tw dh/, the usual phrase for tum demum, e.g.i. 131, 1, ou(/tw dh\ ou(ke/ti e)pe/sxon. to\ stra/teuma, the subject of the sentence, is resolved by partial apposition into o(/soi mh/...oi( loipoi/: cf. iv. 68, 2, oi( frouroi\... h)mu/nonto o)li/goi...oi( de\ plei/ous.
xalepw=s—this adverb is used emphatically of a disastrous or hard-pressed retreat; iii. 23, 4, xalepw=s kai\ biai/ws: iv. 25, 6, xalepw=s a)pexw/rhsan. For e)n xersi/ see ch. 3, 14.

oi( de\ to\n *brasi/dan ..e)teleu/thsen—there is a singular beauty in the simple form of this sentence, especially in the closing cadence. The sound of e)teleu/thsen recalls a:phlla/ghsan in the funeral speech of Pericles (ii. 42 fin.), and may be added to the reasons for there taking a:phlla/ghsan absolutely, ‘they passed away’.
nikw=si—‘are victorious’; for this use of the present cf. a)dikw=, feu/gw, etc.; see Goodwin's Moods and Tenses, § 10, n. 5.

nekrou/s—the article is omitted with nekrou/s i. 54, 4: iv. 14, 4, etc.: so often with words which are repeatedly found in a particular context, as pai=des kai\ gunai=kes (of a captured town), me/son (of an army), etc. Such words get in fact a definite force of their own, and can dispense with the article. See note on polews iv. 18, 2, and me/son iv. 31, 2.

e)/qayan—it appears from Xen Hel. vii. 3, 12 that this was the special honour of founders and benefactors of cities. The historian says of Euphron, a military adventurer of Sicyon, oi( poli=tai au)tou= w(s a)/ndra a)gaqo\n e)/qaya/n te e)n th=| a)gora=|...
kai\ w(s a:rxhge/thn th=s po/lews se/bontai. To show the rarity of such honours Arnold cites Cic. Ep. Fam. iv. 12, 3, where we find the Athenians refusing a place of sepulture within their walls to M. Marcellus, ‘quod religione se impediri dicerent; neque tamen id antea cuiquam concesserant’.

perie/rcantes—elsewhere Thucydides uses the forms of ei)/rgw, and one manuscript here has periei/rcantes. cune/rcete is found Soph. Aj. 593. e)nte/mnousi—e)nte/mnw, according to the scholiast, like e)/ntoma and e)nagi/zw, is properly used of offerings to the dead, or to the powers below, as opposed to sacrifices to the gods above. In the latter case the victim's throat was held up and pierced; in the former its head was struck off on the ground. The present e)nte/mnousi and perfect dedw/kasi imply a custom still continuing. Classen considers the style of expression appropriate to a writer who was connected with the neighbourhood, as we know that Thucydides was (iv. 105, 1).
prose/qesan—thus making Brasidas their tutelary hero.

ta\ *(agnw/neia oi)kodomh/mata—public buildings which commemorated Hagnon's name as founder. These would include a shrine in his honour, if he was dead. He may however have been still alive, as it was only 15 years since he established the city (iv. 102, 3). In 429 we find him in Thrace (ii. 95, 3). The name of Hagnon occurs in ch. 19, 2, and ch. 24, 1, among the Athenian signatories, and in viii. 68, 4, we have a Hagnon mentioned as the father of Theramenes.

ei)/ ti mnhmo/sunon—‘si quod aliud deductionis eius monumentum superfuturum erat’: cf. Hdt. i. 185, mnhmo/suna e)li/peto, of material works executed by queen Nitocris. au)tou= th=s oi)ki/sews—au)tou= refers to the preceding adjective *(agnw/neia. The actual construction of the genitives is open to some doubt. Probably au)tou= depends on oi)ki/sews, the more emphatic word standing first. It is however quite possible to take au)tou= as dependent directly on mnhmo/sunon, in which case th=s oi:ki/sews is added, as a ‘genitive of further definition’ and depends on the combined mnhmo/sunon au)tou=.

swth=ra/ te—the two main divisions of the sentence are to
 me
 *brasi/dan...to
 de\ *(/agnwna. The first of these divisions is expanded by a subordinate te and kai/, connecting the two ideas which led the citizens thus to honour Brasidas; gratitude to Brasidas himself, and a desire at the same time to court the
favour of Sparta. The construction as usual is modified by putting in a fresh governing participle; cf. ch. 28, 10, o(rw=ntes to/n te po/lemon e)so/menon, kai\ a)/ma e)lpi/santes th=s *peloponnh/sou h(gh/sesqai.
to\ pole/mion tw=n—‘their hostility to Athens’: in iii. 56, 2, tw=| e)kei/nwn polemi/w| is ‘their hostile feelings’.

o(moi/ws—probably ‘as formerly’: so i. 99, 2, h(=san ou)ke/ti o(moi/ws e)n h(donh=| a/rxontes. Kruger however understands ‘as Brasidas’. h(de/ws—sc. sfi/si, according to the scholiast; but possibly *)/agnwni, for Hagnon, whether alive or dead, would be dishonoured in his sacred character of founder by the homage of a revolted town.

e(pta/—‘so in the great battle of Corinth, fought A.C. 394, only eight Lacedaemonians were killed (Xen. Hel. iv. 3. 1). For such was the Spartan skill and discipline that, till their ranks were broken, they fought almost without risk’ (Arnold).

toiau/ths—referring to the description already given. proekfobh/sews is active in force. The word seems to occur nowhere else in classical Greek: fo/bhsis is not found and e)kfo/bhsis has no classical authority.
kaqi/stanto—as usual, of political arrangements. For the imperfect, see note on ch. 3, 30.

*(ramfi/as—father of the Clearchus of Xenophon's Anabasis. In viii 8, 2, and 39, 2, we find Clearchus holding a command in the Hellespont. h)=gon—‘were on their way with’. An intended reinforcement had miscarried the year before owing to the influence of Perdiccas with the Thessalian chiefs (iv. 132, 2).
e)s *(hra/kleian—the Lacedaemonian colony and place of arms at the foot of mount Oeta: cf. iii. 93, 94: iv. 78, note.

*pieri/ou—unknown; Arnold supposes it to be ‘a town of Thessaly, not far from Metropolis, and from the road leading from Pellinaeum and Athamania to Larissa’. Livy speaks of Piera (xxxii. 15) and Pieria (xxxvi. 14), for which Pialia or Cieria, the names of known places, have been proposed as emendations.
oi( peri/—including Rhamphias himself; so iv. 33, 1, oi( peri\ to\n *)epita/dan: viii. 56, 1, oi( peri\ to(n *pei/sandron pre/sbeis.

kwluo/ntwn tw=n *qessalw=n—the Thessalians, at the instigation of Perdiccas, had hindered Ischagoras from bringing reinforcements the year before (iv. 132, 2); and Brasidas was obliged to pass through Thessaly by stratagem in 424 (iv. 78).
kai\ a(/ma—giving an important reason, which is further emphasized by w(=|per. h(/ssh|—‘on, by reason of, being defeated’, dative of the efficient cause.

ka)kei=nos—‘he on his part’; lit. ‘they themselves were incompetent to carry out the plans which he also had in contemplation’. The kai/ emphasizes e)kei=nos by a co-ordination which is really false in sense. Jowett compares iv. 62, 3, timwri/a ou)k eu)tuxei= dikai/ws o(/ti kai( eu)/elpi, and says ‘in Greek the word kai/ commonly adheres to the standard of comparison (cf. <*>/sper kai/), in English the corresponding word adheres to the person or thing compared’.
th\n ei)rhnhn—the article denotes the peace which was thought of and discussed.

cune/bh w(/ste—so Hdt. iii. 14, sunh/neike w(/ste with inf. in a similar sense. Classen also compares i. 28, 3, e(toi=moi w(/ste: i. 11, 9, dehqe/ntes w(/ste, and other like instances. Only one clause is affected by w(/ste, after which the general story goes
on with the indicative: so viii. 5, 2, a)napei/qetai *)/agis w(/ste *eu)boi/as me
 pe/ri e)pisxei=n, toi=s de\ *lesbi/ois pareskeu/aze th
 a)po/stasin. The subject of ei)=xon is resolved into two divisions, o<*> me
 *)aqhnai=oi...oi/ d) au)= *lakedaimo/nioi (line 14), and the construction is continued, chiefly in participial clauses, passing into the indicative towards the end of each division.

plhge/ntes—of a severe blow: iv. 108, 5, e)n toi=s *boiwtoi=s newsti\ peplhgme)nwn, of the same defeat at Delium. e)pi\ tw=| *dhli/w|—the battle of Delium was fought in the winter of 424: it is described in iv. 96. It was followed by the reduction of the fort which the Athenians had occupied (iv. 100). For the use of e)pi/ for in or at cf. ch. 15, 10.
th\n e)lpi/da th=s r(w/mhs—‘their confidence in their strength’; cf. ii. 89, 8, katalu=sai *peloponnhsi/wn th\n e)lpi/da tou= nautikou=.

r(w/mh is here used of material power, as in iv. 18, 2, dia\ th
 parou=san nu=n r(w/mhn po/lews: so vii. 63 (fin.) opposed to a)sqe/neia, kai\ meta\ a)sqenei/as kai\ cumforw=n h( u(mete/ra e)pisth/mh krei/sswn e)sti
 e(te/ras eu)tuxou/shs r(w/mhs. In iv. 29, 2, kai\ au)tw=| r\w/mhn h nh=sos e)mprhsqei=sa pare/sxe, it denotes mental confidence: so vii. 18, 1, toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois e)gege)nhto/ tis r(w/mh. There are besides two well-known passages where the word occurs, ii. 43, 3, o( meta\ r(w/mhs kai\ koinh=s e)lpi/dos...qa/natos: vii. 75, 3, ei)/ tw| prolei/poi h( r\w/mh kai\ to\ sw=ma. In both of these passages Liddell and Scott take r(w/mh in the sense of physical vigour, while Kruger understands it to mean spirit and confidence. The passive of r(w/nnumi seems generally used of eagerness and confidence: e.g. ii. 8, 1, e)/rrwnto e)s to
 po/lemon: iv. 72, 1, pollw=| ma=llon e)rrw/sqhsan: vi. 17, 6, ei/ pa/nu e)/rrwntai: so e)pe/rrwse, ‘reencouraged’, iv. 36, 2.

h(=|per—for the dative cf. e)lpi/di ii. 42, 5: ii. 44, 3. prote<*>on —see iv. 21 and 41. th=| parou:sh| eu)tuxi/a|—cf. iv. 14, 3, boulo/menoi th=| parou/sh| tu/xh| w(s e)pi\ plei=ston e)pecelqei=n, where Classen takes the dative as not governed by e)pecelqei=n, a view which the present phrase confirms.

e)de<*>i/esan—this form occurs iv. 55, 3; and as a var. lect. for e)/deisan iv. 117, 2. In several passages in other authors it is the manuscript reading. Grammatical authority is however in favour of e)de/disan: see Veitch's Irregular Verbs, under di/w.

meteme/lonto—this word is usually constructed with a
participle, as in ch. 35, 20: iv. 27, 2. meteme/lonto ta\s sponda\s ou) deca/menoi. Here o)/ti is used, probably to avoid the juxtaposition of two participles. kalw=s parasxo/n—so i. 120, 3, eu) parasxo\n e)k pole/mou pa/lin cumbh=nai: iv. 85, 2, o(/te pare/sxen.

oi( d) au)= *lakedaimo/nioi—see iv. 41 and 55, where the despondency of the Spartans at this time is described in very similar language. For the mixture of participial constructions in this part of the sentence cf. iv. 8, 3, dia\ taxe)wn ei:rgasme/non kai\ a)nqrw/pwn o)li/gwn e)no/ntwn, and the passages there cited. o)li/gwn e)tw=n—‘within a few years’: ch. 74, 2.
e)n th=| nh/sw|—the usual expression for Sphacteria, as in ch. 15, 4. gege/nhto—vii. 18, 2, e)gege/nhto.

lh|steuome/nhs—see iv. 41 and 54 seq. prosdoki/as... mh/—prosdoki/a here implies fear or suspicion, and accordingly is followed by mh/: so ii. 93, 2. Similarly mh/ follows u(potopw=, ii. 13, 1, and u(popteu/w, iii. 53, 2. toi=s e)/cw—so iv. 66, 2, oi( fi/loi tw=n e)/cw. pi/sunos is found in ii. 89, 4, th=| duna/mei pi/sunoi, and vi. 2, 6: but not elsewhere in Attic prose. It is used by Herodotus, and by the poets.
pro\s ta\ paro/nta—cf. iv. 80, 1, mh/ ti pro\s ta\ paro:nta th=s *pu/lou e)xome/nhs newteri/swsin. w(/sper kai\ pro/teron refers to the rising of the Helots in 465 (i. 101 seq.).

cune/baine—see note on ch. 10, 38. triakontae/teis— most manuscripts have this form or triakontaetei=s. Classen reads triakontou/teis with one manuscript, on the analogy of i. 23, 4, and other passages where that form occurs. There are however instances of the resolved form in Xenophon: and Thucydides has penthkontaeti/dwn in ch. 32, 22. It is in fact impracticable to insist on absolute uniformity even in the same author.
e)p) e)co/dw|—the same expression is used in ch. 28, 11; so that the truce lasted at any rate till 421.

ei) mh/ tis—so iv. 68, 5, ei) mh\ pei/setai/ tis: see note on ch. 10, 27. th\n *kunosouri/an gh=n—on the borders of Argos and Lacoma, iv. 56, 3: see also ch. 41, 6. Another form is *kunouri/a (Hdt. viii. 73 etc.), which is also read here in some manuscripts.

w)/st' a)du/nata—i.e. therefore they must make terms with Athens, as difficulties impended on the side of Argos.
There is a similar condensation of the logical conclusion with w)/ste at the end of iv. 85. For the neuter plural a)du/nata cf. note on iv. 1, 2, a)du/nata h)=n.
o)/per kai\ <*>g<*>neto—see ch. 29 seq.
ou(x h(=sson—the usual litotes for ‘especially’; ii. 52, 1, e)pi/ese d) au)tou\s...kai\ ou)x h(=sson tou\s e)pelqo/ntas.

e)piqumi/a| tw=n a)ndrw=n...komi/sasqai—the infinitive is added in explanation of the genitive. Poppo compares Plat. Crito 14 A, ou)d) e)piqumi/a se a)/llhs po/lews ou)d) a)/llwn no/mwn e)/laben ei)de/nai: Xen. Cyrop. v. 2. 31, ou) du/namai e)nnoh=sai a)sfaleste/ran ou)de\ mi/an porei/an h(mi=n th=s pro\s au)th\n *babulw=na porei/as <*>e/nai. For tw=n e:k th=s nh/sou cf. iv. 108 (fin.) boulo/menoi tou\s e) k th=s nh/sou komi/sasqai. It is a pregnant use of the preposition implying getting back the men who had been taken in the island: cf. ch. 34, 10, tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou lhfqe)ntas.
oi( *spartia=tai au)tw=n—‘those of them who were Spartans’, about 120 in number, iv. 38, 4. For the partitive genitive cf. iv. 61, 2, oi( *dwrih=s h:mw=n: iv. 126, 3, toi=s *makedo/sin au)tw=n.

prw=toi/ te k.t.l.—‘either chief men or no less intimately connected with them’, i.e. with the home authorities, who were conducting the negotiations. For the half technical use of prw=toi cf. iv. 105, 1, du/nasqai e)n toi=s prw/tois: iv. 132, 2, xrw/menos a)ei\ toi=s prw/tois. At Sparta the word seems to have denoted some definite rank, though we do not know what.

te and kai/ in this sentence have, I believe, a disjunctive force as in ii. 42, 2, prw/th te mhnu/ousa kai\ teleutai/a bebaiou=sa. o(moi/ws then means, not ‘all equally’, but ‘as much as the prw=toi themselves’; while sfi/si refers to the Lacedaemonian government, the main subject of the whole sentence according to sense if not in actual construction. The words as they stand will fairly bear a satisfactory sense; but many editors believe that there is something wrong in the text, while some consider that o(moi/ws is a corruption of some form denoting the o(moi=oi or ‘peers’, who were the leading caste among the free Spartans. Reiske accordingly proposes o(moi/wn, and Bekker o(moi/ois, ‘related to them (who were) their
peers’, sfi/sin referring to *spartia=tai. Kr&udot;ger suggests tw=n o(moi/wn ‘belonging to the peers’, leaving out sfi/si cuggenei=s as an interpolated gloss. Stahl prefers o(moi=oi sfi/si cuggenei=s= a)/te o(moi=oi o)/ntes. Plutarch (Nic. 10) says oi( e)k *pu/lou komisqe/ntes h)=san e)c oi)/kwn te prw/twn th=s *spa/rths kai\ fi/lous kai\ cuggenei=s tou\s dunatwta/tous e)/xontes, but these last words are a mere paraphrase, and do not help us to determine the reading in Thucydides. They are at any rate not sufficient to justify what Classen proposes to read, prw=toi/ te kai\ oi)/kois e)pifane/si cuggenei=s.

h)/rcanto—see iv. 15 seq. The negotiations were broken off by the overbearing conduct and rough behaviour of Cleon, but it must be remembered that the Spartans are not recorded to have offered any terms which the Athenians could fairly be expected to agree to. ou)/pws—the reading of the best manuscripts, cited from this passage by the grammarians Photius and Suidas. ou)/pw has also good manuscript authority.

e<*> fero/menoi—so ch. 16, 12: ii. 60, 2, kalw=s fero/menos. fe)resqai denotes movement, as we say ‘going on well’, and speak of ‘a prosperous course’. e)pi\ th=| i)/sh|—so i. 27, 1, e)pi\ th=| i)/sh| kai\ o(moi/a|. Such feminine phrases are common; see note on e)c e)nanti/as, iv. 33, 2.

ma=llon a)\n decame/nous—several manuscripts have a)\n e)ndecome/nous: some omit a)/n, or read e)ndecame/nous. There are undoubtedly instances, such as vi. 20, 1, and vii. 67 (fin.), in which the manuscript authority is in favour of a)/n with the future participle; while in others the future infinitive is found with a)/n, as in ii. 80 (fin.) and viii. 25 (fin.) In such cases the manuscript reading was generally retained by the older editors, but modern critics omit a)/n or change the future into the aorist.

th\n e)niau/sion e)kexeiri/an—see iv. 117 seq. e:/dei—i. e. as was then arranged; the imperfect refers to the time when the treaty was made. tou= plei/onos xro/nou—see note on iv. 30 (fin.), peri\ tou= ple/onos.
a)mfote/rwqen—at Athens and Sparta.

h)nantiou=nto—so Plut. Nic. 9, oi\ ma/lista prospolemou=ntes th=| ei)rh/nh| th=s *(ella/dos *kle/wn kai\ *brasi/das h)=san, w(=n o( po/lemos tou= me
 a\pe/krupte th
 kaki/an tou= de\ th
 a)reth
 e)ko/smei.

o( de\ ..diaba/llwn—‘and the other because he fancied that in quiet times his rogueries would be more transparent and his slanders less credible’ (Jowett). No doubt Cleon had been the main promoter of war since the affair of Sphacteria; but, according to the historian's own testimony, it is the grossest injustice to ascribe the policy which he advocated to personal motives only and those of the lowest kind.

to/te de/—‘then, I say’; an instance of de) used resumptively after a parenthetical interruption: so i. 11, 1, e)peidh) de\ .. fai/nontai d) ou)d) e)ntau=qa k.t.l. There is a slight manuscript authority for to/te dh/, which is adopted by Kr&udot;ger.

oi( e)n—these two words are found in three manuscripts, and are read by most editors. Classen however omits them, and takes e(kate)ra| th=| po/lei as governed by speu/dontes, comparing Eur. Iph. <*> 579, u:mi=n t' o)/nhsin, w)= ce/noi, speu(dous: a)/ma ka)uoi/. speu/dontes means ‘anxiously promoting’, ‘eager for’; vi. 10, 2, o(/per nu=n speudomen: vi. 40, 1, kaka\ speu/dontes. There seems however no other instance of a substantive thus governed without a dative. This is in favour of Classen's view. I should incline to retain oi( and omit e)n.

h(gemoni/an—this word is open to suspicion, as it is not elsewhere used of the civil ascendancy of a statesman in his own city, which would be the meaning here required. It denotes (1) the command in war, as in iv. 91, 2, h(gemoni/as ou)/shs au)tou=: vii. 15, 2, polla\ e)n h(gemoni/ais u)ma=s eu)= e)poi/hsa: (2) the sovereign leadership held by a state such as Sparta or Athens. Such leadership would be attained by war rather than by peace; nor were Pleistoanax and Nicias the men to promote the supremacy of their respective countries. It has been suggested that it means a joint leadership of Greece by Athens and Sparta; but to give this force, some qualifying word, such as koinh/n, would be required. Some editors therefore propose o)mo/noian, o)mologi/an, or some similar word, which gives good sense and agrees with ch. 17, 8, prou)qumh/qh th\n cu/mbasin. Classen, following Stahl, takes a different view, and reads ma/list' au)th/n (sc. ei)rh/nhn). He supposes that this had been corrupted into ma/lista th/n, and then a substantive conjecturally supplied. Jowett suggests omitting oi( e)n and referring to/te de\...h(gemoni/an to Cleon and Brasidas, not to Pleistoanax and Nicias, ‘these (Cleon and Brasidas) being at that time the two great champions for the supremacy of their respective states’. The apodosis then begins at *pleistoa/nac te. This gives an intelligible sense to h(gemoni/an, but the position of the clause is very awkward, and it seems clear that to/te de/ ought to begin the apodosis.

plei=sta—cognate or determinant accusative with fero/menos. eu)= fero/menos—ch. 15, 9. Nicias was indeed the only Athenian general of the day who had not met with some great disaster. Demosthenes had been totally defeated in Aetolia in 426. The commanders of the Sicilian expedition had been compelled to withdraw ignominiously in 424. In the same year Hippocrates was defeated and slain at Delium, and Thucydides lost Amphipolis. Cleon had perished at Amphipolis in 422.

h)cio<*>to—either (1) absolutely ‘was held in honour’, or (2) ‘was so esteemed’, referring to a)paqh\s h)=n. In support of the former view editors cite Porson on Eur. Hec. 319, tu/mbon de\ bouloi/mhn a)
 a)ciou/menon to
 e)mo
 o(ra=sqai. I incline however to (2), for the use of a)ciw= meaning simply ‘to honour’, though found in the tragedians, seems not to occur elsewhere in Attic prose; and by rendering the words ‘was so accounted’ we get an excellent sense. It was his reputation as a successful general as well as his actual success which Nicias was anxious to preserve; and h)ciou=to with this meaning is answered by katalipei=n o)/noma below, just as po/nwn pepau=sqai corresponds to a)paqh\s h)=n. So Demosthenes (Lept. 482) says of Chabrias, dokw=n kai\ w)
 a:sfale)statos strathgo\s a)pa/ntwn. ib. diasw/sasqai—the aorist implies securing his good fortune by one definite act, such as the conclusion of peace.

pepau=sqai kai\ au)to/s—i.e. kai\ au)to\s pepau=sqai, or rather pau=sai is added by a slight change of construction to govern poli/tas. See iii. 67, 6, a)mu/nate kai\ tw=| no/mw| kai\ h(mi=n a)ntapo/dote xa/rin, where other instances are cited by Poppo.

katalipei=n o(/noma—cf. vi. 33, 6, toi=s e)pibouleuqei=sin <*>noma katalei/pousin: vi. 16, 5, prospoi/hsin cuggenei/as katalipo/ntas. diege/neto—a second compound with dia/, emphasizing the fact that Nicias did not retain his good fortune ‘throughout his career’: cf. Ar. Av. 45, o(/pou kaqidruqe/nte diagenoi/meq) a)/n.

kai\ o(/stis—lit. ‘and (falls to a man) who’, etc. Far harsher constructions with o)/stis are not uncommon: see instances cited on iii. 45, 5, pollh=s eu(hqei/as, o(/stis oi)/etai: iv. 18, 2, swfro/nwn de\ a(ndrw=n, oi)/tines.. e)/qento. Thucydides puts similar words in Nicias' mouth at the time of the Sicilian expedition, vi. 23, 3, o(/ ti e)la/xista th=| tu/xh| paradou\s e)mauto\n bou/lomai e)kplei=n. ‘We can hardly suppose’, says Professor Jowett, ‘that Thucydides wrote these words without intending silently to recall to the reader's mind the singular contrast between the hopes of mortals
and their final destinies, or without a recollection of the old Greek saying, that no man could be called happy before he died. He who desires only peace may be the author of war; he who aims only at the safety of the state may, by the irony of fortune, be the prime mover in its destruction.’

e)s e)nqumi/an...proballo/menos—lit. ‘put forward as a matter of (religious) anxiety’, explained further by w(s dia\ k.t.l. The personal construction may be illustrated by such expressions as Ar. Nub. 1241, *zeu\s ge/loios o)mnu/menos, ‘it is absurd to swear by Zeus’. The form e)nqumi/a seems not found elsewhere in classical Greek. The adjective e)nqu/mios is however common, e.g. vii. 50, 4, e)nqu/mion poiou/menoi: Soph. Oed. Tyr. 739, ti/ d) e)sti/ soi tou=t' e)nqu/mion; similarly e)nqumei=sqai is used of laying a thing to heart, as in ch. 32, 6.
o(po/te ti ptai/seian—for the construction cf. iv. 18, 3, e)la/xista ptai/ontes

paranomhqei=san—‘illegally effected’. This construction is best explained as the passive equivalent of a cognate accusative with the active. We say a)dikw= tou=to, ‘I commit a wrong in this’, and in the passive this becomes tou=to a)dikei=tai, ‘this is a wrong act’. The participle here has its predicative force, as in iii. 20, 1, tw=| si/tw| e)pilipo/nti e)pie/zonto, ‘they suffered from failure of the corn’. Classen takes it merely as part of the epithet, comparing for its position such passages as iii. 56, 1, kata\ to\n pa=si no/mon kaqestw=ta. This however weakens the sense: see note on iv. 87, 2, toi=s a)po\ u:mw=n xrh/masi ferome/nois par' *)aqhnai/ous.
th\n pro/mantin—so Hdt. vi. 66, *peri/allan th\n pro/mantin a)napei/qei: id. vii. 111, pro/mantis de\ h( xre/ousa, kata/ per e)n *delfoi=si.

pei=sai. <*>w(/ste—so iii. 70, 3, pei/qei w(/ste tw=| no/mw| xrh/sasqai: ii. 2, 4, ou)k e)pei/qonto w)/ste eu)qu\s e)/rgou e)/xesqai: so ii. 101, 3, with a)napei/qetai. This construction connects two ideas less immediately than if the simple infinitive were employed. The meaning here is that the result of their persuasion (or bribery) was that the priestess gave oracles in their interest. We have a double construction with w(/ste in viii. 45, 3, tou\s trihra/rxous e)di/dasken w(/ste do/nta xrh/mata au)to\n pei=sai w(/ste cugxwrh=sai tau=ta e(autw=|.

e)pi\ polu/—of extent of time, as in iv. 72, 2, where see note. qewroi=s a)fiknoume/nois—‘when they came on the public behalf to consult the oracle’. ‘On a former occasion, when the Pythoness was bribed by the Alcmaeonidae to inculcate on
the Spartans the duty of delivering Athens from the Pisistratidae, Herodotus says, that she repeated this charge not only to the qewroi/, who came on the public behalf, but also to any Lacedaemonian who consulted the oracle on his own private affairs. The duties of qewroi/ at Sparta were performed by the four *pu/qioi, two being nominated by each of the kings, who were maintained with the kings at the public expense, and who together with them read the answers which the oracle returned. See Hdt. vi. 57: Xen. Rep. Lac. 15’ (Arnold).

*dio\s ui(ou= h(miqe/ou—‘the Heraclidae at Sparta were believed to hold the kingly power by an inalienable right, derived from the original compact made between their ancestors and the Dorians, when they jointly in vaded Peloponnesus’ (Arnold).

a)nafe/rein—i.e. kata/gein. xra/w and similar words, like other words of commanding or warning, commonly take the present or aorist infinitive, in the sense of bidding or of oracular intimation. Sometimes, as in the next clause, when promise or prediction is especially implied, we have the future: ii. 102, 4, le/getai *)alkmai/wni to\n *)apo/llw tau/thn th\n gh=n xrh=sai oi)kei=n: i. 118, 3, a)nei=len au)toi=s ni/khn e)/sesqai: see Goodwin's Moods and Tenses, § 98

a)rgure/a| eu)la/ka| eu)la/cein—meaning either that they should be obliged to purchase their corn at a great price, or that they should find agriculture costly and unprofitable. eu:la/ka is said to be an old Laconian word for a ploughshare, and eu)la/cein to be equivalent to a)ro/sein. Neither noun nor verb are found elsewhere.

protre/yai—the run of the sentence seems in favour of taking this as following w(/ste and, like xrh=sai, referring to the pro/mantis. Grammatically it might depend on e)ph|tiw=nto, and correspond to pei=sai in coustruction. The following au)to/n would then refer to Pleistoanax, the primary subject, according to the rule set forth by Poppo on i. 17, 1; see note on iv. 50 (fin.).

feu/gonta...e)s—feu(gein often means ‘to be in exile’, as in this passage, and in ch. 26, 28. It still however retains the construction of a verb of motion, and is followed by e)s rather than by e)n. *lu/kaion—ch. 54, 3, pro\s to\ *lu/kaion, the only other place in Thucydides where the word occurs. Lycaeus was a mountain in Arcadia, with a temple of *zeu\s *lu/kaios.

dia\ th\n...a)naxw/rhsin—this was in 445, (i. 114, 3: ii. 21, 1). meta\ dw/rwn dokou=san—‘propter suspicionem acceptae ob discessum pecuniae’: so ii. 21, 1, dio\ dh\ kai\ h( fugh\ au)tw=| e)ge/neto
e)k *spa/rths do/canti xrh/masi peisqh=nai th\n a)naxw/rhsin. dokei=n in the sense of ‘to be reputed’ is often used like uideor, to imply a judicial decision: dokw==‘I am held (guilty)’, e)/doca ‘I was found (guilty)’: cf. ch. 72, 5, do/cantas malakisqh=nai. There is some curtness in the use of meta\ dw/rwn to mean ‘effected by bribery’, and the reading is not free from doubt. Most manuscripts have do/khsin followed by e(/ws. Suidas interprets dw/rwn do/khsin as equivalent to dwrodoki/an, and some commentators propose dw/rwn dokh/sews in the same sense. There is however no sign of the existence of do/khsis in the sense of ‘receiving’ connected with de/xomai: while it occurs several times in Thucydides as derived from dokw=. dwrodo/khsis would be a word legitimately formed from dwrodokei=n, though it is not found in the lexicons; and possibly meta\ dwrodo/khsin or meta\ dwrodokh/sews is the true reading, or else, as Stahl reads, meta\ dw/rwn dokh/sews, ‘with the imputation of bribery’. Classen suggests, meta\ dwrwdokh/sews dokou=san a)naxw/rhsin.

h(/misu th=s oi)ki/as—these words are governed directly by oi)kou=nta, and tou= i(erou= is predicative: it is the partitive genitive, ‘belonging to the temple’. Half of the house in which he lived at this time was in the sacred precinct of Zeus. ‘The reason was, that he might be in sanctuary at an instant's notice, and yet might be able to perform some of the common offices of life without profanation, which could not have been the case had the whole dwelling been within the precinct’ (Arnold). In the same way Pausanias, wheu threatened with arrest, fled to the temple of Athene of the Brazen House, kai\ e)s oi)/khma ou) me/ga d h)=n tou= i(erou= e)selqw\n...h(su/xazen (i. 134, 2).

h(/misu is found without the article i. 8, 1, u:pe\r h(/misu *ka=res e)fa/nhsan: viii. 68, 4, u(pe\r h(/misu tou= xro/nou. It is one of the terms which from frequent use acquire a definite force, just as we say ‘half the time’. There is too a general tendency to omit the article in such prepositional phrases.
fo/bw| tw=n—many manuscripts have fo/bw| tw=|, but tw=n is the usual form, as in ch. 11, 13.

e)/tei—this was in 426 or thereabouts, for the retreat for which he was banished was in 445; see line 32. During his banishment his son Pausanias, a minor, was king (iii. 26, 2). tou\s basile/as—Eurysthenes and Procles, twin sons of Aristodemus; see Hdt. vi. 52.

a)nepi/lhptos—‘not open to attack, or censure’: Eur. Or. 922, a)nepi/lhpton (var. lect.) h(skhkw\s bi/on: Xen. Anab. vii. 6, 37, e)/cestin a)nepilh/ptws poreu/esqai: cf. Soph. Ant. 406, e)pi/lhptos h)|re/qh. and see e)pilamba/nw. a)po\ tw=n cumforw=n—a)po/, ‘from’, denotes the origin and cause: ii. 25, 2, a)po\ tou/tou tou= tolmh/matos e)ph|ne/qh.

prou)qumh/qh th
 cu/mbasin—the cognate construction (ti, tou=to etc.) is here extended to the substantive: so viii. 90, 2, th
 o(mologi/an prou)qumou=nto: viii. 1, 1, toi=s cumproqumhqei=si to
 e)/kploun.
