kai\ to/n te—the punctuation in the text is that of Poppo and Krüger, according to which to/n te xeimw=na h)/|esan is answered by kai\ pro\s to\ e)/ar paraskeuh/ te proepanesei/sqh|. kai) e)peidh/. ‘The final result (to/te dh/) was due first of all to the threatening attitude of the Lacedaemonians; secondly, to the circumstance that the commissioners of both parties were just then finding, after many disputes, a possible basis of agreement’ (Jowett). The second division of this sentence is inconveniently long and complicated, and possibly Classen is right in putting a stop after pro\s to\ e)/ar h)/dh (sc h)/|esan e)s lo/gous), and beginning a fresh sentence with paraskeuh/ te.

pro\s to\ e)/ar—so ch. 39, 20. h)/dh—ch. 59, 3, h(me/ras h)/dh: i. 30 (fin.) xeimw=nos h)/dh. proepanesei/sqh=prohpeilh/qh, as explained by the scholiast, ‘there were threatening demonstrations of an expedition on the part of Lacedaemon’. It is a metaphor from brandishing a weapon at a foe; cf. iv. 126, 4, h( e)pana/seisis tw=n o(/plwn e)/xei tina\ dh/lwsin a)peilh=s: see e)panasei/w.

a)po/—‘on the side of’; iii. 65, 5, gnw=mai a)f) eka/stwn e)le/gonto. periaggellome/nh—ii. 85, 2, nau=s perih/ggellon kata\ po/leis: see note on iv. 8, 2. periagge/llw in this sense takes either the infinitive, or an accusative of the force demanded.

w(s e)pi\ teixismo/n—several manuscripts have w(s e)piteixismo/n, and Arnold therefore approves of w(s e)s e)piteixismo/n, comparing i. 50, 5, where w(s e)s e)pi/ploun is an accepted emendation of the manuscript reading w\s e)pi/ploun. e)piteixismo(s is no doubt a suitable word: it occurs in i. 122, 1, e)piteixismo\s th=| xw/ra|: and we have e)pitei/xisis in i. 142, 1. The simple form teixismo/s however seems used of the construction of hostile works in general, as in viii. 34, 2, pareskeua/zonto e)s to\n
teixismo/n. Poppo accordingly retains teixismo/n in his text, and is followed by modern editors.
a(/ma—rightly taken by Jowett as connecting cunexwrei=to with proepanesei/sqh.

dikaiw/seis—‘claims’ or ‘demands’ professedly grounded on justice; i. 141, 1, h(/ te megi/sth kai\ e)laxi/sth dikai/wsis. proenegko/ntwn—this sentence has two instances of the genitive absolute with subject understood profe/rw, active, iii. 64, 1: middle, iii. 59, 2: passive, ch. 26, 24.

cuuexwrei=to—Classen notes that this is a solitary instance of the passive of this word used impersonally. The imperfect, as he also points out, denotes the slow and difficult settlement of satisfactory terms. For w(/ste, of conditions, cf. iv. 46, 2, w(/ste lelu/sqai ta\s sponda/s: Goodwin § 587, 2.

e)/sxon—‘won’; e)/xein ‘keep’. au)tw=n—explained by the precediug *pla/taian: so in iv. 1, 1, au)tw=n e)pagagome/nwn follows *messh/nhn kate/labon. Plataea surrendered in 427; the city was destroyed and the land occupied by the Thebans (iii. 52 sq.).

oi( *)aqhnai=oi...*ni/saian—sc. e)/xein e)/fasan: see iv. 69. The Athenian claim to Nisaea rested on the same grounds as the Theban claim to Plataea, both places having been compelled by famine to agree to terms.

parakale/santes—i. 67, 1, pareka/loun e)s th\n *lakedai/mona tou\s cumma/xous. plh\n *boiwtw=n—the allies generally regarded with suspicion a private arrangement between Athens and Sparta; while the Bocotians were unwilling to restore Panactum, and the Megarians resented the Athenian occupation of Nisaea. In chapters 30 and 31 we find the particular grounds of dissatisfaction on the part of Corinth and Elis.

tw=n a)/llwn—added to define further the subject of yhfisame/nwn, all the other states but those mentioned. tou/tois refers to the states in question. w)/ste—cf. vi. 88, 9, yhfisa/. menoi au)toi\ w(/ste a)mu/nein.

ta/de—‘as follows’; cf. 76, 20: iv. 117 fin. gi/gnetai e)kexeiri/a...h(/de.
The provisions of the treaty now concluded should be compared with the year's truce made the year before as recorded in iv. 118. ‘The fifty years’ peace is based not, like the treaty which preceded it, upon the principle of uti possidetis, but on that of compensation. As in the preliminary treaty, the right of access to the Delphic oracle is maintained for all Hellenes; and a clause is inserted guaranteeing the Delphians their independence. Great concessions are made by Sparta to Athens, chiefly in return for the Spartan captives' (Jowett). The language of the treaty is sometimes awkward in expression, but the meaning is clear throughout. The main clauses have the usual infinitive construction alternating with the imperative.

kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi—the allies of Sparta alone are mentioned, as in lines 55 and 61. The Athenians seem to have acted independently. On the other hand we have in iv. 119, 1, cune/qento *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi *)aqhnai/ois kai\ toi=s cumma/xois: cf. ch. 47, 3.

koinw=n—the koina\ i(era/ are spoken of iii. 57, 1. They were ‘those of Delphi, Olympia, Nemea, and the Isthmian Neptune, at which the four great national festivals of games were celebrated; that of Jupiter at Dodona, possibly of Abae in Phocis, and any others at which oracles were delivered’ (Arnold).

kai\ i)e/nai—apparently, as Arnold points out, a provision for the safe conduct of worshippers on their way to the temples, as well as in performing their religious offices when there. The position of the words after qu/ein is awkward, and they are bracketed as doubtful by Krüger and Classen. Arnold however justly observes that in all formal instruments many words are inserted to prevent the possibility of evasion, which in ordinary language would be deemed superfluous.

qewrei=n—to go, or send envoys to the games: viii. 10, 1, ta\ *)/isqmia e)gi/gneto kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)qewroun e)s auta). ‘The exclusion from the games was considered an especial grievance, as it implied an unworthiness in the persons excluded to appear before the god in whose honour the festival was celebrated: see ch. 50, 7; and Livy ii. 37, 38’ (Arnold).

to\ i(ero/n—the whole of the sacred precincts; see note on iv. 90, 2. au)tono/mous k.t.l.—‘independent as regards laws
and imposts and jurisdiction’. In 449 the Athenians had placed the temple in the hauds of the Phocians (i. 112, 5). The genitive au(tw=n depeuds on the idea of ‘control over’, which is implied in the preceding adjectives, especially au)tono/mous.

e)pi\ phmonh=|—so ch. 47, 6; an old and poetic word, used in the language of treaties by Thucydides. In line 28 we have e)pi\ kakw=|. mh/te te/xnh| k.t.l.—ch. 47, 10 and 57: Dem. Timocr. 747 (150), ou)de\ dw=ra de/comai ou)/te te/xnh| ou)/te mhxanh=| ou)demi/a|, from the oath taken by the h(liastai/.

ti dia/foron—‘any difference or disputed point’, as in the passages cited in the next note, and others quoted by Krüger on i. 56, 1, gene/sqai dia/fora. We have the singular in vii. 55, 2, e)penegkei=n ti to\ dia/foron, where the word probably means a ‘cause of dissension’. In vii 75, 7, it means a reverse.

dikai/w|—some few MSS. have di/kais, which we should rather expect, compaiing i. 78, 3, ta\ de\ dia/fora di/kh| lu/esqai: i. 140, 5, di/kas tw=n diafo/rwn a)llh/lois dido/nai kai\ de/xesqai. di/kaion means what is in accordance with justice, a just principle, point, or consideration, or as we say ‘a right’; so iii. 54. 1, parexo/menoi a(\ e)/xomen di/kaia. The sense here required is ‘just or legal course of procedure’, and it is so taken by Krüger and Classen. I am not without doubt whether the word will bear this meaning, but I have not taken on myself to alter the text.

pare/dosan—the aorist seems to take the restoration as virtually carried into effect. We might expect o(/sas a)\n paradw=si: cf. e)ge/nonto, line 29. It is not clear whether the provisions of this clause extend to Amphipolis as well. paradido/nai ‘to hand over’ is a more general word than a)podido/nai. The latter seems to be used of the places the actual possession of which was of primary importance.

ferou/sas—‘on condition of paying’. to\n e)p' *)aristei/dou fo/ron—the fo/ros was the money payment furnished by the allies instead of ships for carrying on the war against the Persian power; see 1. 96—99. Its original amount was 460 talents (i. 96, 3). By 431 it averaged 600 talents (ii. 13, 3), ‘not probably by an increase of the rate imposed upon the allies, but from the extension of the tribute to new cities and by the commutation of ships for money’. See Jowett's note, for inscriptions etc. relating to the tribute. There seems reason to believe that the assessment had been doubled in 425, though according to the orators this was done by Alcibiades.
a)podido/ntwn—‘provided they pay’. For the force of the compound cf. ch. 53, 4. e)peidh/—‘after the conclusion of treaty’; 1. 6, 3, ou) polu\s xro/nos e)peidh\ e)pau/santo.

ei(si\ de\ *)/argilos k.t.l.—these are cities fliendly to Sparta, and entitled to her protection. The defection of Argilus, Acanthus and Stageirus to Brasidas is related in iv. 88 and 103, 3. Scolus is not mentioned elsewhere by Thucydides. It appears to have been one tw=n peri\ *)/olunqon po/lewn, and probably, like Olynthus and Spartolus, revolted from Athens at the beginning of the war; see i. 58, 1.

au(tou/s—singularly awkward. It is commonly taken as the subject of poiei=sqai, referring to the Athenians, while *(aqhnai/ois=e(autoi=s. Krüger proposes to alter au)tou/s into au)tono/mous, or omit it; in this case *)aqhnai/ois would depend on e)ce/stw, which certainly seems the most natural construction. The best way seems to take boulome/nas tau/tas as a sort of pendent construction and au)tou/s as the object of poiei=sqai, denoting the inhabitants of the cities. The combination in line 51 is somewhat similar. See too iii. 79, 3, e)pi\ th\n po/lin ou)de\n ma=llon e)pe/pleon, kai/per e)n pollh=| taraxh=| kai\ fo/bw| o)/ntas, It has also been proposed to put the comma before e)ce/stw, thus connecting boulome/nas tau/tas with the words which precede. Another suggestion is to read au)tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, ‘the Athenians independently may make them their allies’: the accusative as in line 27.

*mhkubernai/ous k.t.l.—these appear to be cities which had reniained faithful to Athens. Sane had held out against Brasidas (iv. 109, 3); Mecybern a was afterwards taken by the Olynthians (ch. 39, 1). Singi is not elsewhere mentioned by Thucydides. It appears from Hdt. (vii. 122) to have been in Sithonia. These places may have shown signs of disaffection to Athens; or this may be a stipulation on the Athenian side to secure them against hostile neighbours (Jowett).

*pa/nakton—ch. 3, 27. *korufa/sion—the Spartan name for Pylos (iv. 3, 2). *ku/qhra—iv. 53 sq. *meqw/nhn—iv. 45, 2, note (where the orthography of the word is discussed). *pteleo/n has not been mentioned before. There were four or five places so named. Phny speaks of one in Boeotia, while Strabo places another on the confines of Messenia and Elis. *)atala/nth was a small island off the coast of Locri occupied by the Athenians in 431 (ii. 32).

e)n tw=| dhmosi/w|—i.e. in prison, said to be a Laconian
expression, Xen. Hel. vii. 4, 36. The captives from the island are especially meant. o)/shs—sc. gh=s or xw/ras, as in line 47.
*brasi/das e)se/pemyen—see iv. 123, 4.

*skiwnai/wn de\ k t.l.—these were revolted cities now in the power of Athens. Scione was closely blockaded (iv, 133, 4), while Torone had been retaken by Cleon (ch. 3). *sermuli/wn—mentioned in i. 65, 2 as fliendly to Athens; no revolt is recorded. Classen reads *sermuliw=n, on the ground that the town was called *zermuli/a and the people *sermulih=s.
ei)/ tina a)/llhn—e.g. Mende, which had been recovered in 423 (iv. 129 sq.). The construction is interrupted by the clause with e)/ tina, and peri\ au)tw=n, etc. added by a slight anacoluthon.

to\n me/giston—so ch. 47, 54: iv. 85, 6, o(/rkois katalabw\n toi=s megi/stois. e)c e(ka/sths po/lews—for e)c Classen adopts the emendation e(ptakai/deka, which would be denoted by iz), this being the number of signatories to the treaty on each side.

to\n de\ o(/rkon a)naneou=sqai—‘this arose partly from the feeling that all laws and public acts required to be solemnly confirmed from time to time, to prevent them from becoming obsolete, and partly lest the succeeding magistrates might think themselves not bound by the acts of their predecessors, unless they themselves incurred the obligation. So the Veientines are said to have attacked Servius Tullius, on the ground that their treaty with his predecessor Tarquinius Priscus did not extend to him’ (Arnold).

e)n po/lei—ch. 23, 27: ch. 47, 74. The acropolis is meant, cf. ii. 15 fin. kalei=tai de\ h( a)kro/polis me/xri tou=de e)/ti u(p' *)aqhnai/wn po/lis. There is no article, as the word acquires the force of a proper name; cf. ch. 10, 63.

e)n *)amuklai/w|—the temple of Apollo at Amyclae, stated by Polybius to be twenty stadia from Sparta. So in iv. 133, 2, the temple of Hera is said to be e)n *)/argei, though it was forty stadia from the city.
kai\ o(/tou pe/ri—=o:touou=n, or else connected by kai/ with ei(/ ti, a)mnhmonou=sin being supplied again.

a)/rxei—cf. iv. 118, 8, a)/rxein de\ th/nde th\n h(me/sai, ‘this day to begin it’. In giving the date the year is here put first and forms the subject of a)/rxei, e)/foros *pleisto/las being ‘the year of Pleistolas' office’. Then comes the month, and then the day. Comparing the passage cited from Book iv. we find the same variation of two days at Athens and Sparta, while here Elaphebolion corresponds to Artemisins instead of to Gerastius (see note on iv. 119, 1).
e)k *dionusi/wn eu)qu/s—‘immediately after’; i. 120, 3, e)k pole/mou pa/lin cumbh=nai. The City or great Dionysia were held about the end of March.

kai\ parenegkousw=n—‘with a variation of a few days’. kai/ here has probably the corrective force noticed on iv. 35, 3, and is equivalent to ‘in fact’, ‘that is to say’. The time that the war lasted was a few days more than ten years, reckoning from the attack on Plataea (ii. 2 sq.); and somewhat less than ten years, counting from the time when the Spartans first took the field with the intention of invading Attica (Arnold). For parenegkw/n, in the sense of varying, cf. ch. 26, 21. A few instances of the same usage are cited from late Greek writers.
h)/—dependent on the sense implied in dielqo/ntwn, as if u(/steron had been written.
kata\ tou\s xro/nous—i.e. the half-yearly periods by which the writer reckons, as explained below, line 12. See also ch. 26, 20.

kai\ mh/—‘and not in accordance with the enumeration of the names of those who, in each several state, either were archons or from holding some office served as a mark for past events’, i.e. whose names were used to date by. Thus in Sparta the years were marked by the names of the Ephors, in Argos by the year of office of the priestess of Hera.
The order of this sentence is very awkward, the words th\n a)pari/qmhsin tw=n o)noma/twn, which depend on kata/, being apparently postponed in order to give the most important words an antithetical prominence. But probably th\n a)pari/qmhsin tw=n o)noma/twn ought to be transposed and placed either immediately after mh/, or at the end of the sentence after shmaino/ntwn. Corresponding to h)\ a)rxo/ntwn we have h)\ a)po\ timh=s tino\s shmaino/ntwn. shmai/nein e)s is ‘to furnish a mark as regards’; cf. ii. 8, 3, e)do/kei e)pi\ toi=s me/llousi genh/sesqai shmh=nai=shmei=on ei)=nai: so shmai/nei stands absolutely in ii. 43, 3. Classen however suggests that e)s should here be omitted. pisteu/sas ma=llon is added for the sake of emphasis, without affecting the construction.

a)kribe/s—in its strict sense, implying exactness of detail. oi(=s kai\ k.t.l.—an indirect construction, dependent on a)kribe/s. ‘For whether an event occurred in the beginning, or the middle, or whatever might be the exact point, of a magistrate's term of office is left uncertain by such a mode of reckoning’ (Jowett). Classen however takes the clause ou) ga\r a)kribe/s as parenthetical ‘this gives no exactness’: and makes oi(=s=o(/ti tou/tois. kai/ here has a disjunctive force, as noted on ch. 15, 6.

e)c h(misei/as—‘as each (of these periods) has the value of the year in half-measure’, i.e. is equivalent to half a year. With h(mi/seia ‘half’, moi=ra is probably understood: cf. Dem. Fals. leg. 431, e)f) h(misei/a| xrhsto\n ei)=nai. In such phrases as ch. 31, 9, the gender is determined by the following noun, and so here it might be referred to du/namin.

du/namin—‘value’ or ‘amount’; ii. 97, 3, tetrakosi/wn tala/ntwn a)rguri/ou ma/lista du/namis: vi. 46, 2, a)p' o)li/ghs duna/mews xrhma/twn. So i. 141, 1, th\n au)th\n du/natai dou/lwsin: vi. 40, 3, lo/gous w(s e)/rga duname/nous: cf. ualeo.
e)/laxon—the same construction occurs ch. 35, 9: so Hdt. i. 94, laxo/ntas e)cie/nai: Dem. etc.
*)isxago/ran—Ischagoras was one of the envoys sent to Brasidas in 423 (iv. 132). He is named with Menas and Philocharidas among the signatories to the treaty in ch. 19.
e)pithdei/as—‘favourable to their interests’; cf. iv. 54, 3, e)pithdeio/teron ta\ th=s o(mologi/as e)ge/neto. When used of a person the word often means well-disposed.
bi/a| e)kei/nwn—i. 43, 3, bi/a| h(mw=n: i. 68, 3, etc.
oi( peri\ to\n *)isxago/ran—Ischagoras and his colleagues, so ch. 46, 29: viii. 63, <*> oi peri to\n *peisandron pre/sbeis.

kateilhmme/nas—sc. ta\s sponda/s, line 7, corresponding in sense to h( o(mologi/a. There is some awkwardness in this construction, besides which there seems no instance of kateilhmme/nos being used to mean ‘closed, finally concluded’, which would be the force here required. There is therefore much in favour of reading kateilhmme/nous, finding the Spartans ‘bound by’ the arrangements. This agrees with i. 9, 1, o(/rkois kateilhmme/nous a)/gwn, and iv. 85, 6, katalabw\n ta\ te/lh.
ma)lista me/n...ei) de\ mh/—so i. 32, 1: i. 35 fin. etc. The force of kai/, ‘as well’ as performing the other conditions, is to be noted.

au)tou=—the reading of most manuscripts; Krüger quotes Xen. Hel. vii. 4, 36, e)n th=| *tege/a| au)tou=. There is also some authority for au)toi/, ‘of themselves’, i.e. for purposes of their own, without a summons from Sparta; cf. ch. 30, 15. Classen suggests that au)tou= e)/ti e)/tuxon is the true reading.
th=| au)th=| profa/sei—for the dative cf. ch. 14, 9. The disapproval of the allies is mentioned towards the end of ch. 17.
ou)k e)/fasan de/casqai—‘refused to accept the treaty’. On this aorist construction Poppo writes ‘mutatione non opus videtur’, and it is retained by Krüger and Classen.

nomi/zontes k.t.l. — this sentence is awkward and probably corrupt The alterations, chiefly omissions, which have been suggested are far too numerous to discuss here. They are given fully in Mr Fowler's edition. Taking the words as they stand in the text the key is to be sought in the connexion of the two main dependent clauses, h(/kista a)\n sfi/si tou/s te *)argei/ous kai\ th\n a)/llhn *pelopo/nnhson. By an alliance
with Athens the Spartans hoped to effect two objects, to secure themselves against Argos, and to ensure the tranquillity of Peloponnesus. In construction, the clause with nomi/zontes is left incomplete, the sense which should have followed, ‘thinking that the Argives would be least likely to prove dangerous’ or the like, being resumed with the words nomi/santes au)tou\s k.t.l.

e)peidh/—this gives the reason for apprehending the hostility of Argos. e)pispe/ndesqai—‘to renew a truce’; e)pi/ implying sequence, as in e(pirw/nnumi, gi/gnomai, etc.; see note on iv. 36, 2: cf. ch. 14, 25, a)/llas ou/k h)/qelon spe/ndesqai.

nomi/santes—taking nomi/santes of the Spartans and au)tou/s of the Argives, these words are a resumption of the clause with which the sentence began, ‘having come to the conclusion, I say’, etc.; and the change of time from present to aorist introduces a slight variation of idea. Classen, who omits nomi/zontes .sfi/si, takes au)tou/s to mean ‘by themselves’, further explained by a)/neu *)aqhnai/wn. Some editors make this clause part of the accessory sentence with e)peidh/, and thus refer nomi/santes to the Argives and au)tou/s to the Spartans. Grammatically this is free from objection, though the sequence of nomi/zontes, nomi/santes, in agreement with different subjects is harsh and awkward. But the sense is fatal to such a construction, for it is absurd to talk of the Argives ‘not thinking the Spartans formidable without the Athenians’. They were always more than a match for Argos, and an alliance between them and Athens was a condition seldom present.

pro\s ga\r a(/n—i.e. but for this treaty between Athens and Sparta; cf. iv. 54, 3, a(ne/sthsan ga\r a)\n *kuqhri/ous. Classen believes *)aqhnai/ous to be a copyist's error, and reads *)argei/ous, comparing the concluding words of ch. 14. Treaty between Athens and Sparta. ‘The new agreement was a defensive alliance made between the Athenians and Lacedaemonians, and was confined to one or two points. The clause which is repeated here from the previous treaty, empowering the two contracting parties, of themselves and with
out the consent of their allies, to add or take away from either treaty, naturally created a panic among the Peloponnesians (ch. 29, 15), whose independence was threatened by it. The allies or tributaries of Athens were not in a position to make a similar complaint, for most of them had suffered already what the Lacedaemonian allies dreaded, nor had those of them who were independent anything to fear from Lacedaemon. The provision respecting the revolt of the slaves applies to Lacedaemon only. This indicates that the Athenians were in no such danger from their slaves, as the Lacedaemonians were from the Helots. The older treaty remained in force, and, in accordance with its provisions, the prisoners of Sphacteria now restored’ (Jowett).

kata\ ta/de—these words are commonly printed, not as part of the treaty, but as the end of the foregoing chapter. Classen follows Kruger in placing them as they stand in the text; see ch. 47, 11: ch. 77, 1: ch. 79, 1.

*lakedaimo/nioi—Classen, following Portus, adds kai\ *aqhnai=oi. Hofmann suggests that we may have the text of the treaty as signed by the Lacedaemonians. h)/n de/ tines— de/ ought possibly to be omitted, as in ch. 47, 13, and other passages.
w)felei=n—‘help’; in the treaty given in ch. 47 we have the more ordinary bohqei=n.
tro/pw| dunato/n—the same form occurs twice in ch. 47. Krüger compares Plat. Rep. 458 E, ga/mous poih/somen i(erou\s ei)s o(\u/namin o(/ti ma/lista.

katalu/ein de\ a(/ma—i.e. neither city is to make a separate peace. katalu/ein usually takes a case, as to\n po/lemon in ch. 47, 20; katalu/esqai, as in iv. 18, 4, being used for ‘making terms’, the middle implying joint or reciprocal action. In viii. 58, fin. we have h(\n de\ katalu/ein bou/lontai toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, e)n o\moi/w| katalu/esqai.
a)/mfw tw/—the regular form of the feminine dual; see note on iv. 4, 2, tw\ xei=re.
ei(=nai—Kruger quotes Xen. Hell. iv. 4, 8, pa/nta ei)=nai a)do/lws. Classen notes that such phraseology is archaic, as the language of treaties and public documents often is.

h( doulei/a—‘the slave-class’. Lid. and Scott give instances of the collective use of the word from Plato and Aristotle: cf. Tac. Ann. xii. 17, servitii decem milia offerebant. e)panisth=tai—i. 115, 4, tw=| dh/mw| e)panc/sthsan.

e(kate/rwn—dependent on oi(/ per. For a)naneou=sqai, and the remaining terms of the treaty, see notes on ch. 18, 61 seq. Here par' *)aqhna=| is added, meaning near her statue (ii. 13, 4). For the form *)aqhna= cf. ch. 10, 8.
w)/mnuon—the names are identical with those in ch. 19, with one or two variations in their order. tou\s e)k—cf. ch. 15, 3.

tau=ta ta\ de/ka e)/th—the preceding ten years, implied in e(ndeka/tou. In construction these words are accusative of extent with geno/menos, while they form a predicate to o( prw=tos po/lemos. Classen seems wrong in taking the participle here as part of the epithet, as in ch. 5, 5; ch. 34, 6. The duration of the war is an accessory idea, which is usually expressed in Greek by an appositional predicate; see note on ch. 16, 24; and iv. 48, 5, h( sta/sis pollh\ genome/nh.
dieki/noun—‘tried to upset’, only here in Attic prose; Ar. Nub. 477, diaki/nei to\n nou=n au)tou=, ‘turn inside out, examine thoroughly’.

a)/llh taraxh/—does a)/llh, in the sense of ‘fresh disturbance’, refer to previous difficulties, such as are mentioned in ch. 22; or does it mean ‘besides’ the intrigues of the Corinthians and their abettors? tw=n cumma/xwn pro/s—‘between the allies and Lacedaemon’; a variation from the more common construction with the dative, e.g.i. 17, 1, pro\s perioi/kous tou\s au)tw=n e(ka/stois: cf. note on iv. 80, 2. *lakedai/mona=*lakedaimoni/ous is unusual, to the best of my knowledge: so ch. 28, 14.

e)/stin e)n oi)=s—so e)/stin h)=|, e)/sti par' oi(=s (masc.) etc., but always ei)si\n oi(/. e)k tw=n cugkeime/nwn—so iii. 70, 3, kata\ ta\ cugkei/mena: iv. 23, 1, kaqa/per cune/keito. cu/gkeimai thus used is the perfect passive of cunti/qemai. a(\ ei)/rhto—the several items of the cugkei/mena.
e)pi\ e(\ce)/th me\n kai\ de/ka mh=nas—me/n is answered primarily by e)/peita me/ntoi, as prw=ton me/n is commonly answered by e)/peita with or without de/. The clause with e)/cwqen de/ is also a kind of secondary apodosis to the clause with me/n

mh/—following the negative idea of a)pe/sxonto: Goodwin § 807 (c). Classen collects instances from Thucydides in his note on iii. 32, 2, e)lpi/da ou)de\ th\n e)laxi/sthn ei(=xon mh/ pote . parabalei=n. met' a)nakwxh=s—meta/ is here used of attendant conditions, as in the common phrase meta\ kindu/nwn, for which see Kruger on i. 18, 7. met' e)lpi/dwn, ch. 103 fin., is somewhat similar. For the form of a)nakwxh/ see note on iv. 117, 2, and Poppo on i. 40, 4.
e)s po/lemon fanero\n kate/sthsan—so ch. 84, 17: i. 23, fin. e)s to\n polemon kate/sthsan, of the first outbreak of war.

ge/grafe—compare the opening words of the first Book, *qoukudi/dhs *)aqhnai=os cune/graye k.t.l., where the writer gives the plan and purpose of his history. Similarly in i. 97, 2, he says e)/graya de\ au)ta\...dia\ to/de. Here he is regarding the work as complete, and therefore uses the perfect; so i. 22, fin. kth=ma e)s a)ei\...cu/gkeitai: cf. ch. 22, w(/sper ge/graptai. cuggra/fw, conscribo, is the special word for the compilation of history, and from his frequent use of the word Thucydides in particular was styled o( cuggrafeu/s. kata\ qe/rh kai\ xeimw=nas—see ch. 20.

kate/labon—‘occupied’; iv. 1, 1, note. Two manuscripts have kate/balon, which agrees with Plut. Lys. 14, kabbalo/ntes to\n *peiraia= kai\ ta\ makra\ ske/lh: Xen. Hel. ii. 2, 20, ta\ makra\ tei/xh kai\ to\n *peiraia= kaqelo/ntes. Both words are historically correct, for the Lacedaemonians sailed into the Peiraeus, and continued to occupy Athens till the conditions of the peace, including the dismantling of the walls, were carried out.

kai\ th\n dia\ me/sou—‘and if any one shall think himself entitled to consider the intervening convention as anything but war, he will make a claim which is not justified by facts’. dia\ me/sou—iv. 20, 1, dia\ me/sou geno/menon: viii. 75, 1, u(po\ tw=n dia\ me/sou kwluqe/ntes: so Hdt. and Xen. a)ciw= and dikaiw=, in
the sense of thinking fit and right, differ but slightly in meaning: ou)k a)ciw= is constructed with the negative like ou)/ fhmi, as noted on iv. 40, 1.

toi=s te—apparently answered by e)/cw te tou/twn: unless indeed the latter is merely a continuation of the subordinate relative construction. I rather suspect that this is so, as all the things mentioned seem explanations of toi=s e)/rgois, and the relative clause is otherwise very curt. In this case the sentence is incomplete, unless we take the initial te ga/r as equivalent to nam etiam, as Poppo suggests. (See Jowett on i. 9, 3 for te in the sense of ‘too’.) toi=s e)/rgois—what was actually done, facts, including hostile movements.

dih/|rhtai—most editors take this to mean ‘interrupted’ lit. ‘divided’, which is no doubt the common use of the word. The perfect tense seems against this view; we should expect the imperfect or pluperfect. I therefore incline to the rendering ‘how it is characterised’, of which Poppo approves, taking diairei=n in the sense of ‘defining’. This sense is found in Herodotus ii. 6: vii. 16, 47, 50, and 103; and is common in Plato.

e)/cw—‘besides, not counting’; a usage nearly confined to Herodotus and Thucydides (Krüger on i. 9, 3). *mantiniko/n —the difficulty with Mantinea, which occupies many chapters in this Book, is first mentioned in ch. 33; the quarrel with Epidaurus in ch. 53.

e)ge/nonto—here the plural verb is naturally used, as a(marth/mata occurred on either side and on more than one occasion. But besides instances which can be thus explained Thucydides not uncommonly uses the plural with a neuter nominative of things, e.g. ch. 75, 9, *ka/rneia e)tu/gxanon o)/nta; vi. 62, 4, e)ge/nonto e)c au)tw=n ei)/kosi kai\ e(kato\n ta/lanta. In i. 126, 3, e)ph=lqon(en) *)olu/mpia: ii. 8, 2, polla\ lo/gia e)le)gonto (eto): i. 58, 1, ta\ te)lh u(pe/sxonto (eto), the best manuscripts, according to Krüger, are in favour of the plural. In viii. 10, 1, we have ta\ *)/isqmia e)gi/gneto ..e)phgge)lqhs an ga/r: where the subject of e)phgge/lqhsan is probably ta\ *)/isqmia, though many follow the scholiast in supplying ai( spondai/.
pole/mioi—as hostile to Athens as ever. Thus they opposed the restoration of Amphipolis, and refused to accept the treaty; see ch. 35.

e)kexeiri/an dexh/meron—explained as a truce which had
to be renewed every ten days, or which could be terminated on ten days notice. The word occurs in ch. 32, 19 and 32; also vi. 7, 4; vi. 10, 3.

kata\ tou\s xro/nous—ch. 20, 6, skopei/tw de/ tis kata\ tou\s xro/nous. kai\ h(me/ras—‘that is to say with a variation of but a few days’; see note on ch. 20, 4. The time is calculated from the beginning of April 431, when the Thebans attacked Plataea (ii. 2), to the middle of April 404, when Lysander sailed into the Peiraeus.

kai\ toi=s a)po/—‘and (he will find) that they who on the strength of oracles were positive on any matter found, in this, one solitary instance of the event decidedly corresponding to the prediction’ (Arnold). a)po/=‘starting from’, i.e. grounding their belief on; cf. iv. 18, 2, a)po\ tw=n a)ei\ u(parxo/ntwn: cf. ch. 17, 6. For i)sxurisame/nois with neut. acc. cf. iii. 44, 5, tou=to o)\ *kle/wn i)sxuri/zetai: vii. 49, 1, tosau=ta le/gwn i)sxu/rizeto: also with o(/ti, vi. 55, 1 etc.: with w(s and a participle iv. 68, fin.

e)xurw=s—e)xuro/s ‘secure’ is used somewhat in the sense of pisto/s. iii. 83, 1, lo/gos e)xuro/s: vii. 41, 4, th\n e)lpi/da e(xura/n ei(=xon. The positive adverb is not found elsewhere in Thucydides: in viii. 24, 4, we have e:kosmou=nto e)xurw/teron. cumba/n— Hdt. ii. 3, ei) sumbh/sontai toi=si lo/goisi toi=sin e)n *me/mfi: Ar. Eq. 220, xrhsmoi/ te sumbai/nousi kai\ to\ *puqiko/n.

ai)sqano/menos—of intelligent perception, as in i. 71, 4, pro\s a)nqrw/pwn tw=n ai)sqanome/nwn. th=| h(liki/a|—‘by reason of’; for dat. cf. ch. 13, 6. Thucydides does not speak of himself except as bearing on his history. At the beginning of his book he tells us that he had compiled materials from the first outbreak of the war (a)rca/menos eu)qu\s kaqistame/nou); here he asserts his claims as being capable of seeing and appreciating facts throughout its course. We cannot be certain about his age; but the statement is commonly accepted that he was about forty when the war began. The biography of Marcellinus only says that Thucydides died at over fifty. The question is fully discussed in Classen's introduction. ti is emphatic, as in line 32.
a)kribe/s—of exact detail, as in ch. 20, 10: 68, 5. For the indicative ei)/somai after a secondary tense see Goodwin, § 339: cf. iii. 4 fin., e)/prasson o(/pws boh/qeia h:/cei.

feu/gein—‘to be in exile from my country’, whether by banishment or voluntarily (ch. 72, 4). meta\th\n c)s *)lmfi/polin
strathgi/an—for e(s cf. ch. 7, e)s th\n *pu/lon eu)tuxh/sas. The words simply denote the attempt to relieve the place, and do not prove, as Grote supposes, that Thucydides was sent expressly to Amphipolis. See Appendix to iv. 104.

par' a)mfote)rois toi=s pra/gmasi—‘at what was done on both sides’. ou)x h(=sson = ma=llon. We do not know where Thucydides passed the time of his exile. Marcellinus says that he went first to Aegina, and then to Thrace, where, as we know (iv. 105), he had property and powerful connexions. He probably visited various places, including even Sicily, of which he shows the knowledge of an eyewitness. Most likely he returned to Athens in 403, when the amnesty was proclaimed under Thrasybulus. One account says he was assassinated in Athens, another that he died in Thasos.

ai)sqe)sqai—the present form ai/sqesqai is retained by Poppo and others here, as suiting the sense better; and Classen has ai)/sqesqai, vii. 75, 2, and proai/sqesqai, ii. 93, 4; iii. 83, 4: in each case with good manuscript authority. ai)/sqomai is a form used by late ecclesiastical writers, and the introduction of its infinitive into classical authors may be merely a copyist's error.

th/n—one article belongs to two nouns, which are closely connected in idea; so ch. 5, 1: i. 120, 2, th\n katakomidh\n kai\ pa/lin a)nti/lhyin. ta\ e)/peita may be the direct subject of w:s e)polemh/qh, which is in that case personally constructed; Poppo however (iii. 6, 2) considers such constructions, e.g. iv. 23, 2, ta\ peri\ *pu/lon e)polemei=to, as impersonal with determinant accusative: cf. ch. 52, 6.

cu/gxusin—i. 146, spondw=n cu/gxusis ta\ gigno/mena h)=n: cf. ch. 39, 18, cugxe)ai ta\s sponda/s. e)peidh\ ga/r—ga/r introduces the account which has been already promised; so ii. 2, 1, in a passage like this: compare its use after such prefaces as tekmh/rion de/, dh=lon de/ etc.

kai\ u)/steron — quasi-parenthetical, ‘followed by the alliance’, for the dissentient allies were dismissed from Sparta before the alliance was formally arranged, ch. 22, 8. Classen
follows Cobet in altering ai( cummaxi/ai into the singular, as there was only one alliance, that between Athens and Sparta, and a copyist's error might easily arise from the neighbouring plurals. In the beginning of ch. 48, however, cummaxi/ai occurs again. It is true more than two states are there concerned, but the singular had been used in reference to the same states at the end of ch. 46. The plural comes again in ch. 79, 6. Possibly the singular denotes an alliance in a general sense, while the plural refers to its several conditions, as e)/gklhma in the orators is the plaintiff's ‘declaration’, the several items of which are e)gklh/mata.

kai\ ai(—‘then also’; co-ordinate note of time; i. 50, 5, h)/dh de\ o)ye\ kai\ oi/ *kori/nqioi: Soph Phil. 354, h)=n d) h)=mar deu/teron ka)gw\ kathgo/mhn: Mk. XV. 25, h)=n w(/ra tri/th kai\ e)stau/rwsan au)to/n. It has been suggested to remove the kai/ before oi( me/n in the next sentence, making the construction with e)peidh/ continue to *lakeo=ai/monos.

e)s au)ta/—i.e. to discuss these airangements: au)to/ and au)ta/ are perpetually used by Thucydides in this general sense: so i. 1, 2, ta\ pro\ au)tw=n. a)nexw/roun—‘inceptive’ imperfect, because though they all left Sparta they did not all return home at once.
prw=ton—with e)s *)/argos trapo/menoi: cf. ch. 2, 6.

o(ra=n o(/pws—with indic. future: iii. 46, 4, o(ra=n o(/pws e(/comen: so ví. 33, 3, o(ra=te o(/tw| tro/pw| a)munei=sqe: iv. 128, fin. e)/prassen o(/tw| tro/pw| cumbh/setai: i. 65, 2, e)/prassen o(/ph| w)feli/a tis genh/setai. See Goodwin, § 339.
*suk. kathgorei= de\ ti/s; *di/l. o: boulo/menos. *suk. ou)kou=n e)kei=no/s ei)m' e)gw/, w(s ei)s e)/m' h)/kei th=s po/lews ta\ pra/gmata.

di/kas i)/sas kai\ o(moi\as di/dwsi—see the beginning of ch. 79: i. 28, 1, di/kas h)/qelon dou=nai = they were ready to submit to judgment or arbitration: i. 140, 3, di/kas tw=n diaforw=n a)llh/lois dido/nai kai\ de/xesqai.
w+ste—of conditions; ch. 17, 13 etc. e)pimaxei=n denotes a defensive alliance, as explained in ch. 48, 9. a)podei=cai—‘to name’, or appoint: Hdt. i. 125, strathgo\n a=podeiknu(nai.

a)rxh/n—accusative of respect with au)tokra/toras, ‘of independent authority’. Classen takes it in the adverbial sense ‘to begin with’, i.e. from the first; for which Thucydides elsewhere uses th\n a:rxh/n, ii. 74, 3: iv. 98, 1: vi. 4, 5: vi. 56, 1. a)rxh/n is no doubt common in Herodotus, and is found in other writers; but it seems unlikely that Thucydides would depart from his usual form in one instance only when his meaning would be rendered doubtful. It is also to be noticed that in the great majority of cases both a)rxh/n and th\n a)rxh/n are used in negative sentences.

tou= mh/—i. 4, tou= ta\s proso/dous ma=llon i)e/nai au)tw=|: Goodwin § 798. katafanei=s—especially to the Lacedaemonians. We may compare the account in iv. 22, where the Spartans refused to confer with the Athenian assembly, but were willing to meet select commissioners.

tou\s mh\ pei/santas—mh/ gives a hypothetical force, ‘in case of failure’, lit. ‘those who might have failed’. The phrase here seemingly applies to all those who were conducting the intrigue. Kruger collects similar usages of the article on iii. 81, 3, th\n ai:ti/an e)pife/rontes toi=s to\n dh=mon katalu/ousi, where the sense is equivalent to au)toi=s: cf. iv. 33, 2, kai\ oi/ u(postre/fontes h/mu/nonto: iv. 46, 3, dedio/tes mh\ tou\s e)lqo)ntas ou)k a)poktei/nwsi: see also ch. 5, 9.

oi( de/—for the order, and the position of e)peidh/, cf. iii. 5, 1, oi( d) e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n pre/sbeis w(s ou)de\n h)=lqon pra/cantes, following a clause with kai\ oi( me/n. The nominative is put first to mark the change of subject.

a)nh/negkan—‘referred’, of laying a matter before an
assembly; Hdt. i. 157, e)s qeo\n a)noi=sai (an unusual form): id. iii. 71, a)nafe/rein e)s pleu=nas. ta\s a)rxa/s—ch. 47, 59: see note on ta\ te/lh, iv. 14, 1.

poiei=sqai—‘should make’, dependent, like e)cei=nai, on the sense continued from e)yhfi/santo: so ch. 63, 17. For this use of the relative and mfinitive, which is found especially in quoting the provisions of a law, see Goodwin, § 756. mhdete/rois is governed by spei/sasqai. For a)/neu, ‘without the consent of’, cf. ch. 60, 28. iv. 78, 3, a)/neu tou= pa/ntwn koinou=. to/n te—te and kai/ connect the two main ideas of the Argives, the prospect of war and the hope of supremacy; cf. ch. 11, 11. e)p' e)co/dw|—ch. 14, 25. There and in ch. 22 we find that it was the Argives who refused to renew the truce.
e)lpi/santes—‘conceiving the hope’; note the force of the aorist: so in the next sentence kakw=s h)/kouse k.t.l ‘came into contempt’, etc. (Kruger suggests h)/koue.)

h(/ te oi(/ te—two main reasons co-ordinately stated; so i. 8, 3, e)fie/menoi tw=n kerdw=n oi(/ te h(/ssous.. oi(/ te dunatw/teroi. ma/lista dh/—dh/ emphasizes the superlative; i. 1, 2, ki/nhsis au(/th megi/sth dh/, ‘greatest of all’, not simply ‘very great’. dia\ ta\s cumfora/s—especially the surrender of Pylos, which is particularly called cumfora/, iv. 20, 2: iv. 22, 3, etc.: see ch. 75, 12.

toi=s pa=sin—‘in all points’; vii. 50, 3, toi=s pa=si xalepw/teron i)/sxonta. cunara/menoi—‘having taken part in’; iv. 10, 1: the genitive is partitive. The accusative construction is also found ii. 71, 2, cuna/rasqai ki/ndunon, ‘to join in undertaking.’ e)kkarpwsa/menoi—‘having reaped profit thereout’, i.e. from their friendly neutrality, or from the war itself, which might bring gain to a neutral state. The scholiast takes it of the enjoyment of their own crops and revenues. Thucydides does not use the word elsewhere; karpou=sqai occurs twice.
prosede/xonto—‘were ready to receive’, or ‘were to receive’ according to the arrangements made.

me/ros ti th=s *)arkadi/as—see ch. 33. kate/strapto u(ph/koon—i. 8, 3, prosepoiou=nto u(phko/ous ta\s e)la/ssous po/leis. a)/rxein—either to rule the district in question, or absolutely to hold an empire, or act like a sovereign state. The infinitive with perio/yesqe occurs i. 35, 3, and in several other passages there collected by Krüger. It differs from the participial construction (e.g. iv. 11, 3) inasmuch as that implies a present or accomplished fact, which is to be stopped or avenged, while the infinitive suggests a supposed possibility which is to be guarded against. Grote points out (ch. 55) that the conquest effected by Mantinea during the war was a violation of the principle of the Peloponnesian confederacy; and opposed to the general policy of Sparta, which was in favour of maintaining the independence of the little states, and thus ensuring her own influence as general leader. See note on ch. 31, 15.
e)peidh\ kai/—besides other considerations, they had also leisure to interfere.

w(/sper kai\ au)toi/—sc. dhmokratou=ntai, so ch. 44, 10. This is the more common construction in Greek: in Latin the rule is to follow the antecedent case. Such instances as the following are quite exceptional: Liv. xlii. 37, eodem se loco esse quo Messenii atque Eíei: Tac. Ann. xii. 7, cuncta feminae obediebant, non per lasciviam, ut Messalina, rebus Romanis illudenti: ib. xiii. 19. Plautum. pari ac Nero gradu a divo Augusto, destinavisse.

e)s qrou=n kaqi/stato—‘took to talking’; ch. 30, 1: cf. ch. 7, 8. The imperfect denotes the beginning and continuance of the qrou=s, which in the first words of the next chapter is described as prevalent (kaqestw=ta, ‘on foot, established’).

nomi/santes...kai\ e)/xontes—note variation of tense, as in ch. 28, 10. For ple/on ei)dw/s cf. vii. 49 fin. u(po/noia mh/ ti kai\ ple/on ei)dw\s o\ *niki/as i)sxuri/zhtai. The participle as usual conveys the most important idea; ch. 1, 5: cf. iv. 27, 2, e)/xonta/s ti i)sxuro\n au)tou\s e)no/mizon ou)ke/ti e)pikhrukeu/esqai, ‘they thought they must have some strong point, as’ etc.

di' o)rgh=s e)/xontes—ii. 60, 3, e)me\ di' ai)ti/as e)/xete. also
e)n o)rgh=| e)/xein: ii. 8, 3, o)rgh=| ei(=xon. a)mfoi=n toi=n—see note on ch. 23, 9.

tou=to to\ gra/mma—the wording of this clause. gra/mma in the singular is used of a short piece of writing, e.g. of the Delphian inscription gnw=qi seauto/n. The strong compound diaqorubei=n is only found here in classical Greek.

di/kaion ga\r ei)=nai—the infinitive depends on the sense of saying or thinking supplied from e)s u(pofi/an kaqi/sth. The words pa=si toi=s cumma/xois are as it were in inverted commas and are governed by dokh=|, not gegra/fqai. The sense is, ‘the wording of the (provision for) alteration ought to have been, (o(/ ti a)\n dokh=|) pa=si toi=s cumma/xois, and not a)mfoi=n toi=n pole/oin’.

w(/rmhnto—see note on ch. 1. 11. pro\s tou\s *)argei/ous is probably to be taken with cummaxi/an poiei=sqai, so also ii. 59, 1, pro\s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous w)/rmhnto cugxwrei=n. The infinitive might however be explanatory, as in i. 50, 1, pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous e)tra/ponto foneu/ein. For the ambiguity of position, which is a Thucydidean mannerism, see note on iv. 40, 2.

ai)sqo/menoi to\n qrou=n—cf. ch. 29, 12. didaska/lous genome/nous—so viii. 45, 2, dida/skalos pa/ntwn gigno/menos. Similar instances are collected by Classen on iii. 2, 3, mhnutai\ gi/gnontai toi=s *)aqhnai/ois: see also Poppo on i. 132, 5, mhnuth\s gi/gnetai.

prokatalabei_n—i. 57, 4, prokatalamba/nein tw=n po/lewn ta\s a)posta/seis: also with accusative of the person and absolutely. h)|tiw=nto—‘expostulated with them on’, with accusative. th/n te—te and kai/ couple the two main grounds of complaint, the general stirring up of disaffection and the contemplated alliance with Argos in particular. The second division of the sentence with kai/ is modified in construction after the conditional clause ei) *(argei/ois..., and has a fresh verb e)/fasan with parabh/sesqai/ te ..kai\ a)dikei=n dependent. Krüger and others take kai\ ei) *)argei/ois as corresponding to th\n e)sh/ghsin and dependent on h)|tiw=nto ‘if they should’, i.e. they deprecated the contingency of their secession to Argos. Such a use of ei) is justifiable by examples, e.g. iv. 85, 4, dusxere\s poiou/menoi ei)
mh\ e/de/casqe. But to begin afresh with parabh/sesqai/ te e)/fasan, ‘and they said they would be breaking their oaths’, seems to weaken the sentence; which appears rather to be one connected paragraph.

e)sh/ghsin—iv. 76, 2, *ptoiodw/rou e)shgoume/nou: so vi. 99, 2 etc.: vin. 48, 6 e)shghta\s tw=n kakw=n tw=| dh/mw|. e)sh/ghsis appears to be found here only in classical Greek. It is quoted from Dio Cas. in the sense of rogatio.

kai\ h)/dh a)dikei=n—‘and were already in the wrong’. ei)rhme/non—so ch. 39, 15 etc. See Goodwin § 851. The Lacedaemonians appeal to the fundamental principles of the Peloponnesian confederacy, as implied below in the ‘oaths of the allies’ and the ‘ancient oaths’.

ta\s *)aqhnai/wn sponda/s—‘the truce with Athens’. The ‘adnominal’ genitives in this chapter are worthy of note; line 12, qew=n kw/luma: line 22, cumma/xwn o(/rkous, the oaths taken by, or sworn to the allies: hne 24, qew=n pi/steis, pledges ratified by the names of gods. to\ plh=qos—‘the majority’; i. 125, to\ plh=qos e)yhfi/santo polemei=n.
o(/soi ou\d) au)toi/—‘who, like the Corinthians, had not accepted the truce’. ou)de/=‘also not’, its most usual meaning. The dissatisfied allies are named ch. 17, 21.

sfi/sin—‘for them’, i.e. to restore to them; ch. 32, 23. Sollium (*korinqi/wn po/lisma) had been taken by the Athenians in the first year of the war (ii. 30, 1); while Anactorium, a town at the mouth of the Ambracian gulf, was betrayed to them in 425 (iv. 49).
e)lassou=sqai—‘to be at a disadvantage’, have their claims and rights disregarded; ch. 34, 13 i. 77, 3, ei)/ kai\ o(pwsou=n e)lasswqw=sin: iv. 58, 2, w(s e(/kastoi/ ti e)lassou=sqai e)no/mizon.

pro/sxhma poiou/menoi—with infinitive construction, as in i. 96, 1, pru/sxhma de\ h)=n a)mu/nasqai. meta\ *potidaiatw=n— in 432; see i. 58, 1. a(/llous u(/steron—sc. koinh=|, with the rest of the allies.

e)sio/ntes—so ch. 35, 15: ch. 40, 10: noted by Kruger as an exclusively Thucydidean usage. qew=n pi/steis—Kruger quotes o)/rkoi qew=n from Xenophon, Anab. ii. 5, 7 etc. ei)rh=sqai d) o(/ti—‘the wording was’, citing part of the whole clause given in line 10.
i)e/nai e)s—=e)sie/nai, line 23: so iii. 91, 2, e)s to\ cummaxiko\n i)e/nai. to\n u(/steron cu/llogon—i.e. the next meeting to be held at Corinth.

e)poih/santo—following the sense of presbei/a; some manuscripts have the needless correction e)poih/sato. kaqa/per proei/rhto—by conference with the twelve Argive commissioners, ch. 28, 5, so infr. line 27.

*lepre/ou—this is the first mention of Lepreum in Thucydides, and it is not named again after ch. 62. It was in Triphylia, between Messenia and Elis, not far from the sea. e)pi th=| h(misei/a|—‘on condition of (receiving)’; ch. 5, 12.

kai\ katalusa/ntwn—so Classen for the manuscript reading kai\ lusa/ntwn, lu/ein po/lemon not being a phrase in use. Krüger, with two manuscripts, reads katalusa/ntwn without kai/, and gives it a hypothetical force, ‘in case they ended the war’, but Classen's reading is more consistent with Thucydidean usage.

*)hlei=oi—the subject of the genitive absolute now becomes the subject of the main verb; cf. iii. 13, 7, bohqhsa/ntwn de\ u(mw=n proqu/mws, po/lin proslh/yesqe: so iii. 112, 6: iv. 108, 1, th=s de\ gefu/ras mh\ kratou/ntwn. ou)k a)\n du/nasqai proselqei=n. A more dubious passage in i. 10, 3, is probably to be taken in the same way, o(/mws de\ ou)/te cunoikisqei)shs po/lews. ....fai/noit: a)\n u(podee/stera (sc. h( po/lis). Goodwin (§ 850) says that the intention of such irregularity is to make the participial clause more prominent, and to express its relation (time, cause etc.) with greater emphasis. This principle applies to pausame/nwn, line 13.

nemome/nois au)toi=s—‘the sovereignty of half the territory of Lepreum became vested in the Eleans, who, without disturbing the actual occupiers of the soil, imposed upon them a talent as the rent, or vectigal, to be paid to the treasury of Jupiter at Olympia; of which the Eleans had the management. Compare the conduct of the Athenians to the conquered Lesbians (iii. 50, 3); where the vectigal was not paid to the Athenian state, but to the individual Athenians to whom the state had given the ownership or sovereignty of the land. a)pofe/rein and a)pofora/ are words used peculiarly to
express the payment of rent, whether from a tenant to his landlord, or from a subject to his sovereign, or from a conquered people to their conquerors’ (Arnold).

e)/tacan—i. 19, 1, xrh/mata toi=s pa=si ta/cantes fe/rein. The middle is used of those who agree to the payment on their own part, e.g. i. 101, 4, xrh/mata taca/menoi fe/rein. e)phna/gkazon— only here in Thucydides: Hdt. viii. 130, ou)de\ e)phna/gkaze ou)dei/s. The compound, like the more common prosanagka/zw, implies compulsion to a course of action.

di/khs e)pitrapei/shs—cf. vii. 18, 3, e)s di/kas prokalou: me/n wn tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn ou)k h)/qelon e)pitre/pein. i)/son—‘their just due’; iv. 59 fin. i)/son e)/xonti. a)ne/ntes—‘throwing up’: pausa/menoi tou= e:pitre/pein th\n di/khn toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois (schol.). ‘It presently appeared that Sparta was more disposed to carry out her general system of favouring the autonomy of the lesser states, than to enforce the positive agreement of the confederacy. Accordingly the Eleians, accusing her of unjust bias, renounced her authority as arbitrator’ (Grote).

de/zasqai—of receiving disaffected allies, i. 40, 4, tou\s e(te/rwn a)fistame/nous de/xesqai (other instances in the same chapter): so iv. 75, 1, tou\s e)cio/ntas e)de/xonto, which is sometimes wrongly taken of ‘withstanding assailants’.

th\n cunqh/khn—this covenant is not mentioned elsewhere; but it would seem to be a bond entered into at the beginning of the war by the several states of the Peloponnesian confederacy. Grote (ch. 55) has an interesting note. He takes the view that subordinate states had been exempt while the war lasted from tribute to the imperial cities, in virtue of their military service for the general cause. ‘But the confederacy at the same time gave its guarantee that the imperial state should re-enter upon these suspended rights, so soon as the war should be at an end’. This view may be right, but it can scarcely be drawn from the present passage, which seems rather to mean that Lepreum made the war an excuse for evading a legitimate payment, and the Eleans claimed their rights as soon as their hands were free. But at the same time profasis can undoubtedly be used of a real ground or occasion, e. g. vi. 6, 1, th=| a)lhqesta/th| profa/sei.
tines—i.e. all persons concerned; i. 40, 5, tou\s cumma/xous au)to/n tina kola/zein.

to\ au)to\ le/gontes—‘holding the same language’, i.e. acting in concert; iv. 20, fin. h(mw=n kai\ u(mw=n tau)ta\ lego/ntwn:
‘their aristocratical forms of government, and their common hatred of Athens, as well as their neighbourhood to each other, tending to draw them together’ (Arnold): cf. ch. 38, 7, to\ ga\r au)to\ e)poi/oun, of the same states. Classen and others take the words to mean ‘(though) holding the same views’ as the Corinthians and other actual seceders, but this rendering seems not to agree with the sense of the passage and would require o(/mws or the like.

periorw/menoi—probably ‘looking about them’, i.e. waiting the event and not committing themselves to either side. In all other passages where periora=sqai occurs in Thucydides it is in the middle voice. It is used (1) standing alone, vi. 93, 1, me/llontes e)/ti kai\ periorw/menoi vi. 103, 2, pro/teron periewrw=nto: vii. 33, 2, pro/teron periorw/menoi: (2) with a dependent clause, iv. 73, 1, periorwme/nous o(pote/rwn h( ni/kh e)/stai: (3) with a case, ii. 43, 4, mh\ periora=sqe tou\s polemikou\s kindu/nous, where the meaning is open to question, but is probably ‘regard anxiously’, ‘weigh too nicely’ (Jowett): iv. 124, 4, *me/ndhs periorw/menos, ‘anxious about’. These are all the instances of the word, to which may be added a rare use of the active aorist, iv. 71, 1, to\ me/llon periidei=n, the aorist middle not being in use. In the present passage a difficulty is caused by the following words, u(po\ tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn, which are found in all MSS. If they be genuine, and periorw/menoi is to retain its usual meaning, they must be taken with h(su/xazon periorw/menoi in the sense ‘by reason of Lacedaemonian influence’. Such a construction though harsh is not impossible. Otherwise, periorw/menoi must be regarded as a passive. If this view be admissible, ‘jealously watched’ (Jowett), ‘treated with honour and consideration’, gives the best sense, and corresponds to the use of the middle in iv. 124, 4. Grote's rendering ‘being left to themselves’, i.e. not appealed to, as the Corinthians were (ch. 30), does not correspond to the use of the word in the active, which in the sense of overlooking requires a participle or the like expressed or implied. And the once accepted rendering ‘despised’, or ‘feeling themselves slighted’, is equally inconsistent with classical usage, besides which it is doubtful as a statement of fact and necessitates giving a harsh, though possible, adversative meaning to kai/= ‘and yet thinking’. Classen follows Dobree in omitting the words u(po\ tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn, as an explanatory gloss of the supposed passive construction; while Haase's conjecture is very tempting, ta\ a)po\ tw=n, ‘waiting to see what course the Lacedaemonians took’.

au)toi=s—referring to both states. An oligarchical
revolution had been effected at Megara in 424 (iv. 74). politei/as—form of government; i. 18, 1: ii. 37, 1: in both cases with xrh=sqai.

*skiwnai/ous—ch. 2, 6. a)pe/kteinan—see iv. 122 fin. yh/fisma e)poih/santo *skiwnaious e)celei=n te kai\ a)poktei=nai. Classen points out that Brasidas is said to have removed the women and children from Scione and Mende to Olynthus (iv. 123, 4). The removal must have been incomplete. Similarly it is said of the Spartans at Plataea, in 427, gunai=kas h)ndrapo/disan (iii. 68, 3), though the women and children were removed by the Athenians in 431 (ii. 6 fin.). In the case of Plataea the women were probably the 110 gunai=kes sitopoioi/ (ii. 78, 3) who remained in the city. The absence of the article proves nothing, as it is regularly omitted in these phrases.
*plataieu=sin—some Plataeans (oi( a)xreio/tatoi) had been removed to Athens in 431 (ii. 6), while 212 cut their way out in 428 (iii. 28, 2).

*dhli/ous de/—see ch. 1. This statement agrees with Arnold's note, there cited, as to the anxiety of the Athenians to propitiate Apollo. e)nqumou/menoi—i. 42, 1, w(=n e)nqumhqe/ntes: i. 120, 6: see note on e)nqumi/an ch. 16, 22. In meaning the force of the word extends to the end of the sentence. Two considerations determined the Athenians, which are connected by te and kai/ with the usual variation of construction. tou= qeou= xrh/santos is genitive absolute.

kai\ *fwkh=s—nothing more is said of this war. me/ga me/ros—lit. ‘a considerable fraction’ (of the Peloponnesian powers): so ii. 20, 3, oi( *)axarnh=s me/ga me/ros o)/ntes th=s po/lews. Tegea was of importance, being an independent state on the borders of Laconia. For the attraction of the participle o)/n cf. Plat. Protag. 354 c, th
 h(donh
 diw/kete w(s a)gaqo
 o)/n, where Wayte cites numerous instances.

a)nei=san th=s—‘slackened in’, partitive genitive; vii. 43, 7, a)ne/ntwn th=s e)fo/dou: Dem. etc.: so i. 112, 1, pole/mou e)/sxon oi( *)aqhnai=oi: viii. 31, 1, tou/tou e)pe/sxen, Compare the twofold use of meqi/hmi.
e)s tou)s *boiwtou/s—‘into Boeotia’; ch. 33, 4: iv. 108, 5, e)n toi=s *boiwtoi=s peplhgme/nwn.

e)pisponda:s—only found here. It appears to mean a subsequent or renewed truce; cf. ch. 22, 11, e)pispe/ndesqai. The same truce is called dexh/meroi spondai/ in line 29, and e)kexeiri/a here and ch. 26, 16.

kai\ sfi/si poih=sai—‘to effect, or obtain it for them too’, not=poiei=sqai. a)peipei=n—ch. 43, 13. a)/neu au)tw=n— au(tw=n refers to the primary subject oi( *kori/nqioi: cf. ch. 40, 14, au(toi=s: and see note on iv. 50, 2; and Poppo on i. 17.

e)pisxei=n—viii. 5, 2, *eu(boi/as me\n pe/ri e)pisxei=n: also absolutely, and as transitive, ch. 63, 15: iv. 5, 1. o( strato\s e)/ti e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais w)\n e)pe/sxen. eu)/ronto—of obtaining what one desires: i. 31, 2, w(feli/an tina\ eu(ri/skesqai.

ei)=nai sponda/s—see ch. 18, where the peace is made between Athens and Sparta and their respective allies. We see from ch. 36, 6, that the Corinthians and Boeotians still stood in the position of Lacedaemonian allies. a)ciou/ntwn .. sfi/sin—‘though the Corinthians called on them to do so, and said in expostulation that they had so covenanted with them’.

a)nakwxh\ a)/spondos—‘cf. i. 40, 4, *korinqi/ois me/n ge e)/nspondoi/ e)ste, *kerkurai/ois de\ ou)de\ di' a)nakwxh=s pw/pot' e)ge/nesqe. By a)/spondos is meant a mere agreement in words, not ratified by the solemnities of religion. And the Greeks considered the breach of their word very different from the breach of their oath. See ii. 5, 7, where the Plataeans maintain that they never swore to the Thebans not to injure them’ (Arnold). Grote however considers that the words only mean a simple absence of hostilities de facto, not arising out of any recognized pledge; so i. 66; cf. ch. 25, 14: ch. 26, 18. a)nakwxh/ is the form which is invariably found in the manuscripts; anokwxh/ however, which Classen reads, is in accordance with analogy and derivation. See note on iv. 117, 2.

th=s *)arkadi/as—in this construction, as Kruger points out, the genitive, which commonly stands first, has the article, while the word on which it depends is usually without; iii. 19, 2, th=s *kari/as e)k *muou=ntos a)naba/s. For e)s *parrasi/ous, cf. ch. 32, 17, e)s *boiwtou/s. The Parrhasians, an original Arcadian race, occupied a district south-east of mount Lycaeus.
e)pikalesame/nwn—sc. tw=n *parrasi/wn: see note on iv. 73, 3, w(/sper h(sshqe/ntwn. Similarly in ch. 31, 13, we have pausame/nwn, where the accusative might have been expected.

to\ e)n *kuye/lois tei=xos—viii. 20, 2, to\ e)n th=| *te/w| tei=xos. Cypsela appears to have been a town in the level country, on the Alpheus. a)nairh/sontes—so ch. 77, 7. kaqairei=n, to dismantle or pull down, is much more common in this connexion. e)pi\ th=| *skiri/tidi—e)pi/, ‘to command or annoy’; so ch. 51, 5. cf. ch. 7, 20. Sciritis was a mountain district in the north of Laconia.

th
 po/lin—their own city. th
 cummaxi/an—‘the territory of their allies’; iv. 118, 3, e)pimisgome/nous e)s th
 cummaxi/an. Parrhasia seems meant, or possibly the district which the Mantmeans had conquered, see ch. 29.

tw=n a)po/—attractional, and referring to h(ko/ntwn, as e)celqo/ntwn denotes the expedition to Thrace. Poppo compares ch. 65, 17, tou\s a)po\ tou= lo/fou, also ii. 80, 1, tw=n a)po\ qala/sshs, and a similar construction with e)k in ii. 83, 1. Krüger's suggested transposition, a)po\ *qra/|khs tw=n, is therefore not necessary. For the military use of e)celqei=n cf. ch. 8, 8. ch. 54, 12.

ou(\s o( *kleari/das—in accordance with his instructions, as given at the end of ch. 21. The Lacedaemonians seem now to have evacuated Amphipolis, which remained in the hands of the Chalcidians. We read of an unsuccessful attempt on the part of the Athenians to recover it in 414 (vii. 9).

tou\s me)n—answered by tou\s d) in line 10, but in conscquence of the intervening paragraphs the construction with e)yhfi/santo is dropped, and a fresh verb brought in. For the position of the participle maxesame/nous see note on iv. 5, 2. and compare such passages as i. 11, 2, tou= dia\ tou\s poihta\s lo/gou katesxhko/tos.

oi)kei=n o)/pou a)\n bou/lwntai—‘the Helots, like the villains of the middle ages, were glebae adstricti, and not allowed to leave the spot which was allotted to them. Thus the per
mitting them “to live where they liked” was an essential part of their emancipation’ (Arnold).

u(/steron ou) pollw=|—so i. 18, 2: i. 137, 1 etc. tw=n neodamwdw=n—according to Muller these were probably free Helots of some standing, or the sons of enfranchised serfs; see Arnold. This is the first time that they are mentioned as employed in military service; see also ch. 67, 5. In vii. 58, 3, we find that the Lacedaemonian force which Gylippus took to Syracuse consisted of Neodamodes and Helots; where Thucydides adds the explanation du/natai de\ to\ neodamw=des e)leu/qeron h)/dh ei)=nai.

e)s *le/preon—see ch. 31, 20. e)pi\ th=s—‘in the direction of’, as in ta\ e)pi\ *qra/|khs. tou\s d) e)k th=s nh/sou—oi( e)k th=s nh/sou is the regular expression for these captives. Here, with the addition of lhfqe/ntas, it is a pregnant phrase, as noted on line 1.

dei/santes k.t.l—‘fearing lest they might suppose that their misfortune would stand in their way, and if they possessed their full rights they might attempt some revolutionary design’. ti is probably to be taken with newteri/swsin. Both nomi/santes and o)/ntes e)pi/timoi seem to have a hypothetical force, otherwise there is some awkwardness in the connecting kai/. For th\n cumfora/n, meaning the surrender at Pylos, see note on ch. 28, 15: cf. iv. 17, 1, e)s th\n cumfora/n: iv. 20, 2, cumfora=s metri/ws katatiqeme/nhs. e)lasswqh/sesqai—ch. 30, 18.

tina/s—‘in some cases’; in partial apposition to tou\s lhfqe/ntas: cf. ch. 96, 3, a)posta/ntes tine/s. a)timi/an is a cognate accusative carrying on the idea of the words before; see note on doulei/an ch. 9, 42.

mh/te a)/rxein k.t.l —‘that is, they deprived them of their eligibility to offices, and reduced them in civil contracts to the condition of sojourners or foreigners, who could neither hold property, nor sue or be sued in their own name’ (Arnold).
u(/steron xro/nw|—so i. 8 fin. etc.: with xro/nois Dem. etc. ‘ages after’.

e)n th=| *)/aqw|—elsewhere *)/aqws is masculine as in ch. 3, 30: iv. 109, 2 A few manuscripts here have tw=| It has been suggested that h( *)/aqws denotes the region as opposed to the mountain. The reading of the whole passage is however uncertain, as a difficulty is caused by the word *diktidih=s. The Dictidians are unknown, and there may be a corruption in the name. In ch. 82, 1, the true reading *dih=s is in some copies corrupted into *diktidih=s. Dium is mentioned in iv. 109, 3 as a town in the peninsula of Athos. Accordingly here editors have adopted th
 e)n th=| *)/aqw| *dih=s, th
 e)n th=| *)/aqw| *)akth=| *dih=s, or th
 e)n th=| *)aqw/a| *)akth=| *dih=s. Poppo points out that Thucydides simply calls the peninsula *)akth/ (iv. 109, 3); while moreover Dium was friendly to the Athenians till 417, when it revolted to the Chalcidians (ch. 82). He therefore proposes instead of *diktidih=s to read *xalkidh=s or oi( *xalkidh=s. The Chalcidians would no doubt be hostile to Thyssus; there may however have been a private quarrel between Thyssus and Dium.

e)pimici/ai—of reciprocal intercourse: cf. i. 2, 2, ou)d) e)pimignu/ntes a)dew=s a)llh/lois: see note on e)/fodoi line 40. u(pw/pteuon —so viii. 39, 2, u(pw/pteuon au)to/n. Kruger notes (iv. 51) that the construction with a simple accusative is rare in Attic writers.

th
. .ou)k a)po/dosin—cf. ch. 50, 19: so i. 137, 7, th
 tw=n gefurw=n ou) dia/lusin: iii. 95, 2, th
 ou) peritei/xisin. It is a peculiarity of Thucydides, though occasionally found in other writers. Here a)llh/lois is added to the verbal substantive.

th\n ga\r *)amfi/polin—the restoration of Amphipolis was the main point, accordingly its name stands prominently in the sentence. The a)/lla xwri/a are those specified in ch. 18, 22 sq. and also Panactum. pro/teroi laxo/ntes—ch. 21, 1.

parei=xon—note the change of tense. pare/xw takes the same construction with an adjective in ii. 84, 3, toi=s kubernh/tais a)peiqeste/ras ta\s nau=s parei=xon, and in other passages. le/gontes a)ei/—‘though they continued to declare’.

xro/nous de\ prou)/qento—apparently ‘proposed certain dates’, xro/noi being plural because stipulations affecting dif
ferent states were proposed. The scholiast explains prou)/qento by e)/tacan: but the middle means ‘to put forward on one's own part’; cf. Eur. Iph. T. 1225, ta\ a)/lla o(/sa prou)qe/mhn, i. e. ‘ordered’.

cuggrafh=s—‘a bond’ or written agreement. They would only commit themselves to a verbal arrangement. xrh=n—i.e. according to the Spartan proposal. The imperfect is accommodated to the past tense of prou)/qento, cf. ii. 51, 3, ou)de\ e(\n kate/sth i)/ama o(/ ti xrh=n prosfe/rontas w)felei=n; and see note on iv. 29, fin. h(=| xrh=n e)pibohqei=n.

u(peto/peuon—the same form occurs in viii. 76, 1: u(potopei=n ii. 5, 3, etc. u(popteu/w is the general word in Attic prose, as in ch. 35. 6. ou)/te *pu/lon—answered by ta/ te a)/lla, the clause with a)lla\ kai/ being parenthetical.
poih/seian—‘should have done’, corresponding to e(/ws a)\n poih/swsi with a primary tense. o)/ntas—order as in ch. 34, 6.

kai\ ei)/ tou a)/llou—‘and (had done) everything else in their power’, rather than ‘had recalled their men from any other place in their hands’. For ei)/ tis cf. ch. 37, 13; so iv. 26, 5, e)sa/gein s<*>ton <*>kai\ ei)/ ti a)/llo brw=ma.

a)polabei=n—‘get back’, in order to restore to Athens: cf. ch. 30, 17. komiei=n in the line below probably depends on e)/fasan: Kruger however connects it with peira/sesqai, referring to i. 27, 2, e)deh/qhsan cumprope/myein, where he cites many similar instances of the future infinitive.
*messhni/ous—from Naupactus; see iv. 41. Note the use of the articles here and in line 37.

w(/ste—see note on ch. 16, 26. tou\s a)/llous—a)/llos= ‘besides’. It seems possible that some of the peri/oikoi as well as of the Helots might have deserted to Pylos. No such desertion is however mentioned, but only that of the Helots; see ch. 14, 20; and iv. 41, 3. The following words te kai/ are therefore bracketed by some editors, while Classen brackets te only. Stahl would omit *ei(/lwtas as well as te kai/.

e)n *krani/ois—one of the four cities of Cephallenia, ii. 31 fin. e)/fodoi—of mutual intercourse; i. 6, 1, dia\ ta\s ou)k a)sfalei=s par' a)llh/lous e)fo/dous: cf. e)pimici/a, e)pimi/gnumi: and see Barton and Chavasse on e)ph/rxonto, iv. 120, 1.

spondai=s—speaking generally. Some manuscripts have tai=s spondai=s, which is read by Classen. cummaxi/dos—ch. 110 fin.: i. 110, 4, e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n kai\ th=s a)/llhs cummaxi/dos. Also as fem. adj. i. 98, 2, etc. *)aqhnai/wn k.t.l.—the Athenians were newly allied with Sparta. The Corinthians, though the prime movers of the intrigues against Sparta, were not in open hostility.

ou)de/n—Kruger compares ii. 5, 4, h)/n ti cumbai/nwsi: so iv. 41, 1, me/xri ou(= ti cumbw=si. We have similar neuter accusatives with pei/qw and such words. ou(=toi oi(/per—so Hdt. viii. 124: vii. 170, ou(=tos o/sper. tau)ta/—sc. a)llh/lois, ‘to act in close concert with each other, instead of disputing as they had done: see ch. 32 fin.’ (Arnold). This is better than rendering ‘to maintain the same policy as heretofore’, i.e. to hold aloof still from alliance with Athens.
lo/gous poiou=ntai i)di/ous—‘confer privately’ or ‘separately’; cf. ch. 37, 8, e)s lo/gous h)=lqon.

*boiwtou/s—subject of peira=sqai. After the appositional clause with au)tou/s, meta\ *boiwtw=n is written instead of meq) e(autw=n to avoid any possible misunderstanding. The sentence is thus made laboured and clumsy, as in ch. 32 § 4. Jowett compares the repetition of *)aqhnai/ois in ch. 18, 34. Ullrich suggests meta\ *korinqi/wn for meta\ *boiwtw=n.

h(/kist' a)/n—this reading, instead of h(/kista, is adopted by all modern editors. They also assume that the force of a)/n extends to the following e(le/sqai. Kuhner gives examples of similar construction from Xenophon in his note on Anab. i. 6, 2. In the present passage it seems simpler to take e(le/sqai as a positive statement, ‘the Lacedaemonians chose’. 18 pro) th=s—there is a confusion of thought, or rather of expression, in this sentence. The meaning is that the Spartans attached more importance to gaining the friendship of Argos than to incurring the enmity of Athens. The two contingencies are put as it were in opposite scales. So pro/, ‘in preference to’, is really equivalent to ‘at the price of’. Again we may say that, as in Greek a negative is repeated in a negative clause, so here *)aqhnai/wn e)/xqras is written, instead of fili/as, with a proleptic force. Two somewhat similar instances of a/nti/, implying exchange, are quoted from Aristotle: Rhet. ii. 23, 19, o(/te me
 ga to\
me/nein a)nti\ tou= ma/xesqai h(|rou=nto, o(/te de\ to\ mh\ ma/xesqai a)nti\ tou= mh\ me/nein, ‘at one time they preferred staying at the price of fighting, at another not fighting at the expense of not staying’ (Cope): Eth. Nic. iii. 1, 7, o(/tan ai)sxro/n ti h)\ luphro
 u(pome/nwsi a(nti\ mega/lwn kai\ kalw=n, where a)nti/ means ‘when weighed against the prospect of’. See also Liddell and Scott a)nti/, ii. 2. Classen takes pro/ to mean ‘before they became openly hostile to Athens’, comparing iii. 59, 3, ei(lo/meqa ga a)
 pro/ ge tou/tou: but there too preference of choice seems implied rather than priority of time.

kalw=s—‘on fair and bonourable terms’, or, according to Stahl,=opportune, ‘under favourable conditions’, as in ch. 65, 28: i. 124, 1; cf. pa/ntws, ch. 41, 22. ka)/llws and kai\ a)llws, ‘at all events’, are suggested emendations. h(gou/menoi —Classen adopts the alteration into h\goume/nous: otherwise either (1) the Ephors are identified with the government generally; see ch. 37, 9, sfi/si: or (2) the actual construction is disregarded, and h(gou/menoi written as if e)pequ/moun oi( *lakedaimo/nioi had gone before. The latter view seems too harsh to be possible; and cannot be supported on the analogy of such passages as iv. 52, 3, h)=n au)tw=n h( dia/noia...kratuna/menoi: for there the subject of the sentence is the same in sense though not in actual construction. r(a/|w r(a=|on—cf. ch. 37, 11, r(a|diws.

e)de/onto *boiwtou/s—if the text be sound, we must adopt the accepted explanation, ‘they asked (the envoys) as regards the Boeotians’,=e)de/onto o(/pws *boiwtoi/, for de/omai governs the genitive of the person to whom request is made. See iii. 51, 2, for an accusative supplying the subject to a clause with o(/pws. Krüger suggests h)|tou=nto, for which Classen would prefer e)ph/gonto (ch. 41, 12). But even thus the following future with o(/pws is an awkward and scarcely admissible construction, and it seems as if an infinitive had dropped out dependent on e)de/onto and governing *boiwtou/s. Classen suspects the genuineness of the whole sentence, which he thinks may be a clumsy adaptation of ch. 39, 9.

tau)ta\ <*>pestalme/noi—the dative ‘remotioris obiecti’ which would follow the active verb becomes the subject of the passive participle, while the accusative of the direct object is joined with it; so i. 126, 6, oi( e)pitetramme/noi th\n fulakh/n.
Here the accusative is further connected with the following w(/ste a)paggei=lai. a)po/—‘on the part of’.

e)pi\ ta\ koina/—‘to their respective communities’ or ‘governments’, each of which was a koino/n (i. 89, 3 etc.). This is the plural of a collective singular; so nautika/, ‘fleets’: cf. iii. 82 fin. ta\ me/sa tw=n politw=n, the moderate or intermediate party (to\ me/son) in the several states: Ar. Eth. Nic. iii. 8, 9, ta\ politika\ me/nonta a)poqnh/skei, ‘armies (not, an army) of citizens stand their ground to the death’.

th=s a)rxh=s th=s megi/sths—possibly the a)rtu=nai mentioned in ch. 47, 61. sfi/si=‘with us’ i.e. the Argive nation. After toutou proxwrh/santos the subject expands still further, polemei=n k.t.l. referring to the entire body of proposed allies. an is to be taken with these last infinitives.
w(/sper *kori/nqioi k t.l.—see ch. 31, 28. The Mantineans had been the first to join the league, ch. 29, 1. h)/dh= iam, when this point was reached, or this advantage secured.

koinw=| lo/gw| xrwme/nous—acting and treating in common; so iv. 64, 3, of mutual conference. ei)/ tina=‘any whatever’; i. 14, 3, *)aqhnai=oi kai\ ei)/ tines a)/lloi: cf. ch. 35, 26. tou/twn w(=nper—i.e. a(/per, with e)pesta/lkesan au)toi=s. The fi/loi are Xenares and his adherents.

boiwta/rxais—see iv. 91, 1. h)re/skonto—ch. 4, 13. e)s ta\ o(moi=a speu/dein—Classen quotes Xen. Cyr. i. 3, 4, ei)s to\ au)to\ h(m<*>n speu/dete: elsewhere Thucydides uses speu/dein without a preposition, as in ch. 16, 9. ta\ ei)rhme/na prokalou/menoi—‘with the stipulated proposals’; ii. 74, 2, prokalesa/menoi polla/.

e)do/kei—not e(/doce, for they did not carry their resolution. toi=s a)po\ *qra/|khs—the Chalcidians, ch. 31, 29. e)n tw=| paratuxo/nti—iii. 82, 7: i. 122, 1, pro\s to\ paratugxa/non. tw=| deome/nw|—used generically, like the well-known phrase o( boulo/menos (ch. 28, 6). We find other instances of the generic singular, e. g. iv. 92, 5, to\n me\n h)suxa/zonta...e)pistrateu/ein.

gnw/mhs—‘resolution’ or ‘decision’. ou(/tws=after this;
iii. 96, 2, ta)=lla katastreya/menos ou(/tws .strateu=sai: for h)/dh see ch. 37, 11. to\ au)to\ e)poiou=n—ch. 31, 30, to\ au)to\ le/gontes.

tai=s te/ssarsi boulai=s—not mentioned elsewhere; nothing seems known about them. e)p) w)feli/a|—mutui au<*>il<*> gratia (Poppo); see i. 3, 2, e)pagome/nwn au)tou\s e)p) w)felei/a|. The manuscripts always vary between w\felia and w(fe/leia. The latter, according to Liddell and Scott, is the usual prose form; but Bekker reads w)feli/a throughout Thucydides.
e)kei/nwn—note the use of this pronoun to denote the Lacedaemonians, though they have just been mentioned. See note on iv. 37, 2: also Shilleto on i. 132, 3.

meta\ tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn—Classen follows Stahl in reading met' au)tw=n for meta\ tw=n, understanding cumma/xous with gi/gnesqai. This agrees exactly with ch. 36, 14. Otherwise either (1) meta\ tw=n g<*>gnesqai means ‘to join Sparta’, as in iv. 125, 1, oi( *)illurioi\ met' *)arribai/ou gege/nhntai (Krüger): or (2), supplying cumma/xous, the sense is ‘afterwards to become their allies in company with the Lacedaemonians, i. e. afterwards to form an alliance with the Lacedaemonians as well, in which the Argives and Corinthians would be included’ (Jowett).

sfi/si—the natural construction is to take this as dependent on parainou=sin. The sense then necessitates referring it to the membeis of the four councils, the subject of yhfiei=sqai, while prodiagno/ntes refers to the Boeotarchs, the mam subject of the sentence. There is considerable awkwardness in this; and the difficulty is not removed by comparing such passages as e.g. i. 20, 1, oi( ga\r a)/nqrwpoi ta\s a)koa\s tw=n progegenhme/nwn, kai\ h)\n e)pixw/ria sfi/sin h)=|,...de/xontai: iv. 113, 3, kate/fugon e)s au)tou(s o)/soi h(=san sfi/si e)pith/deioi. For in such passages, though sfi/sin does not refer to the grammatical subject of the relative clause, it does refer to the general subject of the sentence, which is not the case here. It is just possible to take sf<*>si with prodiagno/ntes, ‘for themselves’ or ‘for their own nation’=‘for us’. Goller's conjecture e)n sfi/si is however very tempting, and better than Bekker's sfei=s.

a)nte/sth to\ pra=gma—so ch. 4, 26. ei) tau=ta e)/peisan— the aorist indicative, as Classen points out, implies ‘an unfulfilled condition’. They had been intending to promote the alliance with Argos, (and they would have made the attempt) if they had not failed to persuade the councils.
ou)ke/ti—i.e. the gave up the idea. e)sh/negkan—so viii. 67, 1, with gnw/mhn: Hdt. iii. 81 etc. e)/pempon—lit. ‘went on to send’, that is they gave up their intention. diatribh/— cf. ch. 82, 20.

*mhku/bernan—see ch. 18, 34, where the Athenians stipulate for its independence. It was 20 stadia from Olynthus, on the gulf of Torone. Strabo calls it the arsenal (e)pi/neion) of Olynthus. *)aqhnai/wn frourou/ntwn—i. 89, 2, *shsto\n e)polio/rkoun *mh:dwn e)xo(ntwn, where Krüger collects instances of this frequent use of the genitive absolute.

komi/sasqai—‘recover’; ch. 15, 4 etc. h)=lqon...presbeuo(menoi—so i. 31, 3. It is a regular phrase=pre)sbeis e)/pemyan. ei)rhme/non—‘this provision is not found either in the treaty or the alliance, but it may be understood, as Bishop Thirlwall remarks, in the last clause of the latter (ch. 23), or in the provision that neither party should conclude a war without the consent of the other (ib. l. 9 and 16). Or it may have formed part of a separate agreement, which Thucydides has not given’ (Jowett). For the accusative absolute see note on iv. 17, 2; and Goodwin § 851.

paralabei=n—i.e. in order to transfer to Athens, the regular use of this word; the converse of which is paradido/nai. a)polamba/nein and a)podido/nai are generally used of restoration without a third party intervening, but this is not an invariable rule, see ch. 30, 17: ch. 42, 7.

cugxe/ai—only here in Thucydides; spondw=n cu/gxusis, ch. 26, 33: i. 146, fin.: Dem. Timocr. 729 (91), o(/lhn cugxei= th\n politei/an: Verg. Aen. v. 496, confundere foedus. prouqumoume/nwn—with accusative; cf. ch. 17, 7. ta\ e)s *boiwtou/s—‘the arrangements with Boeotia’; ch. 46, 6, ta\ pro\s *)argei/ous.
tou= xeimw=nos k.t.l.—cf. ch. 56, 19: iv. 135, 1. kaqh|rei=to—the Boeotians at once began to dismantle the fortress; see ch. 42, 8.

a(/ma...qe/rous—so iv. 117, 1, a(/ma h)=ri tou= e)pigignome/nou qe/rous: vi. 8, 1, tou= d) e/pigignome/nou qe/rous a:/ma h)=ri: xeimw/n and qe/ros being the half-yearly periods by which Thucydides reckons.

ou)x h(=kon—this is Krüger's conjecture for the MSS. reading i(/konto. One manuscript has h:)konto, which seems a confusion with the following to/. The uncompounded i(kne/omai does not occur in prose except sometimes in the participle; i. 99, 3, to\ i(knou/menon a)na/lwma: Hdt. vi. 84, ma=llon tou= i/kneome/nou: id. vi. 65, i:kneume/nws: Dem. Macart. 1072 § 66 (in an oracle).

kaqairou/menon—imperfect, as at the end of ch. 39. toi=s *boiwtoi=s pro/s—‘between the Boeotians and Lacedaemonians’: see note on iv. 80, 2. e)s *lakedaimoni/ous...xwrh/sh|—pro/s is more usual, as in ch. 22, 14: e)s, according to Classen, suggests the central position and centralising influence of Sparta. It may be so; on the other hand Thucydides uses e)s more loosely than any preposition to denote relation of every kind: see ch. 41, 6: and the note on ch. 39, 19.

w(/ste ou)de\...ei)=nai—the infinitive does not depend on w)/ste, but is due to the oratio obliqua with w)/|onto, the negative of oratio recta (w(/ste ou)de\...e)/sti) being retained. Otherwise w(/ste takes mh/ with the infinitive. In viii. 76, 7 we have an exact parallel to the present passage, w)/ste ou)de\ tou/tous para\ sfi/si xei/rous ei)=nai (in oratio obliqua). The usage is fully discussed and illustrated in the appendix to Shilleto's Falsa Legatio. For ei)=nai=parei=nai, see note on iv. 8, 5.
e)k tw=n diaforw=n—between Athens and Sparta. The Argives supposed that these differences were now at an end. au)toi=s—i.e. sfi/si: see note on ch. 32, 26.

ai( pro\s *lakedaimoni/ous...spondai/—see the end of ch. 14, etc. a)porou=ntes tau=ta—vii. 48, 5, ta\ me
 a)porei=n: Hdt. iv. 179, a)pore/onti th
 e)cagwgh/n. e)n fronh/mati o)/ntes—‘proudly hoping’, elatis animis sperantes (Poppo): cf. iii. 83, 4, katafronou=ntes ka)
 proaisqe/sqai: iv. 80, 3, u\po\ fronh/matos, ‘from their high spirit’.

h(gou/menoi...kra/tista—it is open to doubt whether kra/tista is to be taken (1) as an adjective with h(gou/menoi, ‘thinking it the best course’, or (2) adverbially with sponda\s
poihsa/menoi, ‘on the best terms admissible’. In the latter case h(gou/menoi is used, as in ii. 42, 4 (a very important passage), in the sense ‘aequum censendi’: cf. Plat. Protag. 346 B, *simwni/dhs h(gh/sato tu/rannon e)paine/sai: and see note on nomi/zw, iv. 117, 1. (1) seems decidedly simpler.
