In i. 85, 3 kra/tista is certainly an adjective; and such neuter plurals (e.g. dunata/) are not uncommon; while a)/pora nomi/zontes (iii. 16, 2) is almost an exact parallel.

o(/ph| a)\n cugxwrh=|—‘on whatever terms might be agreed on’. cugxwrei=n, to accede or agree, does not seem to be elsewhere used impersonally, except in a var lect. from Xenophon, given by Liddell and Scott. If the reading be right, it is to be explained on the analogy of e)gxwrei=, which is common; unless indeed ta\ paro/nta can be understood as the subject. If the impersonal usage were established, it would be convenient to take sugxwrh=sai, Plat. Phaedr. 263 C, in this way.

a)fiko/menoi au)tw=n—for the order of the words, see note on ch. 10, 49, custrafe/ntes. e)f) w(=| a)/n—this use of the relative for o(/tw| is not uncommon, especially in affirmative statements; see Poppo and Krüger on i. 136, 3, dhloi= o(/s e)sti: i. 137, 2, fra/zei o(/stis e)sti\ kai\ di) a)\ feu/gei: viii. 50, 5, gra/yas w)=| a)\n tro/pw| au)ta\ pra/ceie. a)/n of course goes with the verb, not with w)=|: cf. vii. 36, 3, e)c w(=n a)\n a)/nqrwpoi deinoi\...dra/seian.

e)pitroph/n—cf. ch. 31, 15, di/khs e)pitrapei/shs. sfi/si gene/sqai—Krüger considers sfi/si as perhaps an interpolation from two lines above; but it emphasizes the anxiety of the Argives ‘to be allowed to refer the question to arbitration’. ‘This did take place at a later period, and the result was, that Thyrea was awarded to the Argives, and retained by them down to the time of Pausanias’ (Arnold).

*kunosouri/as—*kunouri/as is also read, as in iv. 56, 2, where see the note. h(=s a)ei\ pe/ri—Classen, on i. 18, 3, e)s to/nde a)ei\ to\n po/lemon, gives other instances of this position of a)ei/. meqori/as—the *qurea=tis gh= is similarly described in ii. 27, 2; where Krüger also notes that adjectives compounded from o(/ros have often three terminations.

memnh=sqai—mentionem facere; a sense which, accord
ing to Classen, is elsewhere confined to the aorist mnhsqh=nai. mnhsqh=nai governs the genitive directly (VI. 15, 2) or takes peri/ (viii. 47, 2). e(toi=moi ei)=nai—sc. lego/ntwn: constructed in accordance with the sense, as if e)peidh\ ou)k ei)/wn had gone before: cf. vii. 3, 1, kh/ruka prope/mpei au)toi=s le/gonta, ei)..., e(toi=mos ei(=nai spe/ndesqai: so in viii. 104, 3, we have a genitive absolute construction passing into the nominative.

o(poteroisou=n—‘to either side’; ch. 18, 65: Plat. Rep. 509 A, a)gaqo\n de\ h(gei=sqai o(po/teron au)tw=n (alterutrum) ou)k o)rqo/n: Dem. pro Mag. 209 § 27, e)a\n mh\ e)qe/lwsi poiei=n o\po/teroi tau=ta: so uter is sometimes used indefinitely=either of two. prokalesame/nois—‘after due challenge’. pro/tero/n pote—the account of this combat is given by Herodotus (i. 82). Three hundred picked men fought on either side. At nightfall two Argives and one Spartan remained alive. The Argives claimed the victory because e(wutw=n pleu=nes perigego/nasi, the Spartans because their champion remained on the field, while the Argives went home. This was in the days of Croesus, in the middle of the sixth century.

au)toi\ e(ka/teroi—Hdt i 82, au)toi\ e(ka/teroi e)/fasan nika=n: Thuc. i 105, 4, e)no/misan au)toi\ e(ka/teroi ou)k e)/lasson e)/xein. mwri/a ei)=nai tau=ta—cf. ii. 41, 2, ou) lo/gwn ko/mpos ta/de ma=llon h)\ e)/rgwn e)sti\n a)lh/qeia: Ar. Ach. 125, tau=ta dh=t' ou)k a)gxo/nh;

pa/ntws—‘on any terms’; vi. 20, 1: Hdt. ix. 35, pa/ntws sunexw/reo/n oi(, accepted him on his own terms, pantaxh= is similarly used, Soph. Aj. 1369: Ant. 634: cf. ch. 36, 31, kalw=s. cunegra/yanto—‘had the terms drawn up’.

pri\n te/los.. e)/xein—of final conclusion; iv. 118, 7, te/los e)/xontes, of ambassadors with final powers. dei=cai—sc. these terms, au)ta/, hence the subject of a)re/skonta. Note the use of ei)=nai with the participle. Krüger collects instances on i. 38, 2, a)re/skont<*>s e)smen.
e)s ta\ *(uaki/nqia—ch. 23, 24. The two next chapters deal, as we see from the beginning of ch. 44, with what passed while the Boeotian envoys were at Sparta.

tou\s para/—see note on ch. 15, 4. au)tw=n—without Spartan sanction. We find however that the Athenians took a different view. kaqh|rhme/non—the demolition of the works was now complete; see ch. 40 fin.

e)k diafora=s—‘after a quarrel’; iv. 83, 3: iv. 125, 1. koinh=| ne/mein—‘to use it as common pasture ground’. ‘The land was left unenclosed, on purpose to avoid disputes about the boundary line’ (Arnold).

kai\ tou=to a)podido/nai—‘that this too was restoring it’; kai/ i.e. no less than actually giving it back, or perhaps ‘even this’, ‘this in itself’. Most editors appear to take tou=to as governed directly by nomi/zontes and a)podido/nai as a predicate in apposition. It seems however better to regard tou=to as a cognate accusative with a)podido/nai, in this, the literal rendering being ‘thinking that thereby too they gave it back’. There is an exact parallel to this construction, Eur. Iph. T. 299, dokw=n *)erinu=s qea\s a)mu/nesqai ta/de, ‘thinking that in this he was repelling the Furies’.

legome)nwn—=‘as soon as the Athenians heard this’; the use of the imperfect verbs and participles to the end of the chapter is to be noticed. deina\ e)poi/oun—‘made an outcry’, or ‘broke out in uproar’. There are several instances of this use of the active in Hdt. e.g. ii. 121 E: iii. 14: so [Dem.] Aristog. 788. deina\ poiei=sqai, ‘to take a thing ill’=indignari, is a recognized phrase which occurs i. 102, 4: vi. 60, 4: Hdt. iii 155: vii. 1; poiei=sqai having the sense of ‘making for one's self’, i.e. regarding. It has therefore been proposed to read e)poiou=nto here, but the editors retain e)poi/oun. As Barton and Chavasse point out, in the appendix to their edition of Book iv., the active refers to the external manifestations, noises etc., while the middle expresses the subjective feeling.

o)rqo/n—so ch. 46, 15. Plutarch (Alc. 14) says *lakedai mo/nioi *pa/nakton ou)x e(stw=san. w(/sper e)/dei. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois pare/dwkan a)lla\ katalu/santes. Thucydides says nothing of its restoration; but both accounts agree that the Athenians attributed bad faith to Sparta. kai\ punqano/menoi—=‘and because, as they heard’; kai/ with the participle corresponding to tou= te kaqaire/sei. The conclusion of an alliance with Boeotia seems not to have been generally known at Athens till now. Yet the Argives knew of it from the first (ch. 40, 5).

fa/skontes pro/teron—see ch. 35, 14. o(/sa th=s cunqh/khs—the editors seem to take cunqh/khs as dependent on o(/sa and e)celeloi/pesan as active. It seems better to regard e)celeloi/-
pesan as intransitive, governing cunqh(khs, with o(/sa as cognate accusative. It is not clear whether e)no/mizon e)chpath=sqai is a main statement, or a subordinate one with o)/sa supplied. The monotonous account of intrigues and counter-intrigues is broken for a moment by the mention of Alcibiades, who now for the first time comes upon the scene. He is the first man of commanding a bilities who appeared at Athens since the death of Pericles, and henceforward the most prominent character to the close of our author's history.
au)=—‘in their turn, on their side’, as opposed to the war party in Sparta. e)ne/keinto—instabant, see note on iv. 22, 2.

h(liki/a|. ne/os—the age of Alcibiades is a subject of some discussion, owing to the loose language of the authorities we have. Their statements are collected in Poppo's edition. It seems however agreed that he was in his fifth year when his father Cleinias fell at Coronea in 447. He served in the expedition to Potidaea in 432 (i. 61 sq.), e)/ti meira)kion w)/n (Plut. Alc. 7). He was therefore now about thirty.
w(s e)n a)/llh| po/lei—‘ut in alia civitate’; see note on iv. 84. 2, w(s *lakedaimo/nios. Thirty appears to have been the recognized age in Grecian states for entering on public life.

a)ciw/mati progo/nwn—according to Plutarch Alcibiades claimed descent from Eurysaces the son of Ajax. His mother was Dinomache, of the family of the Alcmaeonidae. In Dem. Meid. 561 § 144, where there is a description of the ancestry and achievements of Alcibiades, he is carelessly said pro\s patro\s *)alkmaiwnidw=n ei)=nai.

kai\ a)/meinon—he supported the Argives from actual conviction also, as well as on other grounds. ou) me/ntoi a)lla/— Krüger quotes Plato Phaed. 62 B, do/ceien ou)/tw g) ei)=nai a)/logon: ou) me/ntoi a)ll) i)/sws e)/xei tina\ lo/gon: see Liddell and Scott, a)lla/, ii. 4. fronh/mati filoneikw=n—fro/nhma is personal pride and self-esteem; as in ii. 43, 6, a)ndri/ ge fro/nhma e)/xonti: cf. ch. 40, 14. For the construction cf. iv. 64, 1, mwri/a| filoneikw=n.

*la/xhtos—Laches is named next to Nicias in the lists of signatories in ch. 19 and 24. He also moved the ratification of the year's truce with Sparta in 423 (iv. 118. 7). e)/pracan— ‘effected’ or ‘negotiated’; cf. what Alcibiades says at Sparta, vi. 89, 2, u)mei=s pro\s *(aqhnai/ous katallasso/menoi toi=s me\n e)moi=s e)xqroi=s du/namin, di) e)kei/nwn pra/cantes, e(moi\ de\ a)timi/an perie/qete. Note the emphatic position of au)to/n. Most manuscripts have e(auto)n, which Classen reads.

kata)—lit. ‘in accordance with’. proceni/an—cf. vi. 89, 2, tw=n d) e)mw=n progo/nwn th\n proceni/an u(mw=n kata/ ti e)/gklhma a)peipontwn, au)to\s e)gw\ pa/lin a)nalamba/nwn e)qera/peuon u(ma=s a)/lla te kai\ peri\ th\n e)k *pu/lou cumfora/n. For the position of pote\ ou)=san see ch. 34, 6: 35, 24 etc.

pantaxo/qen te—‘and so feeling himself slighted (at a disadvantage) in every way’; te sums up and concludes. For e)lassou=sqai cf. ch. 30, 18. to/ te prw=ton kai\ to/te—‘as at first so now’; ch. 75, 27: cf. note on iv. 103, 4, e)/praca/n te e)k plei/onos .kai\ to/te.

bebai/ous—‘to be relied on’; iii. 11, 1, bebaio/teroi a)\n h(mi=n h)=san mhde\n newteriei=n. sfi/si=‘with us’, as in ch. 37, 9: 72, 10. e)ce/lwsi=expugnent, evertant; iv. 122, 6, *skiwnai/ous e)celei=n: also with names of places. Classen notes that in this sense the aorist is always used.

w(s . o)/ntos ..cumpra/cwn—cf. iv. 5, 1, w\s h)\ ou)x u(pomenou=ntas (acc. abs.) .h)\ r\a|di/ws lhyo/menoi bi/a|. th=s te—te and kai/ counect the two things which infiuenced the Argives, the message of Alcibiades, and true information about the Spartan and Boeotian alliance; in ch. 11, 11 we have a similar wording. kai\ e)peidh/—see ch. 58, 2, for the same combination of participial and relative construction.

ou) met' *)aqhnai/wn—so iii. 66, 2, ou) meta\ tou= plh/qous. meta/ thus used is the converse of a)/neu, iv. 78, 3, etc. The Argives were under a misapprehension (ch. 39, 14) when they sent their envoys.
oi(\ sfi/si—lit. ‘whom they had away in Lacedaemon’ (ch. 41); cf. au)toi=s ch. 3, 24. pro\s...th\n gnw/mhn ei)=xon—so ch. 48, 12: cf. ch. 13 fin.

a)po\ palaiou=—1. 2, 3: a)po\ tou= pa/nu a)rxai/ou ii. 15, 1. The two states had been in alliance since 463 (i. 102, 4). dhmokratoume/nhn k.t.l. the same words as in ch. 29, 10. th\n kata\ qa/lassan—these words (omitted by Stahl) are a kind of afterthought. The Argives reflect that Athens is especially strong at sea, where they themselves are weakest.

kaqistw=ntai e)s—i. 23, fin. es to\n po/lemon kate/sthsan, and often: so e)s fugh/n, fo/bon etc. *)hlei=oi—the Eleans and Mantineans had been the first to join the league; ch. 29 and 31. th=s cummaxi/as—the contemplated alliance; ch. 13, 9.

dokou=ntes—‘who were accounted friendly to (on good terms with) the Athenians’. Philocharidas is one of the signatories named in ch. 19 and 24. Endius appears in viii. 6, 3, as connected by hereditary friendship with Alcibiades.

dei/santes—the envoys are identified with the government that sent them. th/n te—te and kai/ connect the two things the Lacedaemonians feared, that the Athenians would make an alliance with Argos and refuse to restore Pylos.
e)pi\ kakw=|—iv. 86, 1, ou)k e)pi\ kakw=| e)lh/luqa. The Lacedaemonian apology would involve some inconsistency with the statement in ch. 39, 14, ei)do/tes me\n o(/ti a)dikh/sousin *)aqhnai/ous.

e)n th=| boulh=|—foreign ambassadors first presented their credentials to the boulh/, they were afterwards introduced to the e)kklhsi/a. mh\ kai\ h)/n—kai/ most probably goes with e)s to
 dh=mon, the order being slightly irregular: Classen compares iv 63, 2, a)lla\ kai\ a)/gan ei) tu/xoimen (=ei) kai\ a)/gan): i. 120, 2, ka)
 me/xri sfw=n, etc. Kruger and Poppo would read h)
 kai/. It is also possible to take kai/ with e)paga/gwntai to\ plh=qos (mh\ kai\, h)/|n..): this agrees with Plutarch (Nic. ch. 10) mh\ kai\ to
 dh=mon apo\ tw=n au)tw=n lo/gwn e)paga/gwntai.
e)s to\n dh=mon—i.e. in the e)kklhsi/a. Classen follows Stahl in reading tau/ta\ for tau=ta. a)pwsqh=|—ch. 22, 6, a)pew/santo.

mhxana=tai de/—Kruger suggests dh/, which Classen reads, comparing vi. 64, 1, toio/nde ti ou)=n mhxanw=ntai. pei/qei—from this is supplied the sense ‘he promises’ and ‘he says’ with the following infinitives; or they may be connected with pi/stin dou/s ‘with the assurance that’. pi/stin dou/s—Plut. Alc. 14, o(/rkous e)/dwken au)toi=s: cf. i. 133, 1, pi/stin dido/ntos: viii. 73, 3.

w()sper kai\ nu=n a)ntile/gein—for w(/sper kai) see Jowett's note quoted on ch. 13, 8. For the infimtive ‘by assimilation’ in the relative clause in oratio obliqua, see Goodwin, § 755: cf. i. 91, 5, o(/sa met' e)kei/nwn bouleu/esqai (=e)bouleu/onto) ou)deno\s u(/steroi (e)/fasan) gnw/mh| fanh=nai. ta)=lla cunalla/cein—‘will effect a reconciliation in all other respects’: i. 24, 4, tou\s feu/gontas cunalla/cai sfi/si.

boulo/menos *niki/ou te—answered by kai\ o(/pws k.t.l. te and kai/ couple the most important words. For the form of the sentence cf. iv. 70, 1, e)/deise peri/ te to<*>=s .kai\ mh/: Plat. Protag. 326 A, swfrosu/nhs te e)pimelou=ntai kai\ o(/pws. a)lhqe/s— Krüger would read u(gie)s, the word used by Plut. Aic. 14 fin. (iv. 22, 2, ei) ti\ u(gie\s dianoou=ntai); but there seems no justification for the change. e)n nw=| e)/xousin—‘mean, intend’; so iv. 22, 2, ou)de\n e)n nw=| e)/xontas di/kaion: nw=| e)/xein without e)n is ‘to bear in mind’, remember: see note on iv. 8, 5, e)n nw=| ei)=xon.
parelqo/ntes—the regular term for ‘coming forward’ in the assembly. paragago/ntes, line 23, is the corresponding active word.

ou)k e)/fasan w)/sper—sc. e)/fasan: ‘in answer to the question whether they had full powers replied No, in direct contradiction to what they had said in the Council’ (Jowett). ou)/ fhmi=to deny, but the clause is framed in accordance with the literal construction rather than the actual force. katabow=ntos—i. 67, 1, katebo/wn tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, o(/ti....

seismou=—‘cf. ch. 50 fin.: viii. 6, 5. But if an earthquake happened after any enterprise was actually begun. it was interpreted as a sign of encouragement on the part of the gods to persevere in it. See Xen. Hell. iv. 7, 4’. (Arnold.) See Liddell and Scott, dioshmi/a.

th=| d) u\sterai/a|—‘next day's assembly’; so i. 44, 1. It has been questioned whether th=| u\sterai)a| (ma/xh|), vii. 11, 2, has this meaning or simply=u(ste/ra|. kai/per belongs especially to kai\ au)to/s, ‘himself too’, as Classen indicates by marking off with commas the clause tw=n.. h)pathme/nwn. The two participial clauses are not coordinate, but the second is the consequence of the first. Alcibiades had deceived the envoys, and Nicias thus found himself in a thoroughly false position. The strengthened form of the participle e)chpathme/nos emphasizes the disappointment of Nicias, if indeed it has any particular force. Poppo however considers that sound is sometimes consulted rather than sense in such alliterative clauses. He cites Eur. Iph. T. 984, sw=son...e)/kswson, etc.
o(/mws—disappointed as he was by the envoys, he still clung to the hope of a Lacedaemonian alliance. e)pisxo/ntas— ch. 32, 28. ta\ pro\s *)argei/ous—ch. 39, 19, ta\ e)s *boiwtou/s.

le/gwn—‘urging’, lit. going on with his speech: Poppo, with Arnold, takes it=iubens, suadens; ‘advising them to put off’; a force of which instances from tragedy may be found in Liddell and Scott. There are also prose instances in Krüger's Grammar, § 55. 3, 13. Here however there is no need thus to force the meaning of le/gw. To render ‘saying, we (thus) put off the war’, gives an excellent sense.

e)n...kalw=|—under conditions and circumstances which bring honour to us and discredit to Sparta. e)n kalw=| is used of conditions and circumstances, ch. 59, 21: ch. 60, 13; though there the sense is somewhat different. For the use of adjectives cf. vi. 11, 6, to\ sfe/teron a)prepe/s.

w)s e)pi\ plei=ston—with diasw/sasqai, as o(/ti ta/xista goes with diakinduneu=sai: it being a common mannerism of Thucydides thus to break up the stiffness of grammatical connexion. For the force of the aorist cf. ch. 16, 14. eu(/rhma— Hdt. vii. 155: Xen. Anab. ii. 3, 18, eu)/rhma e(poihsa/mhn, ei).

o)rqo/n—as Panactum was already known to be dismantled (ch. 42, 19), this looks like an attempt to please the mob with a show of spirit, unless indeed the demolition was supposed to be incomplete. a)nei=nai—so th\n e)pitroph/n ch. 31, 17. kaqa/per ei)/rhto—ch. 39, 15.

o(/ti . pepoih=sqai—after the conditional clause the construction with o(/ti is neglected; so iv. 37, 1, gnou\s o(/ti, ei)... e\ndw/sousi, diafqarhsome/nous au)tou/s. a)\n...pepoih=sqai—pluperfect. The combination of tenses implies, ‘if we wished to wrong you (which we do not), we should have already made the Argives our allies’. The imperfect refers to a wish, the present existence of which is denied, the pluperfect to one definite act, which would have been completed before now: Goodwin, § 410.

w(s parei=nai—ch. 45, 11 note. au)tou\s au)tou=—Poppo, on ch. 30, 14, collects instances of similar jingles, which plainly were not unpleasing to the writer's ear. ei)/ ti=o(/sa, and so it is answered by pa/nta.
tou\s peri\ *niki/an—ch. 13, 2: so infra, line 29. a)nh/sousi *boiwtoi=s—lit. ‘throw it back on the hands of the Boeotians, unless etc.’, or *boiwtoi=s may be dativus incommodi.

e)pikratou/ntwn—vi. 74, 1, e)pekra/toun mh\ de/xesqai. to
 e)/foron—the repetition of the article is ugly, and Classen omits the words as an interpolated note: cf. however ii. 67, 2, to
 *sa/dokon to
 gegenhme/non *)aqhnai=on. e)fo/rwn should possibly be read instead of to
 e)/foron, as two manuscripts have e)fo/rwn and one omits to/n. For Xenares and his party see ch. 36, 9.
th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs—i. 113, 2, o(/soi th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs h)=san. a)nenew/santo—according to the provisions of the treaty concluded the year before, ch. 18, 61.

ai)/tios—‘for he was accounted responsible for the treaty with Sparta’. The position of this clause makes it an explanation of o(/per kai\ e)ge/neto. Note dokw=n not do/cas: not ‘he feared he might be accounted’ etc.: but ‘being held responsible as he was, he feared he should be discredited’.

di) o)rgh=s ei)=xon—according to Classen simply ‘were indignant’, but an object seems implied though not expressed. They were indignant at Nicias' failure or at the conduct of the Lacedaemomans. The other instances which Classen cites may be similarly explained. paro/ntes implies that the envoys were already in Athens; paragago/ntos that they were now brought before the assembly.
Defensive treaty between Athens and the Argive league. Mantinea and Elis, no less than Argos and Athens, are spoken of as imperial States, the meaning being that the towns which Mantinea had acquired (ch. 29) and Lepreum, which was claimed by Elis (ch. 31), are recognised as their subject allies (Jowett). In Professor Jowett's second volume there is an account of a fragment of a marble tablet, containing portions of this treaty, discovered in 1877 on the Acropolis.
e(kato\n *)aqhnai=oi e)/th—cf. the order in iii. 90 fin. e)pelqo/ntwn oi( *messh/nioi tw=n te *)aqhnai/wn...prosexw/rhsan.

e(ka/teroi—Athens and Argos respectively, not=e)/kastoi. The members of the Argive league are here taken as a whole: in line 35 it is different. a)do/lous—see ch. 18, 13, etc. The wording of this treaty is in many respects identical with the formulas in ch. 18 and 23, with slight verbal changes, e.g. mh( ..te/xnh| mhde\ mhxanh=| is here written instead of mh/te te/xnh| mh/te mhxanh=|. There is the usual mixture of imperative and infinitive construction.
e)pi\ phmonh=|—ch. 18, 15.

e)pagge/llwsin—‘send word’ i.e. require; so vi. 56, 1, e)paggei/lantes h(/kein. Sometimes the word is used with the acc. like impero; iii. 16, 3, kata\ po/leis e)ph/ggellon tessara/konta new=n plh=qos: vii. 17, 1, stratia\n e)pagge/llwn e)s tou\s cumma/xous.
tau/thn th\n po/lin—‘the state in question’, so twicc in ch. 23.

mhde\ kata\ qa/lassan—see ch. 56, 7. Krüger, who is followed by Stahl, regards these words as spurious, but they seem intended to guard against any possible evasion. ei)=nai— ‘be allowed’. h)\n mh/—dii/wsi or e)w=si may be mentally supplied. Such participial constructions are not uncommon with ei) mh/, and in effect are simply adverbial. e)ph\n e)/lqh|—e)ph/n occurs twice towards the end of viii. 58, in the terms of a treaty; and three times in Aristo
phanes. In Eur. Herc. Fur. 1364, it is read by Hermann and Paley (for e)pa/n), and is found in Isocrates and Xenophon. The later form e)pa/n, according to Kruger's Grammar, is more strictly Attic. The subject of e)/lqh| is supplied from the sense, sc. h( boh/qeia or h( stratia/.

a)piou=si kata\ tau)ta/—the words kata\ tau)ta/ are confusing. They seem at first to suggest another period of thirty days; but they probably only imply maintenance on the way home, ‘in the same manner’ as on the way out. The city which applied for aid was thus entitled to help for 30 clear days without incurring expense.

tw=| me\n o(pli/th|—for this use of tw=|=‘each’, Krüger compares Xen. Anab. i. 3, 21, u(pisxnei=tai dw/sein tri/a h(midareika\ tou= mhno\s tw=| stratiw/th|. Arnold says ‘It shews the democratic character of the contracting commonwealth, that the archer, and even the light-armed soldier, should have received the same pay as the heavy-armed soldier. Thus at Athens even the seamen received as high pay as the heavy-armed soldier: see iii. 17, 4: vi. 31, 3’. The archers are distinguished from the other light-armed troops, as in iv. 36, 1, where Poppo's note may be consulted.

trei=s o)bolou\s *ai)ginai/ous—usually assumed to be equivalent to five Attic obols; the Aegmetan and Corinthian drachma being worth ten Attic obols. See Jowett on iii. 70, 4, where a different view is noticed.

kata\ i(erw=n telei/wn—‘over’ lit. ‘down over, or on’: Dem. Aph. 852, § 26, kat' e)mou= kai\ th=s a)delfh=s, ‘on our heads’: id. Con. 1269. § 40, kata\ pai/dwn. i(era\ te/leia seem to be ‘fullgrown victims’, rather than ‘victims without blemish’ or ‘in full numbers’. Arnold compares Hdt. i. 183, where ta\ te/lea tw=n proba/twn are contrasted with ta\ galaqhna/. So hostiae maiores are distinguished from hostiae lactentes.

ai( e)/ndhmoi a)rxai/—‘the home authorities’, meaning, according to Arnold, the archons, secretaries etc. as opposed to the strathgoi/ or foreign office. In Aesch. Timarch. 45, we have mhde\ a)rxh\n a)rxe/tw mhdemi/an mh/te e)/ndhmon mh/te u(pero/rion: so Ar. Pol. iii. 9, 8, ta\ e)/ndhma are home affairs, ta\ u(pero/ria foreign affairs: cf. Thuc. i. 70, 4, a)podhmhtai\ pro\s e)ndhmota/tous ‘most stay-at-home people’. For the concrete use of a)rxai/, see note on ta\ te/lh, iv. 15, 1.
e)corkou/ntwn—‘administer the oath’; Dem. Meid. 535, § 65: in Hdt. iii. 133, and iv. 154, e)corkw= takes the accusative and denotes binding a person by oath.

oi( o)gdoh/konta—nothing is known of these. They may have been a more aristocratical council than the boulh/, and the a)rtu=nai may have been the presiding officers, who, as Muller suggests, had succeeded to the civil authority of the kings (Arnold). If ai( a)rtu=nai is the right reading, it is analogous to ai( a)rxai/: oi( a)rtu=nai (Duker) would come from a)rtu/nas (hs). Poppo suggests oi( a)/rtunoi, a form found in Plutarch.

oi( dhmiourgoi/—a common title of the magistrates in the Peloponnesian states, with the exception of Lacedaemon. In i. 56, 2, e)pidhmiourgoi/ are officials sent from Corinth to the colony of Potidaea. oi( qewroi/—‘a sacred college, whose functions were perpetual, like the colleges of pontifices and augurs at Rome. Like the Pythii at Lacedaemon, they had the care of all oracles delivered to the state, and probably had a general control over religious matters’ (Arnold).

oi( ta\ te/lh e)/xontes—Arnold says that the phrase is not simply equivalent to oi( e)n te/lei or ta\ te/lh. He believes that some particular ‘council of administration’ is probably meant, smaller than the general council of six hundred. Krüger brackets the words as spurious, the phrase being unusual. In iv. 118, 7, te)los e)/xontes means ‘having full powers’.

a)naneou=sqai—see ch. 18, 61. Arnold points out that the times specified were such that the renewal of the oaths might be completed on both sides before the return of their respective great public festivals. The great Panathenaea were celebrated every four years, in the third year of the Olympiad.
e)n a)gora=|—ch. 18, 64, note: e)n th=| a)gora=|, as below, is more common.

kataqe/ntwn—‘deposit’, instead of the more usual sth=sai (ch. 18, 62); this tablet aud inscription would be in the care of the Eleans. toi=s nuni/—at the Olympian festival which was close at hand, ch. 49, init.
ai( cummaxi/ai—Classen reads h( cummaxi/a, as in ch. 27, 2, where see note. Here at any rate the plural seems unobjectionable, as four contracting powers are concerned.

ou)k a)pei/rhnto—‘were not renounced’; the active is not uncommon in this sense. The pluperfect denotes not only the fact, but the state of things resulting, i.e., the continuance of the alliance between Athens and Sparta; see note on iv. 13, 1.
ou)d) u(f) e(te/rwn—ii. 67, 5 mhde\ meq) e\te/rwn etc.: so Dem. Aeschin. etc. e)n ou)dete/rois and the like forms are characteristic of late Greek (Kruger).

*kori/nqioi de/ k.t.l.—though the Corinthians had become allies of Argos (ch. 31, 28) they would not join the new league, just as they had before refused to be parties to an offensive and defensive alliance. We have no particulars of this in ch. 29—31; but it would seem that the other confederates of Argos had made such an alliance, while the Corinthians had only concluded a defensive treaty, as they originally proposed (ch. 27, 15). This treaty they now call th\n prw/thn genome/nhn e)pimaxi/an. The words a)lla\ kai\.. ou) cunw/mosan are thus parenthetical, and a)rkei=n d) e)/fasan carries on the sense from ou)k e)sh=lqon.

th\n prw/thn genome/nhn—so iv. 38, 3, o( teleutai=os diapleu/sas. e)pimaxi/an—a defensive alliance; i. 44, 1, e)pimaxi/an de\ e)poih/santo th=| a)llh/lwn bohqei=n. The verb has been noticed ch. 27, 16. These words do not occur elsewhere in Thucydides.
oi( me/n—so ch. 67, 11: iv. 32, 1 etc.: a fresh sentence more commonly begins with oi( me\n ou)=n or kai\ oi( me/n. pro\s... ei)=xon—cf. ch. 44, 8.

*)olu/mpia...oi(=s—so iii. 8, h)=n de\ *)olumpia\s h(=| *dwrieu\s to\ deu/teron e)ni/ka. oi)=s and h(=|, datives of time or date, may explain such constructions as ii. 20, 1, e)kei/nh| th=| e)sbolh=|: iv. 26, 7, galh/nh| ‘in a calm’. Editors note that in later times it was generally the victor in the sta/dion whose name was associated with the Olympiad. Possibly Thucydides names athletes of unusual distinction. See Lid. and Scott for the difference between *)olu/mpia and *)olumpia/s.

e)ni/ka—‘was victorious’; the imperfect is the regular usage with nikw= even when a single definite victory is in
question: i. 13 fin. *karxhdoni/ous e)ni/kwn naumaxou=ntes: so with kratw= etc. (Goodwin § 27). In vi. 16, 2, however, where Alcibiades is speaking of his Olympic victory, he says e)ni/khsa de/, ‘I won the prize’; regarding his former victory as a single fact now entirely past; see note on ch. 51, 8.
tou= i(erou=—the whole of the sacred precincts. The Lacedaemonians were excluded from taking part in the ceremonies and games in any public recognized capacity.

th\n di/khn—‘the penalty’; an uncommon use of the word to denote a specific fine. Such passages as Soph. Aj. 113, kei=nos de\ ti/sei th/nde kou)k a)/llhn di/khn, are only partly analogous. e)n tw=| ..no/mw|—‘in accordance with’; i. 77, 1, e)n toi=s o(moi/ois no/mois poih/santes ta\s kri/seis: ch. 31, 23, e)n h(=|: Dem. Lept. 497, § 131, ta\ yhfi/smata e)n oi(=s a)telei=s ei)si/n. The expression, as Arnold says, seems to denote what was specified in the law; he compares vii. 11, 1, ta\ me\n praxqe/nta e)n a)/llais pollai=s e)pistolai=s i)/ste.

katedika/santo au)tw=n—‘had got them condemned to pay’: katadika/zw, like other legal words (e.g. tima=n, tima=sqai), is used in the active of the court which pronounces the judgment, in the middle of the plaintiff in whose interest the court acts: Dem. Meid. 571, § 176, di(khn e=mporikh\n katadikasa/menos *meni/ppou, ‘having obtained a verdict in a mercantile suit against Menippus’. In the present case the plaintiffs and judges would seem to have been more or less identical, being Eleans; but no complaint is made of this, the only dispute being about the facts.

fa/skontes (e)s) sfa=s—e)s is a conjecture which is due to Shilleto. It might have easily dropped out after the word before, and it gives an excellent sense, the Eleans complaining that ‘their territory was invaded’ at two points; cf. iv. 77, 1, strateu/ein e)s *boiwtou/s. The manuscript reading, fa/skontes sfa=s, is very suspicious. Classen refers sfa=s to *aakedaimo/nioi, the main subject of the sentence, and explains a similar sfa=s in vi. 61, 5, in the same way. See note on sfi/si, ch. 38, 22. Jowett, on the other hand, considers that the Herodotean usage of sfe/as etc. for au)tou/s is not altogether extinct in Thucydides, especially when repetition is to be avoided. Many editors adopt Dobree's conjecture sfw=n, comparing such phrases as viii. 96, 2, sfw=n e)pi\ to\n *peiraia= plei=n. sfi/sin might also be suggested. The military operations of which Elis complained must have taken place after what is related in ch. 31, 20, unless
indeed that account is partly anticipatory. Possibly, as Grote suggests, the Eleans had renewed their attacks on the district of Lepreum.

au(tw=n—dependent on *ae/preon according to most editors: Jowett however seems right in taking it with o(pli/tas. We have seen (ch. 31) that the Eleans refused to accept the award of the independence of Lepreum, after being strengthened by their new allies. Classen inserts xili/ous before o(pli/tas.

katadi/kh—‘fine’; (Dem.) Euerg. 1154, § 51. h)=san—cf. i. 10, 1, *mukh=nai mikro\n h)=n. Arnold points out that two minae was the ordinary ransom of a Peloponnesian soldier taken prisoner in battle; Hdt. vi 79, a)/poina de/ e)sti *peloponnhsi/oisi du/o mne/ai tetagme/nai kat' a)/ndra ai)xma/lwton e)kti/nein.

katadedika/sqai—probably passive impersonal or with th\n di/khn implied as subject, like e)a\n d) a)rguri/ou timhqh=| (Timocr. 721), and similar phrases in Demosthenes. Classen however takes it as middle, which is possible so far as the form is concerned.

*)hlei=oi de/—‘the Eleans maintained that the truce at Elis was already in force &c.’. They were thus precluded from resisting the Spartan aggression. How the Spartans were to be expected to know that the truce had begun does not appear; the Eleans seem to have had the entire regulation of all matters concerning the Olympic festival.

u(pela/mbanon—‘rejoined, urged in reply’; ii. 72, 1, u(polabw\n ei)=pe. The word is perpetually used in Demosthenes of counter-arguments. e)/ti—‘after this’. a)dikei=n—lit. to be already a)/dikoi: a)dikei=n being one of the verbs thus used in the present, like feu/gein, ‘to be in exile’, nika=n, etc. to denote a present condition following a past act. a)dikh/santas, just before, refers to the commission of a definite act of trespass.

a)ll) ou)x w(s nomi/zontas—lit. ‘but that they had done this (announced the treaty) not as if they considered themselves wronged (but as if they did not)’. Kruger (Grammar § 67, 4) shows the elliptical nature of such constructions; cf. Eur. Hip. 699, zhtou=sa fa/rmax' hu)=ron ou)x a(boulo/mhn: Xen. Mem. i. 1, 19, *swkra/ths e)pimelei=sqai qeou\s e)no/mizen a)nq rw/pwn ou)x dn tro/pon oi( polloi\ nomi/zousi.
kai\ ..e)penegkei=n—‘and that they (the Lacedaemonians) had not after this attacked them at any point’. Note the change of subject.

tou= au)tou= ei)/xonto—‘held to the same statement’; iv. 66, 2, tou/tou tou_ lo/gou e)/xesqai: Hdt. vii. 5, toiou/tou lo/gou ei)/xeto: vii. 6, tw=n au)te/wn lo/gwn e)xo/menoi. mh\ a)
 peisqh=nai —‘they could not be convinced’; i. 139, 1, prou)/legon mh\ a)
 gene/sqai po/lemon: vi. 102 fin. nomi/santes mh\ a(
 e)/ti i(kanoi\ gene/sqai: but iv. 99, 2, nomi)zontes ..ou)k a)
 krath=sai. There seems no difference in meaning between the two forms of expression; though ou) is the more regular, being retained from the direct speech: see Goodwin, § 685: Madvig's Syntax, § 205. Can any difference in meaning be seen between le/gontes mh\ e)phgge/lqai pw (line 13) and u)pela/mbanon ...ou)damo/se e)penegkei=n (line 23)? Both represent a direct statement with ou).
gi/gnetai—‘becomes due’: Dem. Timocr. 726, § 83, to\ ti/mhma to\ gigno/menon.

a)pomo/sai—this is the invariable reading, and is interpreted ‘to swear solemnly’. Elsewhere a)po/mnumi always has a negative force, and means ‘to disclaim on oath’. Should e)pomo/sai be read here? Arnold suggests that a)pomo/sai may perhaps be justified, as the oath would be exculpatory in effect.

qusi/as kai\ a)gw/nwn—usually regarded as explanatory of tou= i(erou=, and coordinate in construction. Some authorities however take tou= i(erou= as dependent on qusi/as, or conversely translate, ‘from the sacred observance of sacrifice’. The position of the article is against such renderings. Kruger suggests that qusi/as kai\ a)gw/nwn may be a note interpolated from ch. 49, 4.
e)qew/roun—were formally represented by their qewroi/: viii. 10 init. oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)qew/roun e)s au)ta/ (ta\ *)/isqmia). Individual Spartans were not excluded.

cu
 o(/plois—‘under arms’; one of the regular phrases in which cu/n is used in prose. Classen unaccountably takes tw=n newte/rwn as dependent on o(/plois, and naturally calls it a strange expression. Surely the construction is obvious even
without such instances as new=n triw=n fulakh/ (ii. 93 fin.): th
 fulakh
 tw=n trih(rwn e)la/nqanon (iv. 26, 7).

e)n *)/argei u(pe/menon—‘had been waiting at Argos for the feast’, and then moved towards Olympia (Jowett). This is a legitimate sense of the imperfect, referring to duration of time before h)=lqon; cf. i. 9, 2, o(/swn *eu)rusqeu\s h)=rxe th\n basilei)an *:atre(a paralabei=n. Otherwise the reading e)n *)/argei must be wrong, as Argos was seventy or eighty miles off. Classen accordingly adopts en *(arpi/nh|, Harpina being a town in the valley of the Alpheus, 20 stadia from Olympia. It seems however natural that Argos, the head of the league with Athens, would find quarters for an Athenian detachment, which had probably been sent in readiness by the advice of Alcibiades.

*li/xas—Lichas was a man of eminence. He was one of the envoys to Argos, ch. 22, 11 (cf. ch. 76, 13), and is mentioned several times in the eighth Book. e)n tw=| a)gw=ni— ‘on the course’ or place of contest, an Homeric use; so infr. line 20. Otherwise the meaning might be ‘in the midst of the assembly’ or ‘during the meeting’.

u(po\ tw=n r(abdou/xwn—the r(abdou=xoi were probably the officials acting under orders from the presiding *(ellanodi/kai or a)gwnoqe/tai, rather than these authorities themselves. plhga\s lamba/nw is the regular phrase for ‘being beaten’ and is accordingly constructed with u(po/. For the ‘defective verb tu/ptw’, see the Appendix to Sandys' Private Orations of Demosthenes. Grote points out how much less harsh and rough, by comparison with this incident, was the manner of dealing at Athens, where personal violence was illegal. He adds ‘the boldness of the Eleans in putting this affront upon the most powerful state in Greece is so astonishing, that we can hardly be mistaken in supposing their proceeding to have been suggested by Alcibiades and encouraged by the armed aid from the allies. He was at this moment not less ostentatious in humiliating Sparta than in showing off Athens’ (ch. 55).

nikw=ntos—ch. 49, 2. zeu/gous—chariot and pair. Whether Lichas won the final heat we do not know, or even whether there were more heats than one. Grote (ch. 55) discusses the matter at length, and strives to show that this was the Olympian festival at which Alcibiades made his unparalleled display of magnificence as qewro/s, and entered seven chariots, taking the first, second and fourth place (vi. 16, 2).

*boiwtw=n dhmosi/ou—Lichas had entered his chariot under the name of the ‘Boeotian community’, which was accordingly declared victorious: Xen. Hell. iii. 2, 21, *li/xa parado/ntos *qhbai/ois to\ a(/rma. dhmo/sion may mean a state, as in Hdt. i. 14, *korinqi/wn tou/ dhmosi/ou: and the article is omitted, as it often is with quasi-proper names, so ch. 18, 42, e)n dhmosi/w| (e)n tw=| just before): vi. 31, 3, e(k dhmosi/ou. Poppo suggests that dhmosi/ou might possibly be taken as an adjective agreeing with zeu/gous, ‘his chariot being proclaimed as belonging to the Boeotian state’. States, like kings, seem to have competed in the race; cf. vi. 16, 2, where Alcibiades says that he entered more chariots than any private person before him.
ou)k e)cousi/an—see note on ch. 35, 7. a)gw/nisis is not found elsewhere in classical Greek. a)ne/dhse—iv. 121, 1, stefa/nw| a/ne/dhsan.

h(su/xasan—the aorist, ‘became quiet’ or ‘were pacified’, suggests that they had actually made some threatening movement; otherwise we should expect the imperfect: cf. viii. 86, 2, mo/lis h(suxa/santes h)/kousan. au)toi=s—‘as for them’; ch. 3, 24. The Lacedaemonians seem meant, though Krüger refers the word to pa/ntes. Twelve years afterwards the Spartans avenged the insult they had received, by invading and ravaging the land of Elis; Xen. Hell. iii. 2, 23—31.
te/los—‘finally’; ii. 100 fin. te/los h(suxi/an h)=gon: vii. 44, 7 etc.

*(hraklew/tais—see note on iv. 78, 1. The establishment of Heraclea as a Lacedaemonian colony and place of arms, and the hostility with which it was regarded by the neighbouring Thessalians, are described in iii. 92, 93. In those chapters we have terms corresponding to those in the present passage. For pole/mia h)=n cf. iii. 93, 2, dia\ panto\s e)pole/moun: for e)pi(...e)teixi/sqh ib. w(=n e)pi\ th=| gh=| e)teixi/zeto (so iv. 75, 1, e(pi\ th=| *sa/mw|, of a standing menace): for kaqistame/nh| passive, iii. 92, 4, kalw=s e)do/kei kaqi/stasqai: for fqei/rontes, iii. 93, 2, e)/fqeiron
eu)qu/s te kai\ to/te—see note on ch. 43, 16.

e)ni/khsan—so i. 29, 4, where Classen points out that the aorist is used, instead of the more common imperfect, to denote the single fact of victory, without reference to the state of things resulting. See ch. 49, 3, note.

*cena/rhs—the ephor named in ch. 36, 9. *kni/dios, if the reading is right, seems to be genitive of *kni/dis, Ionic in form, like *)afu/tios, i. 64, 2: *goa/cios, iv. 107, 3. Cnidis however is an unknown name.

pare/labon—‘took into their own hands’; so twice in iii. 50. to/n—so iii. 25, 1, *sa/laiqos o( *lakedaimo/nios: iii. 100, 2, *maka/rios kai\ *meneda/i)os oi) *spartia=tai etc. The article in such instances does not seem to imply previons mention or special distinction. Sometimes indeed there may be an idea of opposition, as in this instance between the Lacedaemonian governor and the other colonists.
w(s ou) kalw=s—see the end of iii. 93, where the ruin of Heraclea is attributed to the Spartan governors. e)ce/pemyan is a milder word than e)ce/balon: cf. iv. 49.

ta\ kata/—determinant accusative; ii. 96, 3, ou= w(ri/zeto h( a)rxh\ ta\ pro\s *pai/onas. Such phrases as iii. 6, 2, ta\ peri\ *mutilh/nhn ou(/tws e)polemei=to, are open to doubt. Classen takes them as nominative; Poppo and Kruger as accusative with an impersonal passive verb: see ch. 26, 32.
tw=n au)to/qen—partitive genitive; iv 80, 2, tw=n *ei(lw/twn e/kpe/myai. paralabw/n is used like parakalw=n in ch. 6, 20.

*patre/as—Hdt. i. 145, *patre/es: *pa/trai (now Patras) was the name of the place; Thuc. ii. 83, 3, e)k *patrw=n th=s *)axai/as. tei/xh kaqei=nai—cf. iv. 103, 5, ou) kaqei=to tei/xh. The Athenians would thus have a secure naval station at Patrae, which would command the entrance to the Corinthian Gulf, being seawards
of Rhium and Naupactus. On the same principle they had built the long walls at Megara, and garrisoned them themselves (iv. 103, 4).
e(/teron—sc. tei=xos, perhaps now, as Poppo suggests, in the sense of fortified position. tw=| *(ri/w|—see ii. 84, 4 and 86, 2 for the opposite promontories called Rhium.

oi(=s h)=n e)n bla/bh| teixisqe/n—‘who would be injured by its construction’; or perhaps ‘who considered that they would be injured’; lit. ‘to whom it was being (was likely to be) injurious’. The imperfect indicative without a)/n is used in certain cases of (generally unfulfilled) condition, e.g. e)xrh=n, e)/dei, h)nagkazo/mhn, ki/ndunos h)=n etc. (Goodwin § 416 sq.: Kruger's Grammar § 53, 2, 7): h)=n e)n bla/bh| is therefore not irregular. For the combination with teixisqe\n = ei) e)teixi/sqh (or teixisqei/h), cf. viii. 92, 10, h)rw/twn ei) dokei= au)tw=| to\ tei=xos a)mei=non ei)=nai kaqaireqe/n = to\ kaqaireqh=nai to\ tei=xos: so i. 100, 3, oi)=s pole/mion h)=n to\ xwri/on ktizo/menon. Dobree, who considered a)/n to be necessary here, proposed to read oi(=s h)=n a(\n bla/bh, but e)n bla/bh| is an idiomatic phrase, equivalent to an adjective, which should in any case be retained: cf. Hdt. iv. 139, *sku/qh|si/ e)sti e(n h(donh=|: Eur. Iph. T. 494, ei)/ soi tou=t' e)n h(donh=| maqei=n: so Tac. Ann. xii. 15, nec fuit in arduo societas.

profa/sei me/n—so vi. 76, 2, profa/sei me\n ..dianoi/a| de/: The accusative is also used, as in ch. 80, 21: iii. 111, 1. Here me/n is answered by e)do/kei de/. *puqae/ws—from nom. *puqaeu/s: so *mhlie/ws, iv. 100, 1. The MSS. have *puqe/ws. Arnold believes that a temple at Argos is meant. Poppo and Classen refer the passage to a temple at Asine, which the Aigives, according to Pausanias, left standing after the destruction of the town. In any case a sacrifice seems to have been due from Epidaurus to the temple, in acknowledgement of some privilege of pasturage or the like.
a)pagagei=n.. a)pe/pempon—compounds like a)podido/nai, ‘to pay when due’: Ar. Ach. 643, to\n fo/ron u(mi=n a)pa/gontes: so Vesp. 707: cf. reddere rationem, poenas, etc.

botami/wn—apparently ‘pasture-lands’, but not found elsewhere. Stahl reads botanw=n. comparing Plat. Rep. 401 B, e)n kakh=| bota/nh| ‘in bad pasture’; but there the word means food rather than land. Poppo adopts the reading of some manuscripts, parapotami/wn ‘river-side lands’. bwtami/wn ‘sacrifices’ (Doric for bout.) has also been suggested; with the meaning that Epidaurus neglected to send the necessary victims which entitled them to share in religious rites. No word of the kind is however known, as is shown in Poppo's edition.
th=s ai)ti/as—‘this ground of complaint’, lit. ‘their’, that which they had. For ai)ti/a cf. iv. 85, 1 etc

th=s te *kori/nqou k.t.l.—‘both to ensure the neutrality of Corinth, and because they thought that the Atheuians would thus have a shorter distance to bring forces from Aegina’. The construction in the clause with te is slightly changed, and e)/sesqai depends on the sense supplied from e)do/kei: so iii. 94, 3, a)napei/qetai *ai)twloi=s e)piqe/sqai, *naupa/ktw| te polemi/ois ou)=si, kai\. prospoih(sein. iv. 3, 3, tw=| de\ dia/foro/n ti e)do/kei, lime/nos te proso/ntos, kai\ tou\s *messhni/ous...e)/sesqai. In all three instances two reasons are given in clauses with te and kai/, and the clause with kai/, instead of corresponding to that with te, is accommodated to the construction which would have followed the main verb. Here e)do/kei first means ‘seemed good’; then the idea of seeming only is carried on. We have the converse Eur. Iph. T. 279, e)/doce d) h(mw=n eu)= le/gein toi=s plei/osi, qhra=n te th=| qew=| sfa/gia ta)pixw/ria, i.e. we decided to do so. The Corinthians had taken a suspicious attitude, as we see from the end of ch. 48, and boh/qeian means aid to the confederacy and Argos in particular.

h(\ .periplei=n—so iv. 66, 3, nomi/zontes e)la/ssw sfi/si to\n ki/ndunon h)\ tou\s e)kpeso/ntas katelqei=n: vi. 60, 3, bebaiote/ran swthri/an. .h)\ .e)lqei=n. In these passages the infinitive is written, without any real construction, when a dative participle or verb with ei) might be expected. So we might say, ‘it was a shorter distance to send aid than rounding Scyllaeum’. From Aegina to Epidaurus was a straight passage, and the distance by land to Argos was not great.

dia\ tou= qu/matos th\n e)/spracin—‘for the sake of exacting the sacrifice’: dia/ is here used in the sense of e(/neka: see other passages in note on iv. 40, 2, di( a)xqhdo/na. Dr Rutherford calls di) a)xqhdo/na a late idiom betraying an adscript, but there seem enough instances to support it. For the order cf. i. 32, 2, meta) th=s cummaxi/as th=s alth/sews.

*leu=ktra—besides the well-known Leuctra in Boeotia, there were two towns in Peloponnesus so called, one s.w. of Sparta, on the coast near the Messenian border, the other N.W. to wards the district which afterwards belonged to Megalopolis; this latter is here meant. *lu/kaion—sc. o)/ros or i(ero/n; the neuter adjective applying to either; ch. 16, 32.

ai( po/leis—the Laconian cities; the allies were summoned later on. diabath/ria—sc. i(era/, the sacrifices for crossing the border; so ch. 116, 3. prou)xw/rei—‘proved favourable’; Xen. Anab vi. 2, 21, i)/sws a)\n ta\ i)era\ proxwroi/h h(mi=n. gi/gnesqai is used in the same way, as in ch. 55, 17. me/llonta—mh=na would have been added but for the following parenthesis. *karnei=os—corresponding to Metageitnion at Athens; about August. The name was derived from the festival of Apollo Carneius. i(eromh/nia—‘a sacred period’, neuter plural, referring to the whole month, in which there were two festivals besides the Carneia. Elsewhere we have the feminine singular, as in iii. 56, 2; and it is read here by Stahl, as ‘the neuter plural must come from an adjective i(eromh/nios which occurs nowhere, and Schol. Pind. Nem. iii. 4, uses i(eromhni/a of the entire month’ (F.).

tetra/difqi/nontos—apparently ‘on the fourth day from the end’, like teta/rth| ch. 19, 2: but see Lid. and Scott, mh/n. a)/gontes— ‘keeping this day all the time’, i.e. calling every day that the expedition lasted the 27th of the month before Carneius. This explanation, now accepted by all, is due to Grote, who shows (ch. 56) that such tricks with the calendar were by no means unknown. Other explanations formerly suggested were ‘marching during this day’ or ‘though they always observed this day’ while pa/nta to\n xro/non was diversely joined with a)/gontes or e)se/balon (v. l. e)se/ballon).

tines oi( me/n—not equivalent to oi( me/n tines. but tines is divided by apposition into oi( me\n.. oi( de/: vii. 86, 4, tine\s, w(s e)le/geto, oi( me\n .a)/lloi de/. Other allies, not included in tines, seem to have actually responded to the call of Epidaurus; ch. 55, 7. h(su/xazon—either not feeling strong enough to act independently, or deterred by the sacred season.
e)n th=|—e)n may be at or near, as noted on iv. 5, 1, o( strato\s e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais w)/n: or ‘Epidaurus’ may mean the district, as it seems to do in ch. 77 and 80. a)po) tw=n po/lewn—from the cities of the league, and the half-neutral Corinth. parakalesa/ntwn—of summoning allies to a conference, as in ch. 17, 19.

sfei=s—so iv. 114, 5, ta\ pro/tera ou) sfei=s a)dikei=sqai: viii. 76, 4. The nominative is used when the speaker represents the entire body, and where h(mei=s would be emphatically expressed in direct speech: otherwise we have the accusative, as in ch. 65, 7: iv. 36, 1, a)/llws e)/fh ponei=n sfa=s, = he said a)/llws ponou=men. where see note.

a)f) e(kate/rwn—probably to be taken with e)lqo/ntas, lit. ‘going from both sides’, i.e. by sending envoys from the partizans of Argos and Epidaurus (or Corinth) respectively. It is also possible to take it with strato/peda, ‘to break up the armies from both sides’; for the position of e)lqo/ntas is not opposed to such a rendering. ou(/tw=when this was done; ch. 38, 6.

peisqe/ntes w)/|xonto—the states are identified with their envoys, as in e)lqo/ntas before. e)s to\ au)to/—iii. 91, 2, e\s to\ au)to\ a)ph/ntwn. ou)d) w(/s—ch. 115, 7: so i. 44, 2, kai\ w(\s e)/sesqai: iii. 33, 2, ei) kai\ w(/s.
*karu/as—on the road towards Tegea, north of Sparta. ou)d) e)ntau=qa—any more than at Leuctra, ch. 54, 7. w(s to\ tri/ton—iv. 31, 2, w(s tria/konta o(pli=tai.

puqo/menoi—i.e. they had marched to aid Argos against a threatened invasion. The manuscripts have puqo/menoi de/, which would necessitate taking this clause with what follows, and either (1) giving to the perfect e)cestrateu=sqai the forced sense, ‘had ended their expedition’; or (2) adopting Poppo's suggestion, that the Athenians had intended to help Argos, not against Spartan invasion, but in attacking Epidaurus, a design which was stopped by the movement of the Spartans. But bohqei=n, as Arnold points out on iv. 4, 3, would not be used of an offensive movement, unless it were subordinate to a scheme of defensive operations.

kai\ w(s—so kai/ ch. 56, 22. If puqo/menoi de/ were read we might compare ch. 44, 2, a)kou/santes...kai\ e)peidh\ e)/gnwsan.
dih=lqen—so ch. 50, 24. It has been suggested that Thucydides uses this expression here, instead of the more usual to\ qe/ros e)teleu/ta, because of the inconclusive character of this summer's doings.
*)aghsippi/dan—probably the same as *(hghsippi/das ch. 52, 3. e)pekaloun—of complaining, ch. 59, 29: iv. 23, 1, a)di/khma e)pikale/santes.

gegramme/non—accusative absolute, like ei)rhme/non, ch. 30, 10: dedogme/non i. 125, 2. The clause in question is in ch. 47, 35; the Athenians, as masters of the sea, being thus held responsible for maintaining a blockade.
tou\s *messhni/ous—see ch. 35, 36. a)dikh/sesqai—passive future, as in vi. 87, 4: Eur. Iph. A. 1437 etc.: often in Dem.

th=| *lakwnikh=|—see ch. 18, 62: ch. 23, 26. u(pe(grayan—‘this was an intermediate step, to show that they did not renounce the treaty with Lacedaemon utterly. Had they done so, the monument on which the treaty was engraved would have been destroyed altogether: see Dem. Megal. 209, dei= ta\s sth/las kaqelei=n ta\s pro\s *qhbai/ous’ (Arnold). u(pogra/fw is here used in the literal sense of subjoining or adding a note. In Dem. Pantaen. 973, u(pogra/yas e)pibouleu=sai/ me au)tw=| is usually mis-translated: it means ‘after starting with the statement that I plotted against him’, u(po/ being used as in u(pa/rxw, u(poti/qhmi etc. see note on iv. 4, 3. With the present passage Kruger compares Ar. Lys. 513, ti/ bebou/leutai peri\ tw=n spondw=n e)n th=| sth/lh| paragra/yai;

tou\s e)k *kran<*>/wn—see ch. 35, 6: for construction cf. such phrases as oi( e)k tw=n nh/swn kakou=rgoi, i. 8, 2. lhi/zesqai— infinitive of purpose (Goodwin § 770): cf. vi. 50, 4, de/ka tw=n new=n prou)/pemyan e)s to\n lime/na pleu=sai. lhi/zomai seems always middle iu Thucydides: Classen accordingly reads e)lhi/zonto for e)lh/izo/n te, iv. 41, 2. e)k paraskeuh=s—e)k fanera=s parata/cews (Schol.): cf. iv. 94, 1, yiloi\ e)k paraskeuh=s w(plisme)noi, ‘regularly armed’, w(s tu/xoien—the optative, like the following imperfect, denotes indefinite frequency.

pro\s e)/ar h)/dh—ch. 17, 9. w(s e)rg/mou—‘They expected that the forces of the Epidaurians would be dispersed over their whole territory in defending forts and strong positions, on account of the plundering warfare which the Argives were carrying on, and that the city would thus be left defenceless’ (Arnold).

au)toi=s—‘seeing their allies’ etc.; ch. 3, 24. ta)=lla— ‘the other powers’ i.e. states: vi. 16, fin. *peloponnh/sou ta\ dunatw/tata: cf. ch. 59, 2. The construction which follows is resolved apposition, like ch. 54, 16. ou) kalw=s—‘in an unsatisfactory state’, i.e. disaffected or disheartened.

prokatalh/yontai—without object expressed; so iii. 2, 3, ei) mh/ tis prokatalh/yetai h(dh: iii. 3, 2: iii. 46, 4, with o(/pws following. au)ta/—‘this’, i.e. the spirit of disaffection, ‘the evil would spread’ (Jowett): iv. 61, 4, etc. For the whole phrase, cf. Cic. Att. i. 13, 3, vereor ne hoc quod infectum est serpat longius.

o(/soi a)/lloi—see ch. 67, 8. e)s *fliou=nta—Phlius was in the north of Peloponnesus, nearly south of Sicyon. a(/mippoi— Xen. Hell. vii. 5, 23, pezoi\ a(/mippoi. Foot-soldiers, armed with missiles, who accompanied the cavalry, and probably if necessary mounted their horses. ‘They seem to be the same sort of troops with the i(ppodro/moi yiloi/ of Hdt. vii. 158. Their use is described by Caesar B. G. i. 48: B. C. iii. 84’ (Arnold). i)/soi— equal in number, as in iv. 1, 1, *lokri/des i)/sai.

w(s e(/kastoi—that is in such numbers as each could furnish; i. 3, 4, oi( w(s e(/kastoi *(/ellhnes. The phrase is elliptical, a verb being in each case implied from the context. e)n th=| e)kei/nwn—the Phliasians, though just mentioned, are called e)kei=noi because apart from the Lacedaemonians, who are the main subject of the sentence; see note on iv. 37, 2.

proaisqo/menoi to/ te prw=ton—answered by kai\ e)peidh/, the participial construction being dropped in the second clause; ch. 44 begins with a similar sentence. ‘The Argives received
the first intimation of the intention of the Lacedaemonians from the preparations of their allies: afterwards their purpose was more distinctly revealed by the march of the troops to Phlius. to/te dh/ refers only to the clause beginning kai\ e)peidh/. The sentence would have run more regularly, proh/|sqonto/ te...kai\ e)peidh/ k.t l.’ (Jowett). Classen prefers to read to/te prw=ton and to omit kai/ before e)peidh/. to/te prw=ton then refers to the gathering of troops by the Spartans (ch. 57). This certainly simplifies the construction, but the sentence seems to lose its Thucydidean character, and the repetition to/te prw=ton...to/te dh/ is awkward.
prosmi=cai—ch. 72, 8: also used of approaching an enemy (iv. 93. 1) ˙ and of coming to close quarters (iv. 33, 2, etc.).
*mequdri/w|—Methydrium lay to the west of Mantinea, beyond a mountain ridge. Arnold points out that the Spartans took a circuitous route to Phlius, to avoid the territory of Mantinea.
katalamba/nousi—of taking up a military position; iv. 1, 1, note. memonwme/nois, as in ch. 8, 18, means ‘without allies present’, rather than ‘deserted by allies’.

a)nasth/sas—iv. 93, 1, a)nasth/sas h)=ge to\n strato/n. e)poreu/eto—began or continued his march. The route would be by Orchomenus to the north of Mantinea. Agis effected the junction with his allies, or at any rate opened commumcations with them, as we find the whole force after this acting in concert.

th\n kata\ *neme/an o(do/n—the accusative seems not to be governed by e)xw/roun e)s, but rather to be explanatory of h)=| prosede/xonto and dependent on katabh(sesqai. kata/—‘by way of’; as we should say, they took the Nemean road: vii. 80, 1, h)=n h( o(do\s kata\ to\ e(/teron me/ros th+s *sikeli/as. Nemea was north of Argos, between Cleonae and Phlius.

tau/thn—ch. 10, 31: iii. 24, 1, e)xw/roun th\n e)s *qh/bas fe/rousan o(do/n. The allied troops entered the enemy's territory in three divisions, two of which crossed the mountains into Argolis, while the third, with the cavalry, went northwards by the regular road to Nemea.

o)/rqion—‘steep’; with two terminations, as in Eur. Hel. 632. o)/rqrion has good manuscript authority, and possibly o)/rqrioi should be read; see ch. 58, 3, h(me/ras h)/dh. e(te/ran o)/rqion however corresponds to xaleph/n.
ei)/rhto—so ch. 10, 36: iv. 77, 1, etc. Though the construction is passive, Agis is still the subject in sense, and accordingly sfa=s=Agis' division.
diata/cas—iv. 31, 2, w(=de ga\r dieteta/xato: iv. 130, 3, diata/ssei w(s e)s ma/xhn, etc. The compound implies the assignment of different posts or duties.

*sa/minqon—unknown. For a)/lla cf. ch. 57, 3, ta)=lla. Here however places, not states, are meant. h(me(ras h)/dh—so i. 30, 4, xeimw=nos h)/dh: iii. 24, 3, e)pei\ h)/dh h)me/ra e)ge/neto. This gives some support to the reading o)/rqrioi, ch. 58, 22.

ou) pollw=| plei/ous—appositional, lit. ‘in a rather greater number’; so ch. 115, 4. e)xw/roun—possibly=‘had been marching’ i.e. during the night; see note on ch. 50, 13: but perhaps simply ‘continued their march.’ They had taken the longer and more level road by Nemea. The tenses throughout, as in all military descriptions, are to be carefully watched.

kate/labon—‘found’, sc. there: in this sense, as Classen points out, this verb is generally followed by a participle or some note of place. kataba/ntes—sc. the Argives. They had marched down from Nemea at once, and were now getting into battle array.

e)n me/sw| de/—on the south the Spartans under Agis occupied the plain, and cut them off from Argos; to the west the Corinthians occupied the mountain ridges, and threatened their flank; while from the north the Boeotian cavalry and the rest of that division were closing on their rear.

to\ de/—iv. 108, 1, ta\ pro\s *)hio/na throume/nwn. pro\s *neme/as—iv. 100, 3, to\ pro\s e(autw=n a)/kron. i(/ppoi de/—there was then no Peloponnesian cavalry on either side. 20 ou)x ou(/tw—as we say ‘not so great’=not very; so non ita: ii. 11, 6, ou)d) e)pi\ a)du/naton ou(/tw po/lin. Such expressions are elliptical, at any rate originally. e)n kalw=|—under favourable conditions, see ch. 46, 8.
a)peilhfe/nai—sc. au)toi/: the construction reverts to the original subject, as if the clause with a)lla/ were a mere parenthesis, e(no/mizon or e)do/koun being supplied.

tw=n pe/nte strathgw=n—seemingly corresponding to the pe/nte lo/xoi, ch. 72, 24. Arnold says these were not originally military but political divisions. The strategi at Argos, as at Athens, were probably the heads of the war department.

o(/son ou)—iv. 36, 1, e)s to\n o(/son ou) paro/nta po/lemon. cunio/ntwn—iv. 94, 2, h)/dh mello/ntwn cunie/nai. mh\ poiei=n ma/xhn —the active is used of the commander who orders or brings on the battle; so iv. 91, 2. ma/xhn poiei=sqai is ‘to fight’, as in ch. 65, 20. In construction the infinitive depends on the sense of requesting implied in dielege/sqhn.
di/kas.. dou=nai—see ch. 27, 14. e)pikalou=sin—i. 139, 2, e)pikalou=ntes e)pergasi/an *megareu=si: iv. 133, 1, without dative of the person expressed: see ch. 83, 17.

oi( me/n—answered by oi( de/, line 10. These particles mark the two main antithetical divisions of the chapter. On the one hand the Argive chiefs acted independently, and so did Agis in accepting their proposals; on the other hand the Lacedaemonians, though they obeyed Agis, were indignant at his conduct, and the Argives were no less enraged with Thrasyllus and Alciphron.

tw=n *)argei/wn—partitive genitive dependent on oi( tau=ta ei)po/ntes: cf. iii. 28, 2, oi( de\ pra/cantes ma/lista pro\s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous tw=n *mutilhnai/wn. There seems no ground for taking tw=n *)argei/wn as dependent on tau=ta, as Classen does; or for omitting the words, as others propose. They are in fact necessary to make the sense clear. a)f) e(autw=n—‘of themselves’, on their own authority; iv. 68, 2, a)f) e(autou= gnw/mhs.
kai\ o( *)=agis—‘and Agis likewise’; this is a subordinate part of the main division under me/n. au)to/s—‘by himself’, on his own authority. ou)de/—no more than the two Argives.

a)ll) h)/—‘except’; ch. 80, 8: iii. 71, 1, mhdete/rous de/xesqai a:ll) h)\ mia=| nhi) h:suxa/zontas. koinw/sas—without an ex
pressed object, as we say ‘having communicated with’: so iv. 2, 1, etc. tw=n e)n te/lei—two ephors, besides other officials, accompanied the king on service. They are enumerated in Arnold's note. Classen suggests custrateuome/nw| as a possible alteration for custrateuome/nwn.

e)/dei—‘they were to’, as arranged with Agis. tw=n a)/llwn cumma/xwn—as opposed to the Lacedaemonians. a)/llos is used, as in i. 128, 5, kru/fa tw=n a)/llwn cumma/xwn, for the sake of sharper contrast. Kruger suggests cunarxo/ntwn or cumbou/lwn, but no change seems required.

e)n ai)ti/a|—i. 35, 4, e)n plei/oni ai)ti/a| u(ma=s e(/comen: so infr. line 25. paratuxo/n—so i. 76, 2: line 29, parasxo/n. au)tw=n ineans the Argives and their allies: it is a good instance of the sense of this word being gathered from the context. a)/cion—so v. 34, 1, a)/cia th=s prosdoki/as: vi. 21, 1, a)/cion th=s dianoi/as.

strato/pedon ..cunh=lqen—this clause resembles i. 1, 2, ki/nhsis ga\r au(/th megi/sth dh\ toi=s *(/ellhsin e)ge/neto: where Classen collects a number of similar sentences, e.g. i. 50, 2, naumaxi/a ga\r au(/th megi/sth dh\ tw=n pro\ au)th=s gege/nhtai. In these instances the pronoun (tou=to), which is the subject, is placed between the substantive (strato/pedon), which is appositional, and a superlative (ka/lliston) which with the verb (cunh=lqen) forms the predicate. *(ellhniko/n is appositional with a limiting force: the whole being equivalent to tou=to ka/lliston h)=n tw=n *(ellhnikw=n stratope/dwn a(\ me/xri tou=de cunh=lqen. The initial substantive from its position is in effect like a genitive plural (stratope/dwn), introducing a general idea of which a particular case is to be described. Classen also cites a few variations from the regular arrangement.

ka/lliston tw=n—see last note: so i. 1, 1, a)ciologw/taton tw=n progegenhme/nwn, where Classen compares Tac. Hist. i. 50, solus omnium ante se principum. Milton imitates the construction: Paradise Lost, iv. 324, Adam the goodliest of men since born His sons, the fairest of her daughters Eve. So Midsummer Night's Dream, v. 1. 239, This is the greatest error of all the rest. This army was ka/lliston, being composed of picked troops. Others may have been larger, for instance the force under Pausanias at Plataea.

w)/fqh—sc. ka/lliston o)/n. a)qro/on—apparently the whole force was collected at Nemea, after withdrawing from before Argos; or e)n may simply mean ‘near’. The army then marched away by the regular Nemean road, and broke up. e)n w)=|—when the divisions were united. The phrase refers to circumstances previously mentioned; iv. 18, 2, e)n w(=| pa=si to\ au)to\ o(moi/ws u(pa/rxei. Krüger renders it ‘at which point’, saying that parh=san would be required if time were meant.

panstratia=|—both position and sense show that this belongs to the Lacedaemonians only, who had marched out pandhmei/: see ch. 57. The Phliasians, it is true, had called out their whole force, but here they are merely named in the general list of the allies, the rest of whom were represented by picked contingents. Those editors who refer panstratia=| to all the nominatives are obliged to render it ‘with all the troops they had in the field’; which is simply explaining the word away.

kai\ ou)=toi—‘these also being picked men’, in apposition to the preceding subjects. a)cio/maxoi dokou=ntes—‘looking a match,’ rather than ‘thinking themselves’, cf. w)/fqh supra. kai\ a(/llh|—this is the manuscript reading, and represents a/cio/maxoi e)do/koun ei)=nai kai\ a)/llh| cummaxi/a| prosgenome/nh| (= ei) prosge/noito), which is perfectly good Greek and gives a satisfactory sense. Krüger however and others adopt ka)\n a)/llh|, on the ground that the idea represented is kai\ a)/llh| a)\n a)cioma/xoi e)do/koun ei)=nai ei) prosege/neto. I cannot see that the alteration is necessary, or even desirable: cf. note on teixisqe/n, ch. 52, 17; and Goodwin § 213—217, for a)/n with participles.

strato/pedon—followed by the plural; so i. 89, 3, *)aqhnai/wn to\ koino/n...diekomi/zonto: iii. 80, 1, o( dh=mos...h)/|esan e)s lo/gous. a)nexw/roun, like ei(/ponto, line 11, denotes the beginning and continuance of the retreat.

kai\ au)toi/—‘on their own part also’. kai\ e)kei=noi—i.e, no less than the Lacedaemonians, with whom they are emphatically contrasted by the use of this pronoun; cf. iv. 73, 4, oi( *)aqhnai=oi...h(su/xazon kai\ au)toi/...logizo/menoi kai\ oi( e/kei/nwn strathgoi/, where both au)toi/ and e)kei/nwn refer to the Athenians. See also note on iv. 37, 2, paradou=nai sfa=s au)tou\s *)aqhnai/ois w)/ste bouleu=sai o(/ ti a)\n e)kei/nois dokh=|: and of Shilleto on i. 132, 3.

mh\ a)\n...parasxo/n—‘when they never could have had a better chance’; see Krüger on i. 76, 1, eu)= i)/smen mh\ a)\n h(=sson u)ma=s luphrou\s genome/nous: and note on ch. 49, 24. For a)/n with a participle, see Goodwin § 41, 3: and for parasxo/n cf. ch. 14, 14.

e)n tw=| *xara/drw|—the bed of a winter torrent, which flows close under the walls of Argos. ‘The military courts were held without the city, because within the walls the ordinary law, with its forms and privileges, would have resumed its authority...So also the Comitia Centuriata at Rome always met in the Campus Martius without the walls, because their original character and divisions were military’ (Arnold).
stratei/as—most MSS have stratia=s, the usual confusion. perigi/gnetai—‘saves his life’: Hdt. ix. 121, a)podw/sw ta/lanta dih/kosia perigeno/menos, ‘if my life be spared’.

*la/xhs—most probably the same who commanded the first expedition to Sicily (iii. 86, 1), and was superseded by Pythodorus. His name appears among the signatories to the treaty and alliance in ch. 19 and 24. Nicostratus was sent to Corcyra in 427 (iii. 75); was employed on the Laconian coast in 424 (iv. 53); and in the Macedonian expedition in 423 (iv. 129 sq.).
o(/mws—though indignant and disgusted at the arrangement made; cf. ch. 46, 4: iii. 28, 2, e)pi) tou\s bwmou\s o(/mws kaqi/zousi, i.e. although terms had been promised.

xrhmati/sai—ch. 5, 3. pri
 h)/—Lid. and Scott say pri
 h)/ ‘occurs here and there in Attic Greek, from which it is sometimes removed by correction: it is common in later Greek’. This, if right, is a solitary instance in Thucydides. Perhaps pri
 dh/, which is common, or pri
 oi( should be read. For pri/n with the indicative, in the sense of ‘until’, referring to a definite past action, see i. 51, 1: ii. 65, 2, etc. It generally follows a negative (Goodwin § 634).

e)/ti ga/r—ch. 58, 5. presbeutou= paro)ntos—‘being there in the capacity of envoy’; and no longer holding a military command. Stahl proposes pario/ntos ‘coming forward’ to speak, but this is no improvement. The statement that Alcibiades was the representative of Athens implies that he was spokesman.

e)/n te toi=s—=e)n toi=s te. Classen considers tau=ta unsatisfactory and reads tau)ta/, believing that separate assemblies
were held, which is also suggested by te and kai/. Most authorities suppose that the allies were merely present in the Argive assembly.

ou)k o)rqw=s ai( spondai/—the influence of the ‘wrongful truce’, which stands first in order, is felt throughout the sentence, though the wording is modified in the second part. a)/neu—so ch. 60, 28 iv. 78, 3, a)/neu tou= pa/ntwn koinou=.

kai\ ge/nointo—probably kai/, in the sense of ‘both’ connects this with kai\ nu=n k.t.l., the conjunctions coupling the two points on which the Athenians insist, the wrong already done them by the treaty, and the present obligation of immediate action. kai/ is then irregularly placed, as noted on ch. 16, 15, and stands where it does to emphasize the antithesis. Krüger however holds that kai/ simply emphasizes ge/nointo, the sense being that ‘even the making of the truce was a wrong’.

kai\ nu=n xrh=nai—the construction with o(/ti is now dropped, as in i. 87, 4, e)/legon o(/ti dokoi=en bou/lesqai de/. a(/ptesqai—viii. 92, 4, h(/ptonto tw=n pragma/twn: so i. 49 fin. e)/rgou ei)/xeto.

pei/santes—the subject at first is the Athenians alone, then by apposition it expands into pa/ntes: cf. iv. 69, 1, gno/ntes de\ oi( strathgoi/. h( strati/a...a)pestau/roun: so in iv. 108, 3, ei)wqo/tes oi( a)/nqrwpoi, where certain particular colonists are the original subject of the sentence.

e)k tw=n lo/gwn—F. compares two instances of e)k with pei/qw, to denote the ground of persuasion; vii. 48, 3, e)k tou/twn au)tou\s pei/sesqai: viii. 47, 1, pei=sai e)k tou= toiou/tou. Otherwise the meaning might be ‘after the conference’; see also ch. 113, 1.

to\n *)arkadiko/n—as distinguished from Orchomenos in Boeotia, iii. 87, 4. o(/mws kai\ peisqe/ntes—though convinced they still hung back: Krüger compares Soph. Oed. Col. 666, o(/mws de\ kamou= mh\ paro/ntos tou)mo\n fula/cei s' o)/noma.

proskaqezo/menoi—the accusative construction is found with this word in i. 26, 5: i. 61, 2. The same participle occurs also in i. 11, 4: i. 126, 4: i. 134, 2; in each case with some tense of poliorkei=n or with a similar word. The form is aorist; see Vertch's Irregular Greek Verbs.

a)/llws te...kai\ h)=san—Poppo says ‘noli o(/ti expectare’, and compares i. 110, 2, tou=ton de\ dia\ me/geqos te tou= e(/lous ou)k
e)du/nanto e(lei=n, kai\ a(/ma maximw/tatoi/ ei)si tw=n *ai)gupti/wn oi( e(/leioi: vii. 47, 2, th=s te w)/ras tau/ths ou)/shs...kai\ to\ xwri/on a)/ma e(lw=des h)=n: so Tac. Hist. i. 76, penes Othonem manebant, non partium studio. sed erat grande momentum in nomine urbis. prosgene/sqai—ch. 32, 11.

kei/menoi—here and in vi. 61, 3, kei=mai does duty as the perfect passive of katati/qesqai, the regular word for bestowing hostages. dei/santes—see note on dediw/s, ch. 8, 5. plh=qos refers to the (small) force in Orchomenos; so iv. 10, 4, a)ntipa/lous tw=| h(mete/rw| plh/qei.

mh\ proapo/lwntai—sc. before help arrived. The subjunctive depends on dei/santes by a modification of construction. The clause with w(s gives the reason of their alarm, ‘as they saw no prospect of succour’.
w(/ste—iv. 46, 2, cune/bhsan w(/ste paradou=nai. *mantineu=si—‘the Mantineans, as the most powerful of the Arcadian allies, are given the charge of these Arcadian hostages’ (F).

e)f) o(/ ti xrh/—Classen collects instances to show that xrh/ is regularly thus used in reporting deliberation; e.g. i. 40, 5, e)yhfisme/nwn ei/ xrh\ au)toi=s a)mu/nein: see ch. 63, 10. e)ke/leuon— i)e/nai is omitted, as with e)yhfi/santo infr.
prose/qento—vi. 50, 1, prose/qeto th=| *)alkibia/dou gnw/mh|: so absolutely ‘to vote’ i. 20, 4, mia=| yh/fw| prosti/qesqai.

*tegeatw=n—Classen follows Stahl in reading tw=n for (*tegea)tw=n, believing that the reading came from *tege/a|, a gloss on po/lei. e)nedi/dosan—the imperfect denotes intention or arrangement; so iv. 76, 2, *xairw/neian a)/lloi e)nedi/dosan. For the uses of e)ndou=nai see note on iv. 66, 2.

*lakedaimo/nioi de/—see ch. 60, 12 and 25. This first sentence deals in a parenthetical way with the state of feel
ing in Sparta before Orchomeuos fell. e)c *)/argous—from the neighbourhood or district of Argos; the converse of the use of e)n noted on ch. 55, 2. xeirwsa/menon sfi/sin—so iv. 28, fin.

parasxo\n kalw=s—ch. 60, 29: cf. 14, 14. This phrase would naturally be answered by w(s ou)/pw pro/teron, sc. pare/sxen. Here however we have w:s <*>e/no/mizon, sc. parasxei=n. The construction is somewhat harsh, and Kruger brackets au)toi\ e)no/mizon. It is also suggested to insert w(s before au)toi/. Note that ou)/pw pro/teron with a relative occurs twice in this chapter, and in 64, 7.
labei=n—‘to get’ or ‘find’, with a)qro/ous. like Hdt. i. 116, to\n bouko/lon mo/non labw/n. Classen compares ch. 102, 2, and vi. 86, 3, o(/tan kairo\n la/bwsi, but these instances are not analogous.

h)gge/lleto—the imperfects in this sentence are to be noticed, ‘when news of the capture of Orchomenos went on to arrive’, etc. For the explanatory infinitive e(alwke/nai cf. i. 50, 1, pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous e)tra/ponto foneu/ein: see Krüger's Grammar § 61. 6, 8.

e)bou/leuon—for this use of the active where we might expect the middle, see note on iv. 15, 1. para\ to\n tro/pon— they were usually slow and deliberate; see i. 132, 5, xrw/menoi tw=| tro/pw|, w(=|per ei/w/qasin e)s sfa=s au)tou\s, mh\ taxei=s e)=nai peri\ a)ndro\s *spartia/tou bouleu=sai/ ti a)nh/keston.
de/ka muria/si—‘about £6700, supposing the sum to be given in Aeginetan drachmae’ (Jowett). For the dative cf. ii. 65, 2, e)zhmi/wsan xrh/masi: so fugh=|, iv. 65, 3.

r(u/sesqai—‘atone for’ or ‘do away with’ is the sense required, and the scholiast explains r(u/sesqai by a)polu/sein. It is suggested that it may have been the actual expression used by Agis. r(u/omai in Homer and Herodotus means to set free or redeem, e.g. from slavery, and the idea of retrieving a fault might thus come in. Poppo says that the word is found in later historians such as Diodorus and Herodian. Dobree proposed lu/sesqai, comparing a)pelu/santo, ch. 75, 13, and similar phrases.

strateusa/menos—‘when he had taken the field’ i.e. if again placed at the head of an army. The best manuscripts have strateuso/menos, and some editors read strateuo/menos. h)\=‘or else’; i. 78, 3, etc.

poiei=n—‘let them do’, dependent on the sense (=e)ke/leue) supplied from parh|tei=to, or simply representing the direct
imperative: so iv. 50, 3, pe/myai, ‘they must send’, appended to the account of a letter. The construction of the infinitive in treaties and laws is similar, e.g. ei)=nai line 18.

e)pe/sxon—ch. 32, 28. e)n tw= paro/nti—we are not told how long the law remained in force, or if it applied to other commauders besides Agis. No further mention is made of such cu/mbouloi, and Agis himself, when in command of the troops at Decelea, is found acting with full authority and independently of the home government; see especially viii. 5, 3; also ch. 66, 12.

cmmbou/lous—such commissioners are mentioned in ii. 85, 1: iii. 69, 1, and 76, 1, as appointed to assist Spartan naval commanders; and Plutarch (Per. c. 22) speaks of cu/mbouloi being sent with the young Pleistoanax when he invaded Attica in 445. The idea therefore was not altogether new.

ei)=nai—for the relative and infinitive in the report of a decree, cf. ii. 24, fin. w(=n mh\ xrh=sqai mhdemi/a|: so Dem. Lept. 505, § 158. e)/qhken e)f) oi(=s e)cei=nai a)poktinnu/nai (Goodwin § 756). a)pa/gein—i.e. he was not to begin any operations. As a)pa/gein is generally used not of marching out from home (e)ca/gein) but of withdrawing troops from an enemy's land, there is something to be said for Haase's conjecture e)k th=s polemi/as for e)k th=s po/lews. Can the last words be merely an explanatory gloss? The Spartans now hear of the danger of Tegea, and realize at length that the leadership of Peloponnesus is at stake. They accordingly act with unusual promptitude and vigour.

*)ore/sqeion—this town gave name to the district of Oresthis; iv. 134, 1; where see note. Pausanias speaks of a founder Orestheus, but Eur. Or. 1647 gives *)ore/steion from Orestes. th=s *mainali/as—w. of Tegea and N. W. of Sparta.

toi=s me\n *)arka/dwn—Krüger collects instances of this position of the partitive genitive in his note on i. 126, 5, oi/ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn e)pitetramme/noi th\n fulakh/n: so iv. 111. 2, oi( tw=n *torwnai/wn e)/ndoqen paraskeua/zontes.

a)qroisqei=si—as this is closely connected with the infinitive i)e/nai, we should expect the accusative; but the practice of Thucydides is not iuvariable. Thus in vii. 20, 1, w(=| ei/rhto... u)fikome/nw| parakalei=n is followed by ei)/rhto d) au)tw=| periple/onta custrateu/esqai: cf. i. 31, 2, e)/docen au)toi=s e)lqou=sin w:s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous cumma/xous gene/sqai. In iv. 5, 1, <*>rmh\ e)se/pese perista=sin e)kteixi/sai, the connexion of the dative is ambiguous.
kata\ po/das au)tw=n—‘to follow them closely’; iv. 126 fin. For au)tw=n referring to the primary subject, see ch. 32, 26, note.

to\ presbu/teron—=oi( presbu/teroi: cf. i. 105, 5, oi(/ te presbu/tatoi kai\ oi( new/tatoi: ii. 13, 7, tosou=toi e)fu/lasson a)po\ tw=n presbuta/twn kai\ newta/twn. Spartans were liable to serve abroad in emergency up to the age of 60, but in Athens men over 40 were usually exempt. See Müller's Dorians, Bk. iii. ch. 12.

toi=s me/n—answered by the clause *lakedaimo/nioi de/ k.t.l. e)c o)li/gou—‘at short notice’; iv. 108, 5: ii. 11, 3, e)c o)li/gou ta\ polla\ tw=n pole/mwn gi/gnetai. The subject of e)gi/gneto, ‘it came’, is implied in the context, as is common with ei)mi/ and gi/gnomai and with passives; see Krüger's Grammar, § 61. 5, 6.
mh\ a)qro/ois—‘unless they waited for one another and came all together’ (Jowett). Poppo notices the combination of an adjective and a participle: so iii. 69, 1, xeimasqei=sai kai\ spora/des.
th\n polemi/an—the districts north of Tegea generally, which either belonged to Argos or had joined the confederacy.

cune/klh|e—the object is implied in the context. The meaning is ‘it blocked their way’ or ‘closed them in’: further explained by dia\ me/sou, which denotes an ‘intervening’ obstacle: cf. Hdt. i. 104, e(\n to\ dia\ me/sou e)/qnos au)tw=n e)sti/, i. e. between Media and Colchis, the countries spoken of. Kruger takes cune/klh|e in a quasi-intransitive sense as in ch. 72, 9, ‘it closed in’, i. e. was continuous. The scholiast explains it by a)pe/kleie.

a)nalabo/ntes—ch. 7, 10. pro\s tw=| *(hraklei/w|—on the road from Tegea to Mantinea. Grote says ‘the Lacedaemonian kings appear to have felt a sense of protection in encamping near a temple of Heracles, their heroic progenitor (see Xen. Hell. vii. 1, 31)’.
katalabo/ntes—ch. 4, 15. The xwri/on e)rumno/n is said by Curtius to be the southern point of Alesium, a position of importance to Mantinea.

sfa=s—see note on iv. 36, 1, a)/llws e)/fh ponei=n sfa=s. kako
 kakw=| i)a=sqai—Classen compares Hdt. iii. 53, mh( tw=| kakw=| to\ kako
 i)w=: Soph. Aj. 362, mh\ kako
 kakw=| didou\s a)/kos ple/on to\ ph=ma th=s a)/ths ti/qei: Plat. Protag. 340 D, i)w/men<*>s mei=zon to\ no/shma poiw=.

dhlw=n—‘meauing that his present ill-timed forwardness was intended to retrieve the discredit incurred by his withdrawal from Argos’. dhlw=n here has the regular participial construction. For the infiuitive see iv. 38, 1, dhlou=ntes prosi/esqai.

e)paiti/ou—‘culpable’; more commonly used of persons who deserve or incur blame. a)na/lhyin—lit. ‘taking back’ i.e. retrieval. The word only occurs here in Thucydides. The verb is sometimes used in this sense, e.g. Soph. Phil. 1249, th\n a(marti/an a)nalabei=n peira/somai.

boulome/nhn—agreeing with a)na/lhyin: bou/lomai in this sense of ‘meaning’ or ‘professing to be’ is common in Plato and Aristotle; e.g. Rep. 595 c, ou)de( cunnow= ti/ bou/letai ei)=nai. e)qe/lw is similarly used. tou=to fronei=, ch. 85. 6, is somewhat similar. Here Classen and Stahl read boulo/menon, referring to Agis, the subject of dianoei=tai. The position of the word seems rather against the alteration.

ei)/te kai\...ei)/te kai/—so vi. 60, 2, ei)/te a)/ra kai\ ta\ o)/nta mhnu=sai ei)/te kai\ ou): so w)/sper kai\ ou(/tw kai/ and the like. ei)/te kai/—‘or because he himself changed his decision’; do/can is accusative absolute, as in viii. 79, 1: viii. 93, 1. Here it is personally constructed, with a)/llo, which is rare without w(s or w)sper: see note on kurwqe(n d) ou)de/n, iv. 125, 1; and Goodwin § 854. The words h)\ kata\ to\ au)to/ seem clumsy and unnecessary, but this is no proof that they are not genuine, and they are found in all the manuscripts. Stahl omits h)/ and refers kata\ to\ au)to/ to the same circumstance striking Agis and the veteran. h)\ kai\ to\ au)to/ is another suggestion; while Dobree would omit the words altogether.

e)cai/fnhs—by some editors taken with do/can, by others with a)ph=ge: the latter way seems to give a more forcible sense. It was the sudden change of tactics which surprised the Argives (line 23). kata\ ta/xos denotes the rapidity of the retreat.
