pro\s th\n *tegea=tin—i.e. at the border.—to\ u(/dwr—the plain of Mantinea, which was high level ground enclosed by mountains, had no outlet but by subterranean channels, such as are not uncommon in a lime-stone country. It is fully described in Arnold's interesting note.
e)ce/trepen—the imperfect here denotes the beginning of the operation, a little below its continuance.

ta\ polla/—‘mostly’. This leaves bla/ptontos without an object: Poppo therefore suggests omitting ta\, when polla\ bla/ptontos would mean ‘doing great damage’. With polemou=sin we might expect a)ei/ or some such phrase.

tou\s a)po/—with katabiba/sai: he wished to draw from the hill those who were on it; ch. 34, 1. bohqou=ntas e)pi/— predicate, ‘to (stop) the turning of the water’. The participle is not equivalent to the future, but is used as in iv. 25, 9, kate/bainon bohqou=ntes e)pi\ tou\s *messhni/ous. The descent from the hill would be in itself the beginning of the boh/qeia.

tou)s *)arge<*>ous k.t.l.—modern editors are disposed to omit these words as a mere explanatory gloss. Poppo however on i. 144, 2, gives several instances of similar apposition. They can scarcely be all interpolations, and are more probably due to the writer's mannerism; see note on iv. 114, 4. th\n ma/xhn=the impending engagement: so iii. 105, 4.

mei/nas—the aorist gives an ‘end-view’ (Clyde). Here, in combination with the imperfect, it either means ‘after halting’; or it regards the day's operations as ended, in which case e)ce/trepen=‘liad been diverting’.

kataplage/ntes—‘astounded’. e)c o)li/gou—usually of time, as in ch. 64, 20: ch. 72, 1. If this be the meaning here, ai)fnidi/w|, which is absent from one manuscript, should be omitted as an explanatory gloss. e)c o)li/gou however is used of space ii. 91, 3, pro\s th\n e)c o)li/gou a)nteco/rmhsin, and may be so understood here. It will then correspond to me/xri me\n li/qou k.t.l. line 5, while ai)fnidi/w| answers to e)cai/fnhs and kata\ ta/xos in line 12.
au)tw=n—the position of this word between th=| and a)naxwrh/sei seems due to the intervening words; so iv. 55, 3, para\ th\n u(pa/rxousan sfw=n i)de/an: see note on ch. 10, 48.

ou)k ei)=xon o(/ ti ei)ka/swsin—so ii. 52, 3, ou)k e)/xontes o(/ ti ge/nwntai. The deliberative subjunctive after a past tense, is a direct and vivid form of expression. ei)=ta (without de/) answers to to\ me\n prw=ton. Krüger suggested e)/peita as more in accordauce with Thucydidean usage, e.g. viii. 67, 2.

e)peidh/—note the tenses and the order of the words: a)naxwrou=ntes affects the whole sentence, though agreeing with e)kei=noi only. ‘Then, when the retreat went on, and the Spartans disappeared, while they found themselves standing still and no pursuit attempted’.

a)pe/kruyan—‘disappeared’, apparently a neuter usage, e(autou/s being understood. This is the scholiast's explanation, and it is supported by Hes. F<*>. 44, a)pokru/ptousi *peleia/des, quoted by Lid. and Scott. This view is simpler than to understand au)tou/s or *)argei/ous, on the analogy of the nautical use found Plat. Protag. 338 A, a)pokru/yanta gh=n ‘losing sight of land’: Luc. Ver. Hist. 2. 38, a)pekru/yamen au)tou/s: Verg. Aen. iii. 291, Phaeacum abscondimus arces. Besides, the point is that the Argives lost sight of the Spartans, not that the Spartans lost sight of the Argives.

sfei=s—i.e. au)toi/: rarely used, as Poppo notes, except in oratio obliqua, or with o(/ti in mixed constructions like liue 31. Here indeed this clause, like the two which conclude the sentence, seems to represent in a sort of half-direct way the actual thoughts or words of the troops.

e)n ai)ti/a| ei)=xon—ch. 60, 12 etc. Here the ground of blame follows with an accusative and aorist infinitive; cf. vii. 81, 1, e)n ai)ti/a| to\n *gu/lippon ei)=xon. a)fei=nai. Then the construction alters to o)/ti with the indicative, giving to some extent, as Classen points out, the effect of direct speech. The converse change from o(/ti to the infinitive is much more common: see ch. 61, 12.
to/ te pro/teron—see ch. 60. The sense is ‘as formerly ...so now’: see note on ch. 43, 15. For kalw=s cf. ch. 36, 21. so e)n kalw=| ch. 59, 21 etc.

o(/ti—according to Kruger, ‘because’; or else ‘that’; depending on ‘they complained’. In either case the irregular
transition to the present indicative has a striking and dramatic effect. a)podidra/skontas—a contemptuous word. kaq) h(suxi/an—ironical, ‘quietly and comfortably’.
e)qorubh/qhsan—‘were bewildered’ (Arnold); iii. 22, 6.
oi)/ te *)argei=oi—answered by oi(/ te *lakedaimo/nioi. h)\n peritu/xwsi—toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois (schol.). pro\s to\ *(hra/kleion— see the end of ch. 64.
di) o)li/gou=e/cai/fnhs, according to the scholiast: but plainly used here of an interval of space, ‘close at hand’; so ii. 89, 7 etc.: cf. iv. 14, 1, dia\ braxe/os.

ma/lista dh/—this abrupt beginning can scarcely be right, and some connecting word seems lost. ma/lista de/ and ma/lista de\ dh/ are suggestions, but not satisfactory. Krüger proposes to connect the clause with what goes before, inserting w(s before o(rw=si and putting a comma after proelhluqo/tas. But, as Poppo says, ‘comectura et audacior est, et propter iteratum Lacedaemoniorum nomen displicet’. e)s o(\ e)me/mnhnto—apparently ‘so far as they remembered’. The scholiast says meta\ th\n tw=n a)nqrw/pwn mnh/mhn, but where does the subject come from? The whole sentence indeed seems doubtful.

e)cepla/ghsan—the natural meaning is ‘were dismayed’, but this does not agree with what follows. On the contrary it is the excellent discipline and rapid formation of the Spartans which are described. e)kplh/ssw is used not only of fear but of any overpowering emotion, such as joy or love. The meaning here may be were ‘excited’, ‘startled’ from their usual slow and deliberate ways, so that they acted with unwonted vigour and alacrity (eu)qu\s u(po\ spoudh=s). e)/kplhcis certainly has some such force in iv. 14, 3, u(po\ proqumi/as kai\ e)kplh/cews: nor is there any idea of fear in kataplage/ntes, ch. 65, 23. By this view we get a satisfactory sense; and it is at any rate better than any of the suggested alterations, e.g. e)cefa/nhsan, ‘came out in their true colours’: e)chlla/ghsan, ‘were different from (surpassed) all others’: *lakedaimoni/ous ..e)cepla/ghsan, ‘they (the Argives) were struck with admiration of the Lacedaemonians’, and other desperate shifts. The passage seems however incomplete, and some words or lines may be missing.

dia/—adverbially used with the genitive. The sense is either ‘they had but short time to get ready’, or ‘they formed at once without delay’. u(po\ spoudh=s—iii. 33, 4, u(po\ spoudh=s e)poiei=to th\n di/wcin.
to\n e(autw=n—emphatic: so iv. 33, 2, th= sfete/ra| e)mpeiri/a| xrh/sasqai: iv. 55, 3, para\ th\n u(pa/rxousan sfw=n i)de/an th=s paraskeuh=s.

e(/kasta e)chgoume/nou—iii. 55, 4, a(\ e)/kastoi e)chgei=sqe toi=s cumma/xois: iii. 93, 2, e)/stin a(\ ou) kalw=s e)chgou/menoi. u(p) e)kei/nou pa/nta a)/rxetai—the passive a)/rxomai is used of persons rather than things: pa/nta may therefore have a personal meaning =‘all are under his orders’, not ‘everything is ordered’. Kruger suggests pa/nta a)/rxontai ‘they are entirely under his orders’: and Dobree would read a)p) e)kei/nou, ‘everything originates with him’. We have seen (ch. 63 fin.) that Agis had been put under the restriction of a military council, while the Spartan kings generally were shackled in the exercise of their power. Thucydides therefore points out that they still had absolute authority on the field of battle.

toi=s me\n polema/rxois—acting as generals of division. This is not the place to discuss the Spartan military organization, which is a rather complicated subject. Arnold and Grote have long notes on the present passage, and the recognized authorities are cited by Classen. See also Muller's Dorians Bk. iii. ch. 12. 14 fra/zei—‘orders’; iii. 15, 1, toi=s cumma/xois e)/frazon i)e/nai. to\ de/on—‘what is to be done’; orders in general, before the battle begins. penthkonth=rsin—found also Xen. Anab. iii. 4, 21: penthkosth/r is another form.

paragge/lseis—orders ‘passed along’ the line, as opposed to those given by herald or sound of trumpet: Xen. Anab. iv. 1, 5, a)nasta/ntes a)po\ paragge/lsews: cf. ch. 58, 18: 71, 21. taxei=ai—adjective with verb; iv. 126, 6, to\ a)ndrei=on o)cei=s e)ndei/knuntai: so with participle iv. 38, 3, o) teleutai=os diapleu/sas etc. e)pe/rxontai=traverse the line: Cobet proposes perie/rxontai.

sxedo/n ti—modifying pa=n: iii. 68, 4, sxedo
 ga/r ti kai\ to\ cu/mpan: vii. 33, 2, sxedo
 ga/r ti pa=sa. plh
 o)li/gou— this of course is not to be taken literally, as far the largest part of the army consisted of private soldiers. The meaning
is that the system of command within command extended throughout all ranks, and was peculiar to the Spartan organization. ‘In other Grecian armies orders were proclaimed to the troops in a loud voice by a herald, who received them personally from the general: each taxis or company had indeed its own taxiarch, but the latter did not receive his orders separately from the general, and seems to have had no personal responsibility for the execution of them by his soldiers’ (Grote, ch. 56).
to\ e)pimele/s—‘the charge of what is doing’; ch. 102, 4: see note on ch. 9, 14.
to/te de/—‘on this occasion’, apodosis to the general description just given. ke/ras eu)w/numon—predicate. The article is omitted, as in line 12, and often. au)toi=s—ch. 44, 7: see note on ch. 3, 24.

*skiri=tai—originally the inhabitants of the rugged district of Sciritis, on the northern border of Laconia. a)ei\ tau/thn ...e)/xontes—this privilege is only recorded here. though the Sciritae always appear as a separate band. e)pi\ sfw=n au)tw=n— ii. 63, 2, e)pi\ sfw=n au)tw=n au)to/nomoi: Hdt. ii. 2, e)p) e)wutw=n ke/esqai. Xen. An. ii. 4, 10, au)toi\ e)f) e)autw=n e)xw/roun. The preposition implies rest on, i.e. dependence, and so the phrase means ‘by themselves’, ‘independently’.

para\ d) au)toi=s—‘by them stood’. h)=san is to be supplied rather than kaqi/stanto: otherwise we should expect the accusative as in line 7. Poppo compares i. 48, 3, to\ me\n decio\n ai( *megari/des nh=es ei)=xon, kata\ de\ to\ me/son oi( a)/lloi cu/mmaxoi (sc. h)=san or e)ta/canto). He adds however that e)n as well as e(s ‘apud similia verba collocandi et considendi reperitur’.

e)pi\ *qra/|khs—the stock phrase for the ‘Thraceward’ regions seems here appropriated to Brasidas' Thracian troops; see ch. 35, 11 and 25. Otherwise we might adopt the correction a)po/ (ch. 35, 33) or e)k. neodamw/deis—ch. 34, 8.

au)toi/—‘veri et proprii, qui discernuntur a superioribus hominibus, quos minus proprie Lacedaemonios nominaveris’ (Poppo). *(hraih=s—from Heraea, in the valley of the Alpheus, near the borders of Triphylia. For *maina/lioi see ch. 64, 9.

e)pi\ tw=| deciw=|—‘The Tegeatae claimed an honourable post in the Peloponnesian armies, from their services in the times of the invasion by the Heracleidae: see Hdt. ix. 26. But, to save the sovereign dignity of the Lacedaemonians, the most honourable post of all, the extreme right wing, was held by Lacedaemonian soldiers. A similar compliment was paid to the Athenians by the Acarnanians and their confederates at the battle of Olpae; iii. 107, 7’ (Arnold).
i(pph=s—in 424 the Spartans set up a force of 400 horse para\ to\ ei)wqo/s (iv. 55, 1). The cavalry was usually placed on the wings.

oi( e)nanti/oi—appositionally resolved in the following clauses: i. 89 fin. oi)ki/ai ai( me\n pollai\...o)li/gai de/. Krüger brackets the following au)toi=s, as not supported by Thucydidean usage. Note the omission of the article with decio\n ke/ras.

to\ e)/rgon—‘the action’: iv. 34, 3 etc. para\ d) au)tou/s— here, with h)=san, we might expect au)toi=s, as para/ with the accusative has the idea of motion to or extent along: cf. however vi. 57, 3, perie/tuxon tw=| *(ippa/rxw| para\ (peri\?) to\ *aewko/rion: Xen. Anab. in. 4, 9, par' au)th
 th
 po/lin h)=n purami/s. Or we may say that previous motion is implied, as in iii. 3, 4, trih/reis ai(\ e)/tuxon para\ sfa=s parou=sai: para\ th
 e)/palcin katakei/menos (Ar. Ach. 72) is ‘extended along’. Krüger suggests omitting h)=san. *)arka/dwn is partitive genitive, as in line 7: cf. ch. 37, 25.

loga/des, oi(=s h: po/lis—a regular force, selected from the wealthier classes, and strongly aristocratic in feeling. After this they helped the Spartans to overthrow the democratic constitution: see Arnold. e)k pollou=—‘from some time back’; i.e. they were kept in regular training: so ch. 69, 21.

*klewnai=oi—Cleone and Orneae lay northwards of Argolis, in the direction of Corinth. The inhabitants appear to have been at this time subject allies, and to have been afterwards absorbed by Argos. The authorities are fully discussed in Arnold.
oi( oi)kei=oi—the Argives had no cavalry force; ch. 15, 18.
h(/de—usually ‘as follows’; we should expect au(/th: so toia/de is ‘as follows’, toiau=ta ‘as aforesaid’, but the practice is not invariable.
paraskeuh/—‘force’; in reference to the several contingents on either side. ta/cis is their respective disposition in the opposing lines.
mei=zon e)fa/nh—‘looked bigger’, i. e., as Classen says, its superiority struck the eye: so i. 8, 1, *ka=res e)fa/nhsan, ‘proved (were seen to be) Carians’.
e(kate/rwn—may depend either on a)riqmo/n or e(ka/stous: I think the latter. cu/mpantas—governed by gra/yai and standing in apposition to a)riqmo/n, instead of being governed by it.

ou)k a)\n e)duna/mhn—sc. ei) e)pexei/roun or ei) e)boulo/mhn: ‘unfulfilled condition’. Classen considers this construction here inadmissible, and follows Stahl in reading ou)k a)\n dunai/mhn, which is free from difficulty, but not necessarily what Thucydides wrote. Krüger points out that e)duna/mhn without a)/n might give a statement of actual fact; cf. cune/graye, i. 1, 1.

e)s ta\ oi)kei=a plh/qh—Krüger and others suspect plh/qh, and render e)s ta\ oi:kei=a ‘in respect of their own affairs’ (generally). Whether plh/qh be retained or not to\ plh=qos is supplied as subject to h)pistei=to. Classen however reads e)s ta\ oi)kei=a, ta\ plh/qh, ‘the several estimates of number were distrusted’. Note the o(moiote/leuton (Ar. Rhet. iii. 9, 9) h)gnoei=to...h)pistei=to.
parageno/menon—‘brought into the field’. So in the orators oi( paro/ntes are literally ‘the (witnesses) present’, oi( parageno/menoi ‘those called in’. ga/r ushers in the promised statement.
zugw=|—‘rank’. Liddell and Scott give no other instance of this use in classical Greek.

e)pi\ de\ ba/qos...o)ktw/—this statement is puzzling and is discussed at length by Grote and others. It may mean, as Jowett suggests, that in some cases one part of the line was deepened at the expense of another, and the rear rank of one
e)nwmoti/a posted behind another. Or possibly the ranks behind the first did not invariably contain four men. Thus an arrangement of 4, 3, 4 etc. would give 9 rows amounting to 32 men in all. But we must remember that Thucydides is not so much discussing the order of the Spartan soldiers, as furnishing an estimate of their numbers. He ‘could not do this exactly’, but he guarantees three things, the number of e)nwmoti/ai, viz. 112; the number of men, 448, in the front rank; and the average (e)pi\ pa=n) depth, viz. 8. Now, if the number of men in each e)nwmoti/a was the same, we have not merely an approximate calculation, but an exact one, the very thing which Thucydides disclaims. May it not then have been the case that, in one or more of the lo/xoi, the e)nwmoti/ai consisted of a number more or less than the standard 32? This would be a part of the ‘system of secrecy’ (th=s politei/as to\ krupto/n); and if it was privately managed by the military authorities we can see at once how the total number was ‘kept dark’ (h)gnoei=to). According to the text this arrangement was left to the respective loxagoi/; but it may be that the clause a)ll) w(s loxago\s e(/kastos e)bou/leto is spurious, as Dobree suspected. The e)nwmoti/a or ‘section’, which was ‘the unit of the Spartan army’, undoubtedly varied in size at different periods; and may possibly have varied in different lo/xoi or ‘regiments’ at the same period. This explanation seems not unreasonable: for if Thucydides had been sure of the number of men in each e)nwmoti/a, why did he not state it, instead of only giving the number in the front rank?

e)pi\ pa=n—‘generally’; ii. 51, 1, toiou=ton h)=n e)pi\ pa=n th\n i)de/an (several examples in Kruger). e)pi\ o)ktw/—‘eight deep’. In this sense e)pi/ takes either the genitive or accusative: vii. 79, 1, ou)k e)p) o)li/gwn a)spi/dwn, ‘in a deep column’: iv. 93, 4, e)p) a)spi/das pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi *qhbai=oi e)ta/canto.

para\ a(/pan—‘along the whole line’. A front of 448 men with an average depth of eight, 600 Sciritae being added, makes the Lacedaemonian division 4184 strong. h)=n—Xen. Cyr. ii. 1, 25, h( ta/cis h)=n e(kato\n a)/ndres: Prop. v. 1, 14, centum illi in prato saepe senatus erat.

paraine/seis—the usual addresses which Greek soldiers expected before an engagement: cf. iv. 95, 1, di) o)li/gou h) parai/nesis gi/gnetai: iv. 93, 1, toiau=ta paraine/sas. parake/leusis and parakeleu/esqai are used in the same way.

kai\ u(pe\r a)rxh=s a(/ma—‘and withal for empire or subjection’. The following explanatory infinitives are connected with h( ma/xh e)/stai, as in ii. 89, 10, o( a)gw\n me/gas h)\ katalu=sai...h)\ katasth=sai.

peirasame/nois—‘after once enjoying it’, i.e. after once gaining the position of a sovereign state; see ch. 29. The alternative was sinking again into political subordination to Sparta. For the dative we might expect peirasame/nous: but see note on ch. 64, 10.

*)argei/ois de/—sc. parai/nesis e)gi/gneto: the construction with u)pe/r, and the following infinitives, being connected with this rather than with h( ma/xh e)/stai. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois ..ei)=nai, line 11, depends on the same.

th=s palaia=s h(gemoni/as—under the Atreidae. The claim of i)somoiri/a was made in the days of the Persian invasion: see Hdt. vii. 148, where the Argives were willing to join Sparta, h(geo/menoi kata\ to\ h(/misu ta/shs th=s summaxi/hs: kai/toi kata/ ge to\ di/kaion gi/gnesqai th\n h(gemoni/hn e(wutw=n, a)ll) o(/mws sfi/sin a)poxra=n kata\ to\ h(/misu h(geome/noisi.

dia\ panto/s—‘always’: iv. 61, 4, pe/fuke to\ a(nqrw/peion dia\ panto\s a)/rxein tou= ei)/kontos: so i. 38, 1. a)stugei/tonas—cf. iv. 92, 3, *)aqhnai/ous de\ kai\ prose/ti o:mo/rous o)/ntas pollw=| ma/lista (a)mu/nesqai) dei=: vi. 88, 1, toi=s *surakosi/ois a)ei\ kata\ to\ o(/moron dia)foroi. The aorist a)mu/nasqai implies ‘once for all’, that is, in the coming battle.
kai\ o(/ti—The sentence now takes a sort of semi-direct form of expression. e)n *peloponnh/sw|—thus turning the tables on the Spartans; hitherto the Athenians had only attacked the enemy's coast.

ou) mh/—this strong negative occurs only in one other passage, iv. 95, 2, where Hippocrates addresses the Atheniansin
much the same words; h)\n nikh/swmen ou) mh/ pote u(mi=n *peloponnh/sioi e)s th\n xw/ran ..e)sba/lwsin. There is the same ethical dative in both sentences, au)toi=s=‘they would have them’.

kaq) e(ka/stous—usually taken of the Lacedaemonian soldiers exhorting one another ‘man by man’. Herbst and Classen however seem right in understanding the plural, as in ch. 68, 4, rather of the ‘several contingents’ of the army, who are all included under the name of Lacedaemonians, as they are in the beginning of the next chapter. The main constiuction of the sentence belongs to the divisions with te and kai/ alike, while meta\ tw=n polemikw=n no/mwn is specially connected with e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s, the Lacedaemonians themselves.

polemikw=n no/mwn—war-songs, according to the scholiast; ta\ a)/smata a(/per h)=|don oi( *aakedaimo/nioi me/llontes ma/xesqai. Kruger however takes the meaning to be ‘military usages’, on the ground that the war-songs would not come in till the actual onset.

w(=n h)pi/stanto k.t.l —‘called on their trusty comrades to remember what they knew so well’=parekeleu/onto memnh=sqai. a)gaqoi=s ou)=sin is taken by Poppo and others as agreeing with sfi/sin au)toi=s. It seems however rather governed by th\n parake/leusin e)poiou=nto: and is a sort of semi-quotation, representing parakeleuo/meqa u(mi=n a)gaqoi=s ou)=sin. Some editors however find a difficulty in the words, and sundry unsatisfactory suggestions and emendations are noted in Classen and Fowler. Arnold compares with the present passage iv. 95, 1, h( parai/nesis. .pro\s tou\s a)gaqou\s a)/ndras . u(mo/mnhsin ma=llon e)/xei h)\ e)pike/leusin: so vi. 68, 4, th=s u(mete/ras au)tw=n a)ci/as mnhsqe/ntes e)pe/lqete toi=s e)nanti/ois.

ei)do/tes e)/rgwn...parai/nesin—note the triple antithesis in this sentence. For e)k pollou= cf. ch. 67, 15. 2 h( cu/nodos h)=n, *)argei=oi—construction in accordance with the sense (pro\s to\ shmaino/menon): cf. iv. 23, 2, ta\ peri\ *pu/lon e)poleme<*>to, *)aqhnai=oi me/n k.t.l. Poppo adds Tac. Hist. i. 19, patrum favor aderat, multi etc.

e)nto/nws—only here in Thucydides, who does not use the adjective at all: Xen. Anab. vii. 5, 7, e)nto/nws a(ph/|tei to\n misqon. o)rgh=|—vii. 68, 1, o)rgh=| prosmi/cwmen. Jowett renders ‘with great fury and determination’.

u(po\ au)lhtw=n—‘to the accompaniment of many fluteplayers stationed in the ranks according to custom’: cf. Xen. Hell. ii. 2, 23, ta\ tei/xh kate/skapton u(p) au)lhtri/dwn: see also Liddell and Scott for the general use of the preposition to denote anything attendant. For no/mw| the best manuscripts have no/mou, and two have o(mou=. no/mou may be retained in the sense of tune (see ch. 68, 18) as governed by u(po/: but e)gkaqestw/twn would thus stand rather awkwardly by itself. Arnold cites Hdt. vi. 60, to show that the flute-players were a separate caste in Sparta as they were in Egypt.

ou) tou= qei/ou xa/rin—the editors quote A. Gellius i. 2, 1, non prorsus ex aliquo ritu religionum neque rei divinae gratia. o(/per filei=—iv. 125, 1, o(/per filei= mega/la strato/peda ..e)kplh/gnusqai. Classen points out (i. 78, 2) that Thucydides always uses filei=n in this sense, in which it occurs more than a dozen times. He adds that it is only used once by Herodotus (v. 5) in the sense of loving, elsewhere of being wont, as here. For poiei=n we might expect pa/sxein: so in line 2 of the next chapter. Poppo cites (from Duker) Ar. Plut. 1204, polu\ tw=n a)/llwn xutrw=n tananti/a au(=tai poiou=si.

toio/nde—the explanation is given in line 16, dei/sas de\ *(=agis, the construction beginning afresh with kai\ to/te after the parenthetical intioduction. Otherwise the words would run toio/nde e)bouleu/sato dra=sai: dei/sas mh/ k.t.l. We have a similar sentence in iv. 67, 2, oi( prodido/ntes toio/nde e)poi/hsan: a)ka/tion .. ei)w(qesan katakomi/zein:...kai\ to/te: cf. vi. 88, 1, oi( *kamarinai=oi e)pepo/nqesan toio/nde: toi=s me\n *)aqhnai/ois eu)/noi h)=san. So Hdt. i. 80, e)poi/hse toio:nde: <*>sai k.t.l.: cf. Xen. Anab. v. 4, 31, ta\ de\ plei=sta toia/de h)=n tw=n xwri/wn: a)pei=xon: Other instances of ‘asyndeton’ are cited by Kuhner on Xen. Anab. iv. 7, 10, mhxana=tai/ ti: proe/trexen k.t.l.
e)bouleu/sato—‘decided’; ii. 74, 1: iv. 57, 4. Sudden change of purpose at a crisis was characteristic of Agis; see ch. 60 and 65.

poiei= me/n—this would be regularly answered by to/te de\ kai\ oi( *mantinh=s, but the construction is dropped. kai\ a(/panta— ‘all without exception do this’; iv. 23, 3, th=s nukto\s kai\ a(/pasai periw/rmoun. tou=to—explained by what follows without a connecting word: so vi. 36, 2, ai( a)ggeli/ai tou=to du/nantai: ou)k a)po\ tau)toma/tou cu/gkeintai: cf. ii. 36, 4, o(\ nu=n u(mei=s dra=te a)fi/esqe: vi. 11, 4, o(/per nu=n u(mei=s pepo/nqate .e)fi/esqe: Xen. Cyr. ii. 3, 4, ou(/tw pws e)poi/hse di/dwsi: cf. note on line 1.

au(tw=n—the position of au(tw=n is due to the insertion of decio/n, otherwise ta\ au(tw=n ke/rata is the regular order, as in line 24: cf. iv. 43, 3, tw=| eu)wnu/mw| ke/ra| e(autw=n. As a general principle the genitive of a personal pronoun and au)tou= stands after the substantive on which it depends, or before the article; while the genitive of reflexive and demonstrative pronouns follows the article. Thus we have h( glw=ssa/ sou, kalai) nw=|n ai( gunai=kes, o: path au/tou=: but fu(latte to
 sautou= tro/pon, e(s ko/smon to
 e(autw=n, o( tou/tou path/r, h( a)llh/lwn dikaiosu/nh. There are however instances where this usage is disregarded for the sake of emphasis or otherwise. Thus, a)nepikou/rhton seautou= to
 bi/on lh/sh| poiw=n, where seautou= has a force like that of an ethical dative. Again, with an additional word the position of au)tou= may be changed, gnw/sesqe th
 a)llhn au)tou= ponhri/an, an exact converse of the present passage: so iv. 55, 3, para\ th
 u(pa/rxousan sfw=n i)de/an: cf. ch. 43, 14. Full illustrations of all these usages may be found in Kruger's Grammar § 47, 9, 9—20: see also Madvig's Greek Syntax, § 10. It should be noticed that Kruger says that au(tou= (au)tw=n) when it means ipsius is placed next the article like e(autou= etc. In such cases however au(tou= is now generally read; see note on ch. 10, 48. These constructions are not to be confounded with the partitive genitive, such as oi( plei=stoi au)tw=n (iv. 43, 2).

e)n tai=s cuno/dois—when closing with the enemy; iii. 107, 3, e)n th=| cuno/dw| au)th=|. e)cwqei=tai—‘thrust outwards’ (Jowett) (mid.), or ‘are forced out’ of the proper line, which is thus unduly extended towards the right.

peri<*>sxousi—‘extend beyond’, ‘overlap’, or ‘outflank’; iii. 107, 3, perie/sxe to\ tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn strato/pedon (nom.); with this verb may be joined a dative of the instrument, ib. fin. perie/sxon tw=| ke/ra|, ‘with their wing’. kata/—‘opposite to’.

proste/llein...th=|.. a)spi/di—either (1) ‘shelter with’, or (2) ‘move up to, the shield of the man next on the right’.
Liddell and Scott are in favour of (1); Poppo and Krüger of (2). Poppo cites Dio Cas. XL. 23, 3, tai=s tw=n parastatw=n a)spi/si ta\s gumnw/seis sfw=n proste/llein, which is equally ambiguous. Classen reads prosste/llein in sense (2) maintaining that this form is required for the construction and meaning.

ta\ gumna/—as in ch. 10. 20, the right arm and side which were not covered by the shield. kai\ nomi/zein—‘and because they think that this closeness of locking up gives the best shelter’. eu)skepasto/taton is probably neuter, in accordance with a common construction; it may possibly be feminine, as in ch. 110, 3: iii. 101, 2, tau/th| dusesbolw/tatos h) *aokri/s. In iii. 89 (fin.) biaio/teron th\n e)pi/klusin poiei=n is ambiguous. eu)ske/pastos is found in Dio Cas. 49. 30, but not elsewhere in classical Greek. skepa/zw is used by Xenophon; see ske/pas.

h(gei=tai th=s ai)ti/as—lit. ‘begins this fault’, ai)ti/a being ground or cause of blame. prwtosta/ths—as we say, ‘the pivot-man’: oi( prwtosta/tai in Xen. are the front-rank men. e)calla/ssein—‘to withdraw from the enemy’.

gu/mnwsin—this unusual word, which is active in form, may mean the side ‘which he exposes’ or ‘finds himself exposing’; or it may be simply a convenient singular, the plural ta\ gumna/ being elsewhere used. We use such words as enclosure in a similar passive way. It is copied by Dio, as cited above.
kai\ to/te—‘and so now’, resuming the particular description after a general digression; so iv. 67, 5: vii. 29, 4. to/te d) ou)=n is used somewhat in the same way.

perie/sxon.. tw=n *skiritw=n—‘overlapped the Sciritae with their wing’. perie/xw, which elsewhere takes the accusative when it means to surround, is here constructed like perigi/gnomai. The datives in line 6 and iii. 107 (fin.) seem decisive as to the construction. Haack however suggested to\ ke/ras and to\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn.
dei/sas .nomi/sas—the aorist implies a sudden thought, as in ch. 65. 12. sfw=n=our: iv. 9, 2, note. The position gives the word an emphatic force=‘lest he should have his left surrounded’.

e)sh/mhnen—of military orders; ii. 84, 1, pri
 a)
 au)to\s shmh/nh|: with infinitive in the general sense of directing, Hdt.
v. 35, shmai/nonta a)pi/stasqai a)po\ basile/os. The order given by Agis was ‘extend away from us, and present an equal front to the Mantineans’. In e)pecagago/ntas, e)pi/ implies motion not towards the enemy, but to the new position required; while e)c denotes leaving their original post, or opening out the line: so of ships, vii. 52, 2, e)pecagago/nta pro\s th
 gh=n: viii. 104, 3, a)ntepech=gon: pausa/menoi th=s e)pecagwgh=s. All of these are flank movements to surround the enemy.

e)cisw=sai—‘to present an equal front to the Mantineans’. to\ eu)w/numon may be the object; or e)cisw=sai may be quasi-intransitive, as in vi. 87, 5, e)cisw)santes toi=s a)/llois, ‘acting like the rest of the world’, lit. ‘making things (or the matter in hand) equal’: cf. Soph. El. 1194, mhtri\ d: ou)de\n e)cisoi=. Here th\n ta/cin, or e(autou/s, or ‘the state of things’, would be implied. We have seen (ch. 67, 1) that the Sciritae were entitled to the left, and ‘among the Lacedaemonians especially ancient routine was more valued than elsewhere’ (Grote). Hence it was impossible to order round a division from the extreme right to the extreme left, and apparently impracticable to move the whole line more to the left. We do not know the nature of the ground.

e)s to\ dia/kenon tou=to—put emphatically first, ‘to fill up this gap’; for the word cf. ch. 72. 16: iv. 135, 1. parh/ggellen —‘consecutio verborum haec est: parh/ggellen tw=n polema/rxwn *(ipponoi/da| kai\ *)aristoklei= parelqei=n a)po\ tou= deciou= ke/rws e)s to\ dia/kenon tou=to e)/xousi du/o lo/xous. Lochos autem duos duo polemarchi aut ideo adducere iussi sunt quod lochi Thucydidei moris Xenophonteis sunt similes, aut quod in graviore negotio vel tempore difficiliore etiam minores partes militum a maioribus ducibus adversus hostes dncendae videntur’ (Poppo).

tw=n polema/rxwn—partitive genitive depending immediately on the proper names; i. 24, 1, *fa/lios *kori/nqios tw=n a)f) *(hrakle/ous: i. 126, 2, *ku/lwn a)nh\r *)aqhnai=os tw=n pa/lai. Aristocles may be the brother of king Pleistoanax mentioned ch. 16, 26. For the position of e)/xousi Kruger compares iii. 26, 1, du/o kai\ tessara/konta nau=s a)pe/steilan e)/xonta *)alki/dan.
e)sbalo/ntas—‘closing in’. ‘throwing (themselves) in’, ingressos; an unusual sense of the word. plhrw=sai—sc. au)to/. bebaio(teron—as the flank could not now be turned.

e)c o)li/gou—‘at short notice’; ch. 64, 20: iv. 108, 5. to/n te—answeied by kai\ tou\s polemi/ous, the clause a)lla\ kai/ being parenthetical in sense, though conforming to the general construction after cune/bh. Arnold compares i. 95, 3, cune/bh te au)tw=| kalei=sqai/ te a(/ma kai\ tou\s cumma/xous .metata/casqai, where au)tw=| applies only to the first clause.

docantas—‘held guilty’; cf. the use of videor. Whether banishment was inflicted as a punishment, or punishment escaped by voluntary exile, is not clear. The latter view is the more probable: see Müller's Dorians, Bk. iii. ch. 11 § 4. Thus Xenophon's Clearchus was an exile, after having been condemned to death for disobedience to the military orders of the Ephors (Anab ii. 6, 4). ib fqa/sai th=| prosmi/cei—‘were beforehand in closing with them’, i e. before the line was restored to proper order. prosmi/cei is a sort of instrumental dative. Krüger indeed considers the construction so unusual that he believes that the two words may be an explanatory gloss; their omission however would be fatal to the rhythm of the clause.

kai\ keleu/santos—‘and when, on the lochi not coming up to the Sciritae, he gave the order (to the Sciritae), close up again to us, he found that (cune/bh au)tw=|) they too were now unable to close in’. This is the explanation adopted by Poppo and is indeed the only one which the wording and sense permit; for keleu/ein e)pi/ would not be an admissible construction. The position of epi\ tou)s *skiri/tas is no doubt awkward, but may be intended to show emphatically that keleu/santos refers to the Sciritae. Classen gives other instances of conjunctions placed like w(s here, e g. iv. 27, 1, punqano/menoi...si=tos toi=s e)n th=| nh/sw| o)/ti e)splei=. It is however tempting to suggest the omission of e)pi/ (or the substitution of e)/ti), governing tou\s *skiri/tas directly by keleu/santos.

e)/ti—‘now’ or ‘after this’, i.e. there was now no time left. mhde/—i.e. they as well as the lo/xoi failed to fill up the gap. tou/tous—the Sciritae, who were unable to regain their old position. It is altered into tou/tois by Classen, who unaccountably takes lo/xoi as the subject of prosmi/cai and cugklh=|sai, and understands tou/tois of Agis and his troops
(sfi/si). He supposes that the lo/xoi had made an ineffectual attempt to reach the Sciritae and now failed to regain their position on the right. This however is quite contrary to Thucydides, who says plainly enough that the commanders of the lo/xoi refused to move at all, and were therefore exiled for cowardice.
cugklh=|sai—‘to close in’ or ‘close up (the ranks)’; virtually intransitive; as in iv. 35, 1: see ch. 64, 22.

ma/lista dh/—cf. ch. 66, 7. The run of the words seems to show that this applies to the whole of the sentence, while kata\ pa/nta extends to e)lasswqe/ntes only, and to/te emphasizes the final clause. The sweeping expression kata\ pa/nta appears to point out the ‘entire failure’ of the movements which Agis had ordered; a failure which was redeemed by no less signal valour and steadiness in the actual encounter.

th=| e)mpeiri/a|—skill in manœuvring in the field, in which both Agis and his subordinates proved deficient: cf. ii. 89, 2, dia\ th\n e)n tw=| pezw=| e)mpeiri/an: iv. 33, 2, th=| sfete/ra| e)mpeiri/a| xrh/sasqai. The dative with e)lasswqe/ntes means ‘worsted’ or rather ‘proving inferior in skill’. F. compares Plat. Alc. i. 121 B, o(/ra mh\ tw=| te ge/nous o)/gkw| e)lattw/meqa tw=n a)ndrw=n kai\ th=| a)/llh| trofh=|, and Xen. Hel. vi. 2, 28, mega/lh zhmi/a h)=n to/ te e)lattou=sqai pa=si tou/tois. There is therefore no reason for spoiling the sentence by adopting such corrections as a)pori/a| or a)taci/a|, or by omitting e)lasswqe/ntes with Madvig, who translates ‘Lacedaemonii, qui semper arte, tum non minus virtute se praestare ostenderunt’, a rendering which seems to introduce an idea foreign to the sense of the present passage. The dative indeed seems naturally used with words denoting superiority or the opposite, and comparison generally; cf. vincere Caecilius gravitate Terentius arte (Hor. Ep. ii. 1, 58).

th=| a)ndri/a|. .perigeno/menoi—‘proved their superiority in valour’, or ‘showed that they gained the victory by their valour’: cf. iv. 73, 2, e)/deican e(toi=moi o)/ntes a)mu/nesqai. Poppo suggests perigigno/menoi or a)\n perigigno/menoi as having a general force, but the text seems to give a preferable sense. e)peidh\ ga/r—ga/r brings in the expected account. For e)n xersi/ cf. ch. 10, 56. The phrase is found with o)/ntes, iii. 108, 1: with geno/menoi vii. 5, 2; but I have not found a parallel to the present dative construction.

to\ me/n—like the resumptive tau/th| me/n below, answered by tw=| d) a)/llw|=‘though...yet’. au)tw=n—ch. 15, 5. For its position Classen compares i. 30, 3, e)pei\ sfw=n oi( cu/mmaxoi e)po/noun: see also ch. 71, 17.

oi( xi/lioi loga/des—see ch. 67, 15. The imperfect die/fqeiron ‘inflicted loss’ is used in combination with aorists, as in iii. 98, 2, to denote what was begun or what lasted some little time. e)ce/wsan—‘drove back’ out of their line and position. e)pitetagme/nwn—‘posted in charge’ or ‘in reserve’; so e)pi/taktoi vi. 67, 1.

kalou/menoi—Hdt. viii. 124, trihko/sioi *spartihte/wn loga/des, ou(=toi oi(/per i(ppe/es kale/ontai. They were the king's body-guard, and though called horsemen fought on foot. Arnold supposes that they were originally chiefs who fought round their king in chariots, ‘this being the early sense of i(ppeu/s and i(ppo/ths, as we find from Homer’. The actual cavalry were stationed on the wings as we learn from ch. 67.

pe/nte lo/xois w)nomasme/nois—nothing is known of these divisions. ‘We can only suppose that Argos originally, like Sparta and Messenia, contained five districts or quarters, each of which sent its own lochus into the field’ (Arnold). Poppo considers the pe/nte lo/xoi identical with the presbu/teroi, from the absence of the article; but pe/nte lo/xoi may have the definite force of a proper name, or the second article may be omitted as it is before cumma/xwn at the beginning of the next chapter. In ch. 67, 17, we have simply oi( a)/lloi *)argei=oi mentioned besides the xi/lioi loga/des.
e)s xei=ras—so iii. 108, 1, e)s a)lkh\n u(pomei=nai: Xen. An. iv. 3, 31, ei)s xei=ras de/xesqai. tou\s pollou/s—partial apposition, ‘for the most part’. e)/stin ou(/s is a still further restriction.

katapathqe/ntas—i.e. by one another in their eager struggles to escape; as in vii. 84, 3, e)pe/pipto/n te a)llh/lois kai\ katepa/toun. This is explained by the following words, in which th\n e)gkata/lhyin is the subject of mh\ fqh=nai, and is equivalent to tou\s e)gkatalamba/nontas, ‘in order that the enemy might not overtake them before they could escape’. Haack and Poppo approve of this view of the passage, which is now generally accepted. tou= mh\ fqh=nai may depend on both the preceding clauses, or on e)ndo/ntas only, the next clause being then parenthetical. If this view is not adopted th\n e)gkata/lhyin must be taken as the object of fqh=nai, which necessitates giving an irregular
sense to tou= mh\ fqh=nai, ‘because they could not escape’, or ‘so that they did not escape being overtaken’. Arnold suggests tw=| mh/, dative of the efficient cause.

e)gkata/lhyis—not found elsewhere in Thucydides, though e:gkatalamba/nw occurs eight times. The compound implies a place, as in ch. 3, 8 In iv. 35, 2, we have o(/soi u(poxwrou=ntes e)gkatelamba/nonto a)pe/qnhskon, ‘all who were overtaken, or seized, on the field (or in the retreat) were slain’, an exact parallel to the present use of the substantive. For the use of the verbal see lh=yis ch. 110, 3.

parerrh/gnunto—iv. 96, 4 tw=n *qhbai/wn e)fepome/nwn kai\ pararrhgnu/ntwn: vi. 70, 2, parerrh/gnuto h)/dh kai\ to\ a)/llo stra/teuma. The ranks were broken by the men being forced from beside their comrades. kai\ e)f) e(ka/tera—i.e., as Poppo explains. ‘cum media acies cessisset, tum simul etiam ab utroque latere vicinos ordines dissolutos esse Thucydides indicare censendus est’. Kruger suggests ta\ e)f) e(ka/tera, otherwise the subject is the Argive force generally. kai\ goes with e(ka/tera, as in vi. 80, 1, with a)mfote/rwn. Classen points out the force of the imperfects in denoting the moment of danger. He however refers this clause to the defeated centre; but it appears to have already broken and fled.
tw=| perie/xonti sfw=n—cf. ch. 71, 13. au)tou(s—the Athenians generally. perieisth/kei—iii. 54 fin., fo/bos perie/sth th\n *spa/rthn: iv. 35, 3, etc.

kukloume/nous=‘on the point of being hemmed in’; imperfect passive: so in vii. 81, 3, kuklou=tai is passive, while ten lines before e)kuklou=nto is transitive. h(sshme/nous—these were the paratetagme/noi, ch. 72, 26

e)talaipw/rhsan—ch. 74, 13, as we say ‘suffered’ to denote actual loss. oi( i(pph=s paro/ntes—the predicate is similarly used in iv. 44, 1, h)=san ga\r toi=s *)aqhnai/ois oi( i(pph=s w)fe/limoi cummaxo/menoi. pario/ntes, which Classen suggests, is no improvement, for the cavalry were met' au(tw=n (ch. 67, 20).
kai\ cune/bh—another ‘concurrent circumstance’ which saved the Athenians. ponou=n—iv. 96. 4, e)po/nei to\ eu)w/numon.
e)ce/klinen—only here in Thucydides: Xen. Cyr. i. 4, 23, e)kkli/nousi kai\ feu/gousi. to\ h(sshqe/n—‘which had been beaten’: h(sshme/nos, as in line 7, denotes the resulting condition.

kai\ plei/ous—if the text is right, plei/ous is a general comparison, lit. more than might be expected, or more than their due proportion, i.e. a large number. In iv. 42, 3, and 103, 3 e)k plei/onos has a similar force. kai\ then emphasizes the serious loss of the Mantineans, contrasted with the slight loss of the Argives. Some inferior manuscripts have oi( plei/ous: but the total loss was only 200. In iv. 44, 2, oi( plei=stoi au)tw=n a)pe/qanon means that their chief loss was at the point spoken of: so vii. 30, 2, a)poktei/nousi e)n th=| e)kba/sei tou\s plei/stous, where the total loss was 250 out of 1300: but such an explanation will not suit the present passage.

to\ polu/—iv. 25, 8, tw=n *aeonti/nwn to\ polu/: iv. 113, 1, to\ polu\ e)qorubei=to. bi/aios—‘hard-pressed’: iv. 31, fin., ei) katalamba/noi a)naxw/rhsis biaiote/ra: ii. 33, 3, biaio/teron a)nagago/menoi of embarking under an enemy's attack. makra/, like e)pi\ polu/ below, of distance.

ta\s ma/xas...poiou=ntai—this sentence is an excellent example of article and substantive with poiei=sqai: see note on iv. 13, 1. ‘The Lacedaemonians fight long and refuse to move until they have put an enemy to flight, but, having once defeated him, they do not follow him far or long’ (Jowett). xroni/ous—so vi. 31, 5: but in i. 12, 1 the feminine is xroni/a. tw=| me/nein—‘by standing their ground’.

kai/—we might expect h)/, as in vii. 86, 5 toiau/th| h)\ o(/ti e)ggu/tata tou/twn ai)ti/a|: but Arnold is right in comparing i. 22, 4, toiau=ta kai\ paraplh/sia: so i. 143, 3: vii. 15, 2, paraplh/sion kai\ ou) pollw=| ple/on: vii. 42, 2, i)/son kai\ paraplh/sion\. kai/ has in fact a sort of corrective force=‘I mean’, ‘that is to say’, as noted in ch. 20, 4. h)/ on the other hand, meaning ‘or else’, would imply some uncertainty as to the facts.

plei/stou. dh/—see note on ch. 60, 16, for dh/ with the superlative. For the genitive of time ‘within which’, see ch. 14, 16: Plat. Gorg. 448 A, ou)dei/s me h)rw/thke kaino\n ou)de/n, ou)de\ pollw=n e)tw=n.

cunelqou=sa—with ma/xh=commissa; constructed with u)po/ as being virtually passive. Somewhat similar is i. 15, 2, po/lemos ou)dei\s cune/sth; cf. Hdt. vii. 144, ou(=tos o( po/lemos susta/s. Poppo quotes ma/xh sunh|ei kartera/ from Josephus, Ant. Iud. xvii. 10 (12), 2.

proqe/menoi—apparently=qe/menoi ta\ o(/pla pro/, ‘taking up their position before’: see note on iv. 44, 1, e)/qento ta\ o(/pla. For constr. cf. Eur. Iph. T. 1218, pe/plon o)mma/twn proqe/sqai. A guard was posted, to oblige the enemy to ask leave to bury the dead, which was a confession of defeat; so fulakh\n katalipo/ntes (iv. 97, 1). Kruger and others take it to mean ‘displaying the arms of the dead’, like ii. 34, 2, ta\ o)sta= proti/qentai, but they cite no instances of such a practice.

i(/stasan—Classen considers that the imperfect is used here because the trophy was not completed till the enemy owned his defeat. But i(/stasan is used again in vi. 70, 3; and probably (like e)sku/leuon) merely denotes what the victors ‘went on to do’ or ‘began to do’ next. The aorists which follow imply the completion of all that had to be done.
*ai)ginh/tais—Athenian e)/poikoi, the inhabitants having been removed in 431 (ii. 27, 1). a)mfo/teroi—Laches and Nicostratus (ch. 61, 1).

e)talaipw/rhsan—ch. 73, 8. kai/—emphatic: there may have been some loss, but it was not ‘also’ (besides occurring) worth taking into account: so iv. 48, 5, ou) ga\r e)/ti h)=n u(po/loipon tw=n e(te/rwn o(/ ti kai\ a)cio/logon: i. 15, 2, po/lemos, o(/qen tis kai\ du/namis parege/neto, ou)dei\s cune/sth: ii. 54, 5, ou)k e)sh=lqen o)/ ti a)/cion kai\ ei)pei=n.

a)pogene/sqai—ii. 34, 1, ta\ o)sta= tw=n a)pogenome/nwn: ii. 51, 7, ta\s o(lofu/rseis tw=n a)pogignome/nwn: ii. 98, 2, of loss to an army generally, as opposed to prosgi/gnesqai: Hdt. v. 4 gino/menos kai\ a)pogino/menos, of births and death. au)tw=n, according to Poppo, depends on puqe/sqai, but the sense seems rather to connect it with some statement of number. It can scarcely depend on a)lh/qeian, but it may be taken with triakosi/ous, the
clause with me\n being thus subordinate in sense to that with de/.
peri\ triakosi/ous—subject; so Xen. Hell. iv. 6, 11, a)peqanon peri\ triakosi/ous: prep. with object, Thuc. iv. 48, 1, e)s e(ch/konta e)/laqon diafqci/rantes: cf. vii. 30, 3.

tou:s te presbute/rous—see ch. 64, 13. e)boh/qhse—‘had marched out’. Poppo refers to the law mentioned by Hdt. v. 75, e)te/qh no/mos e)n *spa/rth| mh\ e)cei=nai e(/pesqai a)mfote/rous tou)s basile/as e)ciou/shs stratih=s. That law appears rather to mean that the two kings were not to be in joint command of the same army. See however Stein on the passage from Herodotus, and the words which he cites from Xen. Hell. v. 3, 10. We there find that the Phliasians in 381 assumed that they were safe from attack on the part of Agesilaus, as the other king was in the field, ou)d) a)\n gene/sqai w(/ste a(/ma a)mfote/rous tou\s basile/as e)/cw *spa/rths ei)=nai.

tou\s a)po\ *kori/nqou—see ch. 64, 18. a)pe/streyan—iv. 97, 2, o(\s au)to\n a)postre/yas. a)pe/treyan was formerly read against MSS. authority: ‘a)potre/pein magis notat avertere, dehortari, dissuadere; a)postre/fein autem retro convertere, iubere redire’ (Bauer, cited by Poppo).
*ka/rneia—ch. 54, 9. e)tu/gxanon—ch. 26, 15.

to/te—‘at this time’, i.e. since the capture of Sphacteria, as is shown by what follows. In iv. 40 we are told of the astonishment caused by the surrender at Sphacteria, while complaints of sluggishness and inaction on the part of Sparta had been made even before the war began, for instance in the speech of the Corinthians (i. 68—71). e)piferome)nhn—cf. iii. 46 fin. th\n ai)ti/an e)pife/rein: so iii. 42, 3, a)diki/as e)piferome/nhs.

e)s—‘for, in respect of’: viii. 88, 1, es filian diaba/llein, where instances from Plutarch etc., may be found in Poppo. th
 a)/llhn—ch. 60, 10: Xen. Anab. i. 5, 5, ou)k h)=n xo(rtos ou)de\ a)/llo ou)de
 de/ndron.
e(ni\ e)/rgw| tou/tw|—ou)=tos thus used without the article has a predicative or appositional force; the sense being ‘and thus by one victory they regained their reputation’. kakizo/menoi—kaki/zw, ‘to reproach’, occurs in i. 105, 5, kakizo/menoi u(po\ tw=n presbute/rwn: ii. 22 fin. e)ka/kizon (to
 *perikle/a). Here therefore the meaning appears to be ‘open to reproach’. Elsewhere, e.g. Hom. Il. xxiv. 214: Eur. Ion, 984, kaki/zomai means to act the coward, and this would give a good sense in the present passage, viz. that the late inaction and seeming cowardice of the Spartans were due to stress of circumstances, not to failure of spirit. A similar opposition between tu/xh and gnw/mh is attributed to the Peloponnesian commanders in ii. 87, 3, di/kaionnomi/sai tai=s me
 tu/xais e)nde/xesqai sfa/llesqai tou\s a)nqrw/pous tai=s de\ gnw/mais tou\s au)tou\s a)ei\ a)ndrei/ous o)rqw=s ei)=nai.

prote/ra|—Cobet would read proterai/a|, but the editors generally retain prote/ra|, as pro/teros can be used of days, e.g. Hom. Il. xxi. 5, h)/mati tw=| prote/rw|. In i. 44, 1, we have th=| me\n prote/ra| e)kklhsi/a| answered by e)n de\ th=| u(sterai/a|. For the following genitive cf. Hdt. v. 56, en th=| prote/rh| nukti\ tw=n *panaqhnai/wn.

w(s e)rh=mon ou)=san—ch. 56, 21. tw=n *)argei/wn—dependent on fu/lakas, e)celqo/ntwn being added as a predicate, ‘as they had gone out on foreign service’. e)zelqo/ntwn au)tw=n, genitive absolute, is also read. Arnold refers e)celqo/ntwn to fu/lakas, whether au)tw=n is read or not, rendering ‘as they had ventured out to fight them’. e)celqo/ntes has this force in viii. 25, 2, but the meaning first given is the usual one, and makes the better sense. pollou/s—predicate, ‘in large numbers’.
*)hlei/wn—see ch. 62, 8. pro\s toi=s prote/rois—ch. 61, 1. Classen points out that no new commander's name is given, though both the Athenian generals had fallen in the battle.

dielo/menoi—sc. th=n po/lin, or the operations against it: cf ch. 114, 4: iv. 11, 3, kat' o)li/gas nau=s dielo/menoi, with no object expressed. e)cepau/santo—a strong expression = a)pe/kamon tou= periteixi/zein (schol.) This is the only instance of the middle given in Lid. and Scott.

th\n a(/kran—a rocky promontory near the harbour. to\ *(hrai=on is in apposition; as in i. 46, 3, h( a)/kra to\ *xeime/rion. There are various forms of such construction with names; e.g. (a) iv. 25, 5, kata\ to\n *)akesi/nhn potamo/n (the usual order
with potamo/s): iv. 108, 1, h( *bo/lbh li/mnh: iv. 43, 1, e/pi\ thn *solu/geian kw/mhn: (b) i. 116, 1, pro\s *tragi/a| th=| nh/sw|: iv. 96, 5, pro\s *pa/rnhqa to o)/ros: (c) i. 100, 3, to\ xwri/on ai) *)enne/a o(doi/: vii. 3, 4, to\ frou/rion to\ *la/bdalon: (d) ch. 41, 8, e)/xei *qure/an po/lin: (e) iv. 46, 1, <*>n tw=| o)/rei th=s *)istw/nhs. See Kruger's Grammar, § 50, 7.
cugkatalipo/ntes—another rare word, denoting the common action of the combined force. The fortified position now occupied was not long retained, see ch. 80, 16.

eu)qu/s—with xeimw=nos a)rxome/nou: ch. 13, 1, with e)pigignome/nou: so iv. 52, 1, e)peidh\ ta\ *ka/rneia h)/gagon—most modern editors regard this clause as an interpolation derived from ch. 75, 23, for the Carneia were over long before the winter period began; see ch. 54, 9. Jowett however holds that the words ‘are not intended as a mark of time, but have reference to the advantage taken of the Carneia by the enemies of Sparta’. If so, they seem somewhat misleading.
cumbathri/ous—a word only found in this chapter in Attic Greek, though used by later writers. Thucydides has lo/goi cumbatikoi/, vi. 103, 3; so viii. 71, 1, and 91, 1, ou)de\n cumbatiko/n.

h)=san de\ au)toi=s—from the position of the words = ‘they had adherents’, though the dative may depend on e)pith/deioi. pro/tero/n te ..kai\ e)peidh/—see note on iv. 103, 3, e)/praca/n te... kai\ to/te. In such cases the clause with te refers to a time before that with which the main part of the sentence deals. e)pith/deioi—favourable to their interests; i. 60, 2, toi=s *potidaia/tais a)ei/ pote e)pith/deios. to\n dh=mon—the democracy, as in line 11: iii. 81, 3 etc.: without the article i. 107, 3: vi. 27 fin. etc.

e)s th\n o(mologi/an—loosely connected with pei/qein = w(/ste th\n o(mologi/an poiei=sqai. poih/santes—‘after effecting’; cf. ch. 38, 27. kai\ cummaxi/an—sc. poih=sai, ‘afterwards to bring about an alliance as well, and then’ etc. e)piti/qesqai—iii. 72, 1, e)piti/qentai tw=| dh/mw|.

*li/xas—see ch. 50, 16. du/o lo/gw—two proposals. kaq) o(/ ti k.t.l.—‘mira verborum brevitas’, says Poppo, who adds that polemh/sousi and ei)rh(nhn a)/cousi are to be understood with kaq) o(/ ti and w\s respectively. We have other forms of ellipse where terms are offered, e.g. iv. 37, 2, e)kh/rucan ei) bou/lointo ta\ o(/pla paradou=nai, sc. that they should accept these conditions: cf. iii. 52, 2, prospe/mpei kh/ruka le/gonta ei) k.t.l. Dobree suggested leaving out ei) in both clauses. The proposal for war may have been something like the arrangement recorded in ch. 41.

e)/tuxe parw/n—ch. 61, 9. toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois—for dative cf. iv. 106, 2, tw=n prasso/ntwn tw=| *brasi/da|, where also e)k tou= fanerou= occurs. tolmw=ntes—so ii. 43, 1, and often. The terms of the treaty in this chapter, and of the alliance in ch. 79, are given in the Doric dialect. The language however, according to the authorities, does not entirely conform to the rules of Laconian speech; and the documents may have been modified in the course of transcription. ‘These two treaties imposed by the victorious Lacedaemonians upon Argos mark the final dissolution of the alliance between Argos and the discontented members of the Peloponnesian league, and also of the alliance between Argos, Athens, Elis, and Mantinea’ (Jowett).

katta/de—i.e. kata\ ta/de: ch. 79 init. so katta\ for kata\ ta/, line 15. ta=| e)kklhsi/a|—‘The usual name of a public assembly in the Doric states was a(li/a. This is the name by which the Spartan assembly is called in Herodotus (vii. 134), and it is also used in official documents for those of Byzantium, of Gela, Agrigentum, Corcyra and Heraclea. In Sparta the ancient name of an assembly of the people was a)pe/lla. In later times the names e)kklhsi/a and oi( e)/kklhtoi appear to have been chiefly in use’ (Müller's Dorians, Bk. iii. 5, 9). See vi. 88, 10, e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a| tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn. In the passage cited from Herodotus a(li/h seems merely his own general term; as he uses it in i. 125, of an assembly of Persians; v. 30, of a meeting held at Miletus; v. 79, of an assembly at Thebes.

cumbale/sqai—‘to make agreement’; so line 24: Xen. Anab. vi. 6, 35, ceni/an suneba/llonto: vi. 3, 3, suneba/lonto lo/fon, ‘they agreed on a certain hill’. pottw/s = pro\s tou/s: Theocr. xi. 1, potto\n *)/erwta: Ar. Lys. 1005, potta\s sponda/s. a)podido/ntas—‘on their restoring’. pai=das must be the hostages mentioned at the end of ch. 61, who were given to the Mantineans: Argos is therefore made responsible for their return.

tw\s a)/ndras toi=s *mainali/ois—‘no former mention had been made of the Maenalians; but as they had no one city, but were dispersed in several villages, an invading army could have had no difficulty in obliging them to give hostages sepalately, nor was there any one town capable of affording such resistance as to make its submission deserve a separate notice’ (Arnold). ‘The men in Mantinea’ are the Arcadian hostages whom the Lacedaemonians had deposited in Orchomenus, and who were handed over to the Mantmeans (ch. 61 fin.). There is a clear distinction made between pai=des and a)/ndres in this passage. Classen supposes that pai=des may be youths who had not attained military age; Krüger suggests that slaves may be meant.

e)c *)epidau/rw—i.e. *)epidau/rou. The district or neighbourhood is meant, as in ch. 55, 2. e)kbw=ntas = e)kbai/nontas: see Lid. and Scott, proba(w. to\ tei=xos is the headland of Heraeum, ch. 75, 26.

ai) de/ ka —ai/ = ei): ka for Ionic ke = Attic a)/n: the whole phrase being equivalent to e)a\n de/. ei)/kwnti = ei)/kwsi, ‘withdraw’: Krüger cites ei)/kous' e)k xw/rhs from Tyrtaeus; Hdt. ii. 80, ei)/kousi th=s o(dou=.

polemi/ous ei)=men— = ei)=nai; so ch. 79, 2. h)=men is also read. The Athenians are the subject. ‘A note of hostility to the Athenians is now first openly expressed, not unnaturally, since the captives were recovered, and the Athenians had taken part in the battle of Mantmea’ (Jowett). e)/xonti—e)/xwnti is also read, but the indicative, as Poppo shows, gives the better sense, as it is a question of actual fact. For ei) with the subjunctive see Goodwin's Moods and Tenses, § 454. Madvig (Greek Syntax, § 125) restricts the use in Attic prose to ‘the archaic phraseology of law’.

peri\ de\ tw= siw= su/matos— = tou= qeou= qu/matos: Ar. Lys. 81, nai\ tw\ siw/. We should expect tw= siw= tw= su/matos; cf. 1. 139, 1, peri\ tw=n e)nagw=n th=s e)la/sews; vi. 33, 1, peri\ tou= e)pi/plou
th=s a)lhqei/as. Otherwise siw= is without the article, having in itself a definite force: cf. iv. 110, 1, a)po\ tou= basile/ws dioru)gmatos, basileu/s, without the article, meaning the king of Persia. For ‘the sacrifice due to the god’, viz. Apollo Pythaeus, see ch. 53, 3. The reading of the remainder of this passage seems hopelessly uncertain, but the general sense is, as Arnold says, ‘that with respect to the victim alleged by the Argives to be owed to the temple of Apollo from the Epidaurians, the matter should be decided by the oath of the Epidaurians, who were to swear whether it was justly due from them or no. It is well known that, where the evidence was not clear, the accused was allowed to clear himself by oath; and if he swore that he was innocent, the accuser had no further remedy’. See the provisions in ch. 18, 20.

ei)=men lh=n—the manuscript readings, e)me\n lh=n, e)me/lhn, etc. are various and unintelligible. lh=n is the infinitive of la/w = qe/lw: Ar. Lys. 981, lw= ti musi/cai ne/on: Ach. 766, ai) lh=|s = ei) qe/leis. The reading in the text is taken (i) ‘that it be allowed to the Epidaurians to choose (lh=n) an oath’; but lh=n can scarcely thus govern an accusative: (ii) ‘that (the contracting parties) desire (lh=n) that an oath be allowed (ei)=men) to the Epidaurians’, or be taken by them. Some support for this rendering is derived, as Jowett points out, from ch. 18, 59, e)/stw de\ *lakedaimoni/ois o(/rkos: but it is most awkward to connect lh=n with the initial dokei=, like the other infinitives throughout the chapter. Should lh=n be omitted?

do/men de\ au)tou\s o)mo/sai—‘if au)tou/s be right it is the subject of do/men (= dou=nai) and must refer to the Argives, who were to tender the oath. This makes sense, but forces the meaning of au)tou/s: Arnold accordingly reads au)toi=s, = that it be tendered to them. The reading adopted of this clause assumes ei)=men lh=n in the clause before. There is however another suggested reading ai) me/n = ei) me/n, the infinitive lh=n being taken with ai), ‘if they will’. ei) with the infinitive in oratio obliqua is Herodotean; there is one instance in Thucydides, iv. 98, 3, ei) ..dunhqh=nai, where see note. With this reading there is a different group of suggestions and explanations; e g. Becker's ai) me\n lh=n tw)s *)epidauri/ws, o(/rkon do/menai au)toi=s o)mo/sai, ‘if the Epidaurians please etc.’: and Ahrens' conjecture ai) me\n lh=n, toi=s *)epidauri/ois o(/rkon do/men, ai) de/, au)tw\s o)mo/sai, ‘if they please, they may tender an oath to the Epidaurians, if (otherwise) they may swear themselves’; i.e. the matter was to be decided either by the oath of the Epidaurians or by that of the Argives.
Further discussion of the text may be found in Classen and Fowler.

kai\ mikra\s kai\ mega/las—‘attende articulum non additum, qui ideo omissus videtur, quia sententia haec est: sive parvae sint sive magnae’ (Poppo). ‘The independence of the cities of Peloponnesus, ‘small and great’, is proclaimed, probably to avoid the suspicion which had been engendered by the former treaty between Lacedaemon and Athens, ch. 29, and on the other hand to prevent larger states, like Elis or Mantinea, increasing their power by the subjugation of smaller ones’ (Jowett). See note at the beginning of ch. 47.

ai) de/ ka tw=n e)kto/s—this clause is especially directed against Athens. e)pi\ kakw=|—ch. 18, 28. a)lece/menai—i.e. a)le/cein: ‘to lend aid’ or repel the enemy from another: mid. ‘repel from one's self’: cf. a)mu/nw, a)mu/nomai.

a)mo/qi—probably = Doric a(ma= (or a(ma=|) i.e. a(/ma: cf. ch. 47, 80, koinh=| bouleuome/nais: ch. 80, 8, mh\ cumbai/nein...a)ll) h)\ a(/ma. Lid. and Scott however say that the word means ‘in any way’, as ou)damo/qi = ou)damou=. a)moqei/ is also read and is interpreted either in the same sense = a(/ma, or as derived from a privative and mo/qos, ‘sine seditione et dissensione’ (Ahrens). o(/pa| ka = o(/ph| a)/n, ch. 18, 67: viii. 56, 4. e)nti/ = ei)si/. For e)ssou=ntai, Ahrens reads e)ssi/ontai.

e)pidei/cantas—‘the contracting parties to show these conditions to the allies before concluding the treaty’. The participle as usual is the emphatic word. For cumbale/sqai see line 2. ai)/ ka au)toi=s dokh=|—au)toi=s seems certainly to refer to the allies. If they approved, the treaty was to be signed at once. Their possible disapproval is dealt with in the next clause, ai) de/ ti, where the addition of kai\ a)/llo as read by Arnold makes the sense clear, but has little authority. One manuscript has mh/. ka a)/llo is a plausible suggestion; but we see from ch. 79, 13, that the subjunctive can stand with ai) alone.

a)pia/llhn— = a)pope/mpein. The subject is not clear. Either the Lacedaemonians and Argives were to send the allies home to consult their respective home governments; or the allies were to send the proposed terms home for con
sideration. Grote and others understand that the allies wer to be summarily dismissed, and the treaty concluded withou them; but this scarcely agrees with the clauses before.
e)pimici/as ou)/shs—with para/: cf. i. 13, 3, par' a)llh/lous e)pimisgo(ntwn: ii. 1, e)pemi/gnunto par' a)llh(lous. e(pimicia occurs ch. 35, 3.
e)/pracan—see the end of ch. 76. a)fe/ntas—i. 102, 3, a)fe/ntes th\n cummaxi/an: so ch. 115, 7. spond<*>s kai\ cummaxi/an— ch. 46, 40.
e)pi\ toi=s i)/sois—ch. 27, 14. dido/ntas—accusative, as if cummaxi/an poiei=sqai had gone before. The construction may have been changed to avoid clashing with the intervening datives.

koinaneo)ntwn— = koinwnou/ntwn: koina/n = koinw/n subst., Pind. Pyth. iii. 28. ta=n cummaxia=n—Classen with Cobet reads ta=s cummaxi/as, see ch. 27, 2. au)topo/lies—not found elsewhere; see the similar compounds at the beginning of ch. 18.

e)/xontes ..dido/ntes—this transition to the masculine is to be noticed. toi=sper—sc. e)n: ch. 42, 2. The plural is here used instead of e)n tw=| au)tw=| e)n tw=|per, ch. 77, 20. 14 o(/pa| ka—ch. 77, 18. Poppo suggests that kri/nwnti should be read for kri/nantas. Otherwise the phraseology is elliptical, kri/nwnti being implied. See Krüger's Grammar, § 69, 7, 2, for somewhat similar examples. The clause refers to the supplies and contingents which the respective cities would have to furnish.

diakriqh=men—in the active diakri/nw is to decide or settle a difference, as Hdt. i. 100, diakri/nwn ta\s e)sferome/nas di/kas. In the passive it is used of the disputants; Plat. Euthyph. 7 c, e)pi\ to\ i(sta/nai e)lqo/ntes diakriqei=men a)/n, ‘we should settle our difference by recourse to weighing’. Here the meaning seems to be that the allied cities are if possible to ‘settle disputes’ between themselves. The next item of the treaty provides for arbitration in case of the dispute going on. Arnold however takes the first clause to refer to a difference between an allied city and one outside the confederacy, and the second to a quarrel between two allied cities. The former case was to be settled as best it could; in the latter arbitration was to be resorted to.

e)ri/zoi—‘if the difference should become a quarrel’ (Jowett). There seems no especial reason for the optative; though it may be explained as following the initial e)/doce and as denoting a more improbable and remote contingency than the subjunctive. dokei/oi is accommodated to the same construction.

a(/n tina i)/san—we should expect a(/tis i)/sa as subject to dokei/oi. As the text stands either (1) dokei/oi means ‘considers’, the subject being the po/lis which goes with e)ri/zoi and ei)=nai being understood: or more probably (2) the full construction is (e)s) a)/n tina (w(s ou)=san) i)/san (e)lqei=n) dokei/oi. dokei/oi is equivalent to dokoi/h.
a)mfoi=n tai=s—we have a)mfoi=n toi=n ch. 29, 17: a)/mfw tw/ twice in ch. 23. These are the only instances of a)/mfw in Thucydides.

tw\s d) e)/tas—the manuscripts have toi=s d) e)/tais, which necessitates giving an impersonal passive meaning to dika/zesqai, ‘justice to be administered’, for which there is no authority. e)/tai are private citizens. In an ancient inscription at Olympia they are opposed to the telestai/ = oi( e)n te/lei; cf. Aesch. Suppl. 247, pro/s se po/teron w(s e)/thn le/gw h(\ po/lews a)go/n; Their ancient legal rights are here secured against change of government, or the centralising influence of dominant states.

e)gege/nhto—for similar pluperfects see iv. 13, 1: iv. 47, 1 (Arnold's note). The alliance is regarded as complete, the following events are the consequences of its completion. o(po/sa ei)=xon—‘ei)=xon is taken in two senses. Whatever were the places belonging to one another which they had gained by war (ei)=xon) they restored, and any other complaint which they had to bring (ei)=xon), they settled with one another. dielu/santo in strictness belongs only to ei)/ ti a)/llo ei)=xon: some word such as a)pe/dosan having to be supplied with o(po/sa pole/mw| ei)=xon’ (Jowett).
dielu/santo—i. 140, 4, bou/lontai ta\ e)gklh/mata dialu/esqai: i. 145, 1, dialu/esqai peri\ tw=n e)gklhma/twn: pass. iv. 19, 2, mega/las e)/xqras dialu/esqai.

tiqe/menoi—managing and arranging; 1. 25, 1, <*>n a)po/rw| ei)/xonto qe/sqai to\ paro/n: vi. 11, 5, to\ sfe/teron a)prepe\s eu)= qh/sontai. ta\ tei/xh—any fortified positions which they might hold; especially the fortress at Epidaurus, line 17.
mh\ cumbai/nein tw|—see ch. 38, 5. a)ll) h)\ a(/ma here corresponds to a)/neu koinh=s gnw/mhs.

qumw=| e))feron—‘carried on with spirit’; ‘they were very energetic in all their doings’ (Jowett): i. 31, 1, o)rgh=| fe/rontes to
 po/lemon: iv. 121, 1, to
 po/lemon proqu/mws oi)/sein: Hdt ix. 40, proqu/mws e)/feron to
 po/lemon. The construction is similar, though the sense is slightly different, in Eur. Suppl. 556, a) dikoume/nous me/tria mh\ qumw=| fe/rein: id. Andr. 144, to\ so
 oi)/ktw| fe/rousa tugxa/nw: where fe/rw means ‘bearing’ rather than ‘conducting’; cf. bare/ws fe/rein etc.

w(s *perdi/kkan—Perdiccas still professed to be an ally of Athens; see ch. 6, 6. dienoei=to—a)posth=nai is understood, as a)posta/ntas is understood with e(w/ra: cf. i. 1, 1, to\ *(ellhniko\n o(rw=n cunista/menon: to\ me\n eu)qu/s, to\ de\ kai\ dianoou/menon, sc. cuni/stasqai: vii. 65, 1, a)nteplh/roun ta\s nau=s e)peidh\ kai\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h)sqa/nonto, sc. plhrou=ntas.

h)=n de\ e)c *)/argous—ii. 99, 2, *thmeni/dai to\ a)rxai=on o)/ntes e)c *)/argous. of Perdiccas and his ancestors: see also Hdt. viii. 137. For constr. cf. iv. 3, 3, oi)kei/ous o)/ntas au)tw=| to\ a)rxai=on. toi=s *xalkideu=si—in ch. 31, 29, we find the Chalcidians making a league with Argos. They had probably been regarded as allies of Sparta since 432, when they revolted from Athens (i. 58, 1).
to\ e)c—ch. 34, 1, note. Arnold quotes Hdt. vii. 37, o) h()lios e)klipw\n th\n e)k tou= ou)ranou= o(do/n. tei=xos—see ch. 75, 26.

o(rw=ntes...o)/ntes—the manuscript reading is o)/ntas, which might possibly be explained as referring to tou\s sfete/rous: o)/ntes however is read by all editors, to avoid ambiguity. The position was held by the Argive confederates jointly (ch. 75).
*dhmosqe/nhn—the common form of the accusative of this name. It is a ‘heteroclite’, like *swkra)ths, which makes both *swkra/thn and *swkra)th.

pro/fasin—the accusative in apposition adverbially used; so iii. 111, 1: cf. proi=ka, dwrea/n etc. In ch. 53, 2, we have profa/sei. ‘Demosthenes seems to have acted partly from bravado, partly because he preferred to give up the fortress to the Epidaurians, rather than leave it in the possession of the confederate troops, which included those of Argos, now in alliance with Sparta. By the terms of the first treaty (ch. 77, 6) the Argives equally with the Athenians were bound to evacuate the fortress, but this may have been unknown to Demosthenes’ (Jowett).

to\ a)/llo frouriko/n—i.e. oi( a)/lloi frouroi/. The reading of the best manuscripts is frou/rion, which Classen retains, in the sense of froura/, ch. 73, 28. There appears however no certain authority for this usage, and here it would be particularly awkward after the word has just been used in its natural way. It is tempting to suggest the omission either of frouriko/n or the preceding tou= frouri/ou.

a)nanewsa/menoi ta\s sponda/s—‘the treaty referred to is probably that made at the general peace (ch. 18), which, after the many vicissitudes of Athenian and Lacedaemonian politics, might well need to be renewed in any particular which was henceforth intended to be observed. The Epidaurians are
mentioned by name in the armistice (iv. 119, 2), but are only included, without being named, among the allies of the Lacedaemonians in the treaty’ (Jowett).
au)toi/—thus avoiding the appearance of compulsion, and excluding their late allies from any credit for the surrender.

ou) duna/menoi—see note on dienoei=to, ch. 80, 12. cune/bhsan—for 30 years, according to Xen. Hell. v. 2, 2. th\n a)rxh\n...tw=n po/lewn—see ch. 29, ch. 33 etc. These cities were given up in accordance with the provision of the treaty, ch. 79, 5.

kai\ *lakedaimo/nioi—this sentence is a curious example of appositional construction, the subject being first contracted with au)toi\ oi( *lakedaimo/nioi and again expanded with cunamfo/teroi. The clause beginning ta/ t' e)n *sikuw=ni is in fact semiparenthetical, and the meaning is that the Lacedaemonians before marching with the Argives to Argos, went by themselves to Sicyon. The Argive xi/lioi seem those mentioned in ch. 67, 15; most of them escaping the slaughter of Mantinea (ch. 73, 22).

e)s o)li/gous...kate/sthsan—i e. set up an oligarchical government; ii. 37, 1, dia\ to\ mh\ e)s o)li/gous a)ll) e)s plei/onas oi)kei=n: viii. 53, 4, e)s o)li/gous ma=llon ta\s a)rxa\s poih/somen: viii. 89, 3, tou= a)/gan e)s o)li/gous e)lqei=n. In viii. 38, 3, the manuscripts have th=s po/lews e)s o)li/gon katexome/nhs, where the meaning required is ‘being reduced to an oligarchy’. No similar instance of e)s o)li/gon is forthcoming, and Classen and Stahl adopt Dobree's correction e)s o)li/gous.

ma=llon—Krüger seems right in understanding h)\ e)s plei/onas. Most editors understand h)\ pro/teron: but Krüger observes that this would require a more emphatic position of ma=llon, such as before e)s. Grote points out that Sicyon had always been oligarchic and favourable to Sparta; but a democratic party may have been making head.

kate/lusan—see ch. 76, 7. e)pithdei/a—‘favourable to their interests’. This was the Lacedaemonian system; see i. 19, 1, oi) me\n *lakedaimo/nioi ou)x u(potelei=s e)/xontes fo/rou tou=s cumma/xous h)gou=nto, kat' o)ligarxi/an de\ sfi/sin au)toi=s mo/non e)pithdei/ws o(/pws politeu/swsi qerapeu/ontes.
pro\s e)/ar—cf. iv. 135, 1, tou= au)tou= xeimw=nos kai\ pro\s e)/ar h)/dh.
*dih=s—see note on ch. 35, 1. e)pithdei/ws—see note on ch. 81, 11. kaqi/stanto—of political ariangements. At the beginning of the war Achaia was neutral, with the exception of Pellene (ii. 9, 2).

kat' o)li/gon—‘little by little’, gradually; i. 61 fin. kat' o)li/gon proio/ntes: usually ‘in small divisions’ as in iv. 10, 4. cunista/menos—‘conspiring’; iii. 70, 4: or perhaps merely ‘getting together’, as in ii. 88, 1. ‘The oligarchy which was established in Argos pro\s e)/ar (ch. 81, 12), say in March, lasted till the time of the gumnopaidi/ai, a period of about 5 months. During this period the secret meetings and deliberations of the popular party were held, until sufficient confidence for a rising had been gained. a)naqarsh/sas in the aorist denotes the conclusion of the deliberations expressed by the present cunista)menos’ (F.). The clause kat' o)li/gon .a)naqarsh/sas is to be taken in apposition (Krüger), otherwise e)pe/qento with the singular participle would be harsh and almost unexampled: cf. iii. 80, 1, o( dh=mos <*>, perideh\s geno/menos, h)/|esan e)s lo/gous.

e)pe/qento—ch. 76, 11. thrh/santes—ii. 22, 1, thrh/santes nu/kta xeime/rion: with infinitive iv. 26, 4, e)th/roun a)ne/mw| katafe/resqai. au)ta/s—‘the exact time of’: ii. 3, 3, fula/cantes au)to\ to\ peri/orqron. The Gymnopaediae were held in Hecatombaeon, about July. The festival consisted of gymnastic and warlike exercises, and, like the Carneia, kept the Spartans at home.

e(/ws me/n—anterior in time to the clause with de/, and subordinate in sense. e)k plei/onos—‘for some time back’, iv.
42, 3: iv. 103, 3. It is to be taken with h)=lqon. The sense is that, though the Lacedaemonians had for some time taken no notice of repeated appeals for help, yet now they postponed the festival and marched out. There is a suspicious incompleteness about the sentence, and a want of antithesis between the clauses with me/n and de/. We should expect to/te de/ or the like.

a)gge/lwn—‘as messengers’. Most editors would omit this word. F. follows Muller-Strubing in reading kai\ a)gge/lwn tw=n. The Argives in the city sent envoys, the exiles could only send messengers. presbe/wn te a)po/ is also suggested for presbe/wn a)po/ te. This would make the sentence clearer, still irregularities with te are common.

a)f) e(kate/rwn—‘on either side’; iii. 36, 5, gnw=mai a)f) e)ka/stwn e)le/gonto: ch. 37, 2. e)/gnwsan—‘pronounced’, as heads of the Peloponnesian league. diatribai/—ch. 38, 30: vii. 49, 3, o)/knos tis kai\ me/llhsis e)nege/neto, prosago/menos—‘courting’ or ‘trying to gain’; more usually of persons, iii. 32, 2, o)li/gous e)s fili/an prosa/cesqai. Also of acquiring places by capitulation, as in ii. 30, 2: vi. 54, 3.

me/giston (a)\n) w)felh/sein—so vii. 24, 3, me/giston e)ka/kwse: vii. 44, 6 me/giston e)/blaye. The plural is more common in such cognate constructions, but the singular is quite regular; see Krüger's Grammar, § 46, 5. a)/n with the future mfinitive is found five times in Thucydides according to manuscript authority. Whether it can be retained is a moot point; see note on ch. 15, 11, and Goodwin, § 208: Madvig's Greek Syntax, § 173, R. 2. Here it is easy to omit a)/n or to read w)felh=sai. The subject of the infinitive in the Athenian alliance, not the contemplated building of walls (Herbst). The latter view involves a gratuitous irregularity in the use of te and kai/, and in no way improves the sense.

makra\ tei/xh—see ch. 52, 15. The distance to the sea, according to Pausanias, was four miles and a half. Plutarch says that the building of the walls was promoted by Alcibiades, who came to Argos after the victory of the demociacy (Alc. 15).
e)pagwgh/—vii. 24, 3, oi( e)/sploi th=s e)pagwgh=s tw=n e)pithdei/wn: i. 81, 1, e)k qala/sshs w(=n de/ontai e)pa/contai.

cunh/|desan—the following accusative is rare: Hdt. vi. 39, suneido/tes tou= patro\s to\n qa/naton: Xen. Hell. iii. 3, 6, cunei-
do/tas th\n pra=cin. Krüger suggests cunh/|nesan. Jealousy and fear of Sparta, no doubt fomented by Alcibiades, had already pioduced an inclination towards Athens, and long walls would draw the Argives into closer connexion with the Athenian naval power. For the position of tine/s cf. i. 45, 2, and i. 53, 4, e)s tw=n e)kei/nwn ti xwri/wn (where Kruger reads xwri/on): Xen. Anab. ii. 5, 32, tw=n barba/rwn tine\s i(ppe/wn. In ch 25, 7, the order is different.

te/ktones—timber was used in such works; vi. 99, 1, li/qous kai\ cu/la cumforou=ntes, of the besieging Athenians at Syracuse. teixizo/ntwn—ai)sqa/nomai is found with the genitive i. 57, 4 etc., but only here with the genitive participle: the accusative construction is common, as in ch. 37, 18.

au)toi=s—probably with u(ph=rxe ‘they had to start with’ but the dative might also be taken with prasso/menon. Indeed its construction is affected by both words, in accordance with a common Thucydidean order. e)k tou= *)/argous au)to/qen—ii. 25, 3, au)to/qen e)k th=s perioiki/dos *)hlei/wn: Hdt. viii. 64, au)to/qen e)k *salami=nos.
ou) prou)xw/rhsen e)/ti—‘came to nothing further’. *(usia/s —near the border of Arcadia on the road to Tegea

o(/ti—gives the reason for dh|w/santes, the participle as usual being the emphatic word. We may compare the clause in the treaty, ch. 47, 17, h(\n de\ dh|w/santes oi)/xwntai. sfw=n—i. 30, 3, sfw=n oi( cu/mmaxoi e)po/noun: so iv. 13, 2, au)tw=n oi( a)/ndres a)pelamba/nonto. The position of the pronoun gives it an emphatic force, ‘they found them receiving, they were aggrieved by their receiving their exiles’, cf. Buttmann on Dem. Meid. 520, § 17, to\n dida/skalon die/fqeire/ mou. katw/|khnto—i. 120, 2, katw|khme/nous: ii. 96, 1, o)/sa me/rh katw/|khto. This use of the perfect and pluperfect is peculiar to Thucydides and Herodotus.

kate/klh|san—‘blockaded’, they stopped any coasting trade which might be carried on in the winter; tou=t' e)/sti tw=n ei)sagwgi/mwn th=s qala/sshs au)tou\s a)pe/klh|san (schol.): i. 117, 2, e)lqo/ntos tou= *perikle/ous kateklh/|sqhsan. This passage and the scholiast's explanation seem enough to support the reading. katelh/isan with *makedoni/as, partitive genitive, and e)lh/|isan have been suggested; but the compound is only found in the middle and that in late authors, and the active of the simple verb is too far from the manuscript reading. According to the best manuscripts it occurs in iii 85, 1, and iv. 41, 2, but even there Classen adopts the middle. Most manuscripts have *makedoni/as *perdi/kkan: which can scarcely mean ‘Perdiccas (king) of Macedonia’, no similar instance being known. Another explanation connects the genitive with kate/klh|san on the analogy of Soph. Aj. 1274, e)rke/wn e)gkeklhme/nous, ‘shut up within your bulwarks’. *makedoni/a| has also been conjectured ‘shut him up with’ i.e. ‘in Macedonia’. Two inferior manuscripts have *makedoni/an, and probably this or *make/donas should be adopted, the scholiast's au)tou/s being in favour of the latter. *perdi/kka|, depending on e)pikalou=ntes, should then be read in accordance with Goeller's suggestion; cf. ch. 59, 29.

cunwmosi/an—see ch. 80, 11. paraskeuasame/nwn—we are told nothing of this intended expedition. It could scarcely have been before Cleon's death, as Perdiccas up to that time had been faithful to the Athenians since he broke with Brasidas in 423; see ch. 6, 6, and iv. 132, 1. Besides, it is mentioned after the cunwmosi/a.
e)/yeusto—‘had belied’, i.e. failed in; iii. 66, 3, th\n yeusqei=san u(po(sxesin: Hdt. vi. 32, ou)k e)yeu/santo ta\s a)peila/s. So Hom., Eur. and Xen.
h( stratia/—this would imply that the troops were actually sent; or the army at any rate embodied. Perhaps stratei/a should be read; but dielu/qh, ‘was broken up’, goes more naturally with stratia/.

a)pa/rantos—elsewhere a)pai/rw is to start, or put to sea, as in iv. 26, 4: iv. 46, 1. Possibly it may here be used to mean ‘by his defection’, which is the sense required. Most editors however believe it to be corrupt. Poppo suggests a)posta/ntos: Classen ou<*> paro/ntos, a)path/santos etc.

tai=s a)rxai=s—‘the authorities’; ch. 28, 2. The o)li/goi seem to have been a select council or assembly. For the place of the ‘Melian discussion’ in the history, see Introduction. The Athenians first propose a debate on the several points at issue instead of continuous speeches.
o(/pws dh/—so vii. 18, 1, where dh/ gives the actual reason, not merely an alleged motive. r(h/sei—only here in Thucydides. a)ne/legkta—not to be questioned or disproved.
tou=to fronei=—‘this is the idea (intention) of’ your bringing us before the few: vi. 36, 2, ai( a)ggeli/ai tou=to du/nantai. For u(mw=n Krüger and others prefer the objective genitive h(mw=n.

a)gwgh/—‘bringing’: there are two passages, iv. 29, 1, and vi. 29, 3, where this word is found in the manuscripts and where the sense required is ‘putting to sea’ or the like. In both passages most editors alter it into a)nagwgh/. In Xen. Cyr. vi. 1, 24, e)n tai=s a)gwgai=s means ‘on marches’ lit. the ‘leading’ of an army. mhd) u(mei=s—mhde/ compares the two parties to the discussion; ‘do not you any more than we’. As the Melians feared the effect of an uninterrupted address from the Athenians, so on their part they were not to restrict themselves to a single speech, but state their objections item by item as they occurred. According to this view e(ni\ lo/gw| depends on the sense ‘giving your answer’ supplied from the following words. Classen however takes e(ni\ lo/gw| of the Athenians' speech, connecting it closely with kri/nete, ‘do not you either form your decision from (hearing) a single speech’ mhde/ then would contrast u(mei=s, the select audience, with the plh=qos. This view gives a good sense, but it seems more natural to refer e(ni\ lo/gw| to the subject of the sentence, and the dative can scarcely equal e(/na lo/gon a)kou/santes.
u(polamba/nontes—‘replying’; ii. 72, 1: ch. 49, 20.

ei)/pate—the only instance of a form from aorist ei)=pa in Thucydides. Generally ei)=pas and ei)/pate are more usual than the corresponding forms of ei)=pon. The Melian representatives fear that they will have no real freedom of discussion. The verdict has already gone against them.
cu/nedroi—‘commissioners’; iv. 22, 1: they are afterwards called o)li/goi a)/ndres in the same chapter.
