e)piei/keia—‘equitableness’, and reasonable consideration; iii. 40, 3, h( e)piei/keia pro\s tou\s me/llontas e)pithdei/ous e)/sesqai di/dotai: iii. 48, 1, mh/t' oi)/ktw| ple/on ne/montes mh/t' e/pieikei/a|. ‘The primary sense of e)pieikh/s is equitable, one who has a leaning to the merciful side and of an indulgent disposition, as opposed to one who takes a strict and vigorous view of an offence, puts a harsh construction on men's motives and actions, and is inclined to enforce on all occasions the letter of the law. From this, and because we think this the better disposition of the two, e)pieikh/s is transferred by metaphor to the general signification of good’ (Cope on Ar. Rhet. i. 2, 4). For further illustration of to\ e)peike/s see Ar. Rhet. i. 13, 13—9: Eth. Nic. v. 10: vi. 11, 1.
au)tou=—‘it’, tou= dida/skein, etc. e)c au)tou= below refers to the same. For this use of au)to/ and au)ta/ see ch. 27, 4; and note on e)pa/qomen au)to/, iv. 25, 1.

perigenome/nois—if we prove the better in the justice of our cause: Dem. Pant. 978, pollw=| tw=| dikai/w| periei=nai boulo/menos. The Athenians call on them in effect to say yes or no to their proposal.
toi/nun—‘well then, if you etc.’ toi/nun occurs in Thucydides only in direct address; ch. 89, 1: 105, 1, etc.

u(ponoi/as—‘to calculate surmises of what is going to happen’. u(po/noia here is a somewhat invidious word: in ii. 41, 4, tw=n e)/rgwn th\n u(po/noian is simply the conception of facts as opposed to the reality. a)/llo ti—pra/contes may be mentally supplied, but really the phrase is independent of construction; cf. iii. 85, 4, a)po/gnoia tou= a)/llo ti h(\ kratei=n th=s gh=s: so iii. 39, 1, ti a)/llo h(\ e)pebou/leusan: iii. 58, 5, ti/ a)/llo h)\ katalei/yete: ii. 16, ou)de\n a)/llo h)\ a)polei/pwn.

e)k tw=n paro/ntwn k.t.l.—contrasted with the invisible future. bouleu/sontes—here and in ch. 111, 5, the active is appropriately used of the commissioners who ‘advise’ in the interests of the people at large. There seem however undoubted instances where Thucydides uses bouleu/w in the sense of ‘taking counsel’, and e)bou/leusa of ‘deciding’; and where other Attic writers would employ the middle: see note on iv. 15, 1.
pauoi/meq) a)/n—‘we will (in that case) stop’, Contrast this cynical affectation of indifference with the peremptory ei(\pate at the end of ch. 85.

e)pi\ tou=to—sc. cunh/kete: iv. 18, 1, e)f) a(\ nu=n a)figme/noi u(ma=s ai)tou/meqa. There are abundant instances to justify the manuscript reading in iv. 3, 2, e)pi\ tou=to ga\r cune/pleuse, though most editors alter it to e)pi\ tou/tw|. The Melians agree to the discussion.
me/n—answered by me/ntoi. cuggnw/mh—iv. 61, 4, tou\s *)aqhnai/ous pleonektei=n pollh\ cuggnw/mh. e)n tw=| toiw=|de kaqestw=tas—‘in a position like ours’.

e)pi\ polla\ tre/pesqai—ch. 111, 14. i. 20, fin., e)pi\ ta\ e(toi=ma tre/pontai. dokou=ntas—‘in thought’: ‘minus invidiosa voce sententiam exprimunt eandem quam Athenienses verbo u(ponoei=n’ (Krüger).

kai\ peri\ swthri/as—‘particula kai/ ita collocata est, ut si in altero membro kai\ to\n lo/gon...e)xe/tw gigno/menon vel similia quaedam essent secutura’ (Poppo): so iii 67, 6, a)mu/nate ou)=n kai\ tw=| no/mw|.. kai\ h(mi=n a)ntapo/dote xa/rin dikai/an. h(/de pa/resti— ‘is here present’. The Athenians deprecate appeals to abstract justice and the like, and call on the Melians to take a practical view of the actual facts.

ou)/te au)toi/ ..ou)/q) u(ma=s—‘well then, we make no pretence of fine words, and we beg you will not’. The o)no/mata kala/ are appeals to justice and the like, contrasted with ta\ dunata/. Similar language is attributed to the Athenian envoy Euphemus at Camarina, vi. 83, 2, ou) kalliepou/meqa, w(s h)\ to\n ba/rbaron mo/noi kaqelo/ntes ei)ko/tws a)/rxomen k.t.l. See also the whole of the Athenian speech at Sparta before the war, i. 73—78. o)no/mata = nomina, names of things; cf. iii. 82, 4, th\n ei)wqui=an a)ci/wsin tw=n o)noma/twn a)nth/llacan
a)dikou/menoi—note the use of the present. e)pecerxo/meqa—‘are seeking redress, exacting vengeance’; iii. 38, 1, o( paqw\n e)pece/rxetai: vi. 38, 2, h(mei=s kakoi\ e)pecelqei=n.

ou)/q) u(ma=s a)ciou=men—ou)k a)ciw= = ‘I request you not’; ch. 26, 9: i. 136, 3, ou)k a)cioi= feu/gonta timwrei=sqai. h(\ o(/ti... h)\ w(s—dependent on le/gontas. *aakedaimoni/wn .cunestrateu/sate—in sentences like this the verb states a fact of which the participle gives the reason; cf. line 2: iv. 27, 2, e)/xonta/s ti i/sxuro\n au)tou\s e)no/mizon ou)ke/ti e)pikhrukeu/esqai, ‘thought they must have some strong ground to rely on as they made no more overtures’. Here we must supply with cun estrateu/sate either (1) au)toi=s, ‘though Lacedaemonian colonists you did not serve with them against us’. or (2) h(mi=n, ‘you did not join us because you were Lacedaemonian colonists’. Either rendering gives good sense. In favour of (1), it is easier to supply au)toi=s from *lakedaimoni/wn than to understand h(mi=n, and we also get a sharper antithesis to the following h(ma=s.

ta\ dunata\...diapra/ssesqai—still dependent on a)ciou=men, u(ma=s being the subject. Classen holds that the subject is now
not merely u(ma=s but e)ka/teroi, a)ciou=men being taken in a somewhat altered sense ‘we think it right (for both of us) to endeavour to effect etc.’ But this view weakens the force of the sentence, in which, from ou)/q) u(ma=s, the Athenians are dictating to the Melians the line which they expect them to take. The middle form diapra/ssesqai implies mutual arrangement. 8 e)pistame/nous pro\s ei)do/tas—‘since you know as well as we do’. pro(s may be taken either with diapra/ssesqai, or generally in the sense of ‘dealing with, having to do with’.

e)n tw=| a)nqrwpei/w| lo/gw|—‘in the language (or reasoning) of (practical) men’, as opposed to the theories of philosophers and the dreams of fanatics: cf. ch. 111, 6, a)/nqrwpoi: ch. 103, 9, a)nqrwpei/ws: i. 76, 2, a)po\ tou= a)nqrwpei/ou tro/pou: iii. 40, 1, a(martei=n a)nqrwpi/nws.

a)po/—‘from the standpoint of’; i. 21, 2, a)p) au)tw=n tw=n e)/rgwn skopou=si: or perhaps ‘starting from’, ‘backed by’; i. 91, 4, a)po\ a)ntipa/lou paraskeuh=s: cf. ch. 103, 2. a)na/gkhs—probably active = ‘power to compel’; i. 99, 1, prosa/gontes ta\s a)na/gkas: but possibly ‘cum sunt e)n i)/sh| a)na(gkh|)’. Questions of justice may be argued, when both parties are equal in strength, but now it is not a question of abstract justice, but of practical possibilities.

dunata/—what can be practically realized; ‘but that is possible which the strong effect and the weak acquiesce in’: or possibly pra/ssousi may mean ‘exact’. For pra/ssousi the scholiast gives prosta/ssousi, which Dobree and Cobet would adopt; pra/ssomen however is similarly used in ch. 105, 4. The neuter plural is the object of cugxwrou=sin, as in ch. 41, 12. CHAPTER XC
The Melians urge that, even setting aside abstract considerations of justice, they may hope for fair treatment on the ground of general expediency.
h(=| me\n dh/—‘as we think, at any rate, it is ad vantageous’. Some editors have <*>me=s dh/, or h(mei=s me\n dh/, making xrh/simon depend on nomi/zomen.

a)na/gkh ga/r—‘we must needs take the ground of expediency’. para\ to\ di/kaion—‘setting aside, passing by the question of justice’. u(pe/qesqe—‘lay down the principle’, ‘make expediency the basis of discussion’.
to\ koino\n a)gaqo/n—explained by what follows. It is the principle of equity, and reasonable consideration.

ei)=nai ta\ ei)ko/ta kai\ di/kaia—‘that for him who from time to time is in danger (1) what is reasonable should be also considered just’; or (2) ‘he should have all that is reasonable and just’. (1) is supported by the absence of kai/ from the best manuscripts; while the scholiast's explanation, ta\ prosh/konta kai\ ta\ di/kaia ne/mesqai, is in favour of (2), which also gives a more emphatic force to ei)=nai. Dobree is in favour of taking ta\ ei)ko/ta k.t.l. as dependent, like ti kai\ e)nto/s, on pei/santa, ‘men in danger should be allowed, if they can plead what is reasonable and just, nay something even short of strict justice, to get the benefit thereof’. For this force of ei)=nai cf. iii. 39, 9, o(/tan h)\ katorqw/santi e)leuqe/rwsis h)=|, h)\ sfale)nti mhde\n a)nh/keston paqei=n. Krüger and Stahl would omit di/kaia.

kai/ ti kai\ e)nto/s—‘something which even falls short of the strict letter’: Cic. Ep. Fam. ix. 26, 9, non modo non contra legem sed intra legem: so cis, citra; Tac. Ann. xi. 30, veniam petens quod ei cis Plautios cis Vettios dissimulavisset, ‘begging pardon for having hidden what he knew, so long as matters did not go beyond a Plautius and a Vettius’: ib. xii. 22, ira Agrippinae citra ultima stetit, ‘stopped short of extremities’.
tou= a)kribou=s—‘strict justice’; iv. 47, 1, w(/ste a)kribh= th\n pro/fasin gene/sqai.

pei/santa—nearly all manuscripts have pei/sonta, which some editors retain as = me/llonta pei/sein, ‘if he has the prospect of getting accepted’; ‘although he may be destined to fail in making out a strict case’ (Jowett). But the slight alteration to the aorist is preferable, ‘quum utilitas perfecta demum persuasione effici possit’ (Poppo). With pei/santa is connected the neuter accusative ti (iv. 17, 1, o(/ ti a)\n pei/qwmen), and also, if Dobree's view be adopted, tina as accusative of the object. Otherwise tina is the subject of w)felhqh=nai. For the use of w)felei=sqai, cf. iii. 53, 3, e)peisenegka/menoi martu/ria w)felou/meq) a)/n.

pro\s u(mw=n—‘for your advantage’, ‘in your interest’; iv. 17, 2, ta\ plei/w o(rw= pro\s h(mw=n o)/nta. ou)x h(=sson—litotes. The following o(/sw| is connected with the comparative. e)pi\ megi/sth| timwri/a|—e)pi/ seems here connected with sfale/ntes, to denote the conditions under which the Athenians would be defeated if such an event should take place: ‘having the heaviest vengeance to look for in case you should be overthrown’. So we say ‘standing to lose’ so much on a future event. Krüger and Classen connect the words with para/deigma a)\n ge/noisqe, taking e)pi/ to denote the accompanying circumstances and conditions; ‘you would, by the heavy vengeance which you would incur, become an example to others’. Others render ‘an example for inflicting vengeance’, meaning that the Athenians are setting a precedent which may be used against them if they fall. But the idea is rather that if punishment should hereafter fall on Athens it would be so heavy as to be a warning to all other nations against lawless ambition. For para/. deigma in the sense of a warning example, which certainly seems the meaning here, cf. iii. 39, 3. CHAPTER XCI

The Athenians set aside general considerations. They are competent to look after their own interests. Now they are come with a definite purpose; and they urge that it is better for both sides that the Melians should submit to their power.

th
 teleuth/n—an unusual accusative. It is explained by Classen as an extension of the adverbial construction, like a)porou=ntes tau=ta ch. 40, 16. There however tau=ta = tau/tas ta\s a)pori/as, and the accusative is cognate and ‘internal’; which is not the case with teleuth/n here. Poppo says ‘compara cum tre/mein ti/, fri/ssein ti, fobei=sqai/ ti, e)kplh/ssesqai ti, Latinis tremere aliquid, horrere aliquid, similibus’. Elsewhere a)qumei=n is connected with the dative; as in vii. 60, 5, tw=| krathqh=nai a)qumou=ntas. Here the dative would give a wrong sense, ‘we are cast down by’, and would imply that the teleuth/ was a fact already reached, not merely a future possibility. Herodotus has a)pore/onti th
 e)/lasin (iii. 4), and a)pore/onti th
 e)cagwgh/n (iv. 179).
w(/sper kai/—ch. 44, 10: ch. 92, 2. ou(=toi—so iv. 44, 3, toi=s d) <*>mi/sesi tw=n *korinqi/wn. tou/tois ou) kata/dhlos h( ma/xh h)=n. It has been suggested to read ou(/tw, as in ch. 59, 20.

e)/sti de/—parenthetical; ou) ga\r ou(=toi deinoi/ being answeied by a)ll) h)/n, sc. ou(=toi deinoi/ or tou=to deino/n. Some editors put a stop before e)/sti, making the opposition between ou) pro/s., and a)ll) h)/n. The sense is against this, as it would imply that the Melians were already u)ph(kooi and the Athenians a)/rcantes, which was not the case. The insertion of a parenthetical clause is also thoroughly Thucydidean.
o( a)gw/n = we are not now contending with Sparta: for a similar use of the article cf ch. 101, 2: ch. 110, 3.

au)toi\ e)piqe/menoi—cf. Cleon's arguments for punishing the Mytileneans, iii. 39 and 40. He especially insists on the danger arising from the unprovoked character of their insurrection; e)pe/qento h(mi=n ou)k a\dikou/menoi—proupa/rcantes a(diki/as, etc.
a)fei/sqw—‘let it be left to us’. kinduneu/esqai—impersonal passive, as in i. 73, 2, e)pi\ w)feli/a| e)kinduneu/eto: so iv. 19, 1, diakinduneu/esqai.
e)p' w)feli/a|—the order is emphatic, ‘that it is with a view to advantage we are here, the advantage that is of our empire’, etc.
a)po/nws—without the trouble of war. a)/rcai—‘to become your lords’; so douleu=sai ‘to submit to your yoke’, in the next chapter, u(pakou=sai; ch. 93, etc. xrhsi/mws—with a)mfote/rois. CHAPTER XCII

xrh/simon—note the adjective with cumbai/h: vi. 34, 9, xrhsimw/taton a)\n cumbh=nai: so especially toiou=tos, i. 74, 1, toiou/tou cu/mbantos tou/tou: vii. 30 fin. etc. Here, cumbai/nein may have the idea of coinciding interests.

w(/sper kai/—so ch. 91, 3: cf. ch. 13, 8 note.
CHAPTER XCIII

The Athenians hint significantly enough that resistance is hopeless, and will involve terrible calamities. ge/noito—gi/gnesqai here = contingere, licere. Krüger compares Xen. Anab. i. 9, 13, e)ge/neto kai\ *(/ellhni kai\ barba/rw| a)dew=s poreu/esqai: id. Cyr. vi. 3, 11, w)= *zeu= me/giste, labei=n moi ge/noito au)to/n. CHAPTER XCIV
The Melians suggest the possibility of a strict neutrality on their part being acceptable.

w(/ste de/—‘but on condition that...would you not accept us?’ or ‘would you not accept such terms?’ For w(/ste of conditions cf. ch. 17, 14: and for de/xomai ch. 32, 24. w(/ste de/ is the reading of some manuscripts but not of the majority. It is probably right, as de/ is used in a similar way in the beginning of cc. 96 and 98. If w(/ste only be read, it goes with ou)k a)
 de/caisqe, on which the infinitive construction fi/lous ei(=nai then depends: cf. i. 143, 2, ou)dei\s a)
 de/caito th
 au(tou= feu/gein. The sentence is thus a timid suggestion on the part of the Melians, ‘so that...you would not agree to our being neutral’, or ‘would you not agree?’

de/caisqe—so most editors for de/coisqe, which has the best manuscript authority, and is retained by Classen. This would be a strange use of the future optative = ou)k a)\n me/lloite de/cesqai; ‘would you not be likely to accept us?’ No similar instance is quoted; indeed the future optative with a)/n is unknown. For its legitimate use see Goodwin § 128—134. CHAPTER XCV
The Athenians reply that to accept such an offer would be a manifest proof of weakness.

ou) ga/r—=‘no, for’ etc. o(/son h( fili/a—in this extraordinary sentence fili/a does double duty, first as the subject
of the verb and then in apposition, while to\ mi=sos corresponds appositionally to h( e)/xqra, the order of fili/a and e)/xqra being reversed. ‘Verba sic resolvenda sunt, o(/son h( fili/a, h( me
 a)sqenei/as para/deigma ou)=sa, to\ de\ mi=sos .dhlou/menon’ (Poppo). Possibly h( fili/a, h( me/n should actually be read for h( fili/a me/n: but more likely the sentence grew up in some such way as this— (1) ou) tosou=ton bla/ptei h( e)/xqra u(mw=n o(/son h( fili/a: (2) o(/son h( fili/a, a)sqenei/as para/deigma ou)=sa: (3) o(/son h( fili/a me
...to\ de\ mi=sos, ‘your enmity does not injure us so much as your friendship, being on the one hand a proof of weakness, your hatred being etc.’ Cleon utters similar sentiments, e.g. iii. 39, 5, pe/fuke ga kai\ a)/llws a)/nqrwpos to\ me
 qerapeu=on u(perfronei=n, to\ de\ mh\ u)pei=kon qauma/zein: cf. oderint dum metuant (Krüger). CHAPTER XCVI
Are friendly relations then, ask the Melians, between you and the Greek islanders, an invariable proof of weakness? Is there no difference between strangers and your own colonists?

tou/s te mh\ prosh/kontas—‘those who have no connexion with you’, and on whom you have no claim. o(/soi...oi( polloi/ tine/s—a notable instance of appositional construction, ‘all who, being mostly colonists, and having revolted in some cases’; cf. iv. 62, 2, plei/ous h)/dh .e)lpi/santes e(/t eroi.
kexei/rwntai—‘the verb does not apply strictly to a)/poikoi, but only to tine/s, and under the influence of a)posta/ntes is used instead of a more general verb, such as a)/rxontai’ (Jowett).

e)s to\ au)to\ tiq<*>asin—‘put under the same head, reckon together’; iv. 73, 2, kai\ au)toi=s th\n ni/khn dikai/ws a)\n ti/qesqai: see Liddell and Scott, ti/qhmi B. ii. 3, for various phrases with ei)s, e)n, adverbs etc. In Latin we have a similar usage of traho, ibidem traho, traho ad, in; e.g. Plaut. Trin. ii. 4, 10, ibidem una traho, ‘I count it under the same head’.
CHAPTER XCVII
No, reply the Athenians; our subjects are convinced that all such things are mere questions of material strength.

dikaiw/mati—‘in plea of justice’, ‘rationes quibus suam causam tueantur’; i. 41, 1, dilaiw/mata ta/de pro\s u(ma=s e)/xomen. The dative is not elsewhere in Thucydides found with e)llei/pein, which takes the genitive, i. 80, 4, pollw=| e)/ti ple/on tou/tou <*>llei/pomen (where Kruger reads tou/tw|): ii. 61, 4, th=s u(parxou/shs do/chs e)llei/pei. The construction is however not unreasonable, as the dative denotes that in which the deficiency occurs; and a genitive of the person, a)/llwn or u(mw=n, is virtually implied. It may also be supported by such constructions as ch. 72, 10, th=| e)mpeiri/a| e)lasswqe/ntes: so vi. 69, 1, th=| proqumi/a| e)llipei=s. Kruger suggests reading e)llipei=s here. One manuscript has dikaiw/mata, and this would go well either with the accusative or ou)dete/rois.

kata\ du/namin—lit. ‘m accordance with’. It is a question of material strength and power, not of abstract justice. perigi/gnesqai = ‘escape submission’; e)leuqe/rous me/nein, as explained by the scholiast.
e)/cw—ch. 26, 13: i. 9, 7 etc. Thuc. and Hdt., also Xen. Anab. vii. 3, 10. kai\ tou= seems awkward; should it be tou= kai/? Note aorist a)/rcai, as in ch. 91, 10.

nhsiw=tai naukrato/rwn—these words are put together for the sake of antithesis, naukrato/rwn being dependent grammatically on perige/noisqe, ‘especially as you are islanders while we are lords of the sea, weaker islanders too than others, should you not escape submission (get the better of us)’. In vi. 82, 2, according to the manuscript reading, there is a still harsher construction, h(mei=s *)/iwnes o)/ntes *peloponnhsi/ois *dwrieu=si ..e)skeya/meqa o(/tw| tro/pw| h(/kista au)tw=n u(pakouso/meqa. There *dwrieu=si is first put out of its place for the sake of antithesis, and then the construction changes. For the juxtaposition cf. vi. 6, 3, *dwrih=s de\ *dwrieu=si...bohqh/santes.
CHAPTER XCVIII
The Melians now point out the probable danger to Athens of her overbearing policy.

e)n d) e)kei/nw|—either (1) ‘in the former case’, i.e. in the neutrality proposed in ch. 94; or (2) like illud, referring to what is coming, o(/soi ga/r k.t.l. (2) seems more probable, as de/ in this dialogue generally introduces a fresh point or suggestion. The meaning affects the sense to be given to ou) nomi/zete a)sfa/leian, either (1) sc. ei)=nai, ‘do you think there is no security?’, or (2) do you not take safety into consideration?’.

dei= ga/r . pei/qein—parenthetical. au)= kai\ e)ntau=qa—as well as in the case suggested in ch. 90. e)kbiba/santes—Classen reads e)kbia/santes, and e)kbia/zoien in vi. 64, 1, with some MSS. authority. e)kbia/zw however is not found before Plutarch (passive Soph. Phil. 1129), while e)kbiba/zw has better classical authority, but only in its literal sense (vii. 39, 2: Hdt. vii. 130: Xen. etc.).

tw=| u(mete/rw| cumfo/rw|—‘to be subservient to your interests’; iv. 87, 2, tw=| u(mete/rw| eu)/nw| bla/ptwntai. to\ au)to/ may be appositional with xrh/simon, ‘at the same time’, like idem; as in iv. 17, 1, o)/ ti a)
 u(mi=n te w)fe/limon o)
 to\ au)to\ pei/qwmen. cumbai=non—the regular participial construction with tugxa/nw. Poppo says ‘simul audi xrh/simon’, as in ch. 92. cumbai/nein is indeed used in the sense of turning out well, as in iii. 3, 3, h)
 cumbh=| h( pei=ra, but u(mi=n cumbai=non by itself can scarcely mean ‘expedient for you’.

mhdete/rois—mh/ shows that o(/soi = ei)/ tines: cf. ch. 110, 6. In ch. 30, 13, where dennite persons are meant, o(/soi is followed by ou). pw=s ou)—‘must you not make them your enemies?’ polemou=sqai is elsewhere passive, as twice in i. 57, 1. Sometimes forms may come either from polemou=sqai or polemei=sqai, for instance polemou=ntai, iv. 20, 3.

ta/de—i.e. our case, what is doing here. Note the emphatic position of pote: they will feel that the day will come when they too will be assailed: vi. 78, 4, ta/x' a)\n i)/sws kai\ toi=s e\moi=s a)gaqoi=s pote boulhqei/h au)=qis fqonh=sai.

ka)n tou/tw|—‘herein’, i.e. hereby: slightly different ii. 8, 3: iv. 14, 2, etc. For ti/ a)/llo h)/ see note on ch. 87, 2. megalu/nete—‘strengthen’, in numbers etc.: in vi. 28, 2, of magnifying a crime. mellh/sontas—In ch. 30, 4, we have the aorist infinitive following the present of me/llein: so vi. 30, 2. Many editors however adopt the correction mellh/santas. which is supported by the scholiast's explanation dianohqe/ntas
e)pa/gesqe—‘bring on yourselves’ as enemies; vi. 10, 1, polemi/ous e/pagage/sqai. CHAPTER XCIX
The Athenians reply that they do not fear the hostility of large powers so much as the insubordinate spirit of islanders.

tw=| e)leuqe/rw|—dative of the cause, ‘from their freedom’, i.e. freedom from Athenian rule or the danger of it. The idea is that the mainland cities would be free from the feeling of imminent peril, which might at any time drive the islanders to desperate risks. Stahl suggests tw=n e)leuqe/rwn, comparing vii. 44, 8, o(/soi h(=san tw=n prote/rwn stratiwtw=n. diame/llhsis is not found elsewhere: the verb occurs i. 142, 1 etc.
a)lla/—following ou) and the comparative; i. 83, 1, o( po/lemos ou)x o(/plwn to\ ple/on a)lla\ dapa/nhs: so ii. 43, 2 etc.
tou\s nhsiw/tas te/ pou—Krüger alters pou into tou/s, and the article seems certainly required; unless indeed a)na/rktous w(/sper u(ma=s (sc. o)/ntas) can be taken as a predicate.

kai\ tou\s h)/dh—‘and those who are already exasperated by the constraint of our empire’. The subject allies are meant, see i. 76, 77, where the Athenians point out that the rule of sovereign states must needs be galling in time of war. Classen misunderstands this passage, taking parocunome/nous to refer to the a)/narktoi who were ‘already made desperate’ by the ‘inevitable danger’ (tw=| a)nagkai/w|) of Athenian empire. With this view he proposes to leave out te after nhsiw/tas and tou/s before h)/dh. The next chapter however shows conclusively that oi( douleu/ontes h)/dh are meant.

plei=sta e)pitre/yantes—Hdt. iii. 36, 1, mh\ pa/nta h(liki/h| kai\ qumw=| e)pi/trepe: in both passages the verb appears to have an active force. Sometimes the accusative is not expressed, Hom. Il. x. 79, e)pe/trepe gh/rai( lugrw=| (the only instance in Homer): Plat Legg. 802 B, tai=s e)piqumi/ais.
e)s prou(=pton ki/ndunon—Hdt. ix. 17, proo/ptw| qana/tw| dw/sein: Aesch. etc. For the construction cf. ii. 100, 6, e)s ki/ndunon kaqi/stasan. Classen quotes other instances with e)s. CHAPTER C
The Melians now urge that tame submission would be most dishonourable.

h)= pou a)/ra—‘surely then’; i. 142, 1, h)= pou dh/, ‘much more’: vi. 37, 3, h)= pou/ ge dh/. For a)/ra. stating an inference subjectively, see Liddell and Scott. Note the emphatic force of ge twice in this sentence.

mh\ pauqh=nai—the infinitives express purpose and follow th\n parakindu/neusin poiou=ntai (Goodwin § 770). a)rxh=s—so iii. 40, 4, pau/esqai th=s a)rxh=s. parakindu/neusis is only found here; the verb occurs twice in Thucydides, and is not uncommon elsewhere. The preposition gives the idea of reckless venture.

pa=n e)pecelqei=n—‘to do and suffer anything’ (Jowett). Xen. Anab. iii. 1, 18, ou)k a)\n e)pi\ pa=n e)/lqoi; ib. pa/nta poihte/on: Soph. O. T. 260, e)pi\ pa/nt' a)fi/comai. For the accusative construction, cf. i. 70, 4, a(\ a)\n e)pinoh/santes mh\ e)pece/lqwsin. pro\ tou= douleu=sai—‘before submitting to your yoke’: or is pro/ used of choice, as in ch. 36, 18? CHAPTER CI
Not so, reply the Athenians; honour does not require you to contend against hopeless odds.

ou)k, h)/n ge—so iii. 66 fin. o( a)gw/n—‘you are not now contending’ etc.; see note on ch. 91, 4. The infinitives are explanatory of the purpose, as in ch. 100, a)po\ tou= i)/sou— opposed to pro\s tou\s krei/ssonas pollw=|, ai)sxu/nhn o)flei=n—‘to incur disgrace, forfeit honour’.
CHAPTER CII
The Melians suggest that their case is not absolutely hopeless, as the chances of warfare are uncertain.

ta) tw=n pole/mwn—ii. 11, 3, a)/dhla ta\ tw=n pole/mwn: see also i. 78. koinote/ras—‘more impartial’; in which sense koino/s is applied to persons iii. 53, 2: koinh=| (perhaps) iv. 83, 4. ‘koinai\ tu/xai sunt casus, qui utrisque possunt accidere, adeoque incerti, ancipites, inexspectati, si accidunt potentioribus quae accidere posse non putares’ (Goller): Lys. ii. 10, ta\s e)n tw=| pole/mw| tu/xas koina\s a(pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn nomi/zontes: Plut. Nic. 27, koinai\ ai( tu/xai tou= pole/mou. So Hom. Il. xviii. 309, cuno\s *)enua/lios, kai/ te ktane/onta kate/kta: cf. Cic. Scst. 5, 12, communem martem belli metuenti, where see Holden's note.

e)/stin o(/te—‘at times’; see note on e)/stin h(=, iv. 32, 3. ta\s tu/xas—the fortunes, various phases of war, on several occasions; i. 78, 1: iv. 18, 4, w(s a)\n ai( tu/xai h(gh/swntai. lamba/nonta—apparently ‘receiving’ or ‘admitting of’. e)/xonta might almost be substituted; but e)/xw would imply what is inherent and invariable, while lamba/nw only suggests what sometimes happens. Classen cites vi. 86, 3, o(/tan kairo\n la/bwsin, ‘when they get an opportunity’, but this is not a similar usage.

h)\ kata/—‘than might be expected from’, lit. ‘corresponding to’ etc.: i. 76, 3, dikaio/teroi h)\ kata\ th\n du/namin. eu)qu/s seems to belong to a)ne/lpiston, as e)/ti does to e)lpi/s, but the position is ambiguous.
meta\ tou= drwme/nou—so meta\ kindu/nwn commonly. vi. 16, 3, e)k tou= drwme/nou. For this use of the participle see note on ch. 9, 14: cf. ii, 63, 1, th=s po/lews tw=| timwme/nw| bohqei=n.

o)rqw=s—with sth=nai: some suggest o)rqou/s oi o)rqoi=s.
CHAPTER CIII
The Athenians reply by urging the great danger the Melians incur by risking their all on one vague chance.

kindu/nw| paramu/qion ou)=sa—the sense required is ‘an encouragement to risk’, rather than ‘a solace (relief) to danger’. Whether this meaning can be fairly derived from the dative construction is doubtful. It scarcely corresponds to such phrases as do/sis qeoi=s Plat. Euthyph. 17 c: diakoni/a po/lei Rep. 493 D: for we conld not say paramuqei=sqai kindu/nw|, though we can say dido/nai qeoi=s paramu/qion is commonly found with the genitive, and Kruger here reads kindu/nou.

a)po\ periousi/as—‘with plenty to fall back on’, not risking their all. For a)po/ see ch. 89, 9. xrwme/nous au)th=|—lit. ‘having recourse to her’, or ‘associating with her’. hope being personified: Ar. Vesp. 1028, ta\s *mou/sas ai(=sin xrh=tai.

bla/yh| kaqei=len—the metaphor of sth=nai in the last chapter is carried on: hope may ‘hinder’ such men, and check them in their course, but does not ‘lay them prostrate.’ kaqei=len is the gnomic aorist, which describes what generally happens because it has happened before; Goodwin § 155. The following is from Dr Sandys' note on Dem. Lept. 471, § 49, where bla/ptousin is immediately followed by a)sfalw=s. bla/ptw (though not from the same root as lamba/nw) has in old Greek the special meaning of impeding, checking, arresting (Il. vi. 39: vii. 271 etc.). Hence it is combined with fugei=n in Soph. El. 697, o(/tan de/ tis qew=n bla/pth| du/nait' a)
 ou)d) a)
 i/sxu/wn fugei=n: and Aj. 455. Even in prose we have what may be fairly regarded as a reminiscence, possibly a half unconscious reminiscence, of the older use of the word: as in the present passage of Thucydides; and in vii. 68, 3, kindu/nwn ou(=toi spaniw/tatoi, oi(\ a)
 h(/kista i)k tou= sfalh=nai bla/ptontes plei=sta dia\ to\ eu)tuxh=sai w)felw=sin.

toi=s d) ...a)narriptou=si—‘but as for those who stake their all on the cast’, lit. throw the die, run the risk, so as to extend to their all: iv. 92, 4, e)s pa=san ei(=s o(/ros pagh/setai, ‘one limit will be fixed, extending to and including all our land’. With a)narriptou=si is to be understood ki/ndunon: iv. 85, 2: iv. 95, 1. Classen reads a)narriptou=sa agreeing with e)lpi/s, but the alteration does not seem to improve the grainmar or the sense. a)narriptei=n is used of the person who incurs the risk, not of hope which causes it.

da/panos—sc. elpis e)stin: according to Lid. and Scott, a rare form of the adjective, which is usually dapanhro/s. a(/ma te—‘she is found out when they are ruined’ (lit. tripped up and brought to the ground), not before. a(/ma goes with the participle, which is in the genitive absolute, sc. au)tw=n.

kai\. .oi)k e)llei/pei—most editors take e)llei/pei transitively, ‘she leaves no room for one to guard against her afterwards when she is found out’, i e. her delusive character is not found out till recovery is hopeless. In support of this view may be cited Soph. El. 736, e)lleleimme/non ‘left in’: Eur. El. 609, ou)d) e)lle/loipas e)lpi/d), ‘nor have you left ground for hope’. So prose/xw is occasionally found in the sense ‘to have besides’, as in Plat. Rep. 521 D. Poppo however takes e)llei/pei here in its usual sense of failing, and e)n o(/tw| to mean ‘whilst’, as e)c o(/tou is used of time by Xenophon. This seems the simpler view; and the sense is excellent; that men continue to hope till their condition is desperate. On the other hand the future fula/cetai seems more appropriate to a dependent relative construction.

o(/—ch. 107, 3: 109, 3. e)pi\ r(oph=s mia=s—Eur. Hip. 1164, de/dorke fw=s e)pi\ smikra=s r(oph=s: Soph. Trach. 82, e)n r(oph=| toia=|de keime/nw|. The metaphorical use of r(oph/, ‘a turn of the scale’, is frequent both in prose and verse.

mh\ bou/lesqe paqei=n—‘do not let this be your case’: Plat. Phaedr. 236 c, mh\ bou/lou: so noli, nolite. The whole phrase is equivalent to ‘do not you act thus unadvisedly’: see note on paqei=n, iv. 17, 4.

oi(=s paro/n—the usual form, not oi(\, paro\n (au)toi=s): so in Latin, cui cum nuntiatum esset, Romam advolavit. For a)nqrwpei/ws see note on ch. 89, 9. kaqi/stantai—‘betake themselves’ = katafeu/gousi (schol.).

met' e)lpi/dwn—‘combined with hopes’, i.e. by encouraging vague hopes. lumai/netai—‘ruin men,’ ‘are their bane.’
CHAPTER CIV
The Melians urge that their hopes are not absolutely unreasonable. Heaven will defend their righteous cause; and Sparta will aid them as allies and kinsmen.

ei) mh\...e)/stai—sc. h( tu/xh: ‘if it shall not be impartial’. According to some a)gwni/zesqai is to be supplied, ‘if we shall not be able to contend’. th=| me\n tu/xh|—cf. ch. 112, 8, which suggests that the dative is governed by pisteu/omen, the following infinitive being explanatory: otherwise we should naturally take it with e)lassw/sesqai, as in ch. 72, 10, which would make the general construction of the sentence more regular.

o(/sioi—only here of persons; ‘righteous’, observant of to\ o(/sion (iii. 84, 2). i(sta/meqa—‘we take our stand’; i. 53, 2, h(mi=n e)mpodw\n i(/stasqe o(/pla a)ntairo/menoi. Here i(/stasqai pro/s denotes opposition. Poppo points out that it generally has a different meaning, as in iv. 56, 4, pro\s th\n e)kei/nwn gnw/mhn e(/stasan.

tw=| e)llei/ponti—dependent on prose/sesqai, as is h(mi=n though less directly, and with an ethical force. In illustration of the double dative, Krüger cites Eur. Hel. 1248, ti/ soi para/sxw dh=ta tw=| teqnhko/ti; what service am I to do for you to the dead?
ai)sxu/nh|—=dia\ to\ ai)sxro/n, ch. 105, 14: because they were bound in honour, as we should say. CHAPTER CV
The Athenians reply that they are doing nothing to forfeit the favour of heaven; and the Melians cannot trust for help the Spartan sense of honour.

pro\s to\ qei=on—Krüger suggests tou= qei/ou and Meineke peri\ to\ qei=on. Classen however seems to give the right explanation. The Athenians are speaking not only of the favour they would receive from heaven, but of the general terms on which they stood with the divinity. Their relations with the gods were as good as any one's, for there was nothing unusual in their conduct. Relationship generally is expressed
by pro/s, see note on iv. 80, 2: cf. iv. 51, poihsa/menoi pro\s *)aqh<*>ai/ous pi/steis, etc. = ‘having secured pledges from the Athenians’: Dem. de Cor. 237 § 36, th\n a)pe/xqeian th\n pro\s *qhbai/ous gene/sqai th=| po/lei.
ou)d) h(mei=s—any more than you; an answer to o(/ti o(/sioi pro\s ou) dikai/ous i(sta/meqa. ch. 104, 5.

a)nqrwpei/as—this adjective belongs to both nouns, ‘there is nothing in our claims or in our conduct beyond what men hold in regard to the divinity and will as regards themselves’: cf. ii. 44, 2, oi(\ a)\n th=s eu)prepesta/ths la/xwsi. oi(/de me\n teleuth=s, u(mei=s de\ lu/phs. no/misis, which is only found here in Thucydides, is explained by h(gou/meqa do/ch| in the next sentence, and therefore denotes current belief and accepted opinion. Classen however follows the scholiast in understanding it of the observances of religion, ta( nenomisme/na, ta\ ei)qisme/na. bou/lhsis—‘will and purpose’, tending to policy and action, h/ ei)s a)nqrw/pous proai/resis, as the scholiast explains.

h(gou/meqa do/ch| . safw=s—‘we hold in point of opinion, as an obvious fact’. dia\ panto/s—always, continually; i. 38, 1, etc. qe/ntes—cf. Hdt. vii. 8, ou)/t' au)to\s kathgh/somai no/mon to/nde e)n u(mi=n tiqei/s, paradeca/meno/s te au)tw=| xrh/somai. All this is an echo of the Athenian speech at Sparta in 432; see i. 76. Note the prominence of the participial clauses in this sentence. ei)do/tes kai\ u(ma=s a)\n ..a\)n—a)/n is repeated ‘in a long sentence, to make the conditional force felt through the whole, especially when the connexion is broken by intermediate clauses. It may also be done in order to emphasize particular words with which it is joined, and to make them prominent, as being affected by the contingency’ (Goodwin, § 223).
h(mi=n—i.e. the same that we have: so with genitive, as in iv. 92, 4, e)pikinduno/teron e(te/rwn th\n paroi/khsin tw=nde e)/xomen, ‘than that of others’.
au)to/—‘it’ or ‘this’; cf. ch. 27, 4. Classen follows Stahl in reading tau)to/.

e)lassw/sesqai—this is a singular instance of the future infinitive with a verb of fearing. Here the construction
with mh/ might be expected; but probably the infinitive has to some extent the nature of an object=‘we regard without fear the prospect of coming off the worse’. Such instances as i. 136, 1, dedie/nai e)/xein au)to/n, ‘to be afraid of keeping him’, iv. 110, 3, kate/deisan e)selqei=n, ‘were afraid to enter’, are different. There the infinitive denotes the direct object of the verb; and mh\ e)se/lqwsin, for instance, could not be substituted. See Goodwin, § 372 sq. As a general principle the future infinitive is a favourite Thucydidean usage when the intention is ‘to make the reference to the future especially prominent’; Goodwin, § 113.
th=s. do/chs—dependent on both to\ a)peiro/kakon and to\ a)/fron: the subjective genitive u(mw=n also belongs to both.

h(/n...pisteu/ete—the conjecture h(=| is tempting, but the cognate construction is scarcely harsher than bou/lhsin e)lpi/zei, vi. 78, 2: cf. a)/ ch. 9, 18. makari/santes—‘we felicitate you on your guilelessness but do not envy your folly’.
plei=sta—i. 3, 4, plei/w xrw/menoi: ii. 11, 5, logismw=| e)la/xista xrw/menoi. pro\s de\ tou\s a)/llous—dependent on prosfe/rontai, and placed first to emphasize the antithesis.

polla\ a)/n—Poppo compares Dem. Olynth. iii. 36, ta\ me
 a)/lla siwpw=, po/ll) a)n e)/xwn ei)pei=n: de Chers. pa/nta ta)/ll) ei)pw
 a)
 h(de/ws. cunelw/n—iii. 40, 4, e(
 de\ cunelw
 le/gw, etc. w(= i)/smen—i. 18, 1, e)pi\ plei=ston w(=n i)/smen xro/non.

pro/s—‘in favour of’; ch. 90, 6. a)lo/gou—which you cannot reasonably expect; cf. Dem. Aristocr. 672 § 158, tugxa/nei tau/ths th=s a)lo/gou kai\ a)prosdokh/tou swthri/as. This clause answers the end of the last chapter. h( toiau/th dia/noia—such principles as these. CHAPTER CVI
But, say the Melians, their own interest will make the Spartans help us.

kat' au)to\ tou=to—‘in accordance with this very thing’, or ‘on this very point’, that is the Lacedaemonians' regard to
their in terests: Soph. Phil. 438, kat' au)to\ tou=to/ ge a)naci/ou me\n fwto\s e)cerh/somai. h)/dh—apparently ‘now that we are come to this point’: Krüger suggests dh/. kai\ ma/lista—ch. 73, 21.

tw=| cumfe/ronti au)tw=n—probably dependent on pisteu/omen, as a similar construction occurs in 104, 4: 111, 6: 112, 8. It may however be taken with the following words, as dative of the cause, like tw=| e)leuqe(rw|, ch. 99, 2. au(tw=n has been proposed, but Classen justly points out that tw=| au(tw=n cumfe/ronti would be required; see note on ch. 71, 3. Why not connect au(tw=n with a)poi/kous o)/ntas? It would give a forcible sense.
katasth=nai—to make themselves, put themselves in a certain position. It implies something more permanent than gene/sqai. CHAPTER CVII
The interests of the Spartans will not lead them into danger.

ou)/koun oi)/esqe—‘you do not then think’, i.e. you seem to forget; so most editors; Classen makes the sentence interrogative, ‘do you not think?’ i.e. of course you do. meta\ kindu/nou dra=sqai—simply ‘involve danger (in doing)’. Poppo takes oi)/esqe as=oi)/esqe dei=n, a force which some give to nomi/zein iv. 86, 4: iv. 117, 1. In those passages however no such sense is required, and here it is entirely out of place. For dra=sqai the reading of nearly all MSS. is dra=sai. Jowett would retain this, supplying tina/ as subject. CHAPTER CVIII
Their interests, say the Melians, will surely impel them to stand by their own colony.
kai/—emphasizes kindu/nous. The following te is suspicious. Classen, comparing ch. 82, 16, considers that it connects the two infinitive clauses.
e)gxeiri/sasqai—‘undertake’; the middle is not found elsewhere before Dio Cassius.

bebaiote/rous—‘will consider such risks less hazardous than (if undertaken) in the case of others’. be/baios seems a strange word to apply to ki/ndunos: cf. however iii. 39, 6, to\n meta\ tw=n o)li/gwn ki/ndunon h(ghsa/menoi bebaio/teron. So we say ‘a safe speculation’. e)s is used by Thucydides in the most general way to denote relation of any kind. Krüger and Poppo suggest leaving out e)s, referring bebaiote/rous to h(ma=s, but the parallel passage supports the text.

ta\ e)/rga—the operations which war would involve. th=s gnw/mhs tw=| cuggenei=—lit. ‘from kinship of views’; being of the same stock they had the same interests and policy. gnw/mh is used of political views, iv. 56 fin. pro\s th\n e/kei/nwn gnw/mhn e)/stasan, etc. The expression is awkward, aud it is tempting to take tw=| cuggenei= separately; in which case we must read th=| gnw/mh| or th\n gnw/mhn, for, though certus animi is good Latin, pisto\s gnw/mhs is unknown in Greek. CHAPTER CIX
Not so, when they have no prospect of support in the event of war.

to\ e)xuro/n—‘security’; predicate with the article: ii. 43, 4, to\ eu)/daimon to\ e)leu/qeron to\ de\ e)leu/qeron to\ eu)/yuxon kri/nantes: Plat. Gorg. 498, ta\ a)gaqa\ fh\|s ei=nai ta\s h(dona\s kaka\ de\ ta\s a)ni/as (Krüger's Grammar, § 50, 4, 14).
a)ll) h)/n—so ch. 91, 5. tw=n e)/rgwn duna/mei—i. 25, 4, xrhma/twn duna/mei: i. 82, 2, nautikou= h)/ xrhma/twn du/namin. Here the genitive = tw=n pro\s ta\ e)/rga.

o(/—ch. 103, 6. kai\ plei=o/n ti—kai\ emphatic, as in ch. 73, 21. ple/on and plei=on are often used for ma=llon, to\ ple/on is more common. ti has an intensive force, as in me/ros ti, etc.: so vii. 21, 4, ple/on ti periesome/nous.
kai\ meta\ cumma/xwn—lit. ‘(not alone but) also with’ etc. So in the speech of Pericles, ii. 39, 2, *lakedaimo/nioi...meta\ pa/ntwn e)s th\n gh=n h(mw=n strateu/ousi.

ei)ko\s..peraiwqh=nai—i. 81 fin. ei)ko\s douleu=sai: where Krüger collects the instances of this construction, and observes that the future infinitive is not found with ei)ko(s in Thucydides. CHAPTER CX
But they may use the help of naval allies, and may themselves attack the Athenian dependencies.

a)/llous—e.g. the Corinthians, their chief naval allies, ii. 9, 2. polu\ de/—vii. 13, 3, pollh\ de\ h( *sikeli/a: Plat. Phaed. 78 A, pollh\ h( *)/ellas. The ‘Cretan Sea’ (iv. 53 fin.) is the sea E. and S.E. of Laconia. di' ou(=—1. 2, 1, ou)/te kata\ gh=n ou)/te dia\ qala/sshs.

tw=n kratou/ntwn ..h( swthri/a—cf. the use of the article ch. 91, 4. The lords of the sea will find it harder to catch their foes than the foes to effect their escape. For the form a)porw/teros cf. iii. 89, 4, biaio/teron th\n e)pi/klusin: iii. 101, 2, dusesbolw/tatos h( *lokri/s. Krüger says that these are the only instances he knows in Attic prose; eu)skepasto/taton, ch. 71, 9, being neuter.

o(/sous mh/—indefinite, such as came under this description, ch. 98, 6; so in the next line. e)ph=lqen—‘visited’, not ‘attacked’: iv. 85, 1, ei) de\ xro/nw| e)ph/lqomen, mhdei\s memfqh=|, in Brasidas' speech at Acanthus: ib. § 3, e)pi\ ou(\s prw=ton h)=lqon u(ma=s.

cummaxi/dos te kai\ gh=s—these words are found in all the manuscripts, and it is therefore improbable that they are merely interpolated. They seem rather added by the historian as a further explanation of oi)keiote/ras. cummaxi/s occurs in ch. 36, 1. CHAPTER CXI

The Athenians reply that such threats will not deter them. They urge on the Melians the immediate necessity of taking a practical view of their interests. They have no real grounds to hope for escape; and their only safe course is to accept the reasonable terms which Athens offers.

tou/twn me/n—‘you too may learn by experience something of this’, i.e. of the hopelessness of deterring us by threats of counter-attacks or invasion. The construction resembles ii. 60, 1, prosdexome/nw| moi ta\ th=s o/rgh=s gege/nhtai: iv. 28, 5, a)sme/nois e)gi/gncto: ii. 3, 2, tw=| plh/qei ou) boulome/nw| h)=n. So pepeirame/nw| gi/gnetai = it is a thing that one has experienced; the perfect implying that knowledge comes when the experience has been undergone. tou/twn refers either to the suggested threats of the Melians or to the Athenian boast, o(/ti ou)d) k.t.l. kai\ u(mi=n—as well as to others before you. Stahl and Classen read ge/noito h(mi=n, kai\ u(mi=n, ‘if such a thing (as invasion) occurred it would be one of which we have experience, and you too may not be unaware etc.’

ou)d) a)po\ mia=s—emphatic; it is the only instance of ou)dei/s or mhdei/s separated in Thucydides. In i. 105, and iii. 26, we find sieges continued by the Athenians in spite of counter-demonstrations.
e)nqumou/meqa—according to Classen, ‘we observe with regret’; the word at any rate always implies serious consideration. fh/santes—‘after you professed’; cf. fa/skontes ch. 42, 21.
a)/nqrwpoi—see ch. 89, 9. nomi/seian—Classen reads this instead of nomi/saien as the proper Thucydidean form; so iii. 49, 2, fqa/seian for fqa/saien.

u(mw=n. me/lletai—‘your strongest grounds are hopes deferred’ (Jowett). me/lletai, lit. ‘are a future matter’, the passive as it were of me(llete tau=ta cognate. The passive of me/llw occurs twice besides; Dem. Phil. i. 50, § 37, e)n o(/sw| tau=ta me/lletai, ‘are going to be done’: Xen. Anab. iii. 1, 47, w(s mh\ me/lloito a)lla\ perai/noito ta\ de/onta. Kruger cites also Soph. O. T. 1628, pa/lai ta)po\ sou= bradu/netai

braxe/a perigi/gnesqai—pro/s is closely connected with braxe/a, ‘slight in comparison with’; ii. 35, 2, e)ndeeste/rws pro\s a(\ bou/letai. For the following infinitive cf. i. 50, 5, nh=es o/li/gai a)mu)nein: i. 61, 2, tapeinh\ h( dia/noia e)gkarterei=n. Such explanatory infinitives are particularly joined with adjectives which imply ability or the opposite (Goodwin, § 758). They have in effect a sort of comparative force = braxu/tera h(\ w(/ste.

pollh/n te—‘and so’, summing up the argument. metasthsa/menoi—‘after bidding us withdraw’, in order to reconsider the matter among yourselves: i. 79, 1, metasthsa/menoi pa/ntas e)bouleu/onto kata\ sfa=s au)tou/s. e)/ti—‘as even now you may’ (Jowett). The word affects the whole clause, but its position gives especial emphasis to the participle, deprecating an immediate decision. o(/mws, a(/ma and the like are similarly used.

ou) ga)r dh/—introducing the final exhortation; cf. i. 122 (fin.), ou) ga\r dh\ e)pi\ th\n plei/stous dh\ bla/yasan katafro/nhsin kexwrh/kate: in both sentences the stress falls on the noun, which is the last word but one. ai)sxroi=s—‘dangers which involve shame’, i.e. which threaten national honour, and which it would be shameful to decline. This is the accepted explanation, but it is not quite satisfactory, as, though the various phrases of ‘shame’ and ‘shameful’ naturally follow the emphatic ai)sxu/nhn, they have no particular force before it. e/sxa/tois, a)/krois, i)sxuroi=s are suggested emendations.

polloi=s ga/r—‘for many have found’ etc.; the Thucydidean initial dative. In construction polloi=s and h(sshqei=si are usually taken as dependent on e)pespa/sato, and e(ko/ntas peripesei=n as the direct object of e)pespa/sato. But e)pispa/sasqai more naturally means ‘drawing on a person to’ a course of action, than ‘bringing a thing on a person’. It may be then that the grammatical object of the verb is to be found in polloi=s, the construction being changed, and the literal meaning being ‘in the case of many.. it drew them on to incur’. The middle e)pespa/sato is decidedly in favour of this view; and it is adopted by Donaldson, who says ‘this use of the dative may be extended to cases where the construction would have admitted of the accusative’. He translates ‘in the case of many still foreseeing the tendency of their actions, that which is called dishonour has been an inducement to involve themselves in irremediable disasters’. The aorist is ‘gnomic’ and general like kaqei=le, ch. 103, 3.

e)s oi(=a fe/rontai—‘what they are rushing on’ or tending towards; fe/resqai, like ferri, being the regular word for moving; see note on iv. 34, 3, u(po\ toceuma/twn ferome/nwn. e)pagwgou=— ch. 85, 4: iv. 88, 1, dia\ to\ e)pagwga\ e<*>pei=n to\n *brasi)dan. e)pespa/sato—see previous note. The sense required, according to the ordinary view of the clause, is ‘brought on them’ and there seems then some ground for the conjecture e)pe/spase to/. In Hdt. iii. 42, i(/na e)pispa/swntai ke/rdos, is ‘to win gain for
themselves’, and here it may be said that the meaning is ‘many have found.. that it has won for them’ etc., i.e. that this is all they gain by it’. In the other passages of Thucydides where the middle is found it has its proper force, iii. 44, 4: iv. 9, 2. We find the passive, iii. 89, 5: iv. 130, 4.

h(sshqei=si tou= r(h/matos—‘esse ipsum turpitudinis vocabulum docet articulus’ (Poppo). For gen. cf. iv. 37, 1, ei)/ pws h(sshqei=en tou= deinou=. Note the antithesis between o)no/matos and r(h/matos and the following e)/rgw|. kai\ ai)sxu/nhn— lit. ‘and incur too a shame which is more shameful as involving folly than from fortune’, i.e. than if it had been due to fortune. meta/—like meta\ kindu/nwn etc.

h)\ tu/xhs—the scholiast has tu/xh|, which, as Poppo says, ‘propter orationem variatam valde Thucydideum est’. There is however no authority for reading it in the text. The preposition is omitted in the second clause, as is common after a comparative; cf. iii. 44, peri\ tou= me/llontos ma=llon bouleu/esqai h)\ tou= paro/ntos: viii. 96, 2, e)c h(=s plei/w h)\ th=s *)attikh=s w)felou=nto. Other instances are given by Poppo on vii. 47, 4, and in Kruger's Grammar, § 68, 9: e.g. Xen. Hel. ii. 3, 21, oi( tria/konta pollou\s me\n e)/xqras e(/neka a)pe/kteinon, pollou\s de\ xrhma/twn. proslabei=n—‘to bring on themselves’ rather than ‘to get in addition’; so iv. 61, 1, with kindu/nous.

o(\ u(mei=s—ch. 103, 6. th=s megi/sths—for this emphatic order cf. ch. 18, 57; ii. 61, 4, cumforai=s tai=s megi/stais: iv. 10, 1, kindu/nou tou= taxi/stou. cumma/xous gene/sqai—explanatory infinitive, defining the terms proposed.

u(potelei=s—sc. fo/rou, as is expressed in i. 19, 1, and i. 80, 3. This was the condition of the great majority of the Athenian so-called allies. See i. 96—99, and the words of Euphemus, vi. 85. ib kai\ filoneikh=sai—kai/ answers to te; the whole clause therefore depends on ou)k a)prepe\s nomiei=te. ta\ xei/rw— cognate, with filoneikh=sai, ‘obstinately to choose the worse’. Dem. Lept. 501, § 144, mhde\n filonei/kei. So we have proqumei=sqai, speu/dein ti etc. In Plat. Protag. 360 E, we have filoneikei=n to\ e)me\ ei)=nai to\n a)pokrino/menon, ‘to stickle for the answer coming from me’ (Wayte): but pro/s is inserted in the same phrase, Rcp. 338 A, in accordance with the usual construction. Phileb. 14 B, has pro/s (wrongly cited by Liddell and Scott). The form of
the word, which according to Cobet and others should be nikis discussed in Liddell and Scott under filo/neikos.
kalw=s prosfe/rontai—‘behave with propriety’, i.e. with due deference.
kai\ metasta/ntwn h(mw=n—‘etiam semotis nobis, non solum praesentibus’ (Poppo). The Athenians deprecate a rash and hasty decision, as in line 10: so infr. polla/kis.

h(\n mia=s pe/ri—Poppo calls this ‘locus desperatus’; and there is in fact no satisfactory explanation or correction as yet proposed. The general sense is plain. The Melians are exhorted to reflect that they are deliberating concerning the only country they have, and that its fate will be determined by one single decision. There is very little difference in the manuscript readings. For h(/n one manuscript has h)/n, and another h)=n. One omits h(\n mia=s pe/ri. For e)/stai are found i)/ste and i(/statai. Thus the first and last words are those which are most open to doubt. Possibly both these words are interpolations. Assuming that h)/n found its way into the text from some error, it would be necessary to supply a verb to govern it, and this would account for the variation in the final word. Omitting h)/n and e)/stai we get a sentence which can be construed, ‘reflect that you are deliberating about your country, your one only country, and this in one deliberation, as it may turn out well or ill’. Further discussion of the passage may be found in the Appendix.

e)s mi/an boulh/n—‘in’ or ‘at one deliberation’; an idea of ‘coming to’ or ‘looking to’ being implied. See Liddell and Scott, ei)s ii. 2, for such phrases as e)s kairo\n e)pei/gesqe (Hdt. iv. 139), which have some resemblance to the present instance: cf. Thuc. vi. 16, 6, *lakedaimoni/ous e)s mi/an h(me/ran kate/sthsa... a)gwni/sasqai

tuxou=sa/n te kai\ mh\ katorqw/sasan—‘according to its success or failure’, i.e. according as you decide well or ill. te and kai/ are here disjunctive as noted on ch. 15, 6: cf. ii. 35, 2, eu)= te kai\ xei=ron ei/po/nti. tuxou=san is opposed to mh\ katorqw/sasan, as in iii. 39, 7, tuxo/ntes to sfale/ntes, katorqw/santi occurring just before in antithesis to sfale/nti. The active form is regularly used of persons, as an object (pei=ran, bou/leuma etc.) is implied, katorqou=n meaning literally to bring
one's design to a successful issue. Here, taking the reading of the text, the active must go with boulh/n. I rather doubt if this can be right: we should expect the passive, as in iv. 76, 4, ei) katorqoi=to h( pei=ra. CHAPTER CXII
The Melians finally refuse to submit, or to concede anything more than a pledge of neutrality.

metexw/rhsan—‘withdrew’; ii. 72, 5. e)k tw=n lo/gwn— ‘from the conference’; so ch. 113, 2: iv. 58, 1, e)s lo/gous kate/sthsan a)llh/lois: iv. 73 fin. e)s lo/gous e)/rxontai. kata\ sfa=s au)tou/s—i. 79, 2, metasthsa/menoi pa/ntas e)bouleu/onto kata\ sfa=s au)tou/s: iii. 78, 1, etc.

paraplh/sia kai/—vii. 71, 7, paraplh/sia kai\ e)/drasan: so kai/ follows i)/sos and other words of sameness or likeness; cf. similis atque, ac, etc. a)nte/legon—imperfect, referring to the time of the conference; lit. ‘what they had been objecting’.

e(ptako/sia e)/th—a rough statement, counting from the supposed time of the establishment of Dorian supremacy in Peloponnesus, the legendary ‘return of the Heracleidae’. Melos is said to have been founded some little time later; Grote, Pt. i. ch. 18.

e)k tou= qei/ou—constructed with swzou/sh|, and placed immediately after tu/xh| to define its meaning. See ch. 104, 4: 105, 1. In this sentence there is perhaps the same difference between e)c and a)po/, denoting respectively motion from within and motion from the surface, which is noted by Donaldson on iv. 126, 3. kai\ *lakedaimoni/wn—kai\ either = atque, ‘and especially’; or more probably it gives a definition ‘even the Lacedaemonians’. This defining or correcting sense of kai/, = ‘in fact, that is to say’, is noticed on ch. 20, 3: iv. 33, 1. Jowett says, ‘the desire to oppose the single idea a)po\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn to e)k tou= qei/ou has led to a formal distinction between a)nqrw/pwn and *lakedaimoni/wn, ‘from men, and in particular from Lacedaemonians’. timwri/a|—‘help’; so three times in i. 25: i. 38, 3 etc.
prokalou/meqa de\ u(ma=s—prokalei=sqai with the accusative and infinitive is to invite another to do something. Here the regular eonstruction is interrupted by the insertion of a nominative clause, referring to the subject of the sentence, the whole, as Classen says, being equivalent to prokalou/meqa u(ma=s, h(mw=n fi/lwn o)/ntwn k.t.l., a)naxwrh=sai. Kruger cites two somewhat similar sentences in which the last clause refers to the subject; i. 26, 3, proei=pon tou\s ce/nous a)pie/nai, ei) de\ mh/, w(s polemi/ois xrh/sesqai: Hdt. ii. 115, au)to\n de/ se kai\ toi\s sou\s sumplo/ous proagoreu/w metormi/zesqai, ei) de\ mh/, a(/te polemi/ous perie/yesqai.
e)pith/deioi—elsewhere e)pith/deios has three terminations, though a few manuscripts have e)pithdei/ous in ch. 21, 9. CHAPTER CXIII
The Athenians accordingly break up the conference with significant threats.

dialuo/menoi e)k—vi. 41 fin. dielu/qhsan e)k tou= cullo/gou: Hdt. iii. 73, dialu/esqai e)k tou= sullo/gou. a)ll) ou)=n—‘well then’, ‘well certainly’: ‘sunt partieulae contra dicendi cum asseveratione, at profecto’ (Poppo). So Plat. Protag. 310 A, a)ll) ou)=n a)kou/ete, ‘well then, hear’. a)ll) ou)=n (with ge commonly following) more usually means ‘but, or yet, at any rate’, as in Plat. Protag. 327 C. Soph. Ant. 84. Poppo cites Xen. Cyr. i. 4, 19, a)ll) ou)=n ponhroi/ ge faino/menoi a)/gousi h(mw=n ta\ xrh/mata, in illustration of the present passage, but there the sense seems rather ‘well but they look but a poor lot to plunder our belongings’.
a)po\ tou/twn tw=n bouleuma/twn—‘from’, i.e. judging from; <*>. 21, 2, a)p' au)tw=n tw=n e)/rgwn skopou=si: cf. ch. 89, 9. dokei=te—ch 9, 21, note.
tw=| bou/lesqai—dative of the cause: cf. a somewhat similar passage in iv. 108, 3, to\ ple/on boulh/sei kri/nontes a)safei= h)\ pronoi/a| a)sfalei= k.t.l.

kai\ *lakedaimoni/ois—the omission of the article gives a somewhat contemptuous force, ‘Lacedaemonians and fortune
and hopes’: see note on iv. 10, 4. parabeblhme/noi—usually taken as middle, ‘having staked, or risked’. e)pitre/yantes parabo/lws, as the scholiast explains. In this sense the word is used ii. 44, 3, pai=das paraballo/menoi: iii. 14, 1, to\n ki/ndunon tw=n swma/twn paraballome/nous. Stahl however takes the word as passive, comparing Ar. Plut. 243, po/rnaisi kai\ ku/boisi parabeblhme/nos, ‘given over to’. The sense thus obtained is not bad; still, as the idea of risk and hazard perpetually occurs in these chapters, the ordinary rendering seems preferable. The perfect participle denotes the general attitude of the Melians, the aorist pisteu/santes refers to their decision in the present case. Classen would omit kai/ before pisteu/santes, ‘having risked everything from your trust’ etc., as he considers that the datives cannot depend on parabeblhme/noi. CHAPTER CXIV

ou)de
 u(ph/kouon—‘showed no sign of submission’; i. 26, 4, ou)de
 au)tw=n u(ph/kousan. e)tre/ponto perietei/xisan—Arnold compares ii. 75, 1, kaqi/sth e)s po/lemon to
 strato/n, kai\ prw=ton me
 periestau/rwsen au/tou/s. Some editors read e)tra/ponto, with slight manuscript authority; but the imperfect is preferable, denoting the beginning and progress of hostile operations.

dielo/menoi—ch. 75, 23, dielo/menoi...perietei(xizon. Note the different tense of the following verb in the two passages. Here, the aorist perietei/xisan gives an ‘end-view’, and the Athenians are regarded as having completed their lines round the city. kata\ po/leis—ii. 78, 1, dielo/menoi kata\ po/leis to\ xwri/on. kata\ gh=n k.t.l.—to be taken with fnlakh\n katalipo/ntes. CHAPTER CXV

*)argei=oi—see ch. 83, 12, for a previous attempt. to\n xro/non to\n au)to/n—‘attende rariorem collocationem pronominis o) au)to/s: cf. vii. 39, 1, th=| e)pixei h/sei th=| au)th=|: Dem. de Chers. 93, 14, me)nein e)pi\ th=s a)noi/as th=s au)th=s: Xen. Cyr. iv. 4, 10 (Poppo). Krüger cites i. 140, 1: and i. 2, 2, a)/nqrwpoi oi( au)toi/.
loxisqe/ntes—iii. 107, 3, loxi/zei o(pli/tas, ‘stations them in ambush’. Here the word is used like loxa=n, as in one or two instances cited by Liddell and Scott from Dio Cassius.

w(s o)gdoh/konta—the same construction as in ch. 59, 7: cf. also ch. 10, 57. oi( e)k th=s *pu/lou—ch. 56, 13. As Pylos was now chiefly held by Lacedaemonian Helots, Kruger would omit *)aqhnai=oi, but it denotes generally those who acted on the Athenian side.

ou)d) w(/s—‘not even after this’: so i. 132, ou)d) w(\s h)ci/wsan new/tero/n ti poiei=n e)s au)to/n etc. kai\ w(/s, i. 44, 2: iii. 33, 1. The negative belongs to both the verb and the participle;—they did not throw up the truce and begin a war. a)fe/ntes—ch. 78, 8. The truce between Athens and Sparta was not considered to be actually broken till 414, when an Athenian fleet ravaged the coast of Peloponnesus (vi. 105, 1).

e)kh/rucan de\ ei)/ tis—sc. that he should do so, see Poppo on iii. 52, 2: cf. iv. 37, 2, e)kh/ruca/n te ei) bou/lointo ta\ o(/pla paradou=nai. para\ sfw=n—i.e. from Lacedaemonia: ii. 41, 1, par' h(mw=n. lhi/zesqai—private depredations of this kind were not considered incompatible with a formal state of peace.

diaforw=n—‘differences’, from diafora/, the manuscript reading. Bekker and others alter it into diafo/rwn, as ta\ i(/dia dia/fora is found ii. 37, 1: ta\ au)toi=s i)di/a| dia/fora, i. 68, 2: ta\ h(mi=n dia/fora, iv. 87, 1: see ch. 18, 19.

to\ kata\ th\n a)gora/n—i.e. the market in the Athenian camp, where their supplies were stored; i. 62, 1, at Potidaea, a)gora\n e)/cw th=s po/lews e)pepoi/hnto: iii. 6, at Mytilene, nau/staqmon h)=n au)toi=s ploi/wn kai\ a)gora=s h( *male/a.

a)/ndras—iv. 132, 3, tw=n h(bw/ntwn a)/ndras e)ch=gon: vii. 43, 3, a)/ndras tw=n fula/kwn a)poktei/nousin. e)senegka/menoi—so e)skomi/zesqai, vi. 22, 1. xrh/sima—the MSS. reading is xrh/masi: hence some read xrh/mata in the general meaning of supplies: so vi. 49, 3, th
 stratia
 ou)k a)porh/sein xrhma/twn: vii. 49, 1, th
 tw=n xrhma/twn a)pori/an.

to\ e)/peita—so iv. 54, 3, to/ te parauti/ka kai\ to\ e)/peita ta\ th=s o(mologi/as e)pra/xqh: iv. 107, 1, kai\ to\ au)ti/ka kai\ to\ e)/peita.
CHAPTER CXVI

mellh/santes—‘having intended’; i. 134, 4, e)me/llhsan me\n.. e)/peita. viii. 23, 5, pezo\s ds e)pi\ to\n *)ellh/sponton e)me/llhsen i)e/nai. ta) diabath/ria i(era/—cf. ch. 54, 6. Cobet would omit i(era\ e)n toi=s ori/ois as an explanatory gloss, such words not being added elsewhere. For e)gi/gneto see ch. 55, 17.

dia\ th\n e)kei/nwn me/llhsin—i.e. hearing of their intended attack. u(potoph/santes—altered by Meineke into u(popteu/santes, as u\potopei=n is not found with an accusative of the person. Possibly it may stand in the sense of ‘having formed a suspicion’, tina/s being governed by cune/labon and then resolved into tou\s me\n...oi( de/: cf. ch. 54, 16.
au)=qis—the best manuscripts have au)=tis, which is also found in some manuscripts in ch. 8, 18, and ch. 43, 18. Lid. and Scott call it a form erroneously introduced into Attic authors.

kaq) e(/tero/n ti—apparently kaq) e(/teron is governed directly by ei)=lon, and is equivalent to a single word; as in iv. 3, 2, e)mprh/santo/s tinos kata\ mikro\n th=s u<*>/lhs: so ii. 76, 4, e)pi\ me/ga kate/seise: see note on iv. 3, 2. Otherwise periteixi/smatos may be regarded as a partitive genitive, ‘took a part of the Athenian lines of attack’. Classen takes kaq) e(/teron separately, governing the genitive by ti, but, as Poppo says, ‘separari posse non videntur’. He suggests that kaq) should perhaps be altered into kai/. The instances quoted are however sufficient to support the view first given.

w(s tau=ta e)gi/gneto—these words, if genuine, must mean, ‘as these things happened’, i.e. as the Athenians found themselves assailed in turn by the enemy. To give the meaning ‘after this happened’, which we should rather expect, e)ge/neto would be needed. Poppo brackets the whole clause as weak and awkwardly inserted between a)/llhs and h(=s: and he is followed by Classen.

kai\...poliorkou/menoi—cf. i. 65, 1, a)poteixisqei/shs au)th=s ...kai\ e)/xwn, where Poppo gives several instances, e.g. iv. 29, 1, of the genitive absolute thus joined with participles in the nominative.
w(/ste—of conditions; ch. 17, 14. bouleu=sai—‘decide’; the usual force of the aorist.

w)/|khsan—‘settled in’; ch. 1, 10. The reading of the best manuscripts however is w)/|kisan, which is adopted by Poppo and Classen; cf. i. 98, 1. Either word makes good sense, oi)ki/zw being ‘to settle’, i.e. to people with settlers; and the aorists are naturally liable to confusion. In the middle voice the forms of oi)ki/zw are to be preferred (e.g. vi. 1, 2), as the use cf oi)kei=sqai middle is doubtful.
